question: How do I enroll in an online German course?
context:
Level B1 – for intermediates
Complete B1 course: "Nico's Way"
In this free and comprehensive course you will learn German at B1 level in 18 chapters.
Each chapter begins with a short video - structured in the style of a telenovela - on the basis of which you work through exercises and thus learn the German language step by step with Nico, the protagonist of the telenovela.
For each chapter there are explanations of the grammar, vocabulary lists, regional information and manuscripts for the video.
The website can be set to 9 different languages, including English, Arabic, Russian, Polish and more.
Complete B1 course with tutor
In this free course you will learn German at B1 level in 12 lessons with videos, audios, pictures and matching tasks.
In the learning portal you will find a vocabulary trainer and phrase trainer for each lesson, so that you can practise new vocabulary.
In addition, a tutor supports you online, who answers questions or corrects texts.
The portal can be set to 19 different languages, including English, Arabic, Turkish, Albanian, Serbian, Polish and many more.
Telenovela: "Jojo seeks happiness"
In three seasons of the telenovela you will learn more about the life of Jojo, a Brazilian who came to Germany, and her friends in Cologne.
Each episode of "Jojo sucht das Glück" is accompanied by interactive exercises and vocabulary aids for learning German.
B1 - German on the Job
With this free course you can practise German for your job.
You can choose from the following occupational areas: Gastronomy, systems engineering, building cleaning, nursing, retail.
For each occupational field, there are seven learning units with videos and subsequent tasks, with which you will mainly learn the vocabulary as well as the idioms and typical phrases used in the respective industry.
Learn German on the Deutsche Welle website
On the Deutsche Welle website you can find a wide variety of offers for learning German.
You can listen to news spoken more slowly for learners, you can find out how Germans live in the Germany Lab, you can meet other learners in the online community, watch videos on various topics, practise your listening comprehension, read up on grammar questions and, above all, do lots of exercises.
The site is available in 30 languages, including English, Arabic, Bosnian, Greek, Polish and many more.
German forum and online community
If you want to join a Whatsapp learning group, chat in German with learners from all over the world or look for a learning partner, you'll find what you're looking for in the online community on the Goethe-Institut site.
You will also find various German exercises at all levels, including B1.
Key words:German course, learn German online, learn German for free, learn German yourself, B1 course, German B1, learn German on the Internet

question: What kind of job assistance does the job center provide?
context:
Job centre and citizens' income
What does the job centre do?
The job centre looks after people who receive citizen's allowance.
Citizen's allowance is the basic income support for jobseekers.
Jobseekers are supported by the job centre in their search for a job or qualification.
What is the citizen's allowance?
Citizen's income is basic security for jobseekers.
It is a benefit provided by the welfare state.
The citizen's income ensures the minimum subsistence level for people who cannot finance their living expenses from their own income or assets.
The citizen's allowance must be applied for at the job centre.
The citizen's allowance is financed from tax money.
Who receives citizen's allowance?
Citizen's income is paid to people who are capable of work and entitled to benefits.
These are people who...
are at least 15 years old and have not yet reached retirement age.
live in Germany and have their centre of life here.
can work at least 3 hours a day.
are in need of assistance.
Asylum seekers do not receive a citizen's allowance.
They receive benefits in accordance with the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act.
Recognised refugees receive citizen's allowance.
Which job centre should I contact?
There are many different job centres.
Each job centre is responsible for a specific municipality.
You can find the job centre for the district of Augsburg here:
Jobcentre Augsburger Land
Hermanstr.
J obcente r-Augsburger-Land.
Hermanstrasse-11@jobcenter-ge.de
Monday to Friday from 7.30 am to 12 noon, Thursday additionally from 2 pm to 5.30 pm
Search terms: livelihood security, no money, Hartz IV, unemployment benefit II, unemployment benefit 2,

question: How can I convert my foreign driving license in Germany?
context:
Cars and mopeds
German driving licence
You need a driving licence to be allowed to drive in Germany.
To drive a car on your own, you must be at least 18 years old.
You have to get your driving licence at a driving school.
You have driving lessons there and an exam at the end.
The exam consists of a written part and a practical part (driving).
You have to pay for your driving licence yourself.
Foreign driving licence
You want to drive in Germany and already have a driving licence from your home country?
Then you first have to check whether your driving licence can also be recognised in Germany or whether you also have to pass the practical and/or theoretical driving test again here.
For EU citizens, the foreign driving licence is generally recognised.
Driving licences from third countries such as Syria, Iraq or Afghanistan are usually not recognised in Germany.
You have to take the theoretical and practical exam again.
In addition to German, the theoretical exam can be taken in the following languages: Arabic, Turkish, Spanish, French, Russian, Polish, Romanian, Italian, Portuguese,and English.
Contact the driver licensing authority:
Driving licence authority
fahrerlaubnis@LRA-a.bayern.de
Opening hours and further information can be found at www.landkreis-augsburg.de/auto-verkehr.
Moped licence
Anyone interested in riding a moped must also take lessons and pass a test.
You have to get your driving licence at a driving school and pay for it yourself.

question: How can I enroll in a German integration course?
context:
Integration courses for adults
What is an integration course?
The Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) offers integration courses.
In an integration course, you will learn German and many things about Germany.
For example on topics such as...
Work and career
Training and further education
Childcare and education
shopping
Housing
Rights and duties in Germany
How can I do an integration course?
When do I have to attend the integration course?
Voluntary attendance: Authorisation certificate required
Would you like to attend the course voluntarily?
Then you needauthorisation from the BAMF, a so-called "certificate of eligibility".
With this authorisation certificate, you can register for an integration course at a language school.
Whether or not you receive a certificate of eligibility depends on your residence status.
You can get help with this from the "Learn German" counselling service.
The counselling service can also help you with the application for the eligibility certificate.
Obligation from the Office for Immigration and Integration
Some people are required to attend an integration course by the Office for Immigration and Integration.
This means that they must attend the integration course.
Important information at a glance
- The general integration course lasts several months and takes place full-time or part-time (e.g. for people in employment).
- It consists of a language course with 600 teaching units (short: UE = 45 minutes) and an orientation course on life in Germany with 100 UE.
- The aim is to reach language level B1 on completion of the course.
You will then receive a certificate.
- The certificate is important.
For example, if you are looking for work or want to do an apprenticeship.
The certificate can also be important if you want to stay in Germany permanently and need a permanent residence permit.
- There are also special integration courses for certain groups of people.
For example, for women (with childcare), working people or people who cannot read and write.
- Participants with a BAMF authorisation certificate pay 220 euros per module (=100 hours).
They can get 50% of this back if they successfully complete the course within two years.
- Participants without a BAMF authorisation certificate pay 440 euros per module (=100 hours).
- The course is free of charge for recipients of social benefits.
They will be exempted from the costs on application.
Necessary travel costs can also be reimbursed.
The language counselling centres offer individual advice on this.
You can also find more information
here.
Language schools (also known as course providers) that offer integration courses in Augsburg and the surrounding area:

Böhm Language Centre
Language Forum International German Courses
Language Centre Alterlingua
Pittner Language Centre
vhs - Adult Education Centre Augsburg e.V.
vhs - Adult Education Centre Augsburger Land e.V.
You can find an overview of the current integration courses in Augsburg and the surrounding area on the district's website under "Downloads" (on the right-hand side: "1) Current integration courses").
You can also find local integration courses on the BAMF website here.
Integration courses for the hearing impaired
The Heesch language school in Munich offers integration courses up to level B1 for the hearing impaired.
The BBW Munich has a BIK class for hearing-impaired immigrants.

question: What documents do I need to bring when registering as an asylum seeker?
context:
Registration
Have you just arrived in Germany?
And you want to apply for asylum?
Then you must register with one of the state authorities immediately after your arrival:
Border authority
the police
Immigration office
Reception centre for refugees
Branch office of the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF)
Your personal data will be registered and stored centrally.
It will be checked whether
You are applying for asylum in Germany for the first time
you have already applied for asylum in another European country
the Federal Criminal Police Office has data about you
You will then receive proof of arrival as proof of registration.
Only at this point does the asylum procedure begin.
Applying for asylum in the district of Augsburg
Would you like to apply for asylum in the district of Augsburg?
Then contact the responsible authority:
Government of Swabia
Central Immigration Office Swabia
Kobelweg 82
zab-poststelle@reg-schw.bayern.de
You will then be sent to another initial reception centre.
Or you can initially stay in the initial reception centre in the district of Augsburg.
The law requires asylum seekers to live in an initial reception centre for up to three months.
The reception centre in which you are accommodated depends on your country of origin.
Asylum applications from different countries of origin are processed in the various BAMF branch offices.
All asylum seekers are distributed evenly among the various federal states in Germany.
Keywords: registration, arrival, asylum application, asylum procedure, asylum, proof of arrival, initial reception centre, reception centre

question: What documents are needed for a residence permit application?
context:
Register and log in
Applying for a residence permit
After registering, you can apply for a residence permit (here: residence permit) at the Office for Immigration and Integration at the Augsburg District Office.
You can find the application form here.
Appointment at the Office for Immigration and Integration
An appointment with the Office for Immigration and Integration is required for the application.
Appointments can be booked online here.
When booking an appointment online, "Your appointment has expired" appears first.
You must then click on "Book new appointment".
You must select "Residence permit for humanitarian reasons (asylum)" as the "Service".
Then click on the appropriate box with the first letter of your surname and enter the number of people (including children) who require a residence permit.
The waiting time for an appointment is approx.
4 weeks.
You need to be patient.
A lot of people need an appointment at the moment.
You must bring the following documents with you to the appointment:
Passport and birth certificate, alternatively: other proof of identity that proves your Ukrainian origin
if available: Allocation notice for the district of Augsburg
Registration of residence at the responsible registration office
The address for the appointment:
You don't speak German well yet?
Then bring an interpreter with you to the appointment.
The residence permit also gives you permission to take up gainful employment with unrestricted access to the labour market.
For further information, please contact the Office for Immigration and Integration at the Augsburg District Office.

question: What kind of health insurance do I need as a refugee in Germany?
context:
Visiting a doctor
Free choice of doctor
There are many different medical professions in Germany.
Every person is free to choose his or her doctor.
General practitioner and paediatrician
If you do not feel mentally or physically well, first go to a general practitioner.
Children should be taken to the children's doctor (paediatrician).
This doctor provides basic care and is the first point of contact for all illnesses.
She or he carries out an initial examination and decides on further treatment.
If treatment by a specialist is necessary, you will receive a referral.
In this context, a “referral” means: The general practitioner or paediatrician will refer you to a specialist.
Specialists / Specialists
A specialist doctor has extensive knowledge in a certain medical field.
Theytake over responsibility for any further treatment from the general practitioner after the referral.
Doctor’s surgery open hours
Doctors' practices are usually open from Monday to Friday.
Each doctor’s surgery has different opening hours.
It is best to make an appointmentbeforehand.

question: How can I save energy at home in Germany?
context:
Save energy
How and where can energy be saved?
Saving energy means achieving the desired "performance" with less final energy (electricity, combustibles and fuels).
But it also means simply doing without something.
We can save energy everywhere: in the home, in industry and commerce and in transport.
Sooner or later, this will pay off through the energy costs saved.
The benefits are twofold: for the environment and for your wallet.
This checklist will show you how you can minimise your electricity and hot water consumption and save money.
Correct heating and ventilation are essential to prevent mould from forming in your home.
The checklist is available in German, English, Arabic, Kurdish and Dari.

question: How are the bike lanes in Augsburg?
context:
Bicycle
Bicycle
Cycling in the district of Augsburg is lots of fun!
A well-developed network of cycle paths with excellent signposting makes cycling not only a sporting hobby, but also a healthy and affordable alternative to buses, trains and cars.
For those of us who love to ride their bike, here are a few tips:
Always drive on the right-hand side of the road
Do not ride side by side, but behind each other.
If there is a cycle lane, you must ride on the cycle lane (always on the right-hand side of the road in the direction of travel).
Only children up to11 years of age are allowed to cycle on footpaths.
It is dangerous if you get your tyres caught in the tram tracks.
Important traffic rulescan be found in a flyer of theADFC (Allgemeiner Deutscher Fahrrad-Club) Munich in 12 different languages(Albanian, Arabic, German, English, Farsi, French, Italian, Kurdish, Russian, Spanish, Tigrinya and Turkish) www.adfc-muenchen.de/adfc-muenchen/arbeitsgruppen/asyl/
Purchase and repairs
When buying a bicycle, make surethat your bicycle is equipped as follows and is therefore roadworthy.
If your bicycle is not properly equipped, you will have to pay a fine if it is checked by the police:
Light front and rear
Reflector front and rear
Reflectors in the spokes (2per wheel)
Reflectors on the pedals
Bell
Two independent brakes

question: Are there any special support programs for newcomer children in schools?

Grundschule
Duration: 4 years
Goal: The children learn reading and writing as well as basic mathematics.
At present, there are 46 state-run primary schools (staatliche Grundschulen) in the district of Augsburg, teaching children basic knowledge and skills.
Afterwards, the children go to a secondary school.

question: How long can I stay in Germany with a Schengen visa?
context:
Visitor visa (Schengen visa)
Visitor visa (Schengen visa)
Holders of a valid Schengen visa (text on the visa label: "valid for Schengen states" in the language of the issuing state) can stay in the entire Schengen area for a period of 180 days up to 90 days.
You can find more informationhere (also in English)
Please note that you must leave the country again within the period of validity of your visa.
You must leave the Schengen area to do so.
A Schengen visa that has not been issued by the embassy for three months can be extended in Germany.
However, the requirements for this must still be met.
It is not possible to change the purpose of the visa.
The application must be justified.
These reasons can be
force majeure,
humanitarian, professional or serious personal reasons.
If you do not have your visa extended by the foreigners authority and only leave the country after your visa has expired, you are breaking the law.
The foreigners authority will then check whether your stay must be terminated.
Re-entry would only be possible if there is no ban on re-entry.
There may also be criminal proceedings in court.
Keywords: visitor visa, visitor visa, visa, Schengen visa, visa extension, Schengen area

question: What should I do in case of a medical emergency?
context:
Medical treatment and advice

question: What are the consequences of illegal employment in Germany?
context:
Irregular and illegal employment
Irregular and illegal employment
A job that is paid but not registered with the Finanzamt (tax office) and health insurance company, and for which thus no taxes and social security payments are paid, is illegal and is referred to in Germany as "Schwarzarbeit” or “moonlighting” in English.
It can be punished with fines and prison!
If someone gets social benefits or unemployment benefits, but still works and keeps their job secret from the Sozialamt (Social Welfare Office), the Arbeitsagentur (Employment Agency) or the Jobcenter, this is also illegal employment: A person is thus wrongly receiving state benefits, even though they are in paid employment.
This is forbidden and against the law.
In German it is known as “Schwarzarbeit”.
You should always inform the office where you get benefits if you want to start a job;
you are allowed to earn money while still receiving social benefits (the benefits are then recalculated) but you must inform the case officers of every kind of earnings and income immediately.
Taking up work even though you are forbidden to work is also regarded as illegal employment.
Depending on your country of origin and reason for staying, illegal employment can lead to you being permanently forbidden to work!

question: Who can I contact for support against labor exploitation?
context:
Labour exploitation
Labour exploitation
Labour exploitation means: when unfair conditions prevail at work or the labour is exploited without the consent of the person concerned.
Trafficked persons receive no or too little money for their work.
They have to work under bad or even dangerous conditions.
They are threatened or experience violence.
Slavery and forced labour are prohibited in Germany.
Human trafficking or forced sex work is prohibited in Germany.
Other forms of exploitation are also punishable:
No wage payment even though you have worked.
Working longer hours for the same wage than agreed in the employment contract (circumventing the minimum wage).
No payment of wages due to you, such as sick pay or paid holidays.
As an EU citizen, you can get help and advice from the "" Fair Mobility Advice Centre.
As a non-EU citizen, you can get help and advice from the "" Fair Integration Advice Centre.

question: What types of vocational training are available in Germany?
context:
School-based vocational training
School-based vocational training
Full-time school-based vocational education and training
There are two types of training in Germany:
Dual system ("" dual training).
Pupils learn both at a vocational school and in a training company.
School-based training at a vocational school
The students only attend school and learn everything there.
The school-based training usually lasts 1 - 3 years.
Depending on the school, there are different types of training and admission requirements.
You can get detailed information directly from the school.
School-based training is usually found in professions in the fields of technology, health and social services, art and foreign languages.
Learn more

question: What medical tests are included in a school health examination in Germany?
context:
Pre-school health examination
Pre-school health examination
Your child will soon be starting school.
All children in Munich have a health examination before starting school, between the ages of four and five.
For example, they have their sight, hearing and language development checked.
In the examination, the medical staff can see how and in what areas your child can best be supported from the penultimate kindergarten year, so that your child can make a good start in everyday school life.
In Bavaria, this examination is compulsory.
You will receive an invitation to the examination from the health department.
You can find further information about the health examination at:
muenchen.de/rseu
If you do not bring your child to the health examination after receiving the invitation from the health department, your details will be given to the City of Munich Stadtjugendamt (Child Welfare Office).
The Child Welfare Office will then have to contact you to find out why the examination has not taken place.
Your Sozialbürgerhaus (Social Centre) can offer help and support for you and your child.

question: How can I get help to understand my rental agreement in Germany?
context:
Renting an apartment
Renting an apartment
Rental contract
The amount of rent you pay is agreed in the rental contract.
When tenants sign this contract, they agree to pay that amount of rent.
The rent consists of ‘Kaltmiete’ (basic amount), ‘Nebenkosten’ (ancillary costs – waste collection, operating costs)and ‘Heizkosten’ (heating costs).
The contract must include the following points:
Name and address of the landlord
Address of the property
Living space in m²
Number of rooms
Agreed amount of “cold” rent
Agreed amount of operational costs
Agreed amount of heating costs
Total rent
The amount of the deposit
The contract stipulates when the rent will be paid.
If the rent is paid late several times, this can lead to therental contractbeing cancelled.
If you are unemployed and receiving financial support from the Jobcenter, please also note the »» “Financial support from the Jobcenter" under “Financial support for housing".
Security deposit
The security deposit is a payment you make to the landlord.
The amount of the deposit is a maximum of 3 months' rent (basic rent without utility and heating costs).
When you move out of the property, you get the money back.
Important: You must not leave any damage if you move out of the property.
If there is any damage, you will not get the full deposit back.

question: What are the rules about noise in my apartment?
context:
House regulations
House regulations
House regulations list specific rules about living together with others.
They apply to all people living in group accommodation or an apartment.
The most important ones are:
Noise: Everyone living in the building is responsible for keeping noise levels as low as possible.
You must take special care from 12:00 to 15:00 and from 22:00 to 07:00: These are known as the quiet times.
Ventilation: You should open the windows frequently to let in fresh air.
This prevents mould from developing.

question: What does German language proficiency level A1 mean?
context:
Levels of language ability
Levels of language ability
There are different levels of language ability.
The levels used in language and integration courses correspond to the Common European Framework:
Language level A: basic language skills
Language level B: independent language skills (necessary for training or work)
Language level C: proficient language skills (necessary for higher education and certain professions)
There are even more sub-divisions in the levels:
A1: Beginner
A2: Basic knowledge
B1: Advanced language skills
B2: Independent language skills
C1: Expert language skills
C2: Approaching native speaker proficiency
And within these levels there are further differentiations (A1/1, A1/2, A2/1, A2/2, etc.)
In detail, the six levels mean:
A1: Beginner
You can understand and use simple words and sentences.
You can introduce yourself and others.
For example: My name is Maria.
I am 30 years old.
I live in Germany.
This is my boyfriend.
His name is Paul.
You can ask personal questions.
For example: What is your name?
Where do you live?
You can answer questions.
For example: How are you?
I’m doing well.
You can talk to a person if they speak slowly and clearly.
A2: Basic knowledge
You can understand full sentences and frequently used words.
You can understand words for the following topics: Information about you as a person and your family, shopping, work and your surroundings.
You can express yourself in simple, everyday situations.
You can describe where you come from, what kind of education you have and your surroundings.
B1: Advanced language skills
You can understand a lot if it’s about work, school or leisure, for example.
You can express yourself when travelling.
You can speak about topics you are familiar with and your personal interests.
You can report on experiences you have had.
You can describe your dreams, hopes and goals.
You can provide brief reasons or explanations for your plans and opinions.
B2: Independent language skills
You can understand the most important parts of complex texts on both specific and abstract topics.
You can even understand expert discussions in topics you know well.
You can express yourself spontaneously and fluently.
It is possible for you to have a normal conversation with
native speakers without a great deal of effort from either party.
You can express yourself on a variety of topics clearly and in detail.
You can articulate an opinion on a question you have been asked.
You can state the pros and cons of various possibilities.
C1: Expert language skills
You can understand much of longer, complex texts.
You can also grasp implicit meaning in the text.
You can express yourself spontaneously and fluently.
You rarely have to search for the right word.
You can use the target language effectively and flexibly in your social and professional life and/or in a vocational training programme or at university.
You can articulate your opinion on complex topics clearly, extensively and in a well-structured way.
In doing so, you can appropriately use various methods of referring to the text.
C2: (Approaching) native speaker proficiency
You can understand practically everything you read or hear without effort.
You can summarise information from a variety of written and oral sources.
You can reproduce reasoning and explanations in a cohesive way.
You can express yourself spontaneously, precisely and very fluently.
You can make subtle nuances of meaning clear, even for more complex issues.

question: How do I vote in Germany's elections?
context:
How to vote
How to vote
In this election, you decide who gets a place on the Migration Advisory Board.
You have 40 votes.
The nominations (= lists) with the candidates for the election of the Migration Advisory Board are finalised at the end of January.
Ballot paper
On the ballot paper, all nominations are sorted by initial letters from A to Z. Each list has a number, an identifying name and numbered candidates.
Each person's name, nationality and profession are listed.
Here you will find all
nominations (lists)and a
sample ballot paper.
You can also use an
online test ballot paperto see how the casting of votes works.
Casting votes
You have 40 votes.
If you cast more votes, the ballot paper is invalid.
Here are four examples of how you can cast your votes:
(1) Cast votes freely
You can cast your votes freely among the candidates on the whole ballot paper.
You put a cross next to all the people you want to vote for, no matter which list they are on.
This is what is known as splitting your vote.
In addition, you can give extra support to individuals and give them not only one vote, but also two, or up to a maximum of three votes.
You can put a cross against the name more than once.
Or write the number of votes (1, 2 or 3) in the box next to the name.
This is what is known as cumulating.
Please make sure that nobody receives more than three votes from you.
(2) Vote for a list
You can also vote for a complete list.
To do this, you only need to put a cross at the top of the list once next to the identifying name.
Your votes will then go to the candidates on this list in turn until all 40 votes have been distributed.
People who appear there three times get three votes.
People who appear there twice get two votes.
(3) Vote for a list - with changes
If you choose a whole list, you can still change something according to your preferences.
For example, you can cross out one or more names from the list.
These people then do not get a vote.
You can also give extra support to people on the list by giving them two or three votes.
(4) Vote for a list and additionally cast votes freely
A mixed form is also possible: You can vote for a list (with and without amendments) and additionally cast votes freely.
This means that you can also put a cross next to people on other lists on the ballot paper and give them up to three votes.
The count then works like this: On your ballot paper, all the votes you have given to individuals are added up first.
What then remains of your
40 votes goes to the list you put a cross next to.
This means that all the remaining votes go to the people on this list in order.
This way, no vote is wasted.
You can also find all examples on the
"How do I vote?” information sheet.
Use the
online test ballot paperto try it out.
Test your vote casting.

question: What documents are needed for a work permit application?
context:
Citizens of third countries
Citizens of third countries
The regulations concerning persons from states outside the EU/EEA getting a work permit are very complex.
For people who have a residence permit, access to the job market depends on the purpose of their stay in Germany.
The»» Ausländerbehörde (Immigration Office) tells you about this when you apply for your residence permit.
For people who are in the asylum procedure, their access to the job market depends on many different factors (time of entry into Germany, country of origin, duration of stay ...). The legal conditions have changed very often in recent times.
Some groups are people are not allowed to work.
Getting advice on the topic of »» job market access is recommended.
Here is some general information:
You need a work permit for almost every kind of employment.
An entry in your residence permit stating that you are allowed to have an occupation activity qualifies as a work permit.
Please note that for
Small-scale employment (mini-job)
Most internships
Vocational training
you also need this entry in your residence permit.
If you work without permission (without a work permit, without registering for social insurance), you may endanger the likelihood of being allowed to stay in Germany and this may lead to a permanent work ban.
Foreign skilled workers with occupational, non-academic training will be able to immigrate to Germany more easily, in order to work here.
The new rules are summarised for you here:
Website

question: How can I apply for social housing in Germany?
context:
Access to sponsored housing / social housing
Access to sponsored housing / social housing
If you are allowed to stay permanently in Germany through EU citizenship, Aufenthaltserlaubnis - (residence permit), Niederlassungserlaubnis (settlement permit), have your main residence in Germany and your income does not exceed a certain limit, you are entitled to move into a subsidised apartment (so-called social apartment).
In order to receive an apartment in this way, you have to make an application for registration at the Amt für Wohnen und Migration (Office for Housing and Migration).
You can submit the application online via the internet platform SOWON (Soziales Wohnen Online, Social Housing Online).
In the last step, you will see which documents you need for the application.
You can upload the documents directly to SOWON.
Here you can find a how-to video regarding the “SOWON online housing application (Sowon Wohnungsantrag online)”.
Alternatively, you can also submit the application on paper.
You can find the application form on the Internet or at these sites:
Infothek (document resource centre) in the Amt für Wohnen und Migration (Office for Housing and Migration), Werinherstraße 87 (House 24)
Infotheks in the Sozialbürgerhäuser
City information in the Rathaus (city hall)
Rathauspforte (city hall reception area)
You can submit the paper application by post or drop it in the letterbox in person:
Amt für Wohnen und Migration, Social Housing Provision
Werinherstraße 89
Documents required:
Proof of income (e.g. salary/wage slips for the last 3 months, SGB II/ SGB XII notification (all pages), last tax assessment)
Identity card, passport or residence permit
Rental contract or proof of current living situation
If applicable, confirmation of pregnancy (Mutterpass or medical certificate)
If applicable, medical certificate
if applicable, proof of custody or declaration of child(ren) in separate households
Searching for somewhere to live:
Once all requirements have been checked, you will be registered for a subsidised apartment (notification).
In the notification, your individual space requirements and the urgency of your housing search are determined.
You can then click on SOWON to search for apartments.
There you will see offers for apartments that suit your household (for example, in terms of apartment size and income level).
In the offer you will find all important information about the apartment (size, position, amount of rent).
The offers are usually available online for 14 days.
You can apply for up to three apartments at the same time.
Costs:
No fees are charged for processing the housing application.
If an apartment is successfully arranged, a fee of 25 euros is charged for the confirmation.
Contact &more information:
You can find more information on the website of the Amt für Wohnen und Migration (Office for Housing and Migration).
The most frequently asked questions about the application are answered in the SOWON Help section.
You can reach the Customer Centre Housing via a contact form.

question: What are the consequences of overstaying a visa in Germany?
context:
Residence with a visa
Residence with a visa
If you enter Germany with a visa with which a longer stay is not intended, you must leave Germany within the validity period of the visa – i.e. at the latest on the last day of validity.
A Schengen visa that has not been issued for three months can be extended in Germany for a maximum period of three months within a deadline of six months, if the requirements still exist.
You are not allowed to change the purpose of the visa.
The application must be justified, in particular
Force majeure,
Humanitarian, professional or serious personal reasons
can be taken into account.
If you leave later, without asking permission of the »» Ausländerbehörde (Immigration Office), your stay would be without permission and an infringement of the law.
The Ausländerbehörde (Immigration Office) then checks how your stay ended.
It would only be possible for you to re-enter the country if you were not subject to a re-entry ban.
Legal action could also be taken against you.

question: Where is the Munich Administrative Court located and how can I get there?
context:
Verwaltungsgericht München
Verwaltungsgericht (VG) München
The Verwaltungsgericht München (Munich district court) supports the Bavarian administrative courts.
It is responsible for the region of Upper Bavaria.
If an application for asylum is rejected by the Bundesamt für Migration und Flüchtlinge – BAMF, you can usually appeal against this at the Verwaltungsgericht München.
The court checks the decision of the Bundesamt für Migration und Flüchtlinge (BAMF).
If the court comes to a different decision, it can compel the BAMF to offer the plaintiff (you) protection.
If it confirms the decision, then the appeal is rejected.
In order to appeal, we recommend that you get advice and representation from a specialist lawyer for asylum and residence law.

question: What documents do I need to bring when applying for asylum protection?
context:
Forms of protection during the asylum procedure
Forms of protection during the asylum procedure
If you make an application for asylum, you apply to receive protection in Germany and not be deported.
The law anticipates several forms of protection.
They correspond to different forms of persecution in your home country.
In an asylum procedure, we check which forms of protection you can be given depending on your individual situation.
You can find a short overview of the different forms of protection below.
Via the links given you can find more detailed information in German, English, Turkish, Russian, French and Arabic.
Entitlement to asylum
According to Art.
16 A of the Grundgesetz (basic law or GG) of the Federal Republic of Germany, people who are politically persecuted receive asylum.
This protection status can be given to people who, according to their
Ethnicity
Nationality
Political opinions
Fundamental religious outlook or
Membership of a particular social group (for example on the grounds of their sexual orientation)
would be faced with persecution in their country of origin and, therefore, face serious violations of human rights if they returned.
Find out more
Protection of refugees
According to the Geneva Convention on Refugees, people are regarded as refugees if they are affected by state or non-state persecution owing to one of the follow characteristics and are outside their country of origin:
Ethnicity
Religion
Nationality
Political opinions
Membership of a particular social group (for example on the grounds of their sexual orientation)
Legal basis: Section 3 par.
German Asylum Law (AsylG)
Find out more
Subsidiary protection
People are entitled to subsidiary protection if they are threatened with serious harm in their country of origin and are not able to utilise the protection of their country of origin.
The threat can be from the state or also from a non-state element.
Examples include:
Death penalty
Torture
Inhuman or humiliating treatment or punishment
Serious individual danger to life or intactness of a civil person owing to arbitrary violence in an international or internal armed conflict
Legal basis: Section 4 par.
1 German Asylum Law (AsylG)
Find out more
National deportation ban
A person seeking protection must not be deported if
the deportation means breaking the European Convention on the Protection of Human Rights and Basic freedoms (EMRK) or
there is a significant concrete danger to body, life or freedom in the destination country.
Legal basis: Section 60 par.
5 German Residence Act (AufenthG)., Section 60 par.
7 German Residence Act (AufenthG).
Find out more

question: Do job center benefits cover language course costs?
context:
Benefits from the Job Centre
Benefits from the Job Centre
Who for: Households that receive financial support from the Jobcentre.
Rent and heating
Costs are covered if they are reasonable (§22 SGB II).
In the case of the City of Munich, fixed
rent ceilings apply.
For households with seven or more persons, the rent ceiling includes 15 m² and 270 Euros per additional person.
The amounts for the rent ceiling refer to the gross cold rent.
A gross cold rent is made up as follows:
Net cold rent = basic rent without operating costs
plus
cold operating costs = for example, the costs for refuse collection, (cold) water, staircase lighting, street cleaning and property tax.
Heating and hot water costs are taken into account separately.
Your benefits officer will explain to you how to proceed in case of unreasonable rent costs.
The "" Office for Housing and Migration of the state capital will advise you on all questions concerning housing in Munich.
If you are threatened with homelessness, we will look for a solution with you at
Sozialbürgerhaus.
Moving
If you want to move, your case worker must check whether the move is necessary and the costs of the new flat are reasonable before signing the tenancy agreement.
The following evidence and documents are required for the check:
Written justification of the reason for the move (if necessary, appropriate evidence proving an important reason).
Unsigned tenancy agreement or an offer of a flat showing all costs related to renting the flat (for example basic rent, ancillary costs and heating costs, deposit).
An important reason exists, for example, if:
the move remedies a threatened or existing homelessness;
the move ends or avoids the need for assistance;
the move is necessary in order to take up or continue employment subject to social security contributions at a greater distance (commute to work, depending on working hours, more than 2-2.5 hours total travel time).
Attention: If you rent a flat without the Job Centre's consent, you may suffer financial disadvantages.

question: Who can I contact for help with housing-related issues?
context:
Help if you are in danger of losing your home
Help if you are in danger of losing your home
If you are in danger of losing your home through termination or eviction, you can contact the Fachstelle zur Vermeidung von Wohnungslosigkeit (office for avoidance of homelessness).
You can find one in every of the twelve Munich Sozialbürgerhäuser.
The office advises and supports you, gets involved and refers you for further help.
It is important to contact to the office as soon as possible so that you can keep various deadlines and avoid additional costs.
The Fachstelle zur Vermeidung von Wohnungslosigkeit advises you on the following topics:
Taking over rent arrears
Legality of the eviction
Possible economic help
Entitlement to housing allowance or other housing payments
Personal help (advice for people in debt, social-pedagogic help)
You need to bring these documents with you.
To have a consultation with the office, you need to arrange an appointment with the clerk in the Sozialbürgerhaus responsible for you.

question: How can I report bullying in school?
context:

JIZ - Counselling for school stress and/or bullying
Are you stressed at school?
Do you sometimes want to stop going at all?
Or do you as a parent realise how much school is stressing your child out?
The reasons for this can be stress about grades, pressure to perform, exam nerves or conflicts or bullying.
Bullying means repeatedly and regularly harassing other people and hurting them emotionally.
Examples of bullying include spreading false information, threats of violence, social exclusion or constant criticism.
It can happen in different places: at school, at work, at sports clubs or on the internet ("cyberbullying").
Are you or your child affected?

question: How can I ensure my child's safety in school?
context:
Protecting children and adolescents
Protecting children and adolescents
Caring for and parenting children is the natural right of the parents.
However, children, adolescents and families are specially protected in Germany.
This protection starts during pregnancy and continues until the child has reached 18 years of age (adult).
In Germany, for example, it is forbidden to hit children or adolescents: Children must be raised in Germany without the use of violence.
All children must attend school.
Public authorities make sure that children are not harmed by their environment – or by their family.
These public authorities also support and help families that need help.
The Sozialbürgerhäuser are responsible for this task in Munich.
You can ask for support there.
The Sozialbürgerhaus responsible for you depends on your address.
Find your Sozialbürgerhaus here

question: How can I contact a private tutor for language lessons?
context:
Private tutoring - General information
Private tutoring - General information
Private tutoring or learning support is additional support for a school subject outside the classroom.
You usually must pay for this yourself.
For example, private tutoring and learning support are useful if a pupil could be held back (not pass to the next school year at the end of the current school year) or their school-leaving certificate is at risk or if a pupil does not know a lot of the contents taught in the classroom.
Talk to the teachers at the school and ask whether private tutoring or learning support is a good idea.
Perhaps the school itself can provide this.
It is sometimes possible to get learning support paid for through the Bildungs- und Teilhabepaket / BuT (education and participation programme).
You can apply for the support in your »» Sozialbürgerhaus .
Find out more

question: Which public schools offer German language classes for children?
context:
Grundschule (primary school)
Grundschule
Registration for Grundschule:
Children who will be six by 30 June are required to go to school.
The parents have to register them at a public Grundschule, the
Sprengelschule.
You can find
information about registration here.
Following consultation with and a recommendation from the school, parents of children who will turn six between 1 July and 30 September can decide whether their child will start school in the current school year or the next one.
The Sprengelgrundschulen can provide you with further information.
Find out more
If you have questions about registering for Grundschule, you can also contact the municipal Referat für Bildung und Sport:
After leaving Grundschule:
All children attend Grundschule up to year 4. Here they learn to read and write and study maths.
Towards the end of year 4 (in May) they receive a so-called ‘Übertrittszeugnis’ (transfer certificate).
In Bavaria, the marks on this certificate determine which school the child will attend:
a »» Mittelschule (years 5 to 9 or 10)
a »» Realschule (years 5 to 10)
or a »» Gymnasium (years 5 to 12/13).
The three types of school differ according to the subjects they teach and the level of the lessons.
There are also two special types of school:
the »» Orientierungsstufe (years 5 and 6, followed by transfer to Mittelschule, Realschule or Gymnasium from year 7)
and the »» Gesamtschule (years 5 to 7, from year 8 three different leaving qualifications are possible: Mittelschulabschluss, Realschulabschluss, gymnasiale Oberstufenreife der naturwissenschaftlich-technologischen Ausbildungsrichtung).
You can find more information about secondary schools
here.

question: What is self-help?
context:
Self-help center
Self-help center
The Selbsthilfe-Zentrum München is a contact point for self-help groups and all people who are looking for or would like to found a self-help group.
What is a self-help group?
means self-help:
People with a common topic or problem join together to form groups or an association (also: initiative).
The members of these groups and initiatives want to support each other and advise other people on this topic or problem.
The activities and objectives can only be important for the self-help groups or self-help initiatives.
But they can also be important for a larger community: for example, other people with the same problem or the neighborhood, district or town.
Self-help groups or self-help initiatives can be organized in very different ways.
Work in a self-help group or self-help initiative is usually voluntary.
The groups or initiatives are independent.
They decide for themselves what they do and how they do it.
All members can have their say.
There is no line that comes from outside.
Professionals may also lead a self-help group or a self-help initiative.
They decide what they do and how they do it, and they get paid for it.
This is referred to as a professionally led group or initiative that is part of social work or therapy.
In therapy, people with problems get help from professionals.
The self-help groups can use the rooms and work equipment (e.g. computers and Internet) of the self-help center.
Call us with the following questions, for example:
What self-help groups are there?
Which self-help group is right for me?
What exactly does a self-help group do?
Can a self-help group help me?
Can another offer help me better?
What other offers are there in Munich?
When and where is my self-help group?
How can I set up a self-help group myself?
You can contact us in person, by telephone or by e-mail.
We will advise you confidentially and anonymously if you wish.
Interpreters on request
Barrier-free access to the building and premises is available.
Self-help center Munich

question: What type of certificate is required for a settlement permit?
context:
Do I need a certificate?
Do I need a certificate?
In some situations it is necessary or very useful to have proof of German language skills.
For example:
Applying for an apprenticeship or job
If you can prove your German language skills, your chances of getting an apprenticeship or a job are higher.
If you have several competitors, you can be more convincing with a certificate.
Further vocational training or qualification
Vocational training courses often require a certain level of German.
You often have to prove this with a certificate.
Access to study at colleges and universities
To study at a college or university, you often have to prove your knowledge of German.
This is possible with one of the following certificates:
Language diploma of the
Conference of Ministers of Education and Cultural Affairs (second stage)
DSH2
TestDaf, level 4 in all 4 sub-areas.
Assessment test at a preparatory college.
This means that no further testing is necessary.
Certificates recognized by the Standing Conference of the Ministers of Education and Cultural Affairs of the Länder in the Federal Republic of Germany (KMK) or the German Rectors' Conference (HRK).
the exams at level C1 or C2 of the
Goethe-Institut
TestDaF certificates and telc certificates from the Munich Language and Interpreting Institute (SDI).
"telc German C1 University".
Completed degree in German studies (no pedagogy studies).
Graduation certificate from a grammar school, a preparatory college, a university of applied sciences or a university.
For a permanent residence permit (settlement permit)
To obtain a settlement permit, you must provide proof of sufficient German language skills.
This is possible, for example, with a certificate from a "" integration course "Deutsch-Test für Zuwanderer" (DTZ).
A German school-leaving certificate can also be proof of German language skills.
For naturalization (obtaining German citizenship)
In addition to sufficient knowledge of German, you must also demonstrate knowledge of the legal and social order and living conditions in Germany.
You can do this, for example, with the "Living in Germany" test.
This test is the conclusion of the orientation course (part of the "" integration course).

question: What information is mandatory in the payslip or pay slip?
context:
Payroll accounting
Payroll accounting
If you are employed, you will receive a payslip or payslip after the first month.
Some employers will continue to issue you with a monthly statement, others only if something is different in the month in question (e.g. Christmas bonus, increase in insurance contributions, etc.).
Mandatory information in the pay slip or payslip:
Name and address of the employer
Name, address, date of birth of the employee
Insurance number of the employer
Date of start of employment
Tax class and tax identification number
Billing period
Gross salary (salary without deductions - gross tax amount and gross social security amount)
Type and amount of supplements or allowances
Type and amount of deductions
Net amount (after all deductions)
The net amount is usually the amount paid out.
Exception: In the case of advances, loans from the company or salary garnishments (if you have debts), further amounts are deducted from the net amount.

question: What happens if you exceed the visa-free period?
context:
Entry / stay without a visa
Entry / stay without a visa
Citizens of the following countries may enter the country without a visa
Schengen area: Australia, New Zealand, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Israel, Japan, Canada, the Republic of Korea, the United States of America.
These are the so-called privileged states.
They may stay in Schengen territory for up to 90 days within a 180-day period (90/180 rule).
If you are planning multiple entries or longer stays, you must take this into account.
Set the departure date so that the total of 90 days is not exceeded.
The calculation is often complicated and visitors do not know whether they have already spent their 90 days in the Schengen area or not.
It is therefore important to keep track of the days.
This
Online calculators can help.
List of countries that require a visa for entry (visa requirement)
Please note: At the end of the maximum period of stay, you must not only leave Germany, but the entire Schengen area.
If you want to stay or work here for longer than three months, you must apply for a residence permit at the "" Foreigners' Registration Office.
If it is not possible to leave the country within the deadline, the Foreigners' Registration Office must be contacted before the deadline expires.
Reasons can be
Force majeure (An unforeseeable event caused by external circumstances that could not have been prevented.
This can be a natural event such as an earthquake, but also war or a pandemic)
Humanitarian, professional or serious personal reasons
be taken into account.
If you exceed the visa-free stay without having applied for a residence permit, your stay is not permitted (violation of the law).
The foreigners authority can terminate the stay.
Re-entry would only be possible again if there is no re-entry ban.
There may also be criminal proceedings in court.

question: Can you work in Germany with a residence permit for temporary protection?
context:
Entry from Ukraine and stay in Germany
Information from the Federal Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs (BMAS):
The Federal Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs helps people who have fled to Germany because of the war with employment and social security issues.
Information from the Federal Foreign Office and the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees
Here you will find the latest information and situation reports from the Federal Foreign Office and the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees.
Entry rules and visa requirements can also be found on the website.
We have included some important questions and answers here:
I am visa-free in Germany.
What options do I have now?
You can stay in Germany legally for up to 90 days from the date of entry without a residence permit.
During the 90-day visa waiver period, you can consider whether you would like to stay in Germany for longer.
You can use the following options for this:
You can apply for a residence permit in accordance with § 24 of the Residence Act within 90 days of your first entry into Germany.
This provision specifically regulates the situation for war refugees from Ukraine on the basis of the EU decision.
You can find out who is eligible for a residence permit under Section 24 of the Residence Act here and you can find answers to questions about the procedure here.
You can apply for a residence permit for a different purpose within 90 days of your first entry into Germany, for example to study or work.
This may be more advantageous for you.
You can get advice on this from the authorities if you have an appointment, or you can find out more in advance on the homepage: https://www.make-it-in-germany.com/.
Or you can apply for asylum.
However, this option is not recommended due to the less favorable legal consequences - such as the restriction on taking up employment and the obligation to live in an initial reception facility.
What happens after entry?
Where can I register in Germany and where can I get accommodation and meals?
The procedure is divided into four consecutive steps: initial registration and (if receiving social benefits) allocation to a place of residence, as well as registration of the residential address at the destination and application for a residence permit.
Further information can be found here.
Can I work in Germany with a residence permit for temporary protection?
Yes, that is possible.
However, gainful employment must first be permitted by the foreigners authority.
The immigration authority will already enter in the residence permit that gainful employment is permitted when issuing the residence permit, even if there is no concrete employment relationship in prospect.
This means that no further work permit from another authority is required.
The immigration authorities will issue so-called fictitious certificates as soon as an application is submitted.
These bridge the right of residence until the actual residence permit can be issued and granted.
The foreigners authority will also enter "Gainful employment permitted" in the fictitious certificate.
This fictitious certificate already allows you to work in Germany as a self-employed person or as an employee.
Special professional access requirements (such as a license to practice medicine or a permit for a trade requiring a license) naturally apply to persons with temporary protection in the same way as to all others.
However, the procedures for the recognition of foreign professional qualifications are also open to those affected, just like everyone else.
People with a residence permit for temporary protection in Germany can also receive advice and placement services from the employment agencies in accordance with SGB III.
Should Ukrainian nationals apply for asylum?
No, that is not necessary.
The necessary protection is granted in a different, faster procedure.
Ukrainian nationals are therefore advised to refrain from applying for asylum.
However, the right to submit an application for asylum at a later date continues to exist regardless of this.
Registration upon entry does not constitute an application for asylum.
The asylum procedure requires an application for asylum to be submitted to the responsible branch office of the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees.
For these reasons, it is not necessary to apply for asylum in order to secure a right of residence or to claim social benefits.
Information portal of the German government
The Federal Ministry of the Interior and for Home Affairs offers a digital information service in German, English, Russian and Ukrainian.
Here you will find all the official information about residence and living in Germany.
Germany4Ukraine
Embassy of Ukraine in Berlin

question: Which groups of people are not permitted to take up employment?
context:
Third-country nationals
Third-country nationals
The regulations for a work permit for people from countries outside the EU/EEA are very complex.
For people who have a residence permit, access to the labor market depends on the purpose of their stay in Germany.
The"" Foreigners' Registration Office will inform you when you apply for your residence permit.
For persons in the asylum procedure, access to the labor market depends on many different factors (time of entry, country of origin, length of stay, etc.). Recently, the legal provisions have changed very frequently.
Some groups of people are not permitted to take up employment.
Advice on the subject of "" access to the labor market is recommended.
Here is some important general information:
You need a work permit for almost every job.
A work permit is an entry in the residence permit that allows you to pursue a professional activity in Germany.
Please note that as a rule you also have to pay for
marginal employment (mini-job)
most internships
vocational training
require this entry in the residence permit.
Unauthorized employment (without an employment permit, without registration with the social security authorities) can jeopardize your stay and lead to a permanent work ban.
In future, foreign skilled workers with vocational, non-academic training will be able to immigrate to Germany more easily in order to work here.
The new features are summarized for you here:
Website

question: What is meant by irregular employment?
context:
Irregular and illegal employment
Irregular and illegal employment
Work that is paid but not registered with the tax office and health insurance fund and for which no taxes and social security contributions are therefore paid is illegal and is referred to as "irregular employment" in Germany.
Fines and prison sentences are threatened!
If someone receives social benefits or unemployment benefit but still works and conceals this from the social welfare office, employment agency or job center, this is called illegal employment: You receive state benefits even though you are in paid employment.
This is prohibited and against the law.
A colloquial term for this is "moonlighting".
Always inform the office from which you receive benefits if you wish to take up work;
It is permitted to earn money while receiving benefits (benefits will then be recalculated), but you are obliged to declare any earnings and income immediately.
Taking up employment despite a work ban is also considered illegal employment.
Depending on the country of origin and reason for residence, illegal employment can lead to an indefinite ban on working!

question: Where can I apply for a residence permit?
context:
Entry - Visa procedure
Entry as part of a visa procedure
If you are entering Germany with a D visa for a longer stay, you must note the following after your arrival:
First of all, you must register at your chosen place of residence.
German law stipulates a period of 14 days for this.
In Munich, registration takes place at the citizens' offices.
To register, you can come in person or have the completed and signed form delivered by a person authorized by you.
In both cases, you need an appointment that you can
can arrange online.
Once you have registered, you will receive a registration certificate.
The second step is to apply for a residence permit:
They were granted a national visa (category D) to enter the country.
It is not issued for the planned duration of your stay.
You therefore need a residence permit.
You must apply for the residence permit at the"" Foreigners' Registration Office.
It is important that you apply for a residence permit while your visa is still valid.
The residence permit is limited in time and can be extended.
The residence permit also depends on the reason for your entry,
whether you are allowed to work or not,
what work you are allowed to accept and
whether time restrictions apply to employment in Germany.
Extension of the residence permit:
Please note that you should apply to extend your residence permit six to eight weeks before it expires.
Depending on the purpose of your stay, there may be other things to consider.
You can also obtain this information from the "" Foreigners' Registration Office.

question: Can a permanent right of residence in Germany be lost?
context:
Residence with residence permit
Third-country nationals with a residence permit
The right of residence in Germany may end when you leave the country.
This depends on the type of residence permit, the duration of the absence, the reason for the departure, the country of residence during the absence, the age or the family circumstances.
Make sure you know which regulations apply to you and your relatives.
Attention: Even an unlimited right of residence can be lost!
If you want to stay abroad for a longer period of time, you will need a certificate from the "" Foreigners' Registration Office, otherwise your residence permit may expire.
Please apply for this in good time before your stay abroad, as a certificate can no longer be issued once you have left the country.
Find out more: on
German and in English
Refugees with a residence permit
People who are granted protection status in the asylum procedure receive a residence permit to protect them from persecution or serious harm in their country of origin.
If you travel to your country of origin, you risk losing your right of residence in Germany.
In this case, a revocation procedure can be initiated upon return to Germany and the residence permit can be withdrawn.
In urgent family matters, the "" Foreigners' Registration Office may grant permission in individual cases.

question: What do you need to open a bank account?
context:
How do I behave correctly?
How do I behave correctly?
Marriage
Everyone in Germany is free to decide whether and whom they want to marry and with whom they want to live.
If you are a minor and have already married abroad, please contact your guardians.
They can explain your options for marriage and housing.
How do I use public transportation?
You can explore the city by subway, S-Bahn, streetcar and bus and get to important appointments quickly.
Before boarding, you must buy and stamp a ticket at the ticket machine.
You then present this ticket at an inspection.
When can I start learning to drive?
In Germany, you may only drive a car with a valid driver's license "".
Beforehand, you have to attend a driving school and take theoretical and practical lessons, which you also have to pay for.
You can get information about this at the driving school.
When can I open my own bank account?
At 18, you can open a bank account on your own.
If you are younger, you will need a legal representative, for example your guardian.
Watch out!
Alcohol, drugs and slot machines quickly make you addicted and ill and also cost a lot of money.
If you notice that you need help, please talk to your counselor as soon as possible or go to an addiction counseling center!
The trade in drugs and prostitution are illegal and dangerous!
It is better to contact your caregivers or your guardian.
They can tell you how you can earn money legally.
There are also people in Germany who have very extreme opinions and want to spread their views through the use of violence.
If they try to approach you, please seek help from someone you trust.
If you join radical people, you will have big problems in Germany and will face deportation.
Female circumcision, forced marriages and child marriages are prohibited in Germany.
Traveling without a valid ticket on public transport such as buses and trains costs a fine.

question: Who will be present at the personal hearing?
context:
4. hearing
Personal interview
This is the most important appointment in the asylum procedure.
You will receive an invitation.
An interpreter will be present.
You must attend this appointment.
If you are unable to attend, you must let us know in good time and explain why you cannot come.
Otherwise their application for asylum may be rejected or the proceedings may be discontinued.
At the personal interview, you can explain why you had to flee your country.
You will be asked about your biography, your living situation, your journey to Germany and the reasons for your persecution in your country of origin.
If possible, you should also provide evidence for your statements at the personal hearing.
The hearing is conducted by specialized employees.
You can be accompanied to the appointment:
a lawyer
a representative of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)
another person of trust who is not themselves in an asylum procedure
In the case of unaccompanied minors, the guardian may attend the hearing.
Their stories are translated and recorded.
They are then translated back.
This gives you another opportunity to make additions and corrections.
Finally, the minutes with the recordings will be presented to you.
If everything is shown correctly, confirm this with your signature.
To prepare for the personal interview in the asylum procedure, you can contact the Munich Refugee Council or Arrival Aid.
Collection of materials for the personal interview

question: Who ensures that children attend school regularly?
context:
School for children from 6 to 16 years
Compulsory schooling and school districts
Compulsory schooling
School attendance is compulsory in Germany: all children between the ages of 6 and 15 have to go to school.
Thereafter, the following applies in Bavaria until the age of 21
Vocational school attendance is compulsory from the age of 18 if attendance at a general school is not continued.
Compulsory vocational schooling does not apply if the school was completed with the Abitur or Fachabitur.
Parents ensure that their children attend school regularly.
Attending public (state and municipal) schools costs nothing.
If a child is ill, parents must call the school before 08:00 in the morning.
School district
If the child attends a public primary or secondary school, it must go to the school that is responsible for its place of residence - a Sprengelschule.
"Sprengel" means "school district".
Further information on school attendance and the different types of schools can be found "" here.

question: What is not allowed in Germany?
context:
Religious freedom
Religious freedom
Religion and faith are private matters in Germany.
The state does not dictate to anyone whether and in which God he or she should believe.
State and religion are separate.
This means, for example:
All people are free to practise and choose their religion and beliefs.
All people have the freedom to be non-religious and to say so.
Anyone who does not believe in God is allowed to say so publicly.
Members of different religions and faiths are allowed to marry each other.
Marriage only counts as a legally valid marriage if it is concluded before the registry office.
Marriages entered into exclusively within the framework of a religion are not legally binding in Germany.
This is not permitted in Germany, for example:
Putting religious rules or traditions above applicable laws, for example being married to several women at the same time or slaughtering an animal without special permission.
Boys may only be circumcised if this does not endanger their welfare.
Many people in Germany today are committed to dialog between religions.
The aim is the peaceful coexistence of religious people, people of faith and people of no religion.
The state is committed to ideological neutrality.
As long as the practice of a religion does not endanger democracy or the separation of state and religion, it is protected.

question: What requirements must be met for the residence permit in Germany to be terminated?
context:
Taxes and social security contributions
Taxes and social security contributions
Every employee pays part of their salary in taxes and social security contributions.
If you are self-employed, you must also pay taxes.
Income tax
Income tax contributes to the financing of federal, state and local government expenditure.
Taxpayers' money is used to build roads and schools, for example, or to finance social benefits.
If you are employed, you will receive the net amount of your salary from your employer, i.e. your taxes have already been deducted.
If you are self-employed, you are responsible for paying tax on your income.
Tax identification number
All employees receive a "tax identification number" at the start of their employment.
This tax ID is an 11-digit number and is used for income tax purposes.
It is valid for a lifetime.
Children born in Germany receive a letter with their personal tax ID within three months of birth, which is also required, for example, to apply for child benefit.
If you work in Germany, you will need the number again and again, for example for your employer.
If you do not know the number, you can ask for it in person at the registration office or in writing at the Federal Tax Office.
Tax return
In your annual tax return, you can claim various expenses from the tax office as tax-reducing.
This may result in either repayments in your favor or additional payments to the tax office.
Many people are required to submit a tax return, so it is best to ask the tax office whether this applies to you.
If you need help with your tax return, it is best to contact your local income tax association.
If you have further questions, the tax office can also help you.
Social security contributions
Social security contributions are the social security contributions that employees have to pay from their gross monthly salary in addition to taxes - this is mandatory by law and is automatically calculated by the employer.
Part of the social insurance is also paid by the employer.
Social security contributions finance the German social system.
If people cannot find work or are no longer able to work, the most basic living expenses can be secured in this way.
Ultimately, social security contributions serve the personal security of each and every individual - for example, if you become unemployed and have previously paid into unemployment insurance for a certain period of time, you are entitled to unemployment benefit I. Your monthly contribution to pension insurance also entitles you to a state pension in old age.
Social security contributions are made up of contributions for:
Pension insurance
Unemployment insurance
Health insurance
Long-term care insurance
The amount depends on the individual income.
The contributions are automatically deducted from your gross salary.
Exceptions for foreign employees apply, for example, if they have been posted to Germany by a foreign company, are employed or self-employed in several countries or are affected by other exemptions.
One of the requirements for a permanent residence permit is that you have paid pension insurance contributions for at least 60 months.
This also applies to self-employed persons.
There are also exceptions to this rule.
Social security number
German Pension Insurance will automatically send you your social security number by post when you take up your first job in Germany.
If you lose your number, you can ask to be notified again:
Telephone of the German Pension Insurance:
German Pension Insurance

context:
Women's shelters
Women's shelters - anonymous accommodation
There are several women's shelters in Munich for women affected by intimate partner violence.
There, the women and their children find protection from further violence.
They also receive advice and support to help them overcome the situation.
They can stay there for as long as they need protection and intensive specialist advice.
Who for: Women and their children who are looking for a safe place due to domestic violence
To ensure anonymity, the addresses of the women's shelters are not published.

question: What rights do parents have when raising their children?
context:
Protection of children and young people
Protection of children and young people
The care and upbringing of children is the natural right of parents.
However, children, young people and families in Germany are under special protection.
This protection begins during pregnancy and lasts until the child is 18 years old (of age).
In Germany, for example, it is forbidden to beat children and adolescents: education must do without the use of violence.
Every child must go to school.
There are authorities that ensure that a child is not harmed by its environment - which can also be its own family.
However, these authorities also advise, accompany and support families who need help.
This task is fulfilled in Munich by the social community centers.
You can ask for support there.
Which Sozialbürgerhaus is responsible for you depends on your home address.
Your responsible social center

question: Who usually carries out examinations on children?
context:
Visit to the doctor
Visit to the doctor
General practitioners and specialists
If you are ill, go to your family doctor.
You can choose these yourself.
GPs are usually open all day on Monday, Tuesday and Thursday.
The GP practice may be closed on Wednesday and Friday afternoons.
The GPs themselves determine the opening hours.
So make an appointment if you need help from a GP.
General practitioners carry out important examinations and are your first point of contact in the event of illness.
They also decide whether medication is required and whether a specialist examination is necessary.
If necessary, your family doctor will refer you to a specialist practice where special examinations can be carried out.
Pediatricians
Children are usually examined by pediatricians.
Regular check-ups and vaccinations are important for the health of every child.
The preventive medical check-ups that are required by law in Bavaria are called "U-examinations".
They take place at a specific time and are always free of charge.
Please ask a pediatrician about the U-examinations.
Gynecologists (gynecologists)
It is important that women are regularly examined by a gynecologist.
Diseases can be detected in good time during such preventive examinations.
You can also discuss the topic of contraception there.
Dentists
If you have a toothache, go to a dentist.
Information on health care via the health insurance fund
When you visit a doctor, present your health insurance card.
With this, most examinations are free of charge for you.
You must pay for certain preventive medical check-ups yourself.
You will have to pay part of the costs for therapies (e.g. physiotherapy) and aids (e.g. bandages) yourself.
People on low incomes can apply not to have to pay this personal contribution.
Ask your health insurance company.
The costs of dental treatment are covered by health insurance.
If a tooth needs to be renewed or replaced, you will have to pay for part of it yourself.
The costs for treatment in hospital are also covered by health insurance.
However, you must pay a daily hospital allowance of 10 euros for each day in hospital.
People on low incomes can also be exempt from this.
