question: When are the normal conditions for family reunification not applied?
context:
Family reunification
Family reunification
People who already have a residence permit and live permanently in Germany have the option of bringing spouses living abroad, partners in a registered civil partnership and their own underage children to join them.
The regulations and requirements that apply depend on which group of people you belong to:
Nationals of an EU Member State
Nationals of the European Economic Area (EEA states Iceland, Norway and Liechtenstein), Swiss nationals
Nationals of the following countries: Australia, Canada, Israel, Japan, United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, New Zealand, United States of America, Republic of Korea, Brazil, El Salvador
Third-country nationals
Persons who have applied for asylum in Germany and have been granted protection status:
Recognition as a person entitled to asylum pursuant to Art.
16a Basic Law (GG) (legal entitlement, attention: time limit, see below!)
Recognition of refugee status in accordance with the Geneva Refugee Convention pursuant to § 3 of the Asylum Act (AsylG) (legal entitlement, please note: deadline regulation, see below!)
Granting of subsidiary protection according to § 4 Asylum Act (AsyG) (legal entitlement, attention: deadline regulation, see below!)
Family reunification is excluded for people with a tolerated stay permit.
In principle, the following applies:
Both spouses must be at least 18 years old
the marriage or registered civil partnership must have already existed in the country of origin
All other requirements vary depending on the group of people.
We therefore recommend that you seek advice from a migration advice center (MBE) or the foreigners authority.
Deadline regulation
Important note: For persons who have been granted protection status in an asylum procedure (see list above), a deadline regulation applies: The normally applicable requirements, such as a secure livelihood and sufficient living space, are waived if the application for family reunification was submitted to the competent authorities (foreign mission in the country of residence of your family members and the Foreigners' Registration Office in Munich) within three months of incontestable recognition.
Further information on family reunification for persons with protection status can be found on the website of the
Foreign Office (German, English, Arabic) and the Munich city administration:
Residence permit according to § 25 Abs.
2 sentence 1, alternative 1 AufenthG and travel document
Residence permit according to § 25 Abs.
2 sentence 1, alternative 2 AufenthG
You can find more information on all other groups here.

context:

Who for: For people who are in the asylum process or have "tolerated stay" status.

question: For which age group is Opstapje suitable?
context:
Opstapje program - Play and learn
Opstapje program - Play and learn
Opstapje (Dutch for "springboard") is a play and learning program.
We support you in promoting the age-appropriate development of your child.
Once a week, our consultant visits you at home and brings play materials for your child: Books, balls, puzzles, pencils and much more.
Every two weeks there is a group meeting where we provide information on various topics relating to education and development.
You can also get to know other mothers and fathers.
Who for: All families with children aged 1 to 3 who would like support
Childcare is available during the group meetings.
The offer costs 10 euros per month.
Evangelical Family Education Center "Elly Heuss-Knapp"
The number of places is limited to 30 participants.

question: Who works in the health clubs?
context:
Health meetings
Health meetings
The health clubs are contact points for health issues in the district.
The health of children and young people is particularly important to us.
Our team consists of a doctor, a social pedagogue and health and pediatric nurses.
We also work together with midwives, hospitals and social institutions.
We will be happy to answer all your questions.
We help with the search for general practitioners and specialists and with making appointments.
We can advise you on possible support services and help you fill out applications.
The consultation is secret.
There are many different offers:
- Consultation hour with a doctor.
- We advise on nutrition, mental health and exercise.
- We advise on a medical diagnosis.
- We advise on medication and vaccinations.
- Health check: We can measure blood pressure and blood sugar, for example.
Or do a hearing test / eye test.
- Support during pregnancy and after the birth.
All offers are free of charge.
You do not have to have health insurance.
There are also interpreters.
You can bring your children with you.
There is a disabled toilet.

question: Where can you turn if you are threatened with losing your home?
context:
Help with the threat of losing your home
Help with the threat of losing your home
If you are threatened with losing your home due to termination, eviction proceedings or an eviction order, you can contact the specialist center for the prevention of homelessness.
It can be found in each of Munich's twelve social community centers.
The specialist center advises and supports you, intervenes and arranges further help.
It is important that you contact the specialist office as quickly as possible in order to meet any deadlines and avoid additional costs.
The specialist center for the prevention of homelessness advises on the following topics:
Assumption of rent arrears
Legality of the eviction action
Possible economic aid
Entitlement to housing benefit or other housing assistance
Personal assistance (debt counseling, socio-educational assistance)
You must bring these documents with you.
For advice from the specialist office, you will need to make an appointment with the caseworker at your local Sozialbürgerhaus.

question: What kind of schools offer vocational training?
context:
Professional development
Professional development
Further vocational training is possible at various vocational schools.
These include vocational schools (master craftsman schools, technical schools) and technical academies.
The offer is aimed at people who have already completed vocational training.
Further training usually takes the form of full-time teaching.
It offers the opportunity to gain further training and qualifications in a profession.
It is also possible to gain admission to a university of applied sciences or a university of applied sciences entrance qualification.
The dates and requirements for registration vary from school to school.
Information evenings are usually held at the schools every year before enrollment.
For more detailed information, please contact the school directly.
Learn more
If you have little money, you can check whether "" state support is possible.
If you need advice, please contact the Continuing Education Advisory Service:
bildungsberatung@muenchen.de
Website
The consultation is free of charge.

question: What offers are there in the BildungsLokalen?
context:
Offers in the BildungsLokalen
Offers in the BildungsLokalen
The offers are free of charge.
Educational counseling
The BildungsLokale centers provide advice on these and other topics:
Early childhood education, starting school, learning support, vacation offers, transition from school to work
Further education for adults, catching up on school-leaving qualifications, language courses, literacy courses, starting a career after a family break or immigration
Sports and leisure activities in the district
The educational counseling team also works with other services in the district such as schools, daycare centers, leisure centers, shelters and adult education facilities.
Who for: Anyone from the local area who has questions about education or needs support with transitions in the education system
You will find this offer at the following locations:"" Hasenbergl, "" Berg am Laim / Ramersdorf, "" Neuaubing / Westkreuz, "" Neuperlach, "" Riem, "" Schwanthalerhöhe.
Open learning workshop
The Open Learning Workshop is a cooperative project with the Munich Adult Education Center (MVHS).
You can learn to read, write, count and speak German here, at your own pace, without pressure, in a pleasant atmosphere.
The open learning workshop is an introduction to learning.
It prepares you for attending a course.
Who for: Adults from the local area who cannot read and write well, who have not been to school or have only been to school for a short time,
who want to learn German but cannot attend a course.
You will find this offer at the following locations: "" Hasenbergl, "" Berg am Laim / Ramersdorf, "" Neuaubing / Westkreuz, "" Neuperlach, "" Riem.
Language café
The language café is a service offered by the local educational advisory service.
Here you can practise speaking German in a relaxed atmosphere.
In addition to vocabulary, grammar and idioms, they also learn about life in Germany.
Speakers on important topics are invited from time to time.
There are also excursions in the district and into the city (for example to museums).
Who for: Adults from the local area who want to practise speaking German.
You will find this offer at the following locations: "" Berg am Laim / Ramersdorf, "" Neuaubing / Westkreuz, "" Neuperlach, "" Riem, "" Schwanthalerhöhe.

question: What do you get back if you move out of an apartment and have not left any damage behind?
context:
Rent an apartment
Rent an apartment
Rental agreement
The amount of rent is agreed in the rental contract.
If the tenant signs the contract, he/she also agrees to pay the rent.
The rent is made up of basic rent (basic amount), ancillary costs (refuse collection, operating costs) and heating costs.
The following points must be included in the rental agreement:
Name and address of the landlord/landlady
Address of the rental property
Living space in m²
Number of rooms
Amount of the net cold rent
Amount of operating costs
Amount of heating costs
Total rent
Amount of the deposit
The rental agreement specifies when the rent is to be paid.
If the rent is increasingly not paid on time, this can lead to termination of the tenancy agreement.
If you are unemployed and receive benefits from the Jobcenter, please refer to the "" "Benefits from the Jobcenter" under "Financial assistance for housing".
Security deposit
The deposit is a security for the landlord/landlady.
The maximum amount for the deposit is 3 basic rents (basic rent excluding ancillary and heating costs).
If you move out of the apartment, you will get the money back.
Important: You must not leave any damage behind when you move out of the apartment.
In the event of damage, the refund of the deposit will be reduced.

question: On what legal basis are refugees recognized?
context:
Forms of protection in the asylum procedure
Forms of protection in the asylum procedure
If you apply for asylum, you are applying for protection in Germany and will not be deported.
The law provides for various forms of protection.
They correspond to different forms of persecution in the country of origin.
In an asylum procedure, it is checked which form of protection can be granted to you based on your individual situation.
Below you will find a brief overview of the various forms of protection.
You will find more detailed information in German, English, Turkish, Russian, French and Arabic under the links provided.
Eligibility for asylum
According to Art.
16 A of the Basic Law (Grundgesetz - GG) of the Federal Republic of Germany grants asylum to politically persecuted persons.
This protection status can be granted to persons who, due to
their ethnicity
their nationality
their political convictions
their basic religious decisions or
their membership of a particular social group (for example, on the basis of sexual orientation)
will be exposed to state persecution and serious human rights violations in their country of origin if they were to return.
Learn more
Refugee protection
According to the Geneva Refugee Convention, people are considered refugees if they are affected by state or non-state persecution for one of the following reasons and are outside their country of origin:
Ethnicity
Religion
Nationality
political conviction
Belonging to a certain social group (for example due to sexual orientation)
Legal basis: § 3 para.
Asylum Act (AsylG)
Learn more
Subsidiary protection
People who are at risk of serious harm in their country of origin and who cannot claim protection in their country of origin are eligible for subsidiary protection.
The threat can come from both governmental and non-governmental sources.
These include:
Death penalty
Torture
inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment
serious individual threat to the life or integrity of a civilian as a result of indiscriminate violence in an international or internal armed conflict
Legal basis: § 4 para.
1A sylG
Learn more
National ban on deportation
A person seeking protection may not be deported if
repatriation constitutes a violation of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (ECHR) or
there is a considerable concrete danger to life, limb or freedom in the country of destination.
Legal basis: § 60 para.
5 AufenthG, § 60 para.
7 Residence Act
Learn more

question: What does the JiBB offer?
context:
JiBB - Young people in education and employment
JiBB - Young people in education and employment
The JiBB is Munich's extended youth employment agency.
Partners are the City of Munich, the District of Munich, the Munich Job Center and the Munich Employment Agency.
This makes the JiBB the central point of contact for all young people (usually up to the age of 25).
age) from the city or district of Munich.
The JiBB staff provide expert advice, guidance and support in all matters relating to work, training, careers, education and studies and can draw on many offers and voluntary services from partners and their specialist agencies.
We offer:
Help in the search for jobs and apprenticeships as well as comprehensive support in the application process
On
Bewerbungspoint will show you the best way to apply or check your documents together with you
Information on school qualifications and how to obtain them
Dropped out of training or studies - what can you do next?
Advice and support with private and social problems
Help with the transition between school and work
Advice for young people with health restrictions
We will clarify with you who is the right partner for your question and concern.
If you wish, various JiBB specialist departments can also work with you, for example to tackle complex problems together.
All offers are free of charge.
Have we aroused your interest?
Just drop by during opening hours or give us a call!
You don't need an appointment for the entrance area at JiBB!
Monday to Friday from 9 am to 12 pm
Monday and Tuesday additionally from 1 pm to 4 pm
Thursday additionally from 1 pm to 5 pm

question: Which residence permits allow you to live and work in Germany permanently?
context:
Permanent residence
Permanent residence
Settlement permit according to § 9 Residence Act
With a settlement permit, you can live and work in Germany without any time or place restrictions.
Prerequisites (selection):
Legal residence in Germany for at least five years (previous periods of study and training are credited at 50 percent)
valid residence permit that was not issued for a temporary purpose (studies) or for humanitarian reasons
Proof of secure livelihood and living space
Proof of sufficient pension provision (at least 60 months of compulsory or voluntary contributions to statutory pension insurance in Germany)
sufficient German language skills and basic knowledge of the legal and social system and living conditions in Germany - usually demonstrated by
successful participation in an integration course
or
through certificates and proof of study relating to vocational training completed in Germany or other language certificates
Further documents may be required in individual cases.
Further information on the requirements can be found here.
Permanent residence - EU
The EU permanent residence permit is an unlimited residence title and offers the same rights as the settlement permit.
With the permit, you can live and work in Germany without any time or place restrictions.
In addition, you can also live, work or study in the countries of the European Union (except Ireland, Denmark, Great Britain) (special regulations apply for individual countries).
Information on the requirements can be found here.
Whether a settlement permit or an EU permanent residence permit is more favorable for you depends on your individual circumstances.
The "" Foreigners' Registration Office.
will be happy to advise you.

question: What are the consequences if a household rents an apartment without the Jobcenter's consent?
context:
Benefits from the job center
Benefits from the job center
Who for: Households that receive financial support from the Jobcenter.
Rent and heating
The costs are covered if they are reasonable (§22 SGB II).
At the City of Munich, the following rules apply
Rent caps.
For households with seven or more people, the upper rent limit includes 15 m² and 270 euros per additional person.
The rent cap amounts refer to the gross rent.
A gross rent is made up as follows:
Net cold rent = basic rent without operating costs
plus
cold operating costs = for example, the costs for refuse collection, (cold) water, stairwell lighting, street cleaning and property tax
Heating and hot water costs are taken into account separately.
Your benefits officer will explain to you how to proceed in the event of unreasonable rental costs.
The "" Office for Housing and Migration of the City of Munich can advise you on all questions relating to housing in Munich.
If you are threatened with homelessness, we will work with you to find a
Social community center a solution.
Relocation
If you want to move, your case worker must check whether the move is necessary and the costs of the new home are reasonable before concluding the tenancy agreement.
The following evidence and documents are required for verification:
Written justification of the reason for the move (if necessary, appropriate evidence proving an important reason)
Unsigned tenancy agreement or an offer of accommodation showing all costs associated with renting the accommodation (e.g. basic rent, ancillary costs and heating costs, deposit).
An important reason exists, for example, if:
the move eliminates imminent or existing homelessness;
the move ends or avoids the need for assistance;
the move is necessary in order to take up or continue gainful employment subject to social insurance contributions at a greater distance (commute to work, depending on working hours, more than 2-2.5 hours total travel time).
Please note: If you rent an apartment without the consent of the Jobcenter, you may suffer financial disadvantages.

question: What kind of residence documents are there?
context:
Residence documents
Residence permit - flight / asylum
Every person who comes to Germany to apply for asylum receives a residence document.
It is often referred to as an "ID card".
The residence document provides information about the status in the asylum procedure and whether there are any restrictions on gainful employment (When am I allowed to work?).
There are five different documents:
1. proof of arrival
Status: Asylum seekers
Background: Issued to persons who have applied for asylum.
Valid for the period between registration as an asylum seeker or
asylum seeker and official application for asylum at the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF).
2. residence permit
Status: Asylum seekers
Background: Issued to carry out an asylum procedure until a decision is made on the asylum application.
The Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) decides on the asylum application.
If the application for asylum is rejected as unfounded, there is the option of lodging a complaint with the administrative court.
The stay is deemed to be permitted until the decision of the administrative court.
The permit for asylum seekers contains conditions regarding employment, residence and, if applicable, spatial restrictions.
If a work permit is required, this can be applied for at the responsible "" foreigners authority (by employer or employee)
Responsible for job placement: "" Employment Agency
Responsible for social benefits: "" Social welfare office
3. fictitious certificate
Status: Recognized refugees
Background: Certificate for the period from the positive decision on the asylum procedure until the residence permit is issued (fiction of permission) or for a phase of review or extension of documents (fiction of continued validity).
4. residence permit
Status: Recognized refugees
Background: positive decision on the asylum application
The residence permit is a temporary residence title.
It is issued for the purposes specified in the Residence Act.
There are various residence permits for refugees on humanitarian grounds.
Opens up the possibility of a later permanent right of residence (settlement permit)
Unrestricted access to the labor market
Responsibility for job placement and social benefits: "" Jobcenter
5. acquiescence
Status: Tolerated
Background: negative decision on the asylum application
A tolerated stay is a suspension of deportation.
It is issued temporarily if deportation is impossible for legal, factual, humanitarian or personal reasons.
General toleration regulation possible for certain groups by order of the highest state authority for a maximum period of 3 months ("deportation stop")
Work permit is generally required, application at the responsible "" foreigners authority (by employer or employee)
Responsible for job placement:"" Employment Agency
Responsible for social benefits: "" Social welfare office

context:

Information on churches and houses of worship
The religious and ideological composition of Munich is very diverse.

Around 9% of Munich residents belong to the Evangelical Lutheran Church.

question: Who is the guardian for a minor, unaccompanied refugee?
context:
What is the legal situation?
My stay in Germany - what is the legal situation?
At your final place of residence, you will be looked after by a person who will help you with all legal matters.
She is your guardian.
What does a guardian do?
If a refugee under the age of 18 comes to Germany unaccompanied, they need an adult to legally represent them instead of their parents.
This person is called a guardian.
The guardian has various tasks.
He or she:
maintains regular personal contact with you
represents your interests vis-à-vis the Youth Welfare Office, the Immigration Office and other authorities
accompanies you through the asylum procedure
applies for necessary help for you
supports you in clarifying other matters, for example on the subject of health
What will my new home look like?
At your new place of residence, you live in a house with other young people.
Adult caregivers are there for you around the clock.
You start school straight away.
It is important that you learn the German language so that you can make contact with your new people quickly.
What does compulsory education mean?
In Germany, schooling is compulsory until the age of 18.
This means that you go to school until you graduate or start an apprenticeship.
What educational opportunities do I have in Germany?
The type of school you go to depends on how old you are and how long you have attended school before.
After you graduate, your counselors will support you in finding a suitable job or apprenticeship, as far as current legislation allows
""Information about the German education system

question: What is recommended to prevent mold?
context:
House rules
House rules
Certain rules for living together are laid down in the house rules.
These apply to all persons living in shared accommodation or apartments.
The most important contents are
Noise: Everyone in the house is responsible for avoiding noise as much as possible.
You must be particularly considerate from 12:00 to 15:00 and from 22:00 to 07:00: This is quiet time.
Ventilation: You should open the windows regularly to let in fresh air.
This prevents mold from forming, for example.

question: What counts as an accident at work?
context:
Accident at work
Accident at work
If you have an accident during working hours or on the way to or from work, this is an accident at work.
In this case, you are covered by accident insurance through the company (employer).
Before seeking medical treatment, please be sure to inform us that it is an accident at work.
The treatment is then not paid for by the health insurance fund, but by the employer's accident insurance.
You can find out the name of the accident insurance company from your employer.
If you have an accident at work
are unable to work for more than one day or
require prolonged medical treatment or
fall ill again at a later date
you must consult a so-called transit doctor.
You can find transit physicians on the website of the
German Social Accident Insurance.

question: Are the costs for municipally organized daycare and a place in a crèche the same?
context:
General information about the daycare center
General information
Childcare for children in Munich daycare centers
Learn more
What is a daycare center?
Kita is a short word for day care center.
There are different forms of care:
Crèche: 9 weeks to 3 years of age
Kindergarten: 3 years to start school (6 or 7 years)
House for children: 9th week of life to 12 years (crèche, kindergarten and after-school care under one roof)
Parent-child initiative: Parents join forces and jointly organize a childcare facility.
The offers are available for all age groups.
After-school care: school children from 1st to 4th grade, care in the school or close to the school
Day care center: school children 1st to 4th grade, care at school, close cooperation with the school
Lunchtime supervision: school children 1st to 4th grade, supervision at school
Children with disabilities
Integration place in a daycare center
Integrative facility: care for children with and without disabilities
Curative daycare: from 3 years, only children with disabilities
What can my child experience at the daycare center?
The daycare center is usually open all day Monday to Friday.
There is a fixed daily routine (meal times, play times, rest times).
The child can make new friends.
The child can play and get to know and use many different toys and materials.
The child can play in the garden.
The child's development is supported by the teachers.
Child day care in families
This form of childcare is particularly suitable for children under the age of three.
Trained childminders look after up to five children at home in a family atmosphere.
If the caregiver falls ill, there is a substitute caregiver.
The costs for municipally organized day care are no higher than for a place in a crèche.
Learn more

question: What is a fictitious certificate?
context:
Residence with fictitious certificate
Departure with a fictitious certificate
With a fictitious certificate, you have a temporary right of residence.
There are different types of fictitious certificate.
Please note:
Re-entry into the federal territory is only possible with a fictitious certificate in accordance with § 81 para.
4 AufenthG possible.
It certifies a fictitious continued residence title and is also known as "fictitious continued validity".
If you apply for an extension of your residence permit, the previous one will be deemed to continue to exist due to the fictitious certificate.
Continued residence is legal with the same conditions as the expired residence permit.

question: How many votes does each voter have in the migration council election?
context:
How you can choose
How you can choose
In this election, you decide who gets a place on the Migration Advisory Council.
You have 40 votes.
The nominations (= lists) with the candidates for the migration council election are finalized at the end of January.
Ballot paper
On the ballot paper, all election proposals are sorted by initial letters from A to Z.
Each list has a number, a password and numbered candidates.
Each person's name, nationality and profession are listed.
Here you will find
all election proposals (lists) and one
Sample ballot.
You can also use a
Online trial ballot, test how the distribution of votes works.
Distribute votes
You have 40 votes.
If you distribute more votes, the ballot paper is invalid.
Here are four examples of how you can distribute the votes:
(1) Distribute votes freely
You can distribute your votes freely to the candidates on the entire ballot paper.
You tick all the people you want to vote for, regardless of which list they are on.
This is known as variegation.
You can also give special support to individuals and give them not just one vote, but two, but a maximum of three votes.
You can check the name multiple times.
Or you can write the number of votes (1, 2 or 3) in the box next to the name.
This is known as accumulation.
Please make sure that no one receives more than three votes from you.
(2) Select list
You can also select a complete list.
You only need to check the list once at the top of the password.
Your votes will then go to the candidates on this list in turn until all 40 votes have been distributed.
People who are listed three times get three votes.
People who are listed there twice receive two votes.
(3) Select list - with changes
If you select an entire list, you can still change something according to your wishes.
For example, you can delete one or more names from the list.
These people then do not get a vote.
You can also give special support to people on the list by giving them two or three votes.
(4) Select list and distribute additional votes freely
A mixed form is also possible: you can vote for a list (with or without changes) and also distribute votes freely.
This means that you can also tick people on other lists on the ballot paper and give them up to three votes.
The counting then proceeds as follows: On your ballot paper, all the votes you have given to individual persons are added up first.
What then of your
40 votes left will go to the list you ticked.
This means that all remaining votes go in turn to the persons on this list.
So no voice is lost.
All examples can also be found in the
Information sheet "How to vote".
Use the
Online sample order form to try out.
Test your vote.

question: Approximately how many inhabitants does Munich have?
context:
Interesting facts about the city
Interesting facts about the city
Munich is the capital of the federal state of Bavaria, which is officially called the "Free State of Bavaria".
With 1.56 million inhabitants, Munich is the third largest city in Germany.
Munich enjoys a worldwide reputation as a center of art, culture and science.
The city offers a lively nightlife and a very good public transport network.
The people of Munich particularly love their numerous green oases, such as the English Garden, the Isar floodplains and the parks of the castles, as well as the proximity to the Alps and the Upper Bavarian lakes.
Munich is economically very successful: a low unemployment rate and a broad spectrum of economic sectors make Munich attractive for many people who find exciting jobs in companies and research institutions or come to study at one of the renowned universities.
The name comes from "apud Munichen" - by the monks - because a Benedictine monastery first stood here.
The most famous member of the Bavarian royal family is undoubtedly fairytale King Ludwig II, who was born in Nymphenburg Palace, the summer residence of the Wittelsbach family in Munich.
Munich has numerous museums.
One of the oldest and best known is the
German Museum, which shows the history and future of technology.
The
BMW Welt and the BMW Museum attract visitors from all over the world.
Munich's history during the Nazi dictatorship is illuminated by the
NS Documentation Center as a central place of learning and remembrance.
In addition to the city's rich culture, the people of Munich love their sport.
Special occasions are often commemorated with a special lighting concept: for example, the arena is illuminated in the blue and yellow of the European flag on Europe Day, and on the Irish national holiday St.
Patrick's Day in bright green and to celebrate Christopher Street Day in the colors of the rainbow.
The Munich Oktoberfest - the largest folk festival in the world - is known worldwide and is visited by six million people every year.
Munich's famous beer can be enjoyed just as well, but more quietly, under chestnut trees in one of the many beer gardens.
These have a tradition of over 200 years in Munich and are considered the epitome of the Bavarian way of life.

question: Where do the U1 and U2 examinations usually take place?
context:
Special examinations for children
Special examinations for children
There are ten early detection examinations for children and adolescents (U1 to U9 and J1).
These examinations determine whether the child is healthy and developing well.
Parents are advised on topics such as vaccinations, nutrition or language and motor development.
The U1 (after birth) and U2 (3rd birthday).
to 10.
The first day of life) usually takes place in the maternity clinic.
You must make an appointment with your pediatrician for further examinations.
The early detection examinations U1 to U9, which extend from the first days of life to the age of 6, are mandatory in Bavaria.
When applying for certain benefits, when registering for nursery and kindergarten and when starting school, you may be asked for proof of complete early detection examinations.

context:

Blumenau girls' meeting place
We offer a safe and free space for anyone who identifies as female and is between the ages of 9 and 21.
We offer great leisure activities and organize excursions.
What you will find with us:
Meeting friends, dancing, playing sports and music, baking, cooking, creative activities, movie afternoons, parties, projects and much more.
It is also about discussing, helping to shape policy, implementing your own wishes and contributing your strengths.
It is important to talk about problems and find solutions together, to plan one's own future and to strive for an exchange on essential topics for girls* and young women* from Blumenau.
We are committed to equal rights for all genders, solidarity and diversity and oppose sexism, racism and other forms of discrimination.

question: What age group of children is Zu Hause Gesund Werden aimed at?
context:
Getting healthy at home - home care service for sick children
Getting healthy at home - home care service for sick children
Getting healthy at home helps parents who are unable to stay at home to care for their sick child themselves due to work demands.
For this purpose, we arrange a volunteer helper at short notice who will reliably look after and care for the sick child in the familiar parental home so that it can recover in peace.
Who for: The offer is aimed at parents who are employed or in training.
Admission requirements:
You live in Munich or in the district of Munich.
Your sick child is at least 6 months and at most 12 years old.
You are working or doing an apprenticeship.
They need care for a minimum of 3 and a maximum of 6 hours a day.
Each hour of childcare costs 6.50 euros.
In addition, there are MVG travel costs.
In the event of financial bottlenecks, we can finance the costs from donations.
Altheimer Eck 13

question: What does a visa holder have to do to leave and re-enter the Schengen area?
context:
Visitor visa (Schengen visa)
Visitor visa (Schengen visa)
Holders of a valid Schengen visa (text on the visa label: "valid for Schengen states" in the language of the issuing state) may stay in the entire Schengen area for a period of 180 days up to 90 days.
Learn more
Please note that you must leave the country within the period of validity of your visa.
This requires leaving the Schengen area.
A Schengen visa that has not been issued by the embassy for three months can be extended in Germany.
However, the requirements for this must still be met.
It is not possible to change the purpose of the visa.
The application must be justified;
in particular can
force majeure,
Humanitarian, professional or serious personal reasons
be taken into account.
If you do not have your visa extended by the "" Foreigners' Registration Office and only leave the country after your visa has expired, you are breaking the law.
The Foreigners' Registration Office will then check whether your stay must be terminated.
Re-entry would only be possible if there is no re-entry ban.
There may also be criminal proceedings in court.

Children born up to the age of 30

Registration information.
Parents of children born between July 1 and the 30th.

question: Where can I find the German literacy course?
context:
Literacy
Literacy
To be able to read and write German, you need to know the Latin alphabet.
These aids are useful for learning the Latin letters:
Serlo ABC
Serlo ABC is a free app for teenagers and young adults aged 15 to 30 that enables independent and intuitive learning of the Latin alphabet and teaches language skills at the same time.

question: On which reference framework are the language and integration courses based?
context:
Advice and placement in German courses
Advice and placement in German courses
If you live in Germany, it is important that you learn German.
Speaking German helps you in everyday life and in contact with other people.
The language is also very important if you want to work, start an apprenticeship or study.
There are different language levels that build on each other.
The "" levels according to the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages are used in the language and integration courses.
There is a wide range of German course programs and different types of courses.
They are open to different groups of people.
The following advice centers will help you find a course:
Asylum seekers / persons with tolerated status:
The "" refugee and integration advice centers in the accommodation facilities (FIB) support residents in registering for initial orientation German courses and refer them to offices that can arrange further courses.
All persons (regardless of residence status) aged 16 and over in the city of Munich:
The"" Integration Counseling Center IBZ - Language and Career can
Determine your language level
choose the right German course for you
Your professional goals are taken into account.
Your family situation is taken into account.
Only through the IBZ - Sprache und Beruf is it possible to attend German courses offered by the City of Munich.
These are also open to people who otherwise have no access to German courses.
Adult migrants aged 27 and over:
The"" Migration counseling for adults supports you
when registering for the integration course (IK)
in the search for a suitable course provider
Young migrants up to the age of 27:
The "" Youth Migration Service supports you
when registering for the integration course (IK)
in the search for a suitable course provider

question: What is the abbreviation for Unterhalts-Vorschuss-Gesetz?
context:
Apply for maintenance advance
Maintenance advance offices of the municipal youth welfare office
Are you bringing up your child alone?
Then the other parent has to pay money for the child.
This money is called maintenance.
Can the other parent not pay maintenance?
Can the other parent not pay maintenance every month?
Does the other parent not want to pay maintenance?
Then you can apply for an advance on maintenance payments.
This means that the youth welfare office pays the maintenance.
The other parent must later repay the advance maintenance payment to the youth welfare office.

question: Who can get a library card free of charge?
context:
Offer and registration
Offer and registration
Free WLAN, Internet workstations and workstations for individuals and groups are available at all locations.
Books, DVDs or music CDs in many languages can be borrowed for a certain period of time with a library card.
Information flyers on using the library are available in over 20 languages.
They are available in all city libraries or can be
can be downloaded here.
Who is it for: Anyone who lives, works or is studying in Munich and the surrounding area can get a library card.
You do not need a library card to visit the library, read on site or attend events.
The library card is free of charge for children and young people under the age of 18, asylum seekers and refugees.
Otherwise, the cost of the library card is
for one year 20 Euro
for one quarter 7 Euro
for one year reduced 10 Euro
for one quarter reduced 4 Euro
Young adults (18 and over) in training or studying, recipients of pensions, benefits and social assistance, the unemployed, volunteers and the severely disabled (degree of disability at least 50 percent) are entitled to a discount.
The following documents must be submitted with the application:
- Identity card OR passport with confirmation of registration from the residents' registration office
- Children under the age of 18: ID of a parent or legal guardian, who must also sign the registration form
- Asylum seekers: residence permit or tolerated stay permit, each valid for at least one month
- If the address of the accommodation is not stated in the document submitted, an official registration certificate for the address of the accommodation is required.
You can find the locations of the district libraries
here.
There you will also find all addresses, telephone numbers and e-mail addresses.
Opening hours of the district libraries:
Tuesday to Friday from 10.00 a.m. to 7.00 p.m.
Saturday from 10.00 to 15.00
The libraries in HP8 (Sendling), Motorama (Haidhausen) and the bibBox (Bogenhausen) have different, longer opening hours:
HP8:
Monday to Sunday from 7 a.m. to 11 p.m.
Service times:
Monday to Friday from 10.00 a.m. to 7.00 p.m.
Saturday from 10.00 to15.00
Motorama:
Monday to Saturday from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m.
Service times:
Monday to Friday from 10.00 a.m. to 7.00 p.m.
Saturday from 10.00 to 15.00
bibBox:
Monday to Sunday from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m.
www.muenchner-stadtbibliothek.de

question: How many weeks does the summer vacation last in Bavaria?
context:
School vacations and public holidays
School vacations and public holidays
School vacations
Summer vacation
The summer vacation period varies from state to state.
In Bavaria, they usually cover the whole of August and the first two weeks of September.
The duration of the vacation is six weeks.
Fall vacation
The fall vacations are around the All Saints' Day holiday (November 1) and usually last one week.
Christmas vacation
The two-week Christmas vacation usually includes Christmas Eve (24.12.) and the Three Kings holiday (6.1.).
Spring break
The one-week spring break begins on Shrove Monday.
Easter vacation
The Easter weekend is in the middle of the two-week Easter vacation.
Whitsun vacation
The Christian festival of Pentecost lies at the beginning of the two-week Pentecost vacation.
You can find out the exact dates of the upcoming school vacations from the
Bavarian State Ministry of Education and Cultural Affairs.
Public holidays in Bavaria
Public holidays are days when people don't go to work and stores and authorities are closed.
Some have a religious background, others a political one.
Some are always on the same day, others shift from year to year.
January 1 (New Year)
January 6 (Epiphany)
Good Friday
Easter Monday
May 1 (Labor Day)
Ascension Day
Whit Monday
Corpus Christi
15.
August (Assumption Day)
October 3 (Day of German Unity)
November 1 (All Saints' Day)
25.
and 26.
December (Christmas Day and Boxing Day)
Religious holidays of different religions
Jewish pupils are exempt from the obligation to attend lessons and other school events on the following days:
on the first two days and the last two days of Easter,
on both days of the weekly festival,
on the first two days and the last two days of the Feast of Tabernacles,
on both days of the New Year celebrations,
and on the Day of Atonement .
Muslim pupils are exempt from the obligation to attend lessons and other school events for the first two days of the religious festivals of Ramazan Bayrami and Kurban Bayrami.
Pupils of Orthodox denominations are exempt from the obligation to attend lessons and other school events on Good Friday, Holy Saturday, Easter Monday, Whit Monday, Christmas Day, the Feast of Theophany and Ascension Day.
The holidays can fall on different dates for the various Orthodox Christian churches.
Learn more

question: Who can work if they have a residence permit for family reunification?
context:
Spousal residence - independent right of residence
Spouse residence - independent right of residence
There are different regulations for foreign spouses or partners who move to Germany.
The decisive factor is whether the partner living in Germany has German citizenship or not.
After entering the country:
If you move to Munich, you must register at the Citizens' Registration Office as soon as possible (the law stipulates a period of 14 days).
You will receive a registration certificate there.
To register, you can come in person or have the completed and signed form delivered by a person authorized by you.
You need an appointment to visit the Citizens' Office.
You will receive a national visa (category D) for entry into Germany or other Schengen states.
For your future stay in Germany, you must apply for a residence permit at the "" Foreigners' Registration Office.
request.
Here you will find the necessary documents and requirements:
Family reunification with foreign nationals
Family reunification with Germans
Integration course
The Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) offers integration courses for foreigners who have a valid residence permit and speak little or no German.
In many cases, language skills are a prerequisite for a settlement permit.
The Immigration Office can oblige you to attend an integration course if you are not yet able to communicate in German and are applying for a residence permit for the first time:
for gainful employment (Sections 18a to 18d, 19c and 21 AufenthG),
on family reunification (Sections 28, 29, 30, 32, 36, 36a AufenthG),
for humanitarian reasons (§ 25 para.
1 and 2, 4a sentence 3 or 25b AufenthG),
for long-term residents in other member states of the European Union (§ 38a AufenthG)
Residence permit according to § 23 para.
2 or para.
4 Residence Act
Learn more
Access to the labor market
People who have a residence permit for family reunification are allowed to work.
The residence permit is also linked to the work permit.
They have unrestricted access to the German labor market and are allowed to work both as employed and self-employed persons.
Independent right of residence
If the marriage has existed for at least three years, foreign spouses who join their spouse living in Germany receive an independent right of residence.
For victims of violence
If the spouse/partner or the children are affected by violence by the spouse/partner and the marriage is therefore no longer reasonable, there may be an exception.
In certain cases, an independent right of residence can also be granted earlier.

question: How does the income affect the tax payment?
context:
Social justice
Social justice
The state must respect and protect human dignity.
It should therefore ensure the best possible social justice.
To this end, it takes legal, financial and material measures.
All people in Germany who earn money pay part of their wages to the state (taxes).
The higher the income, the more you have to pay.
If you earn a lot, you pay more tax.
The state should spend this money on the welfare of people living in Germany.
This means, for example:
All people registered in Germany are entitled to basic medical care.
This includes medical treatment in the event of illness and accidents.
All people who have a job subject to social insurance contributions pay contributions to health, long-term care and pension insurance.
Every adult must make an effort to earn their own living.
If someone is unable to do this, help can be obtained from the state.
The state ensures that taxes are also used to balance social justice and to help in emergency situations (for example for refugees).
The state supports parents financially, for example through child benefit.
This is not permitted in Germany, for example:
Tax fraud, for example paying less tax than required.
Receiving state benefits even though there is no entitlement to them.

question: What happens if you exceed the maximum permitted stay and have not applied for a residence permit?
context:
Stay without a visa
Residence without a visa (for third-country nationals from so-called privileged countries)
Citizens of certain countries may enter Switzerland without a visa.
Schengen territory.
Within a period of 180 days, the stay in Germany or in the Schengen area is limited to 90 days.
If you are planning multiple entries or longer stays, this must be taken into account and the date of departure must be set so that the maximum permitted length of stay is not exceeded.
List of countries without or
with visa requirement for Germany / Schengen area
Please note: After the maximum period of stay has expired, you must not only leave Germany, but also the Schengen area!
Citizens of so-called privileged countries - Australia, New Zealand, Israel, Japan, Canada, Republic of Korea, United States of America - can enter Germany without a visa.
If they want to stay here for longer than three months or want to work, they must apply for a residence permit at the "" Foreigners' Registration Office.
If it is not possible to leave the country within the time limit, the immigration authority must be contacted before the stay expires.
In particular
force majeure,
Humanitarian, professional or serious personal reasons
be taken into account.
If the visa-free stay is exceeded and you have not applied for a residence permit, the stay is not permitted (violation of the law).
The foreigners authority can terminate the stay.
Re-entry would only be possible again if there is no re-entry ban.
There may also be criminal proceedings in court.

question: How long does school education generally take?
context:
Vocational training at school
Vocational training at school
Full-time training at the vocational school
There are two types of training in Germany:
Dual system ("" Dual training)
The students learn both at the vocational school and in a training company.
School education at a vocational college
The pupils only attend school and learn everything there.
The school-based training usually lasts 1 - 3 years.
Depending on the school, there are different training courses and admission requirements.
You can obtain detailed information directly from the school.
School-based training is usually found in professions in the fields of technology, health and social services, art and foreign languages.
Learn more

question: Is female genital mutilation punishable in Germany?
context:
Female genital mutilation
Female genital mutilation
Sewing up, cutting or mutilating the female genitalia is a serious violation of human rights.
Affected girls and women suffer from the physical and psychological consequences for the rest of their lives.
Female genital mutilation is a punishable offense in Germany.
It is also punishable if female genital mutilation is carried out abroad.
Anyone who helps another person at home or abroad to carry out female genital mutilation or circumcision is also liable to prosecution.
You can find more information in the official letter of protection from the German government.
The cover letter is also available in the following languages:
Amharic, Arabic, Dari, English, Farsi, French, Indonesian, Kurmanji, Mandinka, Portuguese, Somali, Sorani, Swahili, Tigrinya, Urdu.
If you are concerned that you or someone you know may be at risk of female genital mutilation, you can contact the police, the youth welfare office or the helpline:
Police
Youth welfare office
Help hotline "Violence against women"
www.hilfetelefon.de
The helpline offers advice in 18 languages (including sign language) - 24 hours a day, free of charge and anonymously.
If you are abroad and need help, you can contact the nearest German diplomatic mission abroad:
German: https://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/de/ReiseUndSicherheit/deutsche-auslandsvertretungen
English: https://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/en/aussenpolitik/laenderinformationen

question: What is the focus of the Munich Job Center?
context:
Job center
Job center
The Jobcenter of the City of Munich is responsible for basic security for jobseekers (SGB II) with the following focal points:
Work and training
Support services and funding opportunities
Basic security benefits for jobseekers
Education and participation for children and young people
The Jobcenter of the City of Munich helps jobseekers and their families.
We will inform and advise you.
We support you in taking up and maintaining gainful employment.
You can receive financial assistance for living expenses (citizen's allowance, social benefit).
Further opportunities are available to you:
the assignment to the"" Integration language courses of the BAMF
Measures to determine professional aptitude
Placement in special measures for refugees
We advise and support you regardless of your nationality.
However, you must have a permanent residence permit and be allowed to work in Germany.
The Jobcenter is not responsible for people with a residence permit or tolerated stay permit.
These people can contact the IBZ - Sprache und Beruf.
Benefits according to SGB II
If you have not yet worked in Germany or have worked for less than a year and are now unemployed, you are generally entitled to benefits under SGB II.
You receive these benefits through the Jobcenter.
The services include:
Citizen's income
Costs for accommodation and heating
Counseling, placement and integration services
Basic income support for jobseekers is intended to strengthen the personal responsibility of those entitled to benefits who are capable of work and those who live with them in a community of need (e.g. a family or civil partnership).
It is intended to help you earn a living from your own means and resources independently of the basic income support and to support you in taking up or maintaining gainful employment.
On the homepage of the Munich Jobcenter you will find a summary of the main support services designed to improve the chances of finding work and enable progress towards integration.
Please discuss your request with your responsible employment agency.
You can find the contact options
here.
Contact us
You will find the Jobcenter in each of Munich's twelve Sozialbürgerhäuser (SBH).
Which one is responsible for you depends on your home address.
Find your local Sozialbürgerhaus
If you are homeless, please contact the Jobcenter Zentrum für Wohnen und Integration (ZWI) at Franziskanerstraße 6-8.

question: When is private liability insurance required by law?
context:
Insurances
Liability insurance
If you cause damage to a person in Germany, the law states that you must pay for the damage, even if you did not cause the damage intentionally.
This applies to personal injury, property damage and financial losses in the private sector.
For example, if you cause a traffic accident or if your child breaks a window pane with a ball.
You can take out personal liability insurance to pay for such damage for you and your family.
It is not compulsory to have this insurance, but it is highly recommended, as otherwise you may be faced with very high costs in the event of a claim.
The migration advice centers can help you find a good offer for private liability insurance.
Learn more
Information on liability insurance in German, Arabic, English, French, Dari/Farsi can be found here.

question: What happens if you cause damage without insurance?
context:

This applies to personal injury, property damage and financial losses in the private sector.
For example, if you cause a traffic accident or if your child breaks a window pane with a ball.
You can take out personal liability insurance to pay for such damage for you and your family.
It is not compulsory to have this insurance, but it is highly recommended, as otherwise you may be faced with very high costs in the event of a claim.
The migration advice centers can help you find a good offer for private liability insurance.
Learn more
Information on liability insurance in German, Arabic, English, French, Dari/Farsi can be found here.

question: Who can offer support if you want to take legal action against the rejection?
context:
5. decision of the BAMF
Decision on the asylum application
After the personal interview, the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees checks all descriptions, information and evidence.
It is checked whether one of the four "" forms of protection exists on the basis of the Asylum Act:
Eligibility for asylum
Refugee protection
subsidiary protection
Ban on deportation
The asylum application will only be rejected if none of these forms of protection can be granted.
The decision will be justified in writing and sent as a "notification" to
the applicant, or
to persons who have been authorized in these proceedings (lawyers).
the responsible foreigners authority
The decision is negative
If your application for asylum is rejected, you will receive a negative decision together with a threat of deportation: you will be asked to leave the Federal Republic of Germany by a certain date.
Otherwise there is a risk of forced deportation.
There are two different types of rejection:
simple refusal: you must leave the country within 30 days.
Rejection as "manifestly unfounded": In this case, the deadline for leaving the country is only one week.
Contestation
If you do not agree with the negative decision, you can take legal action against the decision in both cases.
This must be done very quickly after receipt of the decision.
You should therefore go immediately to the integration and refugee advice center in your accommodation.
You will receive support there.
You should always seek advice and representation from a specialist lawyer for asylum and residence law if you wish to take legal action.
You will be informed of all deadlines and legal options in the written notification: This information is referred to as "information on legal remedies".
Voluntary departure
If you decide to leave voluntarily, you can receive financial support for a new start in your country of origin.
The Office for Return Assistance can advise you on this.
Office for Return Assistance Munich
You should inform the Foreigners' Registration Office as soon as possible that you wish to leave the country voluntarily.
The decision is positive
They are recognized as entitled to protection.
The next steps are:
Fictitious certificate or
electronic residence permit (eAT):Immediately after the positive BAMF decision has been delivered, you must apply for an identity document or residence permit.
take care of an equivalent.
You can obtain this from the "" Foreigners' Registration Office.
They are now allowed to work in Germany without restriction.
If you do not have a job and are dependent on support, you will no longer receive your money from the social welfare office, but must submit an application to the "" Jobcenter.

question: What is taught in the Arabic Saturday School?
context:
Arabic Saturday School
Arabic Saturday School
Our Saturday school is for children aged 6 to 12 whose mother tongue is Arabic but who are not yet proficient in reading and writing.
The children are taught by Arabic teachers.
In three classes, divided according to age and level of knowledge, reading and writing are taught in a playful way through fairy tales and songs, local history and Arabic history.
The aim is for the children to have a good command of their mother tongue, as this makes it easier for them to learn German.
Lessons take place weekly (except during school vacations).
Registration by e-mail:
pateninitiative@gmail.com (please state telephone number, address, first name and age of the children).
Arabic-speaking teachers will then contact you.
Parallel to the children's lessons, parents can take part in a German conversation course with German volunteers.
The lessons are free of charge.
Textbooks and writing materials are also free of charge.
Food and drink during the break costs 10 euros per child per month (15 euros for 2 children, 20 euros for 3 or more children).
Learn more
Bellevue di Monaco e. V.
Müllerstrasse 2 + 6

question: Is there homework for all-day schooling?
context:
All-day programs at schools
All-day programs at schools
There are several forms of all-day teaching at Munich schools:
In the tied all-day program, the class lessons are spread over the whole day.
Learning, practicing, sports, music and art alternate.
The children eat lunch together.
There is no homework.
In the open all-day program, sports, music and art only take place after school.
The groups are made up of children from different classes.
With cooperative all-day education, the elementary school offers childcare on school days and during the vacations until 18:00.
The children are supervised by teachers.
They have lunch together.
It is also possible to attend elementary school in the morning and after-school care ("Hort") in the afternoon.
Learn more

question: Who can attend free integration courses?
context:
Integration course program
Integration course program
In the general integration course, you will learn German up to language level B1 in 600 lessons.
In 100 additional lessons you will gain an insight into the culture, politics and social customs in Germany.
There are also special forms of integration courses, some of which comprise more or fewer teaching units.
The integration courses are free of charge for refugees and other target groups who receive social benefits.
You may attend an integration course,
if you come from an EU country or are an ethnic German repatriate or
are ethnic German immigrants.
if you have a residence permit and come from Syria or Eritrea
if you have a Duldung acc.
§ Section 60 a para.
2 sentence 3 AufenthG (regardless of country of origin)
if you have a residence permit (regardless of your country of origin)
You can be obliged to take part in an integration course by the job center, the social welfare office or the foreigners authority.
If you are not obliged to attend an integration course but would like to do so, you can apply for the course at the BAMF.
If you need assistance with the application, please contact your ""Refugee and integration counseling or
to a ""migration counseling service.
They will also help you choose an integration course provider.
You can decide for yourself which language school in Munich you would like to take the integration course at.
People who do not have access to this service can contact the "" Integration Advice Center IBZ Sprache und Beruf.
There is a supplementary German course on offer there.

question: Where are asylum seekers sent back to if Germany is not responsible?
context:
3. the Dublin procedure
Dublin procedure
The Dublin procedure covers the territory of the 28 EU member states as well as Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Switzerland.
It determines which state is responsible for carrying out your asylum procedure.
As a rule, it is the country in which you were first registered.
An electronic data comparison is carried out for this purpose.
If it has been determined that Germany is not responsible for carrying out your asylum procedure, you will be sent back to the country responsible for you.
If you do not agree with this decision, you should seek professional legal advice on whether it makes sense to file a complaint with the administrative court.
Further information on the Dublin Agreement in German and English

question: What are the two types of training in Germany?
context:
Dual education
Dual education
In Germany, it is a great advantage if you have a vocational qualification.
People with a vocational qualification earn more money over the course of their lives, are less likely to become unemployed and are less likely to have fixed-term employment contracts than people who are looking for work without a vocational qualification.
There are two types of training in Germany:
School-based training at a vocational college ("" School-based training)
The pupils only attend school and learn everything there.
Dual system
The students learn both at vocational school (around one third of the time) and in a training company (around two thirds of the time).
This allows you to learn theory and practice at the same time.
During the apprenticeship you earn a fixed monthly salary.
This video clearly explains dual training: Dual training.
Click here for the video on
Arabic,
Dari,
Tigrinya,
Ukrainian.
Click here for the
Video in sign language.
Dual training is mostly found in commercial professions and industrial-technical professions.
Depending on the type of profession you want to learn, you should contact the right place:
Chamber of Crafts for Munich and Upper Bavaria (HWK)
The HWK is responsible for skilled trades such as bakers, bricklayers, painters and hairdressers.
It provides support in the search for an apprenticeship or an introductory qualification, which can precede an apprenticeship.
There is a special offer for young people with a migration background who would like to start a craft apprenticeship.
Further information can be found here.

The IHK integration team supports refugees and migrants before, during and after their training.
The team advises on all questions relating to training: for example, challenges at vocational school or in the company, exam preparation, rights and obligations during training.
The one-to-one meetings take place online and are free of charge.

question: How many trade unions are there in Germany?
context:
Works council and trade unions
Works council and trade unions
In Germany, employees have the right to have a say at work, in the company and in the economy as a whole and to defend their interests.
Works Council
Above a certain company size, the law provides for employee representation in the form of a works council (in the public sector: staff council).
A works council represents the interests of employees in a company and has co-determination rights.
In accordance with legal requirements, it is elected by the employees.
Trade unions
Trade unions bring together employees to represent and assert their economic and social interests against employers.
There are eight different trade unions in Germany, covering all professional sectors.
They advise their members on labor and social law issues, negotiate collective agreements and support works councils.
German Trade Union Confederation Munich
The German Trade Union Confederation is the umbrella organization of all German trade unions.
We will be happy to tell you which trade union is responsible for you.
Find out more about trade union membership
Who for: Employees, trainees, students and pensioners

question: How many people with foreign citizenship live in Munich?
context:
What is the Migration Advisory Board?
What is the Migration Advisory Board?
Around 446,000 people with foreign citizenship currently live in Munich;
In addition, there are around 268,000 German nationals with a migration background.
Together, that is 46 percent of the total population.
The Migration Advisory Board represents the interests of Munich residents with a history of migration:
he will be on 19.
It then consists of 40 directly elected and 10 appointed honorary members with voting rights, as well as other advisory members
It has an annual subsidy budget of around 160,000 euros for integration projects
How does the Migration Advisory Board work?
The Board is involved in plenary meetings, commissions, working groups and standing committees:
Anti-discrimination and anti-racism
Education and training
Child and youth welfare policy
Labor and social issues
Women's affairs
Sport and leisure
Culture and intercultural dialog
Migration policy and international understanding
Policy for refugees and migration law
Organization of specialist days, office hours and festivals
Local politics for Munich residents without a German passport
The Migration Advisory Board makes recommendations and submits proposals to the City Council and the city administration
organizes political discussion events, for example on integration policy in Bavaria, the recognition of qualifications acquired abroad or unemployment among migrants
campaigns for local voting rights for all
Against racism, discrimination and for integration
Together with the City of Munich and the Lichterkette e.V. association, the Migration Advisory Council awards the annual "Münchner Lichtblicke" prize for tolerance and civil courage
supports the concerns of refugees
is involved in joint alliances against racism and discrimination, including "Munich is colorful"
is a jury member of the Mosaik Youth Prize - With diversity against racism
organizes the annual rally on 21.
March (International Day against Racism) in cooperation with AGABY and Netzwerk Rassismus- und Diskriminierungsfreies Bayern e.V.
is actively involved in AGABY (umbrella organization of municipal integration councils in Bavaria), the Bavarian Integration Council and the Federal Immigration and Integration Council
Bridge between city administration, politics, clubs, associations and citizens
In cooperation with the City of Munich, the Migration Advisory Council organizes events such as the Festival of Cultures and the AnderArt Festival.
The committee also organizes memorial events for victims of racist and misanthropic violence
supports around 100 to 120 integration projects every year
maintains contact with associations and organizations from the migrant communities
is the contact point for all questions concerning migrants in Munich

question: What is a Sprengelschule?
context:
Compulsory schooling and school districts
Compulsory schooling and school districts
Compulsory schooling
School attendance is compulsory in Germany: all children between the ages of 6 and 15 have to go to school.
Thereafter, the following applies in Bavaria until the age of 21
Vocational school attendance is compulsory from the age of 18 if attendance at a general school is not continued.
Compulsory vocational schooling does not apply if the school was completed with the Abitur or Fachabitur.
Parents ensure that their children attend school regularly.
Attending public (state and municipal) schools costs nothing.
If a child is ill, parents must call the school before 08:00 in the morning.
School district
If the child attends a public primary or secondary school, it must go to the school that is responsible for its place of residence - a Sprengelschule.
"Sprengel" means "school district".

question: Who can use TranslAid's interpreting services?
context:

Interpreters and interpreters
If you do not yet speak German well and go to the authorities, such as the immigration office, the social welfare office or the education authority, you will need an interpreter.
But an interpreter is also very helpful for visits to the doctor or at parents' evenings at school and kindergarten.
Some authorities and institutions have interpreters themselves and can use them in consultations.
When making an appointment, please always ask whether an interpreter will be provided free of charge.
TranslAid
TranslAid places volunteer (non-professional) interpreters with refugees and migrants in Munich.
The interpreters accompany people to consultations and appointments (e.g. doctor's appointments, appointments with authorities, asylum and legal proceedings, youth welfare and registry office, etc.) and translate documents that may not be translated by sworn translators.
In the following languages: Amharic, Arabic, Aramaic, Bengali, Bulgarian, Chinese, Dari, English, Farsi, French, Fula, Georgian, Greek, Hindi, Italian, Jula, Krio, Kurdish (Kurmanji), Kurdish (Sorani), Lao, Mandingo, Pashto, Polish, Portuguese, Punjabi, Romanian, Russian, Slovakian, Somali, Spanish, Susu, Swahili, Tigrinya, Tigre, Czech, Turkmen, Turkish, Uyghur, Ukrainian, Hungarian, Urdu, Uzbek, Wolof.
Learn more
Who for: All refugees and migrants who have appointments in the S-Bahn area of the city of Munich.
Important: Requests must be made at least 48 hours in advance on working days in order to be accepted.

question: What topics are covered in the initial orientation courses?
context:
German courses for initial orientation
German courses for initial orientation
The German courses for initial language orientation (also known as initial orientation courses) teach both basic German language skills and information about life in Germany.
They are a practical starting aid in the new living environment and make everyday life easier.
A course comprises 300 teaching units of 45 minutes each and covers topics such as "Health/medical care", "Work", "Kindergarten/school", "Housing", "Local orientation/transport/mobility".
The focus is on oral communication: participants should learn as quickly as possible to find their way around in everyday life.
Across all modules, initial orientation courses are also about teaching values.
Initial orientation courses are primarily intended for asylum seekers with unclear prospects of remaining in Germany.
However, if there are free places, recognized asylum seekers, tolerated persons and asylum seekers with good prospects of staying may also take part.
Anyone who is still required to attend school (6 to 15 years) or vocational school (16 to 21 years) does not attend the initial orientation course, but attends school or a school-based measure.
If you gain access to an "" integration course during your participation in the initial orientation course, you can switch to this course.
The people on the courses have very different backgrounds.
Illiterate people as well as academics can attend the courses.
Initial orientation courses are free of charge.
The course language is German - interpreters are not present during the course.
Contact a "" migration advice center or your local "" refugee and integration advice center in your accommodation.
They will help you to find a suitable course.
Learn more
People who do not have access to this service can contact the "" Integration Advice Center IBZ Sprache und Beruf.
There is a supplementary German course on offer there.

question: What happens if you sign a contract that you don't understand?
context:
Contracts
Contracts
Contracts in Germany
In Germany, freedom of contract applies.
For example, if you want to use a smartphone, rent an apartment or work out at a gym, you must conclude a contract either verbally or in writing.
Be sure to pay attention to the content of a contract: How is the total price made up?
Are there any other monthly costs in addition to a one-off payment?
Contracts are binding and must be complied with.
They can only be terminated within the applicable notice period.
If you are not sure whether you can pay the costs or whether you have really understood everything correctly, do not conclude a contract, otherwise you may be liable to prosecution.
Do not sign anything that you cannot understand or read.
It is possible that you conclude a contract or agreement with your signature.
This may result in costs for you.
Once a contract has been signed, it is very difficult to undo it.
Always compare different offers and don't let yourself be pressured into signing a contract.

question: What does Article 3 of the Basic Law say?
context:
Equal rights for women and men
Equal rights for women and men
Women and men have the same rights in Germany.
This is enshrined in Article 3 of the Basic Law.
Women can learn German, go to the doctor, learn a profession and look for a job.
You do not need permission from your husband or other family members.
Women can marry whoever they want and also separate or divorce if the relationship is not working or if the partner is violent.
You can be in a relationship with a man or a woman or live alone.
When couples separate, the children can live with the mother, with the father or partly with the mother and partly with the father.
If the parents cannot agree on where the children should live, the court decides what is best for the children.
Despite equal rights, women are sometimes disadvantaged at work, in everyday life or in the family.
There are various counseling centers for women.
There you can find out about your rights and get help so that you can lead an independent and equal life.
You can find more information on the topic of equal rights here:
Handbook "Women in Munich", published by the Equal Opportunities Office for Women of the City of Munich;
comprehensive publication with many useful addresses and offers.
Federal Ministry for Family Affairs, Senior Citizens, Women and Youth
Video on the subject of "Equal rights for men and women" in many languages on the website of the Bavarian Ministry of Justice.
The site also contains other short films on the most important aspects of the German legal system.
Information flyer from Terre des Femmes in German, English, Arabic, Albanian, Serbian, Pashto, Farsi, Urdu, French, Swahili;
Here you can find the flyer in Bulgarian, Kurmanji, Romanian, Russian, Somali and Turkish.

question: Where can I find information on the requirements for acquiring German citizenship?
context:
Naturalization
Naturalization
If you have been living legally and habitually in Germany for at least eight years, you can apply for naturalization.
Spouses and children can also be naturalized, even if they have lived in Germany for a shorter period of time.
Young people aged 16 and over can apply for naturalization themselves.
Different requirements apply to certain groups of persons (e.g. persons entitled to asylum, spouses of Germans) (e.g. shorter minimum residence periods).
Information on the different requirements for acquiring German citizenship can be found
here.
The Naturalization Office of the City of Munich offers advice on the subject of naturalization.
You can make an appointment here.
