question: What is a working student job?
context:
Financing your studies
Financing your studies
Many students work alongside their studies.
It is important that you do not neglect your studies as a result.
It is regulated by the state that you are not allowed to work more than 20 hours a week during the lecture period.
If you exceed this number of hours, you may be excluded from the university.
You must also note that there is a maximum number of semesters until you complete your Bachelor's or Master's degree, which you may not exceed.
First of all, you should check whether you can get state support.
Examples of this are the "" Federal Training Assistance Act (BAföG) and"" housing benefit.
BAföG is intended to help students who cannot be financially supported by their parents.
You receive a monthly sum of money (over a fixed period), the amount of which depends on your personal circumstances.
Not every student can claim BAföG.
The responsible BAföG office must examine each application individually.
As a rule, only full-time study is funded.
In addition, you must not be older than 30 for a Bachelor's degree course and not older than 35 for a Master's degree course.
Information in plain language can be found at the Federal Ministry of Education and Research.
There are numerous scholarships for which you can apply.
You can get an overview from the Scholarship Guide and on the Deutschlandstipendium website as well as from the Bildungsberatung Garantiefonds Hochschule in Munich.
In many degree programs, you can become a working student in the first semester, but also later.
You are then employed by a company.
You can gain your first experience there and earn money on the side.
The companies usually offer contracts for ten to twenty hours per week.
Another advantage is that working students with good grades are often taken on as employees after graduation.
Find out from companies in your area whether they offer jobs for working students.
SHK means "student assistant".
These are advertised positions at universities.
Many of them can be found on the notice boards or you can ask the university in person.
As a SHK, you work a fixed hourly rate per week (maximum 20 hours).
This involves carrying out tasks for a lecturer, a department or a university organization.
Mini job on a 520-euro basis
Many students work part-time in the catering industry (for example as bartenders or waiters), give tutoring or help with childcare.
There are always many job advertisements on the university notice boards.
Most students work in a mini-job (€520 basis).
The advantage is that you are considered to be in low employment and do not have to pay taxes or social security contributions (unemployment insurance, health insurance and long-term care insurance).
A mini-job is usually easy to combine with your studies.
Further information can be found at the
Minijob center.

question: Where can used items be recycled?
context:
Waste disposal and recycling
Waste disposal and recycling
Waste disposal in Munich
In the city of Munich, waste is separated using the "3 garbage can system".
On the one hand, the aim is to better manage the huge quantities of waste generated in the city;
On the other hand, it is also about better recycling of materials from waste in terms of sustainability.
Here you can see how the 3-bin system works and what belongs in the different garbage cans:
Residual waste in the black garbage can
Waste that cannot be recycled is placed in the black garbage can:
Diapers, sanitary towels and tampons
Paper handkerchiefs, cosmetic tissues, paper towels
Plastic bin liners
Vacuum cleaner bag
coated paper
Wallpaper, carpeting remnants
Sweepings, ashes, small animal litter, cigarette butts
Paper in the blue garbage can
The blue garbage can is for paper waste, which must be clean and uncoated:
Newspapers and magazines
Cardboard boxes (please fold or
crush)
Catalogs and brochures
Exercise books
Books
Forms and printer paper
Letters and envelopes
Paper bags
Paper packaging
Cigarette packets (without aluminum and without foil)
Boxes of chocolates (without plastic)
Organic waste in the brown garbage can
Compostable waste goes in the brown garbage can:
Kitchen waste (including meat and fish scraps)
Fruit and vegetable leftovers
Salad (without salad dressing)
Potato peelings, eggshells
Coffee filter bags, tea bags
Wilted bouquets
Potted plants (without pot)
Garden waste
Crumpled newspaper to soak up moisture
Glass, metal cans and plastic packaging in the recycling containers
Recycling islands.
Bulky waste, broken electrical appliances and hazardous waste to the recycling center
The recyclable material must:
Waste that doesn't fit in the garbage can
all broken electrical appliances
Hazardous substances such as old batteries, energy-saving light bulbs or chemicals
The transfer to the
12 recycling centers is free of charge (2 m³/day).
Used items in good condition
can be bought and sold in second-hand stores or at flea markets.

question: Who cannot receive housing benefit?
context:
Housing benefit
Housing benefit
The state also helps citizens with low incomes who do not receive benefits from the Jobcenter.
For example, tenants and subtenants of an apartment or residents of a care home can receive a rent subsidy.
Anyone who owns a house, an apartment or an agricultural sideline can also apply for housing benefit.
Prerequisites
The entitlement to housing benefit and the amount depend on three factors:
the number of household members
the amount of the total income
the amount of the rent or the monthly charge
In addition to the person receiving housing benefit, other household members can also be taken into account, for example spouses, life partners, children, parents or siblings.
If you already receive support for housing costs (e.g. with Citizen's Allowance) With Citizen's Allowance and basic income support in old age or reduced earning capacity, you already receive support for housing costs.
Then you cannot receive additional housing benefit.
People who receive benefits under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act are also not eligible for housing benefit.
Application and supporting documents
To receive housing benefit, you must submit an application and various supporting documents:
the annual income of all household members and the pension
the rent or the costs.
The costs include certain expenses for repayment and interest as well as for maintenance or administrative costs.
You can obtain more detailed information and application forms from our information desk or
here.
City of Munich
Social department
Approval office for housing benefit
Werinherstrasse 87
Infothek:
Monday 08:30 - 12:00
Wednesday 08:30 - 12:00 and 15:00 - 17:00
Friday 08:30 - 12:00
Issue of queue numbers: until 11:30 (until 11:00 if there is a large number of customers);
on Wednesday afternoon until 16:30
You can send your application with the supporting documents by post to the following address:
City of Munich
Social department
Approval office for housing benefit
Werinherstrasse 89

question: What topics does "Offene Hilfe" advise on?
context:
Open Help" advice center
Open Help" advice center
Offene Hilfe" is an advice center for women in difficult life situations, e.g. who are homeless or fear losing their home.
The consultation can take place by telephone or in person.
We can advise you on the following topics:
on the subject of "housing" and/or "loss of housing"
for financial problems (securing legal entitlements to financial benefits, support with problems with authorities)
In the event of personal crises (family difficulties, violence)
Referral to other counseling centers (debtor counseling, migration counseling, women's shelters, etc.)
Advice on trust accounts for women who are not allowed to have their own account
We also offer various group activities.
Please make an appointment.
Who for: Women with and without children
The consultation is free of charge.
Children can be brought along.
There is barrier-free access to the building and the rooms.
There is a disabled toilet.
Dachauer Str.
offene-hilfe@skf-muenchen.de
Monday to Thursday 08:00 - 17:00
Friday 08:00 - 13:00 and by arrangement
https://www.skf-muenchen.de/unser-angebot/wohnungslose-frauen/offene-hilfe.html
Counseling, counseling center, housing, homeless assistance, homeless, crisis, financial problems, account

question: In which languages is the brochure "Working in Munich" available?
context:
Munich Employment and Qualification Program (MBQ)
Munich Employment and Qualification Program (MBQ)
The MBQ supports people who have difficulty accessing the Munich labor market.
Employment opportunities in social enterprises, counseling and qualification offers promote (re-)entry into working life.
The MBQ offers refugees, migrants and newcomers a wide range of free services.
The individual support offers are selected individually with you by the "" Jobcenter or the "" IBZ Sprache und Beruf.
Here you can find the integration map
"SUCCESSFUL JOB INTEGRATION MUNICH".
Who for: Long-term unemployed people, people with a migration background, refugees, single parents, people returning to work, the self-employed, highly qualified people, international students, skilled workers, young people under 25 and many more on their way (back) into employment.
The MBQ is financed by the City of Munich.
It complements the services offered by the job center.
The Department of Labor and Economic Affairs and the Department of Social Affairs implement the program.
All projects with detailed project descriptions can be found at
www.mbq-projekte.de
Are you new to Munich and looking for work?
In the brochure
"Working in Munich" you will find useful information about working and living in Munich.
It is aimed at people who have come to Munich from other EU countries, have limited language skills and are looking for work.
The brochure is available in Bulgarian, German, English, Romanian and Ukrainian.

question: Which court is the Administrative Court of Munich subject to?
context:
Munich Administrative Court
Administrative Court (VG) Munich
The Munich Administrative Court is subordinate to the Bavarian Administrative Court.
It is responsible for the administrative district of Upper Bavaria.
If an application for asylum is rejected by the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees, an appeal can usually be lodged with the Administrative Court in Munich.
The court reviews the decision of the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees.
If it comes to a different decision, it may oblige the Federal Office to grant protection to the applicant or the claimant.
If it confirms the negative decision, the claim will be dismissed.
If you wish to take legal action, you should be represented by a specialist lawyer for asylum and residence law.
Munich Administrative Court
Bayerstraße 30
Poststelle@vg-m.bayern.de
Postal address:
P.O. Box 20 05 43

question: What happens if the court confirms the negative decision?
context:
Munich Administrative Court
Administrative Court (VG) Munich
The Munich Administrative Court is subordinate to the Bavarian Administrative Court.
It is responsible for the administrative district of Upper Bavaria.
If an application for asylum is rejected by the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees, an appeal can usually be lodged with the Administrative Court in Munich.
The court reviews the decision of the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees.
If it comes to a different decision, it may oblige the Federal Office to grant protection to the applicant or the claimant.
If it confirms the negative decision, the claim will be dismissed.
If you wish to take legal action, you should be represented by a specialist lawyer for asylum and residence law.

question: Where do I have to register if I arrive in Germany and want to apply for asylum?
context:
1st registration
Registration
If you arrive in Germany and wish to apply for asylum, you must register with one of the following government agencies immediately after your arrival:
Border authority
Police
Immigration office
Reception center for refugees or
Branch office of the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF)
Your personal data is registered and stored centrally.
It is checked whether
you are applying for asylum in Germany for the first time
you have already applied for asylum in another European country
the Federal Criminal Police Office has data about you
You will then receive the proof of arrival as proof of registration.
Only at this point can the asylum procedure begin.
Persons who wish to apply for asylum in Munich should first contact the responsible local authority:
Government of Upper Bavaria
Arrival center for asylum seekers
Maria-Probst-Straße 14
Admission takes place around the clock.
You will be allocated a bed.
You will then be sent to another initial reception center or you will initially stay in the initial reception center in Munich.
The law obliges asylum seekers to initially live in an initial reception center for a period of up to three months.
The reception center in which you are accommodated depends on your country of origin.
Asylum applications from different countries of origin are processed in the various BAMF branch offices.
All asylum seekers are distributed evenly among the various federal states in Germany.

question: What is the central goal of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities for local authorities?
context:
Rights of people with disabilities
Rights of people with disabilities
The UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities describes human rights from the perspective of people with disabilities.
The City of Munich has accepted the mandate that the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities also imposes on local authorities.
The central goal is to shape an inclusive urban society.
Inclusion means the full, equal participation of people with disabilities in the same way and from the very beginning: self-determined participation should be made possible and promoted in all phases of life and in all areas of life in Munich.
Structural, social, individual and psychological barriers and all forms of discrimination should be dismantled and prevented.
Learn more
In Art.
3 para.
3 of the German Basic Law states: "No one shall be disadvantaged because of their disability."
The city administration has now developed strategies for this in two action plans.
They optimize the structural framework conditions for people with disabilities and strive for a city-wide understanding of inclusion.
Learn more
People with disabilities and their relatives can find information and support from the offices listed in this app.

question: What do employees have to do to comply with the safety regulations?
context:
Occupational Health and Safety Act
Occupational Health and Safety Act
The Occupational Health and Safety Act (ArbSchG) stipulates this for all areas of activity:
which occupational health and safety obligations apply to employers
what obligations and rights employees have
how the legal provisions are monitored
The regulations in the Occupational Health and Safety Act are intended to guarantee the health and safety of all employees.
Precise prevention measures have been defined for workplaces where there is a risk to employees.
Employers are responsible for compliance and implementation.
Employees must be regularly familiarized with the protective measures.
Employees are obliged to comply with safety regulations, not to endanger other people during their work and to report any defects that could pose a danger.
Occupational Health and Safety Act

question: Which freedoms are inviolable according to Article 5?
context:
Basic Law and human rights
Basic Law and human rights
All people living in Germany must abide by the central principles of the political and legal order.
The most important legal basis for life in Germany is the Basic Law.
It is the constitution of the Federal Republic of Germany.
According to the Basic Law, every person is a free and self-determined individual.
No distinctions may be made on the basis of gender, origin (ancestry, language, homeland), skin color, religion, belief or ideology, disability, age or sexual orientation.
Germany is a federal state consisting of 16 federal states.
Germany is a democratic state, which means that all state power emanates from the people.
Catalog of fundamental rights
Protection of human dignity
Article 1
(1) Human dignity is inviolable.
It is the duty of all state authorities to respect and protect them.
(...)
Right to freedom of the person
Article 2
(1) Everyone has the right to the free development of his or her personality, provided that he or she does not infringe the rights of others and does not violate the constitutional order or the moral law.
(...)
This also includes the right to sexual self-determination.
This means that everyone is allowed to decide for themselves which sexual acts they want to take part in and no one should be forced to do something they don't want to do.
Equality before the law
Article 3
(1) All people are equal before the law.
(2) Men and women shall have equal rights.
The state promotes the actual implementation of equal rights for women and men and works towards the elimination of existing disadvantages.
www.zanzu.de
(3) No one may be disadvantaged or favored because of his or her gender, descent, race, language, homeland and origin, faith, religious or political views.
No one should be disadvantaged because of their disability.
Freedom of faith, conscience and religion
Article 4
(1) Freedom of faith, freedom of conscience and freedom of religious and philosophical belief shall be inviolable.
(...)
Freedom of opinion, art and science
Article 5
(1) Everyone has the right to freely express and disseminate his or her opinion in speech, writing and pictures and to obtain information from generally accessible sources without hindrance.
Freedom of the press and freedom of reporting by radio and film are guaranteed.
There is no censorship.
(...)
Protection of marriage and family and children of unmarried parents
Article 6
(1) Marriage and family are under the special protection of the state order.
(...)
Here you will find the catalog of fundamental rights in 8 different languages:
Arabic,
English,
Farsi,
French, Kurdish-Kurmanji, Russian,
Spanish, Turkishand of course
German
Universal Declaration of Human Rights
Human rights are important rights that always apply to all people around the world.
Human rights are rights that every person has by virtue of being human.
They protect the dignity of every human being and are equally due to all human beings without distinction of any kind, such as "(...) color, sex, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, property, birth or other status." (Art.
There are30 rights.
The most important are:
All people are worth the same.
Everyone is allowed to have their own opinion.
Right to peace and security.
The rules for living together in Germany are derived from these fundamental rights.
These rules and examples of what is and is not permitted in Germany are presented here under each keyword.

question: What do I have to do to avoid automatic contract renewal?
context:
Telecommunications
Telecommunications
Country code Germany
Munich area code
Munich has the area code 089 for landlines.
Cell phone
There are two different cell phone contracts in Germany: Prepaid contract and fixed-term contract.
The prepaid contract has no fixed contract term.
A fixed-term contract has a minimum contract term;
This contract is automatically renewed if you do not cancel.
If you do not want the contract to be automatically renewed, you must cancel in writing.
Pay attention to the notice period.
It is in the contract.
Before you sign a contract, find out from people you know, ask around and think about which details are particularly important to you.
Ten important questions for concluding a contract:
How high is the basic fee?
Does the fee increase after a certain time?
Is there a minimum monthly turnover (minimum costs per month)?
How long does the contract run for (e.g. 12 or 24 months)?
When do I have to cancel if I don't want to extend the contract?
How much does it cost to set up, switch and deactivate?
Which time cycle (60/1, 10/10) is used for the calculation?
How much does a minute cost (external / own network)?
How much does a cell phone with a contract cost, how much without a contract?
How much does the Internet cost?
How much do international calls cost?
Think about which flat rate is most worthwhile for you and find out what the flat rate does not cover and what costs will be incurred.

question: What happens if the court rejects the appeal against an asylum decision?
context:
6. legal action
Legal action
If you do not agree with the negative decision on your asylum application by the BAMF, you can appeal against this decision.
You are the "plaintiff" or the "claimant", the BAMF is the "defendant".
The Munich Administrative Court is reviewing the decision of the Federal Office in a lawsuit.
If the court comes to a different decision, it will oblige the Federal Office to grant you protection.
You will then receive a residence permit.
If, on the other hand, it confirms the negative decision, the claim is dismissed.
The obligation to leave the country remains in force.
You can also take legal action against a positive decision, for example if you do not agree with the form of protection granted (exception: granting of refugee status).
In any case, it is recommended that you seek advice and representation from a specialist lawyer for asylum and residence law.

If the court comes to a different decision, it will oblige the Federal Office to grant you protection.

You can also take legal action against a positive decision, for example if you do not agree with the form of protection granted (exception: granting of refugee status).
In any case, it is recommended that you seek advice and representation from a specialist lawyer for asylum and residence law.

question: Which means of transport depart from the ZOB?
context:
Munich's train stations / ZOB / airport
Munich's train stations / ZOB / airport
Munich Central Station
The main station is in the middle of the city.
It has 32 above-ground and several underground tracks.
It has the most main tracks of any German railroad station.
All long-distance trains depart from the main hall.
Tracks 5 to 10 - the so-called Holzkirchen station - are usually used by regional trains to Salzburg and Mühldorf.
From tracks 27 to 36 - the so-called Starnberg station - you start in the direction of Lindau, Lenggries or Tegernsee.
Around 350,000 people use the main station every day.
There is also a customer center for public transport, shopping facilities and snack bars.
Munich East Station
The Ostbahnhof is located in the Haidhausen district.
Ostbahnhof is another long-distance station and an important transfer point between regional trains and S-Bahn and U-Bahn trains.
The ExpressBus X30 also stops there and offers a good connection to Giesing and Sendling.
There is also a wide range of restaurants, bars and clubs in the surrounding area.
Munich-Pasing station
This station has 14 tracks and is also a long-distance station.
Around 85,000 people use it every day.
The central bus station in Munich (ZOB)
This is a station for bus connections.
It is an important transportation hub for national and international connections from Munich.
With 29 bus terminals and many sales areas, the ZOB has an airport-like character.
Munich Airport
You can take the S-Bahn lines 1 and 8 to the airport and the visitor park.
You should allow around 40 minutes on the S-Bahn to reach the airport on time.
It is also possible to use the Lufthansa Airport Bus.
It departs from the stops Hauptbahnhof (approx. 45 minutes) and Schwabing Nord / Nordfriedhof (approx. 30 minutes).
Depending on the volume of traffic, however, there may be delays.
Further information is available
here.
MVV tickets are not valid here.
If you want to drive, you can also use a car-sharing vehicle to the airport.
All DriveNow and car2go vehicles can be parked and rented at the airport.

context:

What is the kita finder+?
The kita finder+ is the online registration portal for daycare centers in Munich.
It contains an overview of all daycare facilities in Munich.
You must register once and can then register your child in one or more facilities (at the earliest twelve months before the desired start of childcare).
It is advisable to register with several institutions, as this increases the chances of actually getting a place on the desired date and under the desired conditions.
You can also accept acceptances via the kita finder+.

question: What is the lowest language level?
context:
Language levels
Language levels
There are different language levels.
In the language and integration courses, the levels according to the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages are used:
Language level A: elementary language use
Language level B: independent language use (necessary for training or work)
Language level C: competent use of the language (necessary for studies and certain professions)
A more precise distinction is usually made:
A1: Beginners
A2: Basic knowledge
B1: Advanced use of language
B2: Independent use of language
C1: Competent use of language
C2: Almost native speaker level
And even within these levels there are further differentiations (A1/1, A1/2, A2/1, A2/2, etc.)
The six levels mean in detail:
A1: Beginner
They can understand and use simple words and sentences.
You can introduce yourself and others.
For example: My name is Maria.
I am 30 years old.
I live in Germany.
This is my friend.
His name is Paul.
You can ask questions about yourself.
For example: What is your name?
Where do you live?
You can answer questions.
For example: How are you doing?
I'm fine.
You can talk to a person if they speak slowly and clearly.
A2: Basic knowledge
You can understand sentences and frequently used words.
You understand words in these areas: Personal and family information, shopping, work and your surroundings.
You can communicate in simple, everyday situations.
You can describe your background, education and environment.
B1: Advanced use of language
They can understand a lot when it comes to work, school or leisure, for example.
You can communicate while traveling.
You can say something about familiar topics and personal interests.
They can report on experiences and events.
You can describe dreams, hopes and goals.
You can give brief reasons or explanations for plans and views.
B2: Independent use of language
You can understand the most important content of complex texts on concrete and abstract topics.
You also understand technical discussions in your area of specialization.
You can communicate spontaneously and fluently.
A normal conversation with
Native speakers are able to communicate without much effort on either side.
You can express yourself clearly and in detail on many different topics.
You can explain a point of view on a current issue.
You can specify the advantages and disadvantages of different options.
C1: Professional language skills
You can understand a lot of demanding, longer texts.
They also capture implicit meanings.
You can express yourself spontaneously and fluently.
You rarely have to search for words.
You can use the language effectively and flexibly in social and professional life or in training and studies.
You can express yourself clearly, in a structured and detailed manner on complex issues.
In doing so, you use various means of linking texts appropriately.
C2: (Near) native speaker skills
You can understand practically everything you read or hear with ease.
You can summarize information from various written and oral sources.
You can reproduce reasons and explanations in a coherent presentation.
They can express themselves spontaneously, very fluently and precisely.
They can also make finer nuances of meaning clear in more complex situations.

question: When does your freedom end?
context:
Personal freedom
Personal freedom
All adults are entitled to make their own decisions about themselves and their own lives.
Whether man or woman, young or old, with or without a disability, regardless of skin color or religious affiliation.
All people are allowed to do what they want as long as they abide by the law and do not restrict the freedom of others.
This means, for example:
Everyone can decide what they want to wear.
Women can decide whether they want to wear pants, dresses, long or short skirts, tight or loose clothing or a headscarf.
Men can decide whether to wear a suit and tie, a T-shirt and jeans, a turban, a hat or a beard.
Everyone is allowed to eat what they want and what they like.
The decision whether to eat meat (including pork or beef) is made by people alone.
The state has no generally valid or religiously based dietary regulations.
The consumption of alcohol is permitted for adults.
The consumption of alcohol by children and young people is prohibited.
Every woman and every man can decide for themselves whether and who they want to marry.
Every woman and every man is entitled to divorce.
Unmarried couples are allowed to live together and have children.
Members of different religions and faiths are allowed to marry and have children.
Contraception is permitted for both sexes.
A person's decision to use contraception must be respected.
Same-sex partnerships are accepted.
Same-sex couples can marry.
The rights of a civil partnership are similar to those of a marriage between a man and a woman.
Everyone decides for themselves how and where they want to live.
For persons in the asylum procedure, this right may be restricted until an asylum application is recognized.
Sexual acts between adults may only take place with mutual consent.
Any sexual activity with children is prohibited.
Private property is permitted for every man and every woman in Germany.
It is permitted to own a house or a plot of land.
Many companies are privately owned.
Women and men have equal rights when it comes to inheritance.
Important:
One's own freedom ends where it infringes the freedom or human dignity of others or violates the law.

question: Which groups of people does Blaues Kreuz München e. V. support?
context:
Blaues Kreuz München e. V. - Help for addicts
Blaues Kreuz München e. V. - Help for addicts and their families
We support people at risk of addiction and those suffering from addiction by helping them to help themselves.
We also support relatives.
In our self-help groups, members help each other.
Here you can find people who have the same problem.
They know the daily withdrawal symptoms, the hardships and the despair in which those affected find themselves.
Together, you have the chance to find a way out of addiction.
Our groups are confidential.
This means that nobody is allowed to tell anyone else what was said in the group.
The groups are open to all people, regardless of faith or origin.
We also offer information events, acute help for those affected, talks for those affected and for relatives.
Learn more
Who for: People at risk of addiction or suffering from addiction and their relatives;
Information seekers
The offer is free of charge.
The group takes place weekly and lasts approx.
1 ½ hours.
Please make an appointment.
Blue Cross Munich e. V.
Hesseloherstrasse 1
office@blaues-kreuz-muenchen.de
Group lessons see
Homepage
Addiction help, alcohol, addiction prevention

question: Where can I find support for finding accommodation?
context:
Relocation
As soon as you have moved into your new home, you must register with your new municipal administration within two weeks.
You will need a landlord's certificate from your landlord for this.
If they miss the two-week deadline, they may be fined.
Ask for the forms at the town hall or have a look on the homepage of the town hall.
Inform all important offices of your new address (e.g. bank, district office/job center, insurance company, employer, immigration office).
Please make sure that your name is on the letterbox.

question: Where can you find specific answers to questions about raising children and starting school?
context:
Orientation for families
Family guide
Are you pregnant and would like some advice?
Are you looking for a competent contact person for questions about parenting?
Or do you need vacation care for your child?
There is a contact point for every question in the district of Augsburg.
The Augsburg District Office has compiled all the services, advice centers and contact persons for you in the "Family Guide" brochure.
Just take a look!
Helpful information on family topics
The Federal Ministry for Family Affairs, Senior Citizens, Women and Youth provides information on family issues from A to Z at: www.familienportal.de.
Parents' guide in 16 languages
Education prepares children for their future lives.
Education lays the foundation for your child to develop into a strong and self-confident personality.
Raising children well is therefore a challenge.
The "Strong through parenting" guide aims to support all parents in this challenge.
The guide is available in 16 foreign languages (Albanian, Arabic, English, Farsi, French, Italian, Croatian, Portuguese, Russian, Serbian, Somali, Spanish, Tamil, Thai, Tigrinya, Turkish)
Information portal "Parents on the Net"
The online portal "Parents on the Net" also provides answers to many specific questions, for example about parenting or starting school.
You will also find letters for parents there.
These letters will support you in the first 18 years of your child's life with practical tips and information.
Just take a look at www.elternimnetz.de.
Children have rights too
The rights of children can be read in various languages.
It is important that children and young people also know their rights.
That's why there is also a child-friendly version in different languages:
www.unicef.de (search term "Convention on the Rights of the Child")
www.bmfsfj.de (search term: "Children's rights")

question: Who are the cooperation partners of the "Take Off!" project?
context:
By women for women: Take Off! Shaping career prospects with & for migrant women
By women for women:
In the project "Take Off!
Shaping career prospects with & for migrant women" supports women with their own migration experience.
They discover their skills and develop further: linguistically, professionally and personally.
They find a way to combine family and job.
The women are accompanied confidentially and professionally supported.
The offer is free of charge.
The offers:
Advice and support
Training or further education
Job search and applications
Internships and career entry
All about education and childcare
Trainings and workshops
Understanding Germany and the labor market better
Improve your German language skills
Get to know and use computers
Network and exchange
Women's meeting place - support with everyday issues
Events in Augsburg and the region
Individual and group coaching
Uncover competencies
Activate resources
Develop personal goals
Job application coaching
Who is part of the project?
In "Take Off!
Shaping career prospects with & for migrant women", Tür an Tür-Integrationsprojekte gGmbH is working together with BIB Augsburg gGmbH, Eckert Schulen, Visiones e.V. and Diakonie Augsburg.
It also cooperates with the Augsburg City, Augsburg County and Wittelsbach County Job Centers and the Augsburg Employment Agency.
How is the project financed?
The project is part of MyTurn - Women with migration experience take off.
"MyTurn" is a nationwide program.
The funding comes from Germany and Europe.
In Germany by the Federal Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs (BMAS), in the European Union (EU) by the European Social Fund (ESF Plus).
Where can I find more information?
Since May, Wertachstraße 29 has been a central contact point for the "Take Off!
Shaping career prospects with & for migrant women".
Interested parties can find information about the offers here.
Personal advice (without an appointment) is available on Thursdays between 10am and 12pm and between 2pm and 4pm.
Door to door
Project "Take off!
Shaping career prospects with & for migrant women"
Wertachstr.
Thursday from 10 to 12 and from 14 to 16 (without appointment)
You can also find all the latest information about the offers on Instagram and Facebook.

question: Where can I find the AVV timetables with the fare zones?
context:
Public transportation
There is a good network of public transportation in Augsburg and the surrounding area, such as buses and streetcars.
The Augsburger Verkehrs- und Tarifverbund (AVV) is responsible for this network.
You can find all the important information on the AVV website at www.avv-augsburg.de.
For app users, both AVV (app: AVV.mobil) and Stadtwerke Augsburg (app: swa FahrInfo) offer free apps for download.
You need a ticket to travel by bus or streetcar.
Checks are often carried out on buses and streetcars.
If you do not have a ticket, you will have to pay a fine.
The second time, you will be reported to the police and fined much more.
So make sure you always have a valid ticket with you!
Fare zones and price levels
The area in which the AVV operates is divided into zones.
The price of the tickets depends on the number of zones traveled through.
The more zones you pass through, the more expensive your ticket will be.
Each zone corresponds to a price level.
Each zone is only counted once.
For example, if you travel through zones 20, 10 and 20 again, you need a ticket for price level 2 or
2 stripes on the stripe card.
However, the outward and return journeys count as two separate journeys.
The Augsburg city area includes fare zones 10 and 20.
The district of Augsburg comprises zones 30 - 70.
You can find the fare zone map here.
The timetables with the fare zones are also displayed at the stops.
Note: Your ticket is also valid if you change trains.
The most important tickets
Detailed information on all tickets and current prices can be found here.
Germany ticket
For 49 euros a month, you can use all means of public transportation and travel throughout Germany.
The Deutschlandticket is a subscription.
This means that it is automatically renewed every month.
But you can cancel it every month.
Always by 10.
of each month (for example: 10.
March) for the following month.
You can order your Germany ticket here.
It is then played on the smartphone.
You will need the "myAVV" app for this.
You can find the app in your smartphone's Apple or Google store.
Discount ticket for students, trainees, civil servants or volunteers
In Bavaria, these groups of people can get a discounted Deutschlandticket.
The discount ticket costs 29 euros.
It is also valid nationwide.
This ticket is valid for trainees from 01.
The person's place of education or residence must be in Bavaria.
To apply, you need a certificate of eligibility from your training center / educational institution.
You can apply for the discount ticket here.
Stripe card
9 strips for flexible use (one strip per zone)
Valid for 3 hours (no return and round trips)
No take-away options (one strip per person and zone)
You can find more information about the strip card here
One-way tickets
Once from A to B
Valid for 1 hour (no return and round trips)
No take-away options
4 Stops after boarding buses or streetcars, even across zone boundaries
Change possible
You can find more information about one-way tickets here.
Day ticket
Any number of journeys on the selected day
For adults aged 15 and over
For one person or groups (each additional person costs an extra charge)
Up to 4 children under the age of 14 can travel free of charge.
Valid Monday to Friday from 9:00 a.m., Saturday, Sundays and public holidays all day;
valid until closing time (i.e. until the last bus or streetcar leaves).
Please note: The names of the passengers must be handwritten on the day ticket!
You can find more information about the day ticket here.
365-euro AVV ticket for school pupils, trainees, interns and FSJ volunteers
The 365-euro AVV ticket is available for school pupils, trainees, interns and young people doing a voluntary social year.
For €1 a day, you can travel as often as you like on streetcars, buses and trains throughout the AVV network area - around the clock!
You can pay for the ticket in installments or all at once.
You can find all the information here.
Monthly pass for school pupils
Pupils do not have to pay for the bus and streetcar themselves.
You can submit an application.
The cost of the monthly pass will then be covered.
For this, the journey to school for pupils in grades 1 to 4 must be more than 2 km.
For children and young people from the 5th grade onwards, the journey to school must be longer than 3 km.
Further information and download of the applications: www.landkreis-augsburg.de
Call and collect cab (AST), on-call bus
The call-and-collect cab (AST for short) and the on-call bus operate when there are no regular bus or train connections.
For example, a cab will pick you up from the station or a bus stop and take you to the door of your desired destination.
The journey request must be made by telephone at least 30 minutes before departure.
The regular AVV prices apply.
You can find more information here.
AktiVVO - minibus as required
The minibus runs on demand without fixed stops and without a fixed timetable.
Trips in the minibus can be booked by telephone or in the "AktiVVO" app.
Within a short time, passengers can get on and off at one of the AktiVVo stops or at the AVV regional bus stops.
The fare for the AktiVVo corresponds to the regular AVV fares.
The AktiVVO minibus commutes in these regions:
Holzwinkel and Altenmünster, Roth and Zusam valleys
Bobingen, Königsbrunn and Schwabmünchen
The AktiVVO is only on the road in these regions.
He's not going to Augsburg either.
It does not travel to any locations outside these regions.
Augsburg City Zone
In the city of Augsburg, you can use the bus and streetcar free of charge at a total of 9 stations around Königsplatz and the main railway station.
The free stops are one stop in each direction from Königsplatz and Moritzplatz.
You can find more information here.
At night
With the night bus you are also mobile at night (0.30 to 4 am).
The night buses run from Thursday to Sunday and on public holidays.
Passengers require a special night ticket (also available on the buses).
Regional trains run on some routes.
The regular AVV fare applies here.

question: What should you not do before signing a contract?
context:
Contracts
Particularly important:
Never sign anything that you do not understand or cannot read.
Otherwise you may sign a contract or agreement under which you have to pay something.
It is sometimes very difficult to undo this.
Always check and compare several offers and take your time to decide.
Don't let anyone pressure you into signing.
Here you will find further information and help on contracts.
Contracts, contract, sign contract

question: Where can women affected by violence find support in Ukrainian?
context:

question: Who can do a voluntary internship?
context:
Important information about the internship
What is an internship?
An internship is a temporary position.
This means that interns work in a company or business for a limited period of time.
An internship can be done in almost any profession.
An internship is there to...
get to know a new profession,
get to know a working environment in practice,
and / or to deepen theoretical knowledge through practical (professional) experience.
What are the advantages of an internship?
An internship is very helpful before starting out in working life.
Interns get to know professions and fields of activity.
They can see which job is right for them.
Interns get to know companies and businesses.
They see if they want to work there.
Interns make contacts that can be helpful when entering working life.
The company gets to know the interns.
This may result in a job or apprenticeship after the internship.
For whom is an internship useful?
An internship can be useful for everyone.
When hiring new employees, for example, employers look at where the applicant has already completed internships.
Internships are particularly useful for:
Pupils,
Students,
People about to enter working life (to gain professional experience),
People who want to make a career change,
People who have been out of work for a long time.
The most important types of internships
Compulsory internship
Student internship: Students often have to do an internship at school.
The student internship often only lasts one to two weeks.
The aim is to familiarize pupils with working life and give them an initial career orientation.
Internship during studies: In order to complete your degree, you often have to do an internship.
The procedure and duration are regulated by the study regulations.
The compulsory internships provide initial work experience.
Voluntary internship
Anyone can do a voluntary internship - pupils, students or adults.
The duration is determined together with the company or business.
Payment
Interns sometimes receive money during their internship.
But not always.
This depends on several factors.
For example, the type of internship, the duration or even the sector.
Interns are entitled to payment if
the internship lasts longer than three months
and is voluntary.
This regulation does not apply to compulsory internships during studies.
The rule also does not apply to interns under the age of 18.
Ten tips for interns
Find out about the internship company before the internship (e.g.
B. on the Internet).
Be polite, punctual and reliable.
Show interest and motivation.
Ask if you want to know something or if something is unclear.
Address problems directly.
Stay friendly.
Accept criticism and learn from it.
Private is private: for example, avoid making private phone calls or constantly looking at your cell phone.
Dress appropriately.
Make new contacts.
These contacts can be helpful when looking for a job later on.
Apply for an internship certificate.
The internship certificate can be helpful later when looking for a job.

question: Who can I contact if I have questions about housing shortages?

question: What kind of childcare is offered during the vacations?
context:
Vacation care
Vacations are certainly the best time of the year for children.
For working parents, however, the vacations are often an organizational problem.
If relatives, friends or neighbors can't help with childcare, it becomes difficult.
Many towns and municipalities therefore offer childcare during the vacation periods.
Vacation offers from youth associations and the Augsburg District Youth Council are also open to your children.
Find out more at:
Your municipality or
in the town hall
via the education portal a3 www.bildungsportal-a3.de
Kreisjugendring Augsburg-Land www.kjr-augsburg.de/#ferienprogramm.

Then there are often offers during the vacations.
Ask your institution directly.
You can find an overview of all public holidays and school vacations in the "Everyday life" section under "Public holidays, school vacations and time changeover".

question: What happens if Germany is not responsible for carrying out the asylum procedure?
context:
Dublin procedure
Dublin procedure
The Dublin procedure covers the 28 EU member states as well as Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Switzerland.
The Dublin procedure determines which country is responsible for carrying out your asylum procedure.
As a rule, it is the country in which you were registered for the first time.
This is done with an electronic data comparison.
It may be that Germany is not responsible for carrying out your asylum procedure.
If Germany is not responsible, you will be sent back to the country responsible for you.
If you do not agree with this decision, you can seek advice.
You can get professional legal advice on whether it makes sense to file a complaint with the administrative court.
Further information on the Dublin Agreement in German and English

question: What is the European Health Insurance Card (EHIC) used for?
context:
Health insurance is compulsory
Important: Everyone in Germany must have health insurance.
Statutory or private health insurance?
There is statutory and private health insurance.
Most people have statutory health insurance.
Some people have private health insurance.
You must fulfill certain requirements.
These people in particular have private health insurance:
Self-employed
Employees who earn a lot of money.
If you work, your health insurance is paid for by yourself and your employer.
Health insurance
You take out health insurance with a health insurance company.
There are many health insurance companies in Germany.
The health insurance companies have different services and offers.
Take a close look at the insurance.
Every person is free to choose their health insurance company.
Here you will find an overview of health insurance companies in Germany.
Insurance card
You will receive an insurance card from your health insurance company.
You need the insurance card for medical treatment.
The European Health Insurance Card is on the back.
The European insurance card is called the European Health Insurance Card, or EHIC for short.
This means you are also well covered in all EU countries.
And also in many other European countries.
And you are even insured in some countries outside Europe.
Note:
It is best to always have your insurance card with you.
Then you have the card to hand in the event of a medical emergency.
Information for asylum seekers
Different rules apply to asylum seekers.
Find out more in the section "Information for asylum seekers".
Health promotion and prevention services
Health promotion and prevention services help you to stay healthy.
The aim is to prevent illness.
The risk of illness is reduced by preventive measures.
These offers include, for example:
Nutrition courses
Back training
Yoga courses
etc.
There are many offers for health promotion and prevention.
Most health insurance companies cover all or part of the costs of the services.
Take advantage of the offers!
This way you can protect your health.
Ask your health insurance company about the costs beforehand.
Offers in the district of Augsburg
You can find health promotion and prevention offers in the district of Augsburg in the health portal.
You can find more information here.
Here you will find information for children and young people.

question: What are the two different cell phone contracts in Germany?
context:
Smartphone
There are two different cell phone contracts in Germany: Prepaid contract and fixed-term contract.
The prepaid contract has no fixed contract term.
This means that you pay a certain amount for a certain period of time (often four weeks).
You do not have to cancel the prepaid contract if you no longer want to use it.
A fixed-term contract has a minimum contract term.
This means that you have to stay with a particular provider for a longer period of time.
The contract is automatically extended if you do not cancel.
If you do not want the contract to be extended automatically, you must cancel in writing.
Pay attention to the notice period.
Ten important questions for concluding a contract:
How high is the basic fee?
Does the fee increase after a certain time?
Is there a minimum monthly turnover (minimum costs per month)?
How long does the contract last (e.g.
B.twelve or 24 months)?
If I don't cancel the contract, it will be automatically renewed.
When do I have to cancel if I don't want to extend the contract?
How much does it cost to set up, switch and deactivate?
Which time cycle (60/1, 10/10) is used for the calculation?
How much does a minute cost (external/own network)?
How much does a cell phone with a contract cost and how much does a cell phone without a contract cost?
How much does the Internet cost?
How much do international calls cost?
You can find important information in five different languages (German, English, Arabic, Russian, Farsi) at the consumer advice center: www.verbraucherzentrale.de (search term: "multilingual information").
There you will also find explanatory videos on the topic in German, English, Arabic and Dari.

question: What damage does the private liability insurance cover according to the message?
context:
Insurances
Compulsory insurance
You must have these insurances in Germany:
"Health insurance
For drivers: Motor vehicle liability insurance
For employees: Statutory pension insurance
You can find important information at the consumer advice center: www.verbraucherzentrale.de.
The information is available in these languages:
German
English
Arabic
Farsi
Ukrainian
Romanian
French
Turkish
Bulgarian
Highly recommended: Liability insurance
You have caused harm to a person in Germany?
Then you have to pay compensation according to the law.
Even if it wasn't your intention.
This applies to personal injury, property damage and financial losses in the private sector.
For example, if you cause a traffic accident.
Or when your child breaks a window pane with a ball.
Many landlords and landladies require their tenants to have liability insurance.
Private liability insurance pays for these damages for you and your children.
Liability insurance is not compulsory.
You don't have to lock it.
But we strongly recommend it.
You can find explanatory videos with important information on liability insurance in German, English, Arabic and Dari at the consumer advice center;
Search term: "Multilingual consumer videos".

question: In which languages is the Deutsche Welle website available?
context:
Level B2 - for advanced learners
Telenovela: "Jojo seeks happiness"
The Brazilian Jojo comes to Germany.
In the telenovela, you can find out more about her life and her friends.
There are interactive exercises and vocabulary for each episode.
There are three seasons in total.
Learn German on the Deutsche Welle website
On the Deutsche Welle website you will find various offers for learning German.
You can...
Listen to messages that are spoken more slowly for learners.
learn how Germans live in the Deutschlandlabor.
get to know other learners in the online community.
Watch videos on various topics.
train your listening comprehension.
Read up on grammar questions.
work on many exercises.
The site is available in 30 languages.
For example: English, Arabic, Bosnian, Greek, Polish and many more.
B2 - German for the workplace
In this free course you will learn German for the workplace at B2 level in 20 lessons with videos, audios, pictures and suitable tasks.
You will be supported by an online tutor who will answer questions or correct texts.
German forum and online community
The online community on the Goethe-Institut website enables you to:
to join a Whatsapp learning group,
chat in German with learners from all over the world,
or to find a learning partner.
You will also find various German exercises at all levels, including B2.

question: What types of child daycare are there in Germany?
context:
Basic information on childcare
Important information on childcare
In Germany, there are numerous child daycare services in daycare centers and childminders.
Childcare has many advantages for you.
The teachers are very well qualified and do interesting projects with the children.
Your children will learn lots of new things in a positive atmosphere.
Above all, your children will learn German very quickly.
And they come into contact with other children.
That is very important.
Because children need other children to play together, to learn and to make friends.
Several short films on childcare in Germany show all these advantages.
The films are available in German, English, French, Russian, Arabic, Farsi, Dari, Turkish, Kurdish and Tigrin.
You can also see how children learn and play best in their first years of life.
Take a look at both sides:
www.kita.bayern.de
www.bvktp.de/themen/kinder-mit-fluchthintergrund

question: What is the minimum interval between the two measles vaccinations?
context:
Measles Protection Act
All children must be vaccinated or immune against measles.
The parents must provide proof.
This obligation also applies to children who are cared for in a children's home for at least four weeks.
And also for children in refugee accommodation.
Measles is one of the most contagious infectious diseases.
This is why almost all people without vaccination protection become infected with the virus after just one contact with a sick person.
Measles can lead to serious complications, particularly in children under five and adults over 20.
Inflammation of the middle ear or lungs and diarrhea are among the most common symptoms.
When are vaccinations given?
1st vaccination: Between the age of 11 and the age of 18.
and 14.
Month of life (after the 9th month at the earliest)
2nd vaccination: before the 2nd birthday at the latest
The minimum interval between the two vaccinations is four weeks.
The measles vaccination is given in combination with a vaccination against mumps, rubella and possibly
Chickenpox.
Further information on the measles vaccination can be found at: https://www.masernschutz.de/

question: What type of training is school-based training?
context:
School education
How does school-based training work?
You learn a profession mainly in theory at school.
Depending on the profession, you will attend a vocational college, a technical college or a vocational college.
You do internships to gain practical experience.
The apprenticeship lasts two to three and a half years, depending on the profession.
You don't usually receive a salary during your training.
Some professions in Germany can only be learned in school-based training, for example dietician or healthcare and nursing assistant.
How do I find an apprenticeship?
If you would like to do a school-based apprenticeship, apply directly to the school.
In the district of Augsburg, you can complete school-based training at five vocational schools (BFS for short):
BFS for nutrition and care, BFS for childcare and BFS for dietary assistance at the vocational school center / Neusäß
BFS for Nursing / Bobingen
BFS for emergency paramedics / Schwabmünchen (private)

question: Where can I search for an apprenticeship online?
context:
Dual education
Germany is well known for its dual training system.
There are approx.
325 recognized training occupations.
How does dual training work?
You will learn the theory at vocational school one or two days a week.
You will learn practical work in a company three to four days a week.
The apprenticeship lasts two to three and a half years, depending on the profession.
You receive a salary.
How much you earn varies depending on the industry, company and year of training.
There are around 330 professions that can be learned in dual training.
Information films from the Federal Institute for Vocational Education and Training show exactly how dual training works in ten languages.
Arabic, Chinese, German, English, Farsi, French, Italian, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish
How do I find an apprenticeship?
If you would like to complete a dual apprenticeship, you must first find a training place.
You are applying for an apprenticeship at a company (company, firm, institution).
"Training place" means: You have a job in a company.
There you will learn the practical work for the profession.
Only then is it time to register for vocational school.
The company is responsible for registration.
The following online job boards will help you to find an apprenticeship:
Job exchange of the employment agency: www.jobboerse.arbeitsagentur.de
IHK apprenticeship exchange: www.ihk-lehrstellenboerse.de
HWK apprenticeship exchange: www.hwk-schaben.de/lehrstellenbörse
Azubiyo apprenticeship exchange: www.azubiyo.de/ausbildung
Training market: www.ausbildungsmarkt.de
AUBI-Plus: www.aubi-plus.de
Apprenticeship radar: www.lehrstellen-radar.de
In addition to these apprenticeship exchanges, there are many others on the Internet.
You can also use these.
You will also find apprenticeships
through the "AzubiWelt" app from the Federal Employment Agency (www.arbeitsagentur.de/azubiwelt)
in newspapers,
on company websites,
through unsolicited applications.
Which vocational school should I go to?
The vocational schools usually have a specialization.
In the district of Augsburg, for example, there are two departments at the Neusäß State Vocational School Center: Business and administration (office, industry, retail, wholesale) and agriculture (agriculture, horticulture, floristry).
If you would like to do a dual apprenticeship in a different area, you will attend a different vocational school.
Who can help me find an apprenticeship?
Numerous companies are looking for people who would like to do an apprenticeship.
The following pages will help you with your search:
www.jobboerse.arbeitsagentur.de
www.ihk-lehrstellenboerse.de
www.hwk-schwaben.de/lehrstellenboerse
Good to know
Many companies start looking for trainees at a very early stage.
Many training positions are advertised a year in advance or have even already been filled.
So make sure you find a training place early on!

question: How can people without certificates prove their professional experience and skills?
context:
Recognition of foreign professional qualifications
In Germany, certificates play an important role for school, university or work.
They are proof of what you have already learned and achieved.
Certificates of school-leaving qualifications or professional qualifications are the decisive prerequisite for getting a job, a training place or a place at university.
If you have already obtained qualifications at school, in an apprenticeship or at university abroad, it often makes sense for the certificates to be recognized in Germany.
This means that they will check what you are qualified to do in Germany based on your certificates.
It may be that you no longer have your certificates.
In this case, you can try to prove your professional experience and skills through tests.
IQ recognition and qualification advice
Have you completed a vocational qualification abroad?
Have you already gained professional experience abroad?
Then the Recognition and Qualification Advisory Service is the right place for you to go.
The advice center will look at your documents.
She then compares your qualification with the German qualification.
For example, duration or content is compared.
Relevant professional experience is also taken into account.
At the end you will receive an assessment of whether you can get recognition or not.
Sometimes there are too big differences between foreign and German qualifications.
Because there are many factors to consider when recognizing professional qualifications, it is best to seek advice:
Door to door - Recognition and qualification advice
anerkennungsberatung@tuerantuer.de
www.migranet.org/angebote/ratsuchende/anerkennungsberatung
Telephone consultation hours: Monday and Thursday from 10 a.m. to 12 noon, Tuesday from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m.
Recognition grant
The recognition of foreign qualifications costs money.
The costs vary depending on the profession.
Some people can apply for a recognition grant.
This affects people who
live permanently in Germany,
have a low income and
are working below their professional qualification.
Get advice directly by e-mail or phone:
Research Institute for Vocational Education and Training (f-bb) gGmbH
anerkennungszuschuss@f-bb.de
Further detailed information
You can also find detailed information in eleven languages on the "Recognition in Germany" portal at www.anerkennung-in-deutschland.de.
The portal also offers a recognition app in German, English, Arabic, Dari, Farsi, Pashto and Tigrinya.

question: How long do asylum seekers have to live in an initial reception center?
context:
Registration
Have you just arrived in Germany?
And you want to apply for asylum?
Then you must register with one of the government agencies immediately after your arrival:
Border authority
Police
Immigration office
Reception center for refugees
Branch office of the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF)
Your personal data is registered and stored centrally.
It is checked whether
You are applying for asylum in Germany for the first time
you have already applied for asylum in another European country
the Federal Criminal Police Office has data about you
You will then receive proof of arrival as proof of registration.
Only at this point does the asylum procedure begin.
Asylum application in the district of Augsburg
Would you like to apply for asylum in the Augsburg district?
Then contact the responsible authority:
Government of Swabia
Central Foreigners Authority Swabia
Kobelweg 82
zab-poststelle@reg-schw.bayern.de
You will then be sent to another initial reception center.
Or you can initially stay in the initial reception center in the district of Augsburg.
The law obliges asylum seekers to live in an initial reception center for a period of up to three months.
The reception center where you will be accommodated depends on your country of origin.
Asylum applications from different countries of origin are processed in the various BAMF branch offices.
All asylum seekers are distributed evenly among the various federal states in Germany.

question: What opportunities are there for children and young people to learn German?
context:
German for children and young people
There are many opportunities for children and young people to learn German at daycare centers and schools.
Would you like more information?
Parents of children under the age of six can enquire directly at the daycare center or at the Augsburg District Office at the Child Daycare Department.
Parents of school children can obtain information directly from the school or the State Education Authority.
For children under the age of six
Child day care center
Petra Hetzner
petra.hetzner@LRA-a.bayern.de
For children aged six to 16
State education authority
schulamt@LRA-a.bayern.de
For young people between the ages of 16 and 21 who are required to attend school
State Vocational School Center Neusäß
District Administrator Dr.
sekretariat@bszneusaess.de
Further offers for learning German
There are also often opportunities to learn German locally in libraries (search term: "libraries" or "Bibliotheken") or volunteer centers and agencies (search term: "Freiwilligenzentrum" or "Freiwilligenagentur") (e.g.
e.g. German courses, language mentors, reading mentors).
Ask directly on site.
You can also improve your German online.
Tips can be found here.

question: Who advises benefit recipients on their energy consumption free of charge?
context:
Benefits from the job center
Electricity
The electricity costs are not covered by the Jobcenter.
You have to pay the electricity costs from your own money.
If you rent a new apartment, the landlord or landlady will normally automatically notify the electricity provider (e.g.
B. Municipal utilities).
You can also look for a new provider.
You then have a notice period (usually two weeks).
You can then switch to the electricity provider of your choice.
The Enervie consumer portal provides a neutral overview of all providers.
You can also compare prices there: www.energieverbraucherportal.de.
Tip: The Team Stromsparcheck - SKM Augsburg advises benefit recipients free of charge on their energy consumption after moving in.
You can find all the information here:
www.stromspar-check.de.
Internet/ Television
Internet costs are not covered by the Jobcenter.

question: When do you need permission to leave the district of the reception center?
context:
Application for asylum
After registration and accommodation in the reception center, the asylum application is submitted in person.
Are you accommodated in the reception center in the district of Augsburg?
You will then be given an appointment to apply at the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees - Augsburg branch office:
Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF)
Augsburg branch office
service@bamf.bund.de
www.bamf.de (multilingual)
An interpreter will also be available for this appointment.
You submit your application for asylum.
And you will receive important information about the asylum procedure.
You have submitted your application for asylum?
Then you will receive a residence permit.
This is proof of your legal residence in Germany and your application for asylum.
As long as you are accommodated in a reception center, the government of Swabia is responsible for immigration and residence law issues:
Government of Swabia
Central Foreigners Authority Swabia
zab-poststelle@reg-schw.bayern.de
Residence obligation
The residence permit is initially associated with spatial restrictions.
This means that you may only stay in the district of your reception center.
Would you like to leave the area temporarily within the first three months?
Then you need a permit from the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees.
After the three months, you will need a permit from the relevant immigration authority.
Depending on your country of origin and the course of your asylum procedure, this geographical restriction applies for different lengths of time.
Change of address - important note!
Are you in the asylum procedure and have been granted permission or obliged to move?
Then you must inform the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees of your new address yourself.

question: What are house rules?
context:
House rules, waste separation and energy saving
House rules
The cohabitation of many or more people in one house requires mutual consideration and tolerance.
The landlord can stipulate certain rules for the cohabitation of tenants in an apartment building.
These rules are then laid down in the house rules.
The most important contents of house rules are
Quiet times/noise
Waste disposal
Use of the common areas
Ventilate
You can find detailed house rules in different languages here: www.allbau.de/kundenservice/hausordnung
Waste separation
Waste must be disposed of in the garbage cans provided.
There are different garbage cans for plastic, paper and cardboard, for fruit and vegetable waste (organic waste) and for other waste.
Please keep to waste separation, as a large part of the waste is reused and it is an important part of environmental protection.
What belongs in which garbage can?
When are the garbage cans emptied?
Where is there a recycling collection point?
You can find information at www.awb-landkreis-augsburg.de.
You can also use the AbfallApp.
If you have any further questions, you can contact the waste advisory service of the district of Augsburg.
Waste consulting
abfallwirtschaft@LRA-a.bayern.de
You can find information on waste separation here.
Saving energy through ventilation and correct heating
Make sure that you ventilate regularly.
This means that you open the window fully for five minutes at least three times a day.
It is also important that you heat correctly.
This will prevent mold from forming and you can save energy.
You can obtain detailed information and helpful tips in German, English, Russian, Arabic and Farsi from the consumer advice center: www.verbraucherzentrale.de (search term: "multilingual information").

question: Which important card is recommended for people with disabilities?
context:
Rights and financial assistance
Disabled person's pass: important to have!
A disabled person's pass is very important for people with disabilities!
This card entitles them to certain benefits.
We recommend: Apply for a severely disabled person's pass at the Bavarian Center for Families and Social Affairs.
You can find the application form here.
Bavarian Center for Family and Social Affairs
poststelle.schw@zbfs.bayern.de
Financial aid
People with disabilities are in a special situation.
That is why they receive financial support.
You can find information on the website of the Federal Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs at www.bmas.de (search for "Ratgeber für Menschen mit Behinderungen").
Also in plain language.
The guide "My child is disabled - what help is available" provides a good overview of rights and financial assistance for people with disabilities and their families.
The guide is also suitable for adults without children.
It is available in Turkish, Russian, Arabic and Vietnamese.

question: What happens when the time changes from winter to summer time?
context:
Public holidays, school vacations and time changeover
Holidays
No work is done on a public holiday for religious or secular reasons.
Stores and authorities are closed on these days.
The following holidays are on the same date every year:
01.01.
New Year
06.01.
Three Wise Men
01.05.
Labor Day
08.08.
Peace Festival (only in the city of Augsburg)
15.08.
Assumption of the Virgin Mary
03.10.
Day of German Unity
01.11.
All Saints' Day
25.12.
1st Christmas Day
26.12.
2nd Christmas Day
Other holidays shift from year to year.
You can find an overview of public holidays in Bavaria here.
School vacations
Vacations are the times of the year when pupils are off school.
In Bavaria, the new school year begins every year in September.
Fall vacation: There is a week around All Saints' Day (public holiday).
Christmas vacation: There are two weeks around Christmas and New Year (public holidays).
Winter vacation: There is a week's winter vacation in February.
Easter vacation: There are two weeks of vacation in spring
Whitsun vacation: There are two weeks of vacation in early summer.
Summer vacation: In summer, the school year ends at the end of July/beginning of August with six weeks of vacation.
You can find an overview of all upcoming public vacations and vacations here, for example.
Religious holidays
Jewish, Muslim and Orthodox pupils are exempt from lessons on certain religious holidays: www.km.bayern.de/ministerium/termine/ferientermine.html
Please inform the school if your child cannot come to school due to these holidays.
Intercultural calendar
The intercultural calendar provides an overview of the most important holidays of the different religious communities.
Time change
There is also a time change in Germany.
This means that the clock is set forward by one hour from winter to summer time.
The clock is set back by one hour from summer to winter time.
