question: What does "inclusion" mean?
context:
Together for inclusion
"It's normal to be different.
Everyone is welcome."
(Aktion Mensch about the inclusive society)
Inclusion means that everyone belongs naturally and can take part in all of life's activities.
This is especially true for people with disabilities.
The idea of inclusion is very important to the district of Augsburg.
There are therefore numerous offers for people with disabilities.
Even in the foyer of the Augsburg District Office, you can see that the topic plays a major role for the district: The CABito system presents the services of the district administration in a very simple way.
The information can be called up via text, image or voice.
Just give it a try!

question: When should you be careful when paying online?
context:
Online shopping
More and more people are shopping online.
There are a few things to bear in mind.
Remember that:
Online shopping does not only have positive effects.
Packaging material and returns are a burden on the environment.
And even local stores cannot keep up with the competition on the Internet.
That's why many stores are closing.
The local stores are empty.
It is therefore worth considering what you order on the Internet or buy directly on site.
What should I look out for when shopping online?
Reputable online store or fake store?
Want to order something online?
Then you should find out about the online store beforehand.
Because not all platforms are reputable.
So-called fake stores offer cheap goods that you do not receive after payment or that you receive in poor condition.
How can I recognize a dubious online retailer?
Strikingly low price
The goods in the online store are remarkably cheap?
However, this is not always an indication of a fake store.
But you should take a closer look.
Conspicuous Internet address
A well-known website suddenly shows inconsistencies?
The domain extension has been extended (e.g.
B. instead of ".de" it says: ".de.com")?
The Internet address contains the keyword "plants", but it sells shoes?
Then these are signs of a fake store.
No imprint:
Every online store in the EU must have an imprint.
If the legal notice is missing, it is a sign of a dubious online store.
However, the fraudsters know this too.
Therefore, make sure that the imprint includes the following: Address, representative, e-mail address, reference to the commercial register.
If these criteria are met, it is highly likely that you are dealing with a reputable store.
Missing GTC (General Terms and Conditions) and termination conditions
GTCs are pre-formulated contractual terms and conditions.
So these are rules that apply to every purchase from this online store.
If you cannot find any terms and conditions on the site, then you should be careful with this online store.
A reputable online store will provide information about the terms of termination.
You have a right of withdrawal with every purchase.
Insecure payment methods
Normally the rule is: first the goods, then the payment.
However, many stores also offer prepayment.
Prepayment means: You transfer the money before the goods are dispatched.
Many payment methods are offered?
But in the last step you can only select "Prepayment" as the payment method?
Then be careful!
False quality seals
Many fake stores use quality seals to gain the trust of potential customers.
Do you see a quality seal on an online store?
Then click on it.
If the quality seal is not linked to the corresponding website, then it is probably a fake.
Missing or only positive customer reviews
Customer reviews on the online store's website are not always meaningful.
Often only positive reviews are published.
The bad ratings will be deleted.
You can also search for customer reviews on other platforms.
No encrypted connection
Make sure that the online store has an encrypted connection.
Especially if you have to enter your data or bank details.
Insufficient product descriptions
Does the product description match the goods or services offered?
If not, it could be a fake store.
Shortcomings in the offer
You should be informed about delivery times and shipping costs before making a purchase.
Be careful if this is not the case.
Lack of contact options
Avoid online stores that only offer an e-mail address or a chargeable telephone number as a contact option.
You can easily check whether an online store is reputable with the Fake Shop Finder from the consumer advice center: Fake Shop Finder.
Tips for safe online shopping
Be careful when entering your data.
Of course, the online store needs your name and address for delivery.
But sometimes other things are also asked.
Think about whether you really want to specify them.
Choose online stores wisely.
Pay attention to the criteria listed above.
Compare the prices with offers in the store.
Not everything is cheaper on the Internet.
Pay attention to the total price: Is the price shown really the final purchase price (including taxes, customs duties and shipping costs)?
Contact customer service if you are unsure about anything.
Read the experiences and reviews of other customers.
Check again before you place the order: Which products are in your shopping cart?
How high are the delivery costs?
Are additional taxes due if the product comes from outside the EU?
Print out your order or purchase contract, the product description and the terms and conditions and cancellation policy or save them on your computer.
This means that the online retailer cannot change anything afterwards.
Here you will find further information on safe shopping on the Internet in German and English (including an explanatory video in German).

question: Who can receive support from the Office for Youth and Family Affairs?
context:
Support from the Office for Youth and Family
The Office for Youth and Family (Youth Welfare Office) supports parents and their children
The Youth and Family Office (Jugendamt) supports parents and guardians in the upbringing, care and education of children and young people.
It focuses on preventative, family-supporting services that help to create positive living conditions for families.
It is the point of contact for all related questions, uncertainties and problems.
Better too early than too late!
If you have any questions, don't hesitate to contact the staff at the Office for Youth and Family Affairs.
The specialists there will be happy to help you and only want the best for you and your family!
The task of the Youth and Family Office is also to protect children and young people.
Because they have a right to grow up in a safe and healthy environment (see the information "Children have rights too").
The employees therefore follow up on all indications that a child could be in danger.
The Office for Youth and Family thus fulfills the tasks of the Child and Youth Welfare Act.
You can find questions and answers on child and youth welfare in German and English at www.bmfsfj.de (search term "Fragen und Antworten Kinder- und Jugendhilfe").
Who can contact the Youth Welfare Office?
Parents
Children and young people
People who notice that a child or family needs support
What issues can I contact the youth welfare office about?
Advice and support right from the start
Adoption and foster care
Paternity, maintenance and parental custody
Family education - "Parenting made easy"
Advice and support in certain life situations
Questions about education
Separation and divorce
Juveniles in criminal proceedings
Financial support
Offers for young people
Legal advice for young people
Special topics and tasks
Child and youth protection
You can find more information here.

The social service supports children, young people, young adults and adults with advice, information and help.

question: Where can I find information about "learning German" and advice in Ukrainian and Russian?
context:
German courses
Integration courses
Adult refugees from Ukraine have the opportunity to take part in an integration course free of charge.
A certificate of eligibility is required to take part in an integration course.
You can get the certificate of eligibility either from the Jobcenter or from the BAMF.
Certificate of eligibility from the Jobcenter
Anyone who is registered with the Jobcenter and receives benefits (AlgII) has been obliged by the Jobcenter to attend an integration course since July.
This means that the Jobcenter sends you the certificate of eligibility.
You can use this to register for a German course at a language school.
Anyone who is registered with the Jobcenter and is obliged to attend an integration course must register for a German course.
You can find out which language schools offer integration courses and when new courses start on an overview list, which is updated monthly for the district and city of Augsburg.
The current list can be found on the website of the District Office here under "Downloads" under "Integration courses".
Authorization certificate from the BAMF
You can apply for the authorization certificate at the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF).
As soon as the refugees have received a fictitious certificate (= temporary residence permit from the foreigners authority) or their residence title, they can submit a voluntary application for admission to the integration course to the BAMF.
You can find the application form on the BAMF website here.
Step 1: Fill out the application for admission to the integration course:
Enter personal data

Reasons: German needed to live and work in Germany"
Signature of the applicant
"I apply for exemption from the cost contribution for the integration course: I am
financially needy for other reasons" (proof is not required).
be settled, as refugees from Ukraine with the admission
automatically exempt from the cost contribution obligation and thus the course
free of charge).
Signature of the applicant
Step 2: Make a copy of the ID card
Make a copy of the fictitious certificate or residence permit and send it to the
Enclose application
Step 3: Submit application
The completed application together with a copy of the ID card
to the following address:
Federal Office for Migration and Refugees,
Streitfeldstr.
39
Step 4: Wait for an answer from the BAMF
As soon as the BAMF has processed the application, you will receive the
Authorization certificate sent to you.
Step 5: Find a language school and register
With the authorization certificate from the BAMF, you can register with a
Register for an integration course at a language school.
Which language schools offer integration courses and when new courses
can be found on an overview list that is published monthly for the district of
and the city of Augsburg.
The current list can be found on the website of the District Office here under "Downloads" under "Integration courses".
You can also find more information about the integration course on the BAMF website here.
You can find help with the application process and other questions on the subject at the language advice centers at the Augsburg District Office.
And finally, a tip: Until you receive your residence permit and then, in a second step, the certificate of eligibility for an integration course from the BAMF, you may be able to bridge the gap with free online courses.

question: How long can holders of a valid Schengen visa stay in the Schengen area?
context:
Visitor visa (Schengen visa)
Visitor visa (Schengen visa)
Holders of a valid Schengen visa (text on the visa label: "valid for Schengen states" in the language of the issuing state) may stay in the entire Schengen area for a period of 180 days up to 90 days.
Here you can get more information (also in English)
Please note that you must leave the country within the period of validity of your visa.
You must leave the Schengen area to do this.
A Schengen visa that has not been issued by the embassy for three months can be extended in Germany.
However, the requirements for this must still be met.
It is not possible to change the purpose of the visa.
The application must be justified.
These can be reasons:
force majeure,
humanitarian, professional or serious personal reasons.
If you do not have your visa extended by the foreigners authority and only leave the country after your visa has expired, you are breaking the law.
The foreigners authority will then check whether your stay must be terminated.
Re-entry would only be possible if there is no re-entry ban.
There may also be criminal proceedings in court.

question: Where can I request a certified translation?
context:
Professional interpreting and translation by specialists
You don't speak German very well yet?
Then an interpreter can help you in appointments.
For example, at the immigration office or the education authority.
But also at parents' evenings at school or kindergarten.
Some authorities and institutions will provide you with an interpreter free of charge.
Ask when you make an appointment.
Interpreting is not free of charge at some authorities and institutions.
Then you must bring your own interpreter.
And also pay for them.
Who can interpret and translate for you?
Interpreters and interpreters:
Interpreters speak several languages.
They translate from the source language into the target language and vice versa.
Language and cultural mediators:
People with a migration background work in language and cultural mediation.
They were specially trained.
These people do not only communicate linguistically.
But also between cultures.
They ensure that no misunderstandings arise due to cultural differences.
Augsburg interpreter pools
When looking for an interpreter, you can use the Augsburg interpreter pools:
Babel" interpreter pool
Mon - Fri from 10.00 am - 1.00 pm
babel@assyrer-augsburg.de

Oberbürgermeister-Dreifuß-Str.
eb@diakonie-augsburg.de
"SprInt" (language and integration mediator)
Anne Pawletta
Wertachstr.
anne.pawletta@tuerantuer.de
You can find more detailed information on all interpreter pools at www.tuerantuer.de/sprach-und-kulturmittlung.
Have documents translated
In Germany, official documents may only be translated by state-certified translators.
For example:
Certificates
Marriage certificates
Birth certificates
These translations can be expensive.
It is best to check carefully beforehand whether you really need such a certified translation.
If you need a certified translation, you can contact the Augsburg interpreter pools.
They will find you a qualified translator.

question: Approximately how many people live in the district of Augsburg?
context:
The district of Augsburg
What is a district?
A district is an association of several towns, markets or municipalities.
A total of 46 towns, markets and municipalities belong to the district of Augsburg.
The district of Augsburg
The district of Augsburg is an attractive place to live and work.
This is why more and more people are moving to the district.
A little more than 250,000 people now live here.
This makes the district of Augsburg the third largest district in Bavaria.
The district of Augsburg is very popular with companies, investors and start-ups.
For example because of
the central location between Munich and Stuttgart
its proximity to the city of Augsburg
ideal transport connections.
The district of Augsburg combines an attractive economic area with an excellent quality of life.
Here you can enjoy pure joie de vivre in a wonderful natural and cultural landscape.
City or country?
The district of Augsburg surrounds the city of Augsburg from the north, west and south.
Nevertheless, the city of Augsburg and the district of Augsburg are two independent municipalities.
The city and state of Augsburg work closely together in many areas.
Together with the district of Aichach-Friedberg, the district and the city of Augsburg form the A3 region: www.region-a3.com.

question: What are the consequences of non-compliance with compulsory education?
context:
Bavarian school system and compulsory education
The Bavarian school system enables every child to follow an individual educational path.
Various qualifications can be obtained at all schools.
With every school-leaving qualification achieved, the path to the next higher qualification is open.
The Bavarian education and school system is in part different to that of other federal states.
There is an explanatory film in German and English about the school system in Bavaria.
The following overview should make it easier for you to find your way around.
They are available in these languages:
English
Spanish
Arabic
French
Italian
Czech
Ukrainian
Turkish
Russian
(Source: Bavarian State Ministry for Education and Culture)
Compulsory schooling
Schooling is compulsory for every child from the age of six.
Compulsory schooling in Bavaria lasts twelve years.
Compulsory schooling is divided into the
Compulsory full-time schooling (nine years) and
Compulsory vocational school (three years).
Compulsory schooling ends with the completion of vocational training or on reaching the age of 21.
age.
If compulsory school attendance is not observed, consequences (e.g.
e.g. fines).

Bavarian school system and compulsory education
The Bavarian school system enables every child to follow an individual educational path.
Various qualifications can be obtained at all schools.
With every school-leaving qualification achieved, the path to the next higher qualification is open.
The Bavarian education and school system is in part different to that of other federal states.

question: What minimum contract term do I often have to adhere to?
context:
Internet, TV and broadcasting license fee (GEZ)
Internet and TV
You are free to choose your provider.
You often have to adhere to a minimum contract term of 24 months with your old provider.
Termination is only possible in special cases.
Broadcasting fee (GEZ) - compulsory
In Germany, every household has to pay broadcasting fees.
This finances public broadcasting media in Germany.
Some people may be exempt from this fee obligation.
For example, if you receive social benefits or have other reasons for exemption.
More information (also in other languages) is available here: www.rundfunkbeitrag.de/welcome/index_ger.html
Information for asylum seekers
You have no legal right to television (TV) in your asylum accommodation.
This means that there does not have to be a television in the accommodation.
Maybe you have a television.
You may then be sent an invoice for the broadcasting fee.
If you receive an invoice: Show it to your accommodation provider.

question: What do you share in a shared flat?
context:
Shared flats (WGs)
In a shared flat, people live together who are usually not a family.
You can live with friends or strangers in a shared flat.
If you are looking for an apartment for yourself, a shared flat can be a good alternative to an apartment of your own.
Living in a shared flat means that you share an apartment with other people.
Each flatmate has their own room.
You only share communal areas such as the bathroom, kitchen or living room.
You save money if you live in a shared flat.
You share the rent in a shared flat.
The best way to find free rooms in shared flats is either on the website "WG-gesucht" ( www.wg-gesucht.de ) or on the corresponding Facebook pages or
Groups such as "WG & apartment Augsburg wanted".
For refugees, there is a special platform called "Zusammenleben Willkommen" (Living Together Welcome) for finding a shared flat and with some explanations and insights into life in a shared flat.

question: What language level is required to study in Germany?
context:
The German higher education system and helpful links
Would you like to study in Germany?
Then you need the school-leaving certificate "Abitur" or "Fachabitur".
Do you have a university admission from your home country?
Then you can also study in Germany.
You must have your university admission from your home country recognized.
You can find the information here.
You need language level C1 to study.
Types of universities
There are different types of universities in Germany.
The universities lead to various degrees and career paths:
Universities
They have a strong scientific orientation.
If you would also like to obtain a doctorate, a university is suitable for you.
Universities of Applied Sciences
They are very practice-oriented.
Art, film and music academies
At these universities, the focus is on artistic subjects such as fine arts, drama, graphics, singing or modern media.
All universities offer Bachelor's and Master's degree programs.
There are state and private universities:
Most universities in Germany are financed by the state.
They are state-owned.
Private universities are independent of the state.
Some of them charge high tuition fees.
University and colleges in Augsburg
University (www.uni-augsburg.de)
University of Applied Sciences (www.hs-augsburg.de/international)
Private University of Applied Sciences for Economics and Management (short: FOM) for professionals (www.fom.de/hochschulzentren/augsburg)
Advice for prospective students
Are you interested in studying in Germany?
Then there are offices and agencies that can help you.
In Germany, these advice centers are called either "Akademisches Auslandsamt" or "International Office".
There you will receive advice on all questions relating to your studies.
These offices also organize many intercultural activities.
This makes it easier for you to get to know German and other foreign students in Augsburg.
Interesting links about studying in Germany
You can find general information about studying in Germany here: www.daad.de/de/ (also in English)
www.study-in-germany.de (in German and English)
Free preparatory course for university studies in Germany: Ready for Study
Free online university for refugees: KironOpenHigher Education

question: What financial support can families receive?
context:
Cash benefits for families
Gain an overview
Families can receive financial support.
In addition to direct cash benefits such as parental or child benefit, families will also benefit from tax relief.
You can find out about cash benefits and tax advantages at www.familienportal.de.
This information tool also offers help: www.infotool-familie.de.

In Augsburg there is a Family Fund Service Point for families.
Here you will find all the important information about many family policy services:
Child benefit
Child supplement or child bonus
Parental allowance
Parental allowance plus
Family allowance
Crèche allowance
You can find all further information about the offer here.
Financial help through the education and participation package
Would your child like to take part in sports, games or culture?
Would your child like to go on a school or daycare excursion?
Would your child like to eat lunch with the other children?
Or does it need help with learning or new things for school?
The education and participation package helps families who don't have that much money.
Your contact person in the district of Augsburg:
Thomas Geldhauser
Thomas.

question: How can you report dangerous spots on cycle paths?
context:
In nature
In the Nature Park - Western Forests
The Western Forests Nature Park is the only nature park in Central Swabia.
It is a valuable recreational area for people from the city and district of Augsburg.
You can enjoy nature on hikes and bike tours.
The adventure trails provide lots of information about native plants.
You can find more details at www.naturpark-augsburg.de.
Lakes in the district of Augsburg - recreation and swimming fun
Whether in winter or summer: the lakes in the Augsburg region guarantee a welcome change from everyday life.
From a simple walk to a relaxing sunbath to sports activities such as diving or beach volleyball - there's something for everyone here!
Our lakes: Badesee Kühlenthal, Ilsesee Königsbrunn, Badesee Gablingen, Rothsee Zusmarshausen
Cycle paths in the district of Augsburg - Explore the district by bike
Enjoying nature, exploring the countryside and exercising in the fresh air?
What better way to do this than by bike!
The district of Augsburg therefore has a well-developed network of cycle paths.
Whether you are a family outing, an everyday cyclist or a top athlete - there is a suitable cycle route for everyone here.
So get on your bike and discover the district!
More information at: www.landkreis-augsburg.de/radwege.
For people who enjoy cycling, the Augsburg district cycling officer is open to requests, ideas and criticism.
Cycling officer
Jonas Fricke
radverkehr@LRA-a.bayern.de
Have you discovered a disturbing or dangerous spot on the cycle path?
With the RADar reporting platform, you can easily report annoying or dangerous spots.
Help the district of Augsburg to make the cycle paths safer.
At www.landkreis-augsburg.de/radar or via the free "RADar!" app.
Leisure tips in the great outdoors
Bonstetten land art trail - art meets nature
For art lovers, the land art trail designed by Hama Lohrmann with nine stations around Bonstetten offers a special approach to the theme of transience.
The starting point is the first station in the town center.
The signposted path then leads over an approx.
six-kilometer circuit through the adjacent western forests.
Land Art Trail Bonstetten
www.kunstpfad-bonstetten.de/
Perennial meditation path - time for peace and contemplation
Beautiful scenery, peace and quiet, time for yourself - that's what the meditation trail in the Augsburg - Western Forests Nature Park offers.
Nine stations with meditation exercises from various religions promise relaxation.
The route extends via Fischach, Langenneufnach, Walkertshofen, Mittelneufnach to the district of Unterallgäu.
On foot or by bike: relaxation is guaranteed!
Bonstetten Geological Trail - The history of the Staufenberg
Do you know why there are so many lakes in the foothills of the Alps?
No?
Then visit the geological nature trail in Bonstetten!
The nature trail is located on the Staufenberg and is 4.5 kilometers long.
The history of the landscape's formation during the cold and warm periods is vividly described with the help of six information boards.
The circular route begins in the center of Bonstetten: www.bonstetten.de/index.php/geologischer-lehrpfad
Deuringer Heide culture and nature trail - nature and puzzle fun
A varied puzzle and information trail provides entertaining information about the flora and fauna of the Deuringer Heath.
The circular trail with ten different stations can either be discovered independently or as part of a guided tour.
Deuringer Heide culture and nature trail
www.eva-augsburg.de/?mp=lehrpfade
Barbecue areas in the district of Augsburg and the region
The smell of grilled meat or crispy vegetables on a hot grill is simply part of summer.
For all barbecue fans without a garden, there are signposted public barbecue areas.
You can find an overview here.
For the sake of the environment, please take your garbage back with you.

question: What does confidentiality mean in an internship?
context:
Rights and obligations during an internship
Internship contract
No internship contract is required.
But it's good to have an internship contract.
This is because the regulations for the internship are laid down there.
Working hours
Depending on age, there are different regulations on working hours during internships:
Under 15 years of age: Work is generally prohibited.
This does not apply to internships for school pupils, for example.
Adolescents aged 13 and over may also carry out light activities (e.g.
e.g. tutoring, delivering newspapers).
Young people under the age of 15 are under special protection: they may work a maximum of 7 hours per day and a maximum of 35 hours per week.
Between the ages of 15 and 18: Young people of this age may work a maximum of 8 hours per day and a maximum of 40 hours per week.
Over 18 years: The regular working time of 8 hours per day should apply.
However, regular means that there may be exceptions.
If there is a lot to do, interns are allowed to work more than 8 hours.
A maximum of 10 hours may be worked per day.
Breaks
People on internships may and must also take breaks.
Age also plays a role in the break times:
Under 18 years of age: If you work between 4.5 and 6 hours, you must take a 30-minute break.
For more than 6 hours even 60 minutes.
Over 18 years: If you work for more than 6 hours, you must take a 30-minute break.
For working hours of more than 9 hours, even 45 minutes.
Duty of confidentiality
Interns learn a lot about the company during their internship.
Much of the information is confidential.
This means that interns are not allowed to pass on this information.
This is called "confidentiality".
For example:
One person is doing an internship in a doctor's surgery.
She learns a lot about the patients there.
For example, the names and illnesses of the patients.
She must not disclose this information to anyone.
Illness
In the event of illness, the intern must inform the internship company immediately.
Interns often need a medical certificate from a doctor.
It is best to ask the internship company whether a certificate is required.
Vacation
There is no entitlement to vacation during a mandatory internship.
It is possible to take vacation during a voluntary internship.
But only if the internship lasts more than 4 weeks.
The vacation days depend on the age of the intern and the duration of the internship.
Behavior in the workplace
Interns mean time and work for the internship company.
Interns should be aware of this.
Interns should therefore behave accordingly.
You can find tips on this under "Ten tips for interns".
Entitlement to an internship certificate
Interns are entitled to an internship certificate.
This means that the company or business must issue an internship certificate.
The internship certificate is important for the intern.
It helps later when applying for an apprenticeship or job.
It describes which activities the intern has carried out.
Sometimes the assessment of your performance during the internship is also included in the certificate.

question: What do the abbreviations LGBTQIA+ and LGBTTIQ mean?
context:
Freely selectable gender identity / LGBTQIA+
Gender diversity
Sexual orientation is a central aspect of one's personality.
In Germany, every person is allowed to choose their own sexual identity.
Every person is free to decide who they are with and who they love.
And every person is free to live out their own sexual orientation.
Because this is an important right, it is enshrined in law (General Equal Treatment Act).
In Germany, a great deal of effort is being made to break down rigid role models and open up the view to all ways of life.
A lot has therefore happened in recent years:
Regardless of whether gender reassignment from male to female or from female to male has taken place or is planned.
What does LGBTQIA+ or LGBT mean?
LGBTQIA+ or
LGBT are abbreviations from the English language.
In German, the abbreviation LSBTTIQ is often used, which stands for the following terms:
L=lesbian - S=gay - B=bisexual - T=transgender - T=transsexual - I=intersexual - Q=queer.
Lesbians are women who love other women.
Gays are men who love other men.
Bisexuals fall in love with people, regardless of gender.
Transgender people are women who were born in a male body or men who were born in a female body.
Like transgender people, transsexuals are born in the "wrong body" and change their appearance through hormones and operations.
Intersex people have both male and female genitals.
People with an asexual orientation have little or no interest in sexual activity.
Queer stands for everything that deviates from traditional gender roles and partner models.
The "+" in LGBTQIA+ means that there are even more sexual or gender identities.
Support
You will also find acceptance and support in the district of Augsburg.
There are associations that look after the LGBTIQ* scene.
In general, this is about:
Equal rights and equal treatment
Fight against discrimination and misanthropy
Educating the LGBTIQ* scene
Contact points
Advice and support for under 27-year-olds can be found with the employees of "In & Out".
More information at: https://gladt.de/
In the city of Augsburg, there are the following organizations and associations that look after the LGBTQIA+ scene.
They are primarily concerned with equal rights and equal treatment, the fight against discrimination and misanthropy as well as educating the LGBTQIA+ scene.
Queerbeet Augsburg e.V.
Queerbeet Augsburg e.V. is a group for LGBTQIA+ young people aged 14 to 27 in Augsburg and the surrounding area.
They organize group evenings, school projects and other activities and are contact persons for LGBTQIA+ issues.
More information at: www.queerbeet-augsburg.de
CSD Augsburg - Christopher Street Day Augsburg e.V.
The Christopher Street Day Augsburg association organizes the well-known CSD in Augsburg, as well as other events such as IDAHIT*.
They are particularly committed to the interests of queer people.
More information at: www.csd-augsburg.de
Queer Christians Augsburg
The queer Christians Augsburg are a group of bi-, trans-, asexual, lesbian and gay Christians of all ages.
The group meets once a month (Fridays 19:00).
The dates can be found at: https://qcaux.de/termine/.
The group is open to all queer people who are interested in the Christian faith or are searching for it.
More information at: https://qcaux.de/
Café Queer at Moritzpunkt
The Café Queer is open every 1st Tuesday of the month at 19:00.
Cultural events and discussions on current socio-political topics take place here.
Everyone who wants to meet in a friendly and open atmosphere is welcome.
More information at: https://qcaux.de/cafe/

question: What forms of daycare are available?
context:
Forms of childcare
There are different forms of daycare for children in Germany depending on their age:
Crèches for children under the age of three
Kindergartens for children from three years to school age
Houses for children aged one to twelve (daycare center with mixed age groups)
After-school care for children from school attendance up to the age of 14.
Year of life
Another option is child day care.
In this form, your child is looked after by a qualified and certified childminder (also known as a "childminder").
This care usually takes place at the person's home.
The district of Augsburg, child day care department, helps with the search for a day carer.
Child day care center
Petra Hetzner
petra.hetzner@LRA-a.bayern.de
You can find more information on the website of the district of Augsburg.
Looking for childcare?
Are you looking for childcare for your child?
Your child is already being looked after, but you have further questions?
Then contact our specialist department at the Augsburg District Office:
Child day care and day care center
Petra Hetzner
petra.hetzner@LRA-a.bayern.de
Childcare in your community
Would you like to know? What childcare is available in my community?
Then take a look at the education portal a3 (www.bildungsportal-a3.de) under "Bildungsorte".

question: What does the "Sprengelprinzip" mean?
context:
Elementary school
Duration: 4 years
Aim: The children learn...
Read
Writing
Basic knowledge of mathematics
There are currently 46 state elementary school in the district of Augsburg.
After elementary school
The children then go on to secondary school.
There are three different "secondary schools, which lead to different qualifications: Mittelschule, Realschule or Gymnasium.
The district of Augsburg also has a wide range of these schools: 15 secondary schools, six intermediate schools and five grammar schools.
Good to know
When choosing a primary and secondary school, the "Sprengelprinzip" must be observed.
This means that each primary or secondary school is responsible for a specific area (called a "Sprengel").
Children must therefore attend a particular school.
Would you like your child to go to a different primary or secondary school?
Then you must submit a guest school application.
You must give good reasons for your wish to go to another school.
You can find detailed information with a school search at www.km.bayern.de/eltern/schulsuche.html.

question: What are the benefits of saving energy?
context:
Save energy
How and where can energy be saved?
Saving energy means achieving the desired "performance" with less final energy (electricity, fuels and combustibles).
But it also means simply doing without something for once.
We can save energy everywhere: in the home, in industry and commerce and in transportation.
This will pay off sooner or later through the energy costs saved.
This brings double benefits: for the environment and for your wallet.
This checklist tells you how you can save money by using as little electricity and hot water as possible.
To prevent mold from forming in your home, it is important to heat and ventilate properly.
The checklist is available in German, English, Arabic, Kurdish and Dari.

question: Which age group is particularly affected by meningococcal disease?
context:
Further STIKO vaccination recommendations
1. tBE (tick-borne encephalitis)
TBE is transmitted via tick bites.
Possible consequences of the disease are inflammation of the brain, the meninges and the spinal cord.
Bavaria, Baden-Württemberg and southern parts of Hesse, Thuringia and Saxony in particular are considered risk areas in Germany.
Vaccination against TBE is recommended by the STIKO in these areas in particular.
All children can be vaccinated against TBE from their 1st birthday.
2. flu (influenza)
Influenza is as contagious as a normal cold (flu-like infection).
Transmission in kindergartens and schools usually occurs from child to child.
Or about objects.
Children with pre-existing conditions are particularly affected.
They can lead to complications such as pneumonia.
The recommendation for an annual flu vaccination is therefore only aimed at children with a higher risk of complications.
You can find further information on the pre-existing conditions concerned here.
3. HPV (human papillomavirus)
Papillomaviruses can cause cancer in the long term.
Vaccination can therefore reduce the risk of cancer of the cervix, anus, penis and throat.
Vaccination before the first sexual contact offers the best protection.
Both vaccinations are recommended between the ages of 9 and 14.
4. meningococci
Meningococci are bacteria that can cause bacterial meningitis or blood poisoning (sepsis).
Children under the age of 5 and adolescents in particular are among the risk groups.
Vaccination against meningococcal type C is recommended at the age of 12 months.
There is currently no general recommendation for vaccinations against other types (B and ACWY).
The bacteria are transmitted via the so-called
Droplet infection.
This means, for example, coughing, sneezing or kissing.
5. pneumococci
Pneumococcus is the most common pathogen causing serious bacterial infections.
They can cause meningitis, pneumonia or middle ear infections.
They are particularly dangerous for babies and small children.
Three vaccinations against pneumococci are recommended.
These should be administered at the same time as the vaccination against tetanus, diphtheria and whooping cough.
6. rotaviruses
Rotaviruses are the most common cause of diarrhea and vomiting in children.
The pathogen is very contagious.
This is why almost all children contract the disease in the first five years - usually at the age of 2.
In infants in particular, a large loss of fluids and salt can lead to dangerous dehydration.
This may have to be
be treated in hospital.
Vaccination against rotaviruses is given two or three times, depending on the vaccine.
The first vaccination should be given between 6 weeks and 2 months of age.
The second vaccination at 3 months.
And the third, if necessary, at 4 months.
Vaccination against the coronavirus is currently only recommended for children aged 5 to 11 years with the "Comirnaty" vaccine from BioNTech/Pfizer.
Vaccinations can be given three to six weeks apart between the first and second vaccination.
The vaccination recommendation is primarily aimed at children who have an increased risk of a severe course due to a previous illness.
In addition, the recommendation also applies to children who are surrounded by people with a high risk of severe COVID-19 if they cannot be vaccinated themselves or the vaccination protection is not sufficient.
There is currently no recommendation for children without pre-existing illnesses or pre-existing illnesses of close contacts.
Nevertheless, it is possible to have your child vaccinated after consulting a doctor.
Further information on the pre-existing conditions concerned can be found at:
https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/impfen/kinder/corona-schutzimpfung-ab-5-jahren/
Further information on the vaccination recommendations mentioned here.

question: What is the "certificate of eligibility" for the integration course?
context:
Integration courses for adults
What is an integration course?
The Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) offers integration courses.
In an integration course you will learn German and many things about Germany.
For example on topics such as...
Work and profession
Training and further education
Care and education of children
Shopping
Living
Rights and duties in Germany
How can I do an integration course?
When do I have to attend the integration course?
Voluntary visit: authorization certificate required
Would you like to attend the course voluntarily?
Then you need a permit from the BAMF, a so-called "Berechtigungsschein".
With this authorization certificate, you can register for an integration course at a language school.
Whether or not you receive a certificate of eligibility depends on your residence status.
You can get help with this from the "Learn German" advice service.
The consultation can also help with the application for the certificate of eligibility.
Commitment from the Office for Foreigners and Integration
Some people are required to attend an integration course by the Office for Foreigners and Integration.
This means that you must attend the integration course.
Important information at a glance
- The general integration course lasts several months and takes place full-time or part-time (e.g. for working people).
- It consists of a language course with 600 teaching units (short: UE = 45 minutes) and an orientation course on life in Germany with 100 UE.
- The aim is to achieve language level B1 on completion of the course.
You will then receive a certificate.
- The certificate is important.
For example, if you are looking for work or want to do an apprenticeship.
The certificate can also be important if you want to stay in Germany permanently and need a permanent residence permit.
- There are also special integration courses for certain groups of people.
For example, for women (with childcare), working people or people who cannot read and write.
- Participants with a BAMF authorization certificate pay 220 euros per module (=100 hours).
They can get 50% of this back if they successfully complete the course within two years.
- Participants without a BAMF authorization certificate pay 440 euros per module (=100 hours).
-The course is free of charge for recipients of social benefits.
You will be exempted from the costs upon request.
Necessary travel costs can also be reimbursed.
The language advice centers offer individual advice on this.
You can also find more information here.
Language schools (also known as course providers) that offer integration courses in Augsburg and the surrounding area:
ADK Augsburg German Courses
Vocational Training Center (BBZ) Augsburg gGmbH
Vocational Training Centers of the Bavarian Economy (bfz) gGmbH Augsburg
BIB Augsburg
Caesar Language & Education Institute
DAA - German Employees Academy Augsburg GmbH
Kolping Academy Augsburg
Languages Prisma GbR
Böhm Language Center
Language Forum International German Courses
Alterlingua Language Institute
Sprachinstitut Pittner
vhs - Volkshochschule Augsburg e.V.
vhs - Volkshochschule Augsburger Land e.V.
You can find an overview of the current integration courses in Augsburg and the surrounding area on the district's website under "Downloads" (on the right-hand side: "1) Current integration courses").
You can also find local integration courses on the BAMF website here.
Integration courses for the hearing impaired
The Heesch language school in Munich offers integration courses up to level B1 for the hearing impaired.
The BBW Munich has a BIK class for hearing-impaired immigrants.

question: What kind of educational and advisory services are presented on the A3 education portal?
context:
Education portal A3
Would you like to continue your professional training and are looking for a suitable offer?
Are you looking for a language course and don't know where?
Would you like to attend a yoga class?
Or do you want to do further training to become a business administrator?
Or are you wondering: Where are there libraries in the district?
Or kindergartens?
Then the A3 education portal is the right place for you!
What is the A3 education portal?
The A3 education portal is a joint project of the city of Augsburg, the district of Augsburg and the district of Aichach-Friedberg.
The portal presents all educational and advisory services in the region.
There is also a lot of up-to-date information on the subject of education and further training.
What can I find on the A3 education portal?
Course search: Search for the right course for you.
Counseling services: There is a counseling service in the region for almost all life issues.
You can find the right course for you via the education portal.
Providers: There are many training providers in the region.
On the portal you can get an overview and search specifically for providers.
Funding: The portal provides information on the possibilities of financial support for your professional development.
Dates: You can find regional events relating to education and further training on the education portal.
Where can I find the A3 education portal?
Click on this link:
www.bildungsportal-a3.de

question: What do employers say about vocational training in Germany?
context:
Vocational training
In Germany, you have a better chance of getting a job if you have the right training.
There are professions for which a degree is necessary.
Other professions can be learned in a vocational training program.
Germany has a very good vocational training system.
Vocational training is worth a lot in Germany.
Many employers are looking for people who have vocational training.
Those who complete an apprenticeship therefore have a very good chance of finding a job.
There are two different types of vocational training: dual training and school-based training.

question: Who can offer support if you disagree with the rejection?
context:
Decision of the BAMF
Decision on the asylum application
After the personal interview, the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees checks all descriptions, information and evidence.
It is checked whether one of the four forms of protection exists on the basis of the Asylum Act:
Eligibility for asylum
Refugee protection
subsidiary protection
Ban on deportation
The asylum application will only be rejected if none of these forms of protection can be recognized.
The decision will be justified in writing and sent as a "notification" to
the applicant, or
to persons who have been authorized in these proceedings (lawyers).
the responsible foreigners authority.
The decision is negative
If your asylum application is rejected, you will receive a negative decision and a deportation warning.
Deportation threat means: You will be asked to leave the Federal Republic of Germany by a certain date.
If you do not leave the country by this date, you may be forcibly deported.
There are two different types of rejection:
simple refusal: you must leave the country within 30 days.
Rejection as "manifestly unfounded": In this case, the deadline for leaving the country is only one week.
Contestation
If you do not agree with the rejection, you can take legal action against the decision in both cases.
This must be done very quickly after receiving the decision.
Therefore, go immediately to the integration and refugee counseling service in your accommodation.
You will receive support there.
You should always seek advice and representation from a specialist lawyer for asylum and residence law if you wish to take legal action.
You will be informed of all deadlines and legal options in the written notification: This information is referred to as "information on legal remedies".
Voluntary departure
If you decide to leave voluntarily, you can receive financial support for a new start in your country of origin.
You can get advice on voluntary departure here:
Central Return Counseling South Bavaria
info@zrb-suedbayern.de
www.zrb-suedbayern.de/
Inform the immigration office as soon as possible that you wish to leave the country voluntarily.
The decision is positive
You are recognized as entitled to protection.
The next steps are:
Fictitious certificate or
Electronic residence permit (eAT): Immediately after the positive BAMF decision has been delivered, you must apply for an identity document or residence permit.
take care of an equivalent.
You can obtain this from the Office for Immigration and Integration.
You are now allowed to work in Germany without restrictions.
If you don't have a job and are dependent on support, you will no longer receive the money from the social welfare office.
You must submit an application to the Jobcenter.

question: What qualifications does attending a special school offer?
context:
Secondary schools
Middle school
Duration:five to six years
Goal: Preparation for an apprenticeship or profession
Degrees:
Qualifying secondary school certificate (Quali)
Secondary school certificate
Secondary school leaving certificate (for high-achieving students by attending the M branch)
Secondary schools in the district of Augsburg: 15 secondary schools.
Good to know:
When choosing a primary or secondary school, you must observe the "Sprengelprinzip".
This means that each primary or secondary school is responsible for a specific area (called a "Sprengel").
Children must then attend a specific school.
Would you like your child to go to a different primary or secondary school?
Then you must submit a guest school application.
You must give good reasons for your wish to go to another school.
You can find detailed information with a school search at www.km.bayern.de/eltern/schulsuche.html.
Secondary school
Duration:six years
Goal: Preparation for an apprenticeship in all kinds of professions or transfer to a technical secondary school (FOS)
Qualification: Secondary school leaving certificate / intermediate school leaving certificate
Secondary schools in the district of Augsburg: six secondary schools.
Grammar school
Duration:eight to nine years
Goal: Preparation for university studies
Degree: General higher education entrance qualification (Abitur;
Authorization to study at universities and colleges)
Grammar schools in the district of Augsburg:five grammar schools
Support centers and special schools
Duration: Special schools are available for all ages
Goal: Individual support and encouragement for children with special educational needs (e.g.
e.g. severe learning difficulties, delayed development, disabilities)
Degrees:
Secondary school certificate
Qualifying secondary school certificate (Quali)
Support centers and special schools in the district of Augsburg: three state and two private schools.
Private schools
There are also two private schools in the district of Augsburg: an international school (grades 1-12).
grade) and a Montessori school (1st-10th grade).
class).
You can find more information here:
International School: www.isa-augsburg.com
Montessori School Dinkelscherben: www.montessoridinkelscherben.de

question: What can I get with a prescription at the pharmacy?
context:
Medicines and pharmacies
If you need medication, you will receive a prescription from your doctor.
You can get your medication with this prescription at any pharmacy.
Even with a prescription, not all medicines are free.
Ask your doctor about this.
If you don't have a prescription, you always have to pay for the medication.
Some medications, such as antibiotics, require a prescription.
This means that you cannot buy them without a prescription.
Opening hours
Pharmacies are generally open from Monday to Saturday.
Opening hours vary depending on the pharmacy (often: 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.).
On-call service
If you need medication urgently at night or at the weekend, you will find a sign at every pharmacy with the name and address of the pharmacy that is open for emergency service.
You can also find this information on the Internet at www.lak-bayern.notdienst-portal.de/blakportal/.
Pharmacy emergency service
from cell phone 22 8 33 (max.
69 cents/min.)

question: Is there an online community for German learners at C1 and C2 level?
context:
Level C1 and C2 - for experts
Learn German on the Deutsche Welle website
On the Deutsche Welle website you will find various offers for learning German.
You can...
Listen to messages that are spoken more slowly for learners.
learn how Germans live in the Deutschlandlabor.
get to know other learners in the online community.
Watch videos on various topics.
train your listening comprehension.
Read up on grammar questions.
work on many exercises.
The site is available in 30 languages.
For example: English, Arabic, Bosnian, Greek, Polish and many more.
Grammar exercises
On this free site you will find exercises on various grammar topics at C1 level.
All about the German language
On this page you will find various exercises for listening comprehension, vocabulary and reading comprehension.
You can get to know the most beautiful German words, idioms or colloquial expressions.
German forum and online community
Want to join a Whatsapp learning group?
Do you want to chat with learners from all over the world in German?
Are you looking for a learning partnership?
Then you will find what you are looking for in the online community on the Goethe-Institut website.
You will also find various German exercises at all levels, including C1.

question: What is the Bavarian family allowance and what is it paid for?
context:
Childcare costs
If you would like to have your child looked after in a facility or by a childminder, you will have to pay a fee.
The fee depends on the facility or
of the childminder, but also, for example, on your income and the weekly childcare hours.
If you have a low income, you can be exempted from the costs: www.landkreis-augsburg.de/uebernahme-kitabeitrag.
Financial relief for the care of children under the age of three
As an "indirect reduction" of the daycare center fees, all parents with children in their second and third year of life (i.
h. from 13.
up to 36.
month) the Bavarian family allowance.
You will automatically receive family allowance if you have already applied for parental allowance.
Do you have questions about the Bavarian family allowance?
Then get in touch:
Bavarian Center for Family and Social Affairs
Swabia region
poststelle.schw@zbfs.bayern.de
Financial relief for childcare from the age of three
Parents receive an allowance of 100 euros per month and per child (from September 1 of the year in which the child turns three until the child starts school).
Parents do not have to submit an application.
The kindergarten fee is automatically reduced by the daycare provider.
You can find more information here.
Costs for the care of school-age children
The school offers are free of charge.
Only small amounts of money (e.g. for lunch) have to be paid.
Extracurricular activities, on the other hand, are subject to a fee.
The costs vary depending on the facility.
Therefore, ask the institution directly.

question: Does the Jobcenter cover the rental costs?
context:
Cost absorption by the job center
Cost absorption by the job center
If you are unemployed and receive benefits from the Jobcenter, the Jobcenter pays the rent.
However, only if you are in need of help and the rent is reasonable (not too high).
Each job center sets its own upper rent limit, which can even vary within a jurisdiction (e.g.
B. Jobcenter Augsburg-Land).
Upper rent limit means: The Jobcenter sets a maximum amount for the rent.
If your rent is more expensive, you have to pay the rest yourself.
Here you can find more information about the rent cap in the district of Augsburg.
You can find the tables for the rent ceilings of the individual authorities here:
Jobcenter Augsburg City
Jobcenter Augsburg Land
What needs to be considered?
Important: If you have found an apartment and the rent is paid by the Jobcenter, you must not sign the rental agreement immediately.
The Jobcenter must check and approve the appropriateness of the accommodation costs before the contract is signed.
This is possible during regular opening hours without an appointment.
The Jobcenter's decision on appropriateness and acceptance of the deposit will be communicated immediately in a written rental confirmation.
It is important that a rental agreement or at least a rental offer with all the minimum details of the apartment is already available.
It is important to note that the tenancy agreement must already be signed by the landlord, but not by the tenant.
The following points must be included in the rental agreement:
Name and address of the landlord
Address of the rental property
Living space in m²
Number of rooms
Amount of the net cold rent
Amount of operating costs
Amount of heating costs
Total rent
Amount of the deposit
Security deposit
The Jobcenter can grant the deposit on a loan basis upon application.
Loan basis means: you are lent the money and have to pay it back.
As a rule, this is unproblematic and is approved if the accommodation costs are reasonable.
The Jobcenter usually pays the deposit directly to the landlord or tenant.
paid by the landlord.
Repayment of the loan to the Jobcenter is automatically deducted from the monthly standard benefits (normally max.
ten percent) is deducted and retained.
Initial equipment
If you receive benefits from the Jobcenter, you have the option of applying for initial furniture and furnishings.
You will be paid a lump sum according to the number of people, the size of the apartment and the equipment required.
The initial equipment includes furniture, curtains, mattresses, cooking utensils, dishes and, if not available in the apartment, stove, sink, refrigerator and washing machine.
It is important that the application is submitted before the furniture is purchased.
A list with an overview of where you can buy cheap and used furniture can be found "here.
Caution: It may take some time before the money is paid out!
In addition, the Jobcenter has the right (and uses this right) to inspect the apartment in order to check the amount of the initial equipment.
If it is determined that, for example, furniture is already present that has not been demonstrably (in writing!) borrowed (e.g.
B. emergency sleeping bed from SKM), you have no further claim to initial equipment for these items.
Info for refugees
When you move out of your accommodation, you are not allowed to take the furniture with you.
That's why you need new furniture.
You can submit an application for initial equipment to the Jobcenter.

question: When can I not apply for additional initial furniture?
context:
Cost absorption by the job center
Cost absorption by the job center
If you are unemployed and receive benefits from the Jobcenter, the Jobcenter pays the rent.
However, only if you are in need of help and the rent is reasonable (not too high).
Each job center sets its own upper rent limit, which can even vary within a jurisdiction (e.g.
B. Jobcenter Augsburg-Land).
Upper rent limit means: The Jobcenter sets a maximum amount for the rent.
If your rent is more expensive, you have to pay the rest yourself.
Here you can find more information about the rent cap in the district of Augsburg.
You can find the tables for the rent ceilings of the individual authorities here:
Jobcenter Augsburg City
Jobcenter Augsburg Land
What needs to be considered?
Important: If you have found an apartment and the rent is paid by the Jobcenter, you must not sign the rental agreement immediately.
The Jobcenter must check and approve the appropriateness of the accommodation costs before the contract is signed.
This is possible during regular opening hours without an appointment.
The Jobcenter's decision on appropriateness and acceptance of the deposit will be communicated immediately in a written rental confirmation.
It is important that a rental agreement or at least a rental offer with all the minimum details of the apartment is already available.
It is important to note that the tenancy agreement must already be signed by the landlord, but not by the tenant.
The following points must be included in the rental agreement:
Name and address of the landlord
Address of the rental property
Living space in m²
Number of rooms
Amount of the net cold rent
Amount of operating costs
Amount of heating costs
Total rent
Amount of the deposit

question: What are the three areas of the German healthcare system?
context:
The German healthcare system
German healthcare system
In Germany, many facilities are part of the healthcare system.
The healthcare system has three areas:
1. outpatient medical care by doctors and pharmacies.
"Outpatient" means that the patient goes home after treatment.
2. inpatient medical care through acute care in hospitals.
"Inpatient" means that the patient stays in hospital for treatment.
3. health protection of the population through services provided by the public health department, e.g. infection protection and preventive services.
"Preventive" means: offers to maintain health and avoid becoming ill).
The outpatient and inpatient care services provide medical treatment for sick people.
Everyone is free to choose their own doctor or facility.
The public health department ("Öffentlicher Gesundheitsdienst") fulfills many different tasks.
You can find a list here.
The public health department also fulfills preventive tasks.
For example, they provide information and advice on the subject of health.
This should enable a healthy life in the district.
The health department organizes many projects at schools.
These projects provide information on the topic of "health" in a fun way.
They explain what is important for a healthy life.
You can find more information about the health department here.
You can find offers for health promotion and prevention here.
Good to know
Hospitals treat seriously ill and life-threateningly injured people.
So they will help you in an emergency!
For minor injuries or illnesses, go to a doctor's surgery.
You will get good help there.
You may need a doctor at night or at the weekend.
But it is not always an emergency.
You can then go to the medical on-call service.
Medical on-call service
only in the evening and at weekends
116 117
Dental emergency service
only on weekends
www.notdienst-zahn.de (also in English)
Pharmacy emergency service
from cell phone: 22 8 33(max.
69 cents/min.)
The German healthcare system in 14 languages
The brochure "Health for all - A guide to the German healthcare system" contains important information in 14 languages.

question: How long is the sick note valid if an employee is ill?
context:
Illness
If you are working, doing an internship or attending a German course and are ill, you must call them and report sick.
As a rule, your doctor must certify that you are unable to work (certificate of incapacity for work)
Ask your employer or language course provider when you need to submit a certificate of incapacity for work.
If you are ill, you will receive your salary/wages for 6 weeks.
From the 7th week you will receive sickness benefit from the health insurance fund, which is 70%.
Please note: Illness is not protection against dismissal!

question: Who is entitled to minimum wage?
context:
Minimum wage
A statutory minimum wage applies in Germany.
The amount is regularly increased.
The minimum wage may not be undercut by working longer hours than contractually agreed without corresponding wage compensation.
The minimum wage does not apply to:
Young people under the age of 18 without completed vocational training
Apprentices
Long-term unemployed persons during the first six months of their employment after the end of unemployment
Interns in certain types of internships (school or study-related internships or
Internships for professional orientation up to three months)
Voluntary activities
Self-employed
You can find more information here.

question: What deadlines apply for termination in Germany?
context:
Termination
If you wish to resign as an employee, you must send your notice in writing, preferably by post, to your employer.
If you have been dismissed by your employer and want to do something about it, you only have 3 weeks to do so.
You must file a claim with the help of a lawyer or/and with the Legal Claims Office at the labor court.
The notice period for employers is normally 4 weeks to the end of a month.
The deadline for employees depends on the duration of the employment relationship.
For example, 5 years --> 2 months notice period
Probationary period maximum 6 months --> 2 weeks notice period

question: What rights and obligations do I have as a toleration permit holder in Germany?
context:
Toleration (§60a)
Duration: limited
Status: Tolerated
Background: Negative asylum decision, obligation to leave the country
A tolerated stay is a suspension of deportation and not a legal stay.
It is issued if deportation is currently impossible for legal, factual, humanitarian or personal reasons.
A work permit is generally required.
It is applied for at the foreigners authority in your place of residence.
Here, too, you must complete applications with the help of your employer.
Your social worker will help you.
The employment agency is responsible for finding work.

question: How can I save energy in my everyday life?
context:

Saving energy = saving money
Make sure that you air the room regularly (open the window fully for 5 minutes at least 3 times a day) and heat it properly.
This prevents mold from forming and saves energy and therefore money.
You can obtain detailed information and helpful tips from the consumer advice center in various languages.

Energy saving check

Households are given tips on energy-saving behavior and receive a free starter pack containing energy-saving light bulbs, sockets with an off-switch, energy-saving showers and more.

question: What is the Opportunities Residence Act?
context:
Opportunities Residence Act
Since 31.
Those who have been living in Germany for many years with a tolerated status can now obtain a permanent right of residence more quickly.
The requirements for the new right of residence are:
Possession of a tolerated stay permit
No criminal offenses
No false statements or deception about identity
Commitment to the free democratic basic order
Please note: The residence permit is only issued for 18 months.
It cannot be extended.
What happens afterwards:
Those affected receive a residence permit for 18 months.
During this time, they are given the opportunity to fulfill the requirements for a permanent right of residence in Germany.
This requires that they:
are able to secure their livelihood mainly through gainful employment,
have proof of identity,
be able to demonstrate a good command of German.
Contact us
If you have any questions about the Opportunities Residence Act, please contact the immigration office responsible for you.
Further information from the Federal Government can be found here.
Handbook Germany

question: How can I apply for a work permit with tolerated stay?
context:
Can I work with a tolerated stay permit?
Permission to work with a tolerated stay permit depends on this,
whether you are living in an initial reception center or have already been accommodated outside the initial reception center
how many months you have already been in Germany.
They are still living in the initial reception center
If you are in possession of a tolerated stay permit for 0-6 months, you are not allowed to work.
If you have a tolerated stay permit according to §60a for at least 6 months, you are only allowed to work with the permission of the immigration authority.
You will find this information on your identity document as an additional provision.
You may be granted an employment permit.
You must complete and sign the job description and the declaration of employment and submit it to the Foreigners' Registration Office.
The approval of the Federal Employment Agency is requested by the Foreigners' Registration Office.
It checks the working conditions (e.g. minimum wage, scope of work).
You no longer live in the initial reception center
If you are in Germany for 0-3 months, you are not allowed to work.
If you have already been in Germany for 4 months, you can apply for an employment permit at the Foreigners' Registration Office.
Your identity document states "Gainful employment only permitted with the approval of the foreigners authority."
This means that you must fill in and sign the job description and declaration of employment and hand it in to the Foreigners' Registration Office.
The approval of the Federal Employment Agency is requested by the Foreigners' Registration Office.
It checks the working conditions (e.g. minimum wage, scope of work).
The granting of an employment permit is at the discretion of the immigration authority.
If you have already been in Germany for 4 years, a general work permit applies.
They have full access to the labor market.
This means that approval from the Federal Employment Agency is no longer necessary.
You do not generally need a work permit for school-based training.
Persons with a tolerated stay permit according to §60a AufenthG
There is a ban on working if:
They entered Germany with the motive of obtaining asylum seeker benefits.
The deportation is not possible for a reason for which the applicant is responsible and which is the cause of the impossibility of deportation.
Persons with a tolerated stay permit §60b AufenthG
Tolerance for persons "with an unresolved identity"
Gainful employment is not permitted for these persons (work ban).
This toleration is granted to persons who have not fulfilled their obligations to cooperate.
Obtaining a passport and clarifying identity
It is very important that you cooperate in obtaining a passport and clarifying your identity.
Otherwise, the immigration authority or the regional council may issue you with a general work ban under immigration law.
If you have such a work ban, you cannot submit an application to the Foreigners' Registration Office for admission to employment/training or continuation of existing employment.
If you have any further questions, please contact your social services department or the responsible integration management team.

question: What rights do I have if I receive provisional protection?
context:
Decisions of the BAMF
The decision from the BAMF (Federal Office for Migration and Refugees)
Some time after your hearing (interview) at the BAMF, you will receive your notification by post (yellow envelope).
The decision states how your asylum procedure was decided.
After receiving the notification, show it immediately to your social services.
They will explain to you what the BAMF has decided and what steps you can take.
Important!
You have a period of 2 weeks to lodge an appeal against the decision.
The deadline begins on the date shown on the yellow envelope.
There are the following decisions of the asylum procedure:
Right to asylum Article 16a of the Basic Law (GG):
Residence permit for 3 years
Settlement permit possible after 3 years at the earliest (requirements are checked individually)
Unrestricted access to the labor market
Entitlement to family reunification
Granting of asylum/refugee status § 3 Asylum Act (AsylG):
Residence permit for 3 years (may be extended thereafter)
Settlement permit possible after 3 years at the earliest (requirements are checked individually)
Unrestricted access to the labor market
Entitlement to family reunification
Granting of subsidiary protection § 4 Asylum Act (AsylG):
Residence permit for 1 year (2 additional years for each extension)
Settlement permit possible after 5 years at the earliest (requirements are checked individually)
Employment permitted, self-employment only with permission from the foreigners authority
The possibility of family reunification must be examined individually
Determination of national prohibition of deportation § 60 para.
5 and 7 of the Residence Act (AufenthG):
Residence permit for 1 year (1 additional year for each extension)
Settlement permit possible after 5 years at the earliest (requirements are checked individually)
Employment possible with permission from the foreigners authority
Family reunification not possible
The asylum application was rejected?
There are two types of rejection:
The asylum application is rejected as inadmissible because another country is responsible for processing the asylum application (Dublin procedure).
This is the case if you have already applied for asylum or given fingerprints in another country.
Deportation to this country is threatened (example: Italy).
The asylum application is rejected (national procedure).
They are threatened with deportation to their home country.
In these two cases, you are obliged to leave the country and must leave Germany again.
As long as your deportation is not possible, you will receive a tolerated stay under certain circumstances.
A tolerated stay is not a residence permit.
The regional council is responsible for tolerated persons.
Deportation is also checked and carried out there.
What can I do if I don't want to be deported but no longer have any options to stay in Germany?
If you decide to leave voluntarily, you can receive financial support for your new start in your home country.

question: Where can I find medical help for children?
context:
What should I do if my child is ill?
If your child is ill or cannot go to school for other important reasons, you must report it to the school.
Please call the school before the start of lessons.
Most schools also expect a written apology.
This is a letter from the parents.
The written excuse must often be received by the school within three days.
If your child is ill for a longer period of time, they will need a doctor's note.
The certificate must also be handed in at school.
It is best to ask the secretary what the school needs.
If your child does not come to school without a telephone or written excuse or a medical certificate, the school must look for your child.
If necessary, the school will even search for your child with the police.
You may then have to pay a fine.

question: How can I connect with LGBTIQ* communities?
context:
Counseling centers regarding LGBTIQ*
In Germany, people of different religions, genders, origins and political views live together peacefully and enjoy the same rights.
The same also applies to people of different sexual orientations or gender identities: lesbians, gays, bisexuals, transgender people, intersex people and queer people (LGBTIQ for short) have the same rights in Germany as other people.
In addition to the two genders "male" and "female", Germany has recently introduced a third gender entry "diverse".
Transgender people can have their gender entry and name changed in Germany.
In Germany, women are allowed to love and marry other women, and men are allowed to marry other men.
Many LGBTIQ* people have fled to Germany because they were persecuted in their home country.
If you have fled and are lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender or intersex, you can find support, social contacts and information from many LGBTIQ organizations in Germany.
Lesbian and Gay Association in Germany (LSVD)
Queer Refugees Germany" project
www.queer-refugees.de
queer-refugees@lsvd.de
Advice in the Rems Murr district
Pro Familia in Waiblingen
LGBTIQ* counseling (profamilia.de)
Rems-Queer district
Open group for queer young people in the Rems-Murr district and surrounding area
Every 1st Saturday of the month at 2 pm at Mühlstraße 3 in Backnang.
www.instagram.com/rems_queer_kreis/
jugendgruppe.remsqueerkreis@gmail.com
Advice in Stuttgart
The Regenbogen Refugium of Weissenburg e. V. offers encounters and networking opportunities for LGBTTIQ refugees and their supporters.
Twice a month, a counseling session for LGBTTIQ refugees is held in cooperation with Amnesty International Stuttgart.
The Turkish community in Baden-Württemberg (tgbw) has a "Specialist advice service for gender and cultural diversity in Stuttgart".
It is aimed specifically at LGBTIQ* people with an international history and/or experiences of racism.

question: What is the income limit for a mini-job?
context:
Mini job
The maximum earnings per month are € 520 and are tax-free.
The employee does not have to pay any contributions to statutory health insurance or unemployment insurance.
You can also apply for exemption from compulsory pension insurance.
A mini-job only gives you very limited entitlement to a later old-age pension.
You will have to take care of your own health insurance. The best way to do this is to seek advice from a statutory health insurance company.
You can find more information on this topic here.

question: What is the difference between simultaneous interpreting and consecutive interpreting?
context:
Certified interpreters
You will need an interpreter for many visits to authorities such as the immigration office, social welfare office and education authority, but also for visits to the doctor, parents' evenings at school or kindergarten.
If you need an interpreter, go to your social services or integration management.
If possible, they will arrange for a suitable interpreter to accompany you to your appointment.
Every request is treated confidentially.
Please note that interpreters do not provide professional advice, legal advice or legal representation.
Translation of documents
Official documents such as certificates, marriage or birth certificates may only be translated by state-certified translators in Germany.
These translations can cost a lot.
It is best to check carefully beforehand whether you really need such a certified translation.
Here you will find a selection of certified interpreters:
