question: What is the difference between statutory and private health insurance?
context:
Health insurance and health insurance
Insurance is compulsory in Germany.
This means that you must be a member of a health insurance fund in order to see a doctor.
As soon as you have a residence permit, you must register with a regular health insurance fund.
You can choose and change your health insurance company yourself.
You will receive an insurance card from the health insurance company and are therefore entitled to the same benefits as all residents in Germany.
Always take your insurance card with you to your doctor's appointments.
Here you will find an overview of health insurance companies in Germany.
The basic medical care provided by the health insurance fund includes
Benefits for the prevention and alleviation of illness
Pregnancy benefits
Services for the detection of diseases
Benefits for the treatment of illnesses
Costs
When you go to a doctor, show your health insurance card.
With this, most examinations are free of charge for you.
You must pay for certain preventive medical check-ups yourself.
You will have to pay part of the costs for therapies (e.g. physiotherapy) and aids (e.g. bandages) yourself.
People who have little money can be exempted.
Ask your health insurance company about this.
The costs of dental treatment are covered by health insurance.
If a tooth needs to be renewed or replaced, you will have to pay for part of it yourself.
The costs for treatment in hospital are also paid by the health insurance company.
However, you must pay a daily hospital allowance of €10 for each day in hospital.
People who have little money can be exempted.

question: What types of insurance are there in Germany?
context:
Insurances
Important insurances
In addition to the five statutory social insurance schemes (health insurance, long-term care insurance, pension insurance, accident insurance and unemployment insurance), there are also other insurance schemes.
These are voluntary, even if the word "compulsory" sometimes appears in their name, as in the case of "liability insurance".
Most of them insure you against financial risks.
Depending on your life situation, some of them may make sense.
The best-known supplementary insurances are
Liability insurance
Household contents insurance
KVZ insurance
Cell phone insurance
Further information in various languages on the subject of insurance can be found here.

question: What is the difference between discounters and supermarkets?
context:
Shopping facilities
In Germany, stores are generally open from Monday to Saturday.
They are generally closed on Sundays and public holidays.
The opening hours of the stores may vary.
You can find out more on the Internet or at the entrance to the respective stores.
Restaurants, cafés and leisure facilities (e.g. swimming pools, museums, cinemas) are also open on Sundays and public holidays.
You can shop here:
Discounter
You can buy cheaper food in the discount stores.
The range of goods is relatively limited and simply presented.
There are discount stores in almost every town.
Supermarkets
In the supermarkets you can mainly buy slightly more expensive food.
You will also find many branded products here.
Greater emphasis is placed on the presentation of the goods than at the discounters.
Weekly markets
At the weekly markets you can buy mainly regional foods (e.g. fruit, vegetables, eggs, bread).
The weekly markets only take place on certain days of the week and usually in the mornings.
However, not every town has a weekly market.
Specialty stores
Specialty stores are stores where you can buy goods in a particular category.
These are, for example, bakeries, butchers, sports stores and shoe stores.
Retail stores with foreign products
Especially in larger cities, there are stores where you can buy foreign products.
For example, there are Turkish, Russian and Asian grocery stores.
Drugstores
Drugstores are specialist stores with an extensive range of products.
You can mainly buy hygiene products (e.g. shampoo, cleaning products) or cleaning products (e.g. washing powder, washing-up liquid) here.

question: What German courses does VwV offer?
context:
VwV German language courses
For people who are not allowed to attend integration courses, the state of Baden-Württemberg has set up a special program with the VwV Deutsch.
The courses build on the respective language level and lead to the next higher language level (e.g. from A1 to A2).
Each course usually consists of 300 lessons and lasts approx.
4-5 months.
The special courses, such as literacy courses, take a little longer.
Costs
The course is free of charge for participants.
Travel costs can be covered proportionately by the district office if required.

question: What options are there to catch up on school-leaving qualifications?
context:
Catch up on school-leaving qualifications
In principle, it is also possible to catch up on higher school qualifications.
For example, after completing the intermediate school leaving certificate (Mittlere Reife), you can also take the Abitur at a grammar school.
This is also possible, for example, at vocational schools, various vocational colleges or evening grammar schools.
Even if you do not yet have a school-leaving qualification, you can still catch up.
Or you have a foreign school-leaving qualification that is not recognized in Germany.
Even then, you can still catch up on your school-leaving qualifications via the second educational pathway.
You can find more information here.

question: Who is eligible for the BuT program?
context:
Education and participation package (BuT)
If you receive social benefits, you can receive financial support for your child.
This support is called the Education and Participation Pact, or BuT for short.
The education and participation package gives children, teenagers and young adults on low incomes the opportunity to take advantage of offers such as tutoring, music school, sports, lunch at daycare centers and schools or school trips.
Who can apply for BuT?
All children, teenagers and young adults,
whose families are receiving income support or social assistance or
whose families receive housing benefit or
for whom child supplement is received or
who receive asylum seeker benefits
Where can I apply for the benefits?
Rems-Murr district job center
Beneficiaries who receive citizen's allowance under SGB II

Beneficiaries who receive housing benefit, social assistance, supplementary child allowance or asylum seeker benefits
Rems-Murr district administration office

question: What is the difference between a home birth and a hospital birth?
context:
Important information about pregnancy
First appointment with the gynecologist
Pregnant women in Germany enjoy special protection and are entitled to advice, medical care and support with new purchases for the child.
If you are pregnant, you must first go to your gynecologist.
Have the preventive check-ups carried out there.
You will then receive a maternity pass.
The maternity record is a document containing important information about your pregnancy, your health and that of your child.
Always take your maternity pass with you in case of emergencies.
Maternity protection for working pregnant women
Working pregnant women have special protection - known as maternity protection.
Maternity protection begins 6 weeks before the birth and ends 8 weeks after.
This protection is regulated by law in Germany.
Pregnant women are generally not allowed to work during this time.
Your job is retained and you can return to work at the end of your maternity leave.
In addition, pregnant women may not work more than 8.5 hours per day and may not perform heavy physical labor.
Midwife
Midwives support women and their families from the beginning of pregnancy to the end of breastfeeding.
Midwives provide advice during pregnancy, can help with the birth, introduce breastfeeding after the birth and also take care of the woman's physical and psychological recovery.
Every woman can call on the help of a midwife.
Most services are covered by health insurance.
Website Midwives Association in German and English
You can find a midwife in the Rems-Murr district here
Pregnancy counseling
Women and men can go there for free and anonymous advice on all questions, issues and changes relating to pregnancy and family planning.
Regardless of whether they need medical or legal information, for example.
The counseling service is also available for mothers and young families after the birth of a child.
Women and men with an unfulfilled desire to have children can also seek advice.
Counseling centers Rems-Murr-Kreis:
Rem-Murr district administration office
schwanger@rems-murr-kreis.de
pro familia Waiblingen
waiblingen@profamilia.de
Financial support
If you have little or no income, you can apply for unemployment benefit II or assistance under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act (AsylbLG).
After the twelfth week of pregnancy, the Jobcenter or social welfare office will pay expectant mothers additional needs and initial equipment for pregnancy and baby.
Child benefit
As a rule, all children in Germany are entitled to a child allowance from birth until they reach the age of 18.
You are entitled to child benefit from the age of 18.
In individual cases, the entitlement may last longer.
Parental allowance
Many parents want to look after their child after the birth.
In return, they do not work for a certain period of time.
Or they only work part-time.
Parental allowance is paid during this time.

Refugee Council
Baden-Württemberg Refugee Council
The Baden-Württemberg Refugee Council forms an independent and supra-regional network of local initiatives that are committed to helping refugees.
They support local refugee work by providing comprehensive information on the social and legal situation in Baden-Württemberg.
They also advise on refugee policy and the situation in the countries of origin.
Counseling is free and confidential.

question: How long is a residence permit valid for?
context:
Residence permit
The residence permit can be issued for various reasons, for example for humanitarian or family reasons or after a positive asylum decision.
Duration: limited
The residence permit is a temporary residence title.
It is always earmarked for a specific purpose.
It forms the basis for legal residence and opens up the possibility of a subsequent permanent right of residence (settlement permit).
Some residence permits allow unrestricted access to the labor market without a work permit from the Federal Employment Agency.
Other residence permits require the approval of the Federal Agency.
Each residence permit specifies the extent to which you are allowed to work.
Here you will find the applications for applying for or extending a residence permit:
Application for a residence permit / EU Blue Card (PDF file)
Application for a residence permit for a child under the age of 16 (PDF file)
Application for extension of a residence permit / EU Blue Card (PDF file)
Application for extension of a residence permit for a child under 16 (PDF file)

context:
Volunteering in the refugee and migration sector
In almost every town and municipality in the Rems-Murr district, there are groups that are committed to helping migrants and refugees.
The volunteers help the migrants to find their way around their surroundings.
They help with questions about daily life, for example.
For example, if a letter is not understood in German.
Many helper groups also offer support in learning German.
Would you like to volunteer in the refugee sector?

question: What does the integration work of volunteers involve?
context:
Volunteering in the refugee and migration sector
In almost every town and municipality in the Rems-Murr district, there are groups that are committed to helping migrants and refugees.
The volunteers help the migrants to find their way around their surroundings.
They help with questions about daily life, for example.
For example, if a letter is not understood in German.
Many helper groups also offer support in learning German.
Would you like to volunteer in the refugee sector?
Then you can contact the district's volunteer coordination office:
Harald Luttmann
Promotion of volunteering
h.luttmann@rems-murr-kreis.de
Sandra Kreb
Promotion of volunteering
s.kreb@rems-murr-kreis.de
Further information can be found here.
If you would like to volunteer in a particular municipality, you can contact the respective town hall.

question: How do I register my child for school in Germany?
context:
How do I enroll my child in a school?
Are you new to Germany?
Your child is allowed to go to school.
After 6 months in Germany at the latest, you must register your child at a school.
School attendance is compulsory.
Ask at the town hall which school your child can go to.
There are special classes to learn German.
Further information can be found here.
Have you been in Germany for a while?
Does your child already attend a daycare center or an elementary school?
There are certain days for registration.
You will need the following documents:
Your identity card, birth certificate or proof of arrival
Registration certificate
all documents relating to your child (ID/passport, birth certificate, school reports, medical certificates, ...)
Please take your child to the school to register.
School enrollment dates and registration dates at elementary school in Baden-Württemberg:
Baden-Württemberg Deadline: end of June.
(Your child must be 6 years old by this date)
School registration: Beginning of March to end of April
School enrollment: September
Information on school enrollment (elementary school) can be found here.
Enrolment and registration dates for other schools (secondary schools) in Baden-Württemberg:
Registration dates take place in March.
Ask at the school several weeks or months before this date.
Please note: There are other times when you can register at vocational schools.
Ask the school in good time.
You don't know which school your child should go to?
Ask your social counseling/integration manager, youth migration counseling or migration counseling.
You can also obtain information from the town hall or directly from the schools in your area.

question: What support is available for integration?
context:
Integration management (social counseling for refugees in follow-up accommodation)
If you are a refugee living in private accommodation or in municipal accommodation, you have access to integration management.
The integration managers can support you in many areas, for example
when applying for social benefits, residence permits
with support in everyday life (for example, explaining letters)
in personal and family matters
for contacts with authorities
for other questions
In order to promote your integration in Germany, an individual plan (integration plan) can be drawn up.
If you need help or support, give us a call and make an appointment.
The contact details of the respective integration management can be found here.
General information on integration management:
Rems-Murr district administration office

question: How can I apply for housing benefit?
context:
I have found an apartment
Rental agreement
The amount of rent is agreed in the rental contract.
If the tenant signs this, he also agrees to pay the rent.
The rent is made up of basic rent (basic amount), ancillary costs (refuse collection, operating costs) and heating costs.
The rental agreement specifies when the rent is to be paid.
If the rent is increasingly not paid on time, this can lead to termination of the tenancy agreement.
You must read the rental agreement carefully.
If you don't understand everything, ask someone who can help you.
The rental agreement is very important.
Once it has been signed, it cannot be terminated so quickly!
The following points must be included in the rental agreement:
Name and address of the landlord
Address of the rental property
Living space in m²
Number of rooms
Amount of the net cold rent
Amount of operating costs
Amount of heating costs
Total rent
Amount of the deposit
If you agree with what is written in the rental agreement, then sign it.
Further information in several languages is available here.
Security deposit
The deposit is a security for the landlord/landlady.
The maximum amount for the deposit is 3 basic rents.
If you move out of the apartment and leave no damage behind, you will get your money back.
Possible assumption of costs
If you receive money from the Jobcenter or the district office, you must observe the following:
Important: You may not sign the rental agreement yet, but must first have it approved.
First of all, you must obtain a cost estimate from your future landlord.
This should include:
The amount of the rent
The amount of ancillary costs (heating, water, electricity)
The amount of the deposit
Possible graduated rent (automatic rent increase)
You must go to the job center / district office with the cost estimate.
They check the cost estimate.
If everything is in order, they approve it.
If you have a residence permit, you must submit an application to the immigration authorities.
Initial equipment
If you receive benefits from the Jobcenter, you have the option of applying for initial equipment for furniture and furnishings.
You will be paid a lump sum.
It is important that the application is submitted before the furniture is purchased
Caution: It may take some time before the money is paid out!
The Jobcenter also has the right to inspect the apartment in order to check the amount of initial equipment.
Information for refugees: When moving out of accommodation, you are not allowed to take the accommodation's furniture with you.
That's why you need new furniture.
You can submit an application for initial equipment to the Jobcenter.
Housing benefit
If you and the people living in your household earn little money, you are entitled to housing benefit under certain conditions.
If you receive money from the state for yourself and your family, you do not usually need to apply for housing benefit.
Information about housing benefit in the Rems-Murr district

question: What is the difference between gross and net salary?
context:
Payroll accounting
If you are employed as an employee, you will receive a payslip or payslip after the first month of work.
Some employers will continue to issue you with a monthly statement, others only if something is different in the month in question (e.g. Christmas bonus, increase in insurance contributions).
Mandatory information in the pay slip or payslip:
Name and address of the employer
Name, address, date of birth of the employee
Insurance number of the employer
Date of start of employment
Tax class and tax identification number (tax identification number)
Billing period
Gross salary (salary without deductions - gross tax amount and gross social security amount)
Type and amount of supplements or allowances
Type and amount of deductionsNet amount (after all deductions)
The net amount is usually the amount paid out.
Exception: In the case of advances, loans from the company or salary garnishments (if you have debts), further amounts are deducted from the net amount.

question: Where can I find support for my job search?
context:
Entry from Ukraine and stay in Germany
Current information and entry requirements:
Federal Foreign Office
Federal Office for Migration and Refugees.
Further information specifically for the Rems-Murr district can be found here.
Can I enter Germany legally and stay there legally?
Foreigners normally require a residence permit - such as a visa or a residence permit - to enter and legally reside in Germany.
Due to the special situation in Ukraine, an exception has been made: War refugees from Ukraine are temporarily exempt from the requirement of a residence permit in Germany.
As things stand at present, this exception applies to first-time entries up to 31.
What happens after entry?
Where can I register in Germany and where can I get accommodation and meals?
The procedure is divided into four consecutive steps:
First registration
Distribution to a place of residence (if receiving social benefits)
Registration of the residential address at the destination
Application for a residence permit.
Further information can be found here.
Can I work in Germany with a residence permit for temporary protection?
Yes, that is possible.
However, gainful employment must first be permitted by the foreigners authority.
The immigration authority will already enter in the residence permit that gainful employment is permitted when issuing the residence permit.
This means that no further work permit from another authority is required.
Should Ukrainian nationals apply for asylum?
No, that is not necessary.
The necessary protection is granted in a different, faster procedure.
Ukrainian nationals are therefore advised to refrain from applying for asylum.
However, the right to submit an application for asylum at a later date continues to exist regardless of this.
Information portal of the German government
The Federal Ministry offers a digital information service in German, English, Russian and Ukrainian.
Here you will find all the official information about residence and living in Germany.
Germany4Ukraine
Embassy of Ukraine in Berlin

question: Where can I find free online language courses in Germany?
context:
Learn German independently
Of course, you can also learn German independently without attending a course or in addition to a course.
Your helper group will support you.
Libraries are an important place to learn German independently.
Studying in the library and using the WLAN and Internet PCs are free of charge.
Online offers
There are also free offers on the Internet to learn German:
The Goethe-Institut has a free online offer with exercises for German at work.
These are specially tailored to specific occupational groups.
The radio station Deutsche Welle offers online language exercises that work with video clips and series.
They are adapted for language levels A1 to C and offer an entertaining supplement to other German courses.
VHS learning portal
For immigrants who want to learn German quickly and without bureaucratic hurdles, the German Adult Education Association (DVV) has now put a free learning offer online.
The learning portal is available at vhs-lernportal.de and can be used on all common end devices.

question: How can I find vocational training?
context:
Career planning in the Rems-Murr district
Dual training preparation (AVdual)
AVdual support at schools in the Rems-Murr district helps AVdual students to improve their chances on the training market and labor market.
Tasks:
Advice and support with career and education planning
Help with creating application documents and preparing for job interviews
Support in preparing and carrying out an internship
Mediator between school, company and parents
The AVdual mentors have their office at the vocational schools.
This means that they are always in contact with the class teachers or the school social workers.
Here you will find an overview of the AVdual training program in the Rems-Murr district.
Career counseling
The careers advice service supports you in your choice of studies and career, during your training and at the beginning of your working life.
You can clarify all important questions about your professional future in a personal consultation.
Advice is available:
Pupils and students
Apprentices
Students and
Graduates of the universities.
In addition, all those who are seeking vocational training for the first time or want to reorient themselves professionally.
Request a consultation
Youth vocational assistance
To ensure that every young person has a chance of finding an apprenticeship and a job, the youth vocational assistance service offers advice, support and guidance.

question: What help is available in cases of domestic violence?
context:
Domestic violence
Domestic violence includes all forms of physical, sexual and/or psychological violence between people, usually in the home.
It does not matter whether the persons live together in a marriage, a registered partnership or just like that, what sexual orientation they have or whether it is a community of several generations.
The scene of the crime can also be outside the home, for example on the street, in a store or at work, but the home itself is often the scene of the crime.
No one has to endure if she or he
is humiliated, insulted, beaten or threatened,
is prevented from leaving the house,
from meeting up with family, relatives, friends or girlfriends,
is forced to have sex,
separation or separation requests are not accepted,
is persecuted, harassed or terrorized.
Victim counseling Rems-Murr district
The counseling service is confidential, free of charge and personally tailored to you.
Victim counseling advises people of all genders and ages.
info@opferberatung-rems-murr.de
victim-counseling-rems-murr.de
Violence against women helpline
Women affected by violence can find support on the helpline.
At the request of a caller, the counselors will call in an interpreter in the required language within one minute.
Free, anonymous and confidential advice is available in 18 foreign languages.
You can receive advice by phone, chat or e-mail.
Help hotline "Violence against women"
Women's and children's shelter
The women's and children's shelter offers protection for women affected by domestic violence and their children.
frauenhaus@drk-rems-murr.de
Further information and contact details can be found here.

question: What steps are necessary for self-employment in Germany?
context:
Independence
Would you like to start your own business or work freelance?
There are many things you need to consider:
the market situation
Legal issues
Administrative guidelines
Financing
Note: If you are only allowed to stay in Germany temporarily, you first need permission from the immigration authorities to set up a company.
A portal for the self-employed offers helpful information on setting up a business in Germany.
The website is available in 14 languages.
Addresses of regional and national advice centers specifically for founders with a migration background can be found on the business start-up portal under "Advice and addresses".
Netwerk IQ" also provides information and support for people from abroad when setting up a business.
Further information can be found in the online guide for refugees with tips in German and Arabic.
Please enquire at the relevant immigration office.

question: Which driving licenses are valid in Germany?
context:
Car
Driver's license
If you drive a car in Germany, you must have a valid driver's license and always have it with you.
In Germany, you can drive a car from the age of 18 with a valid driver's license.
It is also possible to get a driver's license at the age of 17.
Would you like to get your driver's license?
If you want to get your driver's license, choose a driving school.
The driving school will explain to you which documents you need and how to proceed.
Getting a driver's license costs money.
Inquire about the amount of these costs beforehand.
To obtain a German driving license, you must pass the theoretical and practical test.
The theoretical exam can be taken in many other languages in addition to German.
Talk to your driving instructor about this.
You must also take part in a first aid course.
There you will learn how to provide assistance in an emergency situation, for example in the event of accidents, burns and poisoning.
Here you will find further information and contact details for applying for a driver's license at the district office.
Do you already have a foreign driver's license?
Do you have a foreign driver's license and live in Germany?
In this case, your foreign driver's license is valid for 6 months after you move to Germany.
After these 6 months, you must convert your driver's license into a German driver's license.
You also have to take a theoretical and practical test.
Persons from EU/EEA countries with a valid driver's license do not need to transfer their foreign driver's license.
Here you can obtain further information and applications to transfer your driving license.
For your information: There are many rules to ensure that road traffic is safe for you and others.
You must observe these when driving.
These rules are set out in the Road Traffic Regulations (StVO).
If you violate these rules, you will be fined.
Penalties can be: A fine, a driving ban or points in Flensburg.
Here you will find further information in several languages.
Register car
Would you like to buy a motor vehicle (e.g. car, truck, motorcycle, scooter) and drive it?
You must then register this vehicle.
To do this, you must go to the registration office.
Please make an appointment online in advance.
Waiblingen, Schorndorf and Backnang
Here you will find all the important information on admission and the contact details of the respective locations.

question: What does dual training involve in Germany?
context:
Dual education
Dual vocational training is a special feature in Germany.
Around one third of dual training takes place at a vocational school and around two thirds at a training company.
In this way, you learn theory and practice at the same time and earn money in a company during your training.
If you would like to apply for an apprenticeship, German language skills are very important (at least B1).
Because German is spoken in companies, vocational schools and technical colleges.
The examinations are also held in German.
Vocational training is presented in various languages in a short film by the Network Companies Integrate Refugees.

question: Where can I find psychological support?
context:
What do I do in an emergency?
If you need help very quickly in an emergency situation, the emergency numbers will help you.
You can also call the telephone counseling service (Telefon-Seelsorge).
They will advise you directly on the phone:
The call costs nothing and you can call at any time.
You do not have to say your name and will not be asked for it.
For children and young people, there is the number against grief:
What can you do in an acute mental health crisis?
Anyone can have a mental health crisis - no matter how old they are, how they live or where they come from.
You can have a crisis because something very bad has happened to you (for example, someone has died, you were in great danger...). You can also have a crisis if you have experienced bad things for a long time or are seriously mentally ill (for example, you have depression or anxiety disorders).
In an emergency, call 112.
If you have a crisis or think you want to die, you can always go to hospital - day and night and at weekends.
For the Rems-Murr district
Center for Mental Health Winnenden
Winnenden Castle Clinic
info@zfp-winnenden.de
The following offers are available here:
Outpatient offers
Partial inpatient services
Stationary offers
Further information can be found here.

question: What contraceptive methods are available?
context:
Sexual counseling and contraception
Family planning
Everyone decides for themselves how and with whom sexuality is lived.
You also decide for yourself whether, when and how many children you want to have.
You could also say that you have the right to family planning and sexual self-determination.
Multilingual information on the subject of sexuality can be found at:
www.zanzu.de
Sexual counseling
In sexual counseling, you can talk about your sexuality in a protected environment.
Questions about the body, sexual orientation, but also experiences of sexual violence can be topics.
More information can be found here: www.zanzu.de
Advice center
Pro Familia Waiblingen
waiblingen@profamilia.de
Contraception
There are various methods if you do not want to get pregnant or want to prevent infection with sexually transmitted diseases.
For example, barrier methods such as the condom, or methods with hormones such as the pill.
Multilingual information on the subject of contraception can be found at:
www.zanzu.de
www.profamilia.de
A condom protects against sexually transmitted diseases such as HIV.
You can find out about contraceptive methods from a gynecologist.
Emergency contraception:
If you have sexual intercourse without contraception, you may become pregnant, even if you don't want to.
Mistakes can also happen when using contraception.
Then you will get pregnant despite using contraception.
In these cases, you can take the morning-after pill.
You must take these as soon as possible, preferably in the first twelve hours after sexual intercourse.
You can buy the morning-after pill without a prescription from a pharmacy.
You can obtain advice on this from a pharmacy or doctor.

question: How can I terminate a contract in Germany?
context:
Contracts
In Germany, there are contracts for many things.
For example:
Renting an apartment (rental agreement)
New job (employment contract)
New cell phone (cell phone contract)
Register at the gym (membership contract)
If the contract is signed by two parties, it is legally binding.
Everything agreed in the contract must be complied with by the buyer and also by the dealer.
For example, if you have signed a contract with a gym for 2 years, then you must also pay the fees for 2 years.
You should therefore consider whether you can pay for everything during this period.
Contracts often also contain "small print".
This is usually written in small letters at the bottom of the contract.
You must always read this and agree to it before you sign.
Do not allow yourself to be pressured into signing a contract.
You always have the right to read and check everything.
Ask if you can take the contract home with you if necessary.
Then you can read the contract at your leisure or have it translated.
If you have a disagreement with the other party to the contract, you can also seek legal advice or a lawyer.
Termination
You must cancel in writing (usually 3 months before the end of the contract).
If you do not comply with the notice period, the contract is often extended automatically.
Cell phone contract
There are two different cell phone contracts in Germany.
Prepaid contract
The prepaid contract does not have a fixed contract term, but you have to top up credit (money).
Term contract
A fixed-term contract has a minimum contract term.
Ask how long the contract lasts and whether you can pay for it for that long.
This contract is automatically renewed if you do not cancel.
If you do not want the contract to be automatically renewed, you must cancel in writing.
Pay attention to the deadline.

question: How can I find a kindergarten place?
context:
Where can my child be looked after before and after school?
Reliable elementary school
At the reliable elementary school, children are looked after directly before and after lessons.
Children can be looked after for up to six hours in the morning.
This also includes lessons and breaks.
Childcare can be provided from 7 a.m. to 1 p.m., for example.
However, the reliable elementary school ends at 2 p.m. at the latest.
The reliable elementary school takes place in the school or in rooms next to the school.
The children are usually looked after by teachers during this time.
There are often also various activities, for example sports or creative activities.
If your child is to attend the reliable elementary school, you must register him/her.
The reliable elementary school costs money.
Ask at the school or the town hall whether there is a reliable elementary school.
Ask there for further information (costs, registration).
Flexible afternoon care
Some schools offer flexible afternoon care.
These are offers in the afternoon.
These offers take place at the schools.
Flexible afternoon care begins at 12 noon at the earliest and ends at 5.30 pm at the latest.
If your child is to take part in afternoon care, you must register your child.
Flexible afternoon care costs money.
Ask at the school or at the town hall whether there is flexible afternoon care.
Ask there for further information (costs, registration).
Homework supervision
Many schools offer homework supervision after lessons.
During homework time, pupils are supervised and monitored.
The supervisor will help with any questions.
You may have to pay for homework supervision.
Ask the school whether homework supervision is available.
Hoarding
In after-school care, children are looked after by teachers.
It is also known as a day nursery.
Children can eat lunch, do their homework and play with other children in the after-school care center.
They can receive help with their homework from teachers.
The after-school care center is for elementary school children (1st grade).
grade to 4th grade).
Sometimes older children can also attend the after-school care center.
You have to register at an after-school care center.
After-school care costs money.
The costs can be covered in full or in part by the Youth Welfare Office if you are unable to pay them.
To do this, you must submit an application to the Youth Welfare Office.
Ask at the school or town hall whether there is an after-school care center in your community.
Vacation care
In some municipalities there is a vacation care program.
Your children will be looked after there during the school vacations.
In some municipalities, vacation care is also called urban recreation.
There are many different activities for the children (games, sports, creative activities) during vacation care.
If your child is to take part in vacation care, you must register it.
Vacation care costs money.
Important: Holiday care does not normally take place during the entire school vacation.
Ask at the town hall whether there is vacation childcare available.
Ask there for further information (costs, registration, period).

question: What are the different types of employment contracts in Germany?
context:
Employment contract
Anyone who starts work is given an employment contract.
The employment contract regulates the most important conditions of an employment relationship such as
Working hours
Vacation
Amount of the salary and
Notice periods
Both sides - employee and employer - must adhere to these agreements.
As the contract becomes legally binding when you sign it, you must only sign it once you have fully understood its contents.
If you later realize that you have signed a contract that you do not agree with, you can have the clauses reviewed.
A lawyer, for example, can help you with this.
Further support is available here.
Please note:
An employment contract can also be established verbally or tacitly through conclusive behavior!
If you have worked, your employer must pay you for it, even if you do not (yet) have a written employment contract!
Contract types
Permanent employment contract
There is usually a probationary period of three or six months.
During this period, an employment relationship can be terminated by either the employer or the employee at short notice within two weeks.
At the end of the probationary period, a permanent employment relationship begins with longer protection against dismissal.
Working hours are usually up to 40 hours per week.
Fixed-term employment contract
The employment relationship ends on the agreed date without the need for notice of termination.

question: How long do you have to live in Germany to apply for a permanent residence permit?
context:
Settlement permit
Duration: unlimited, validity of the eAT (electronic residence permit) corresponds to the duration of the passport
Entitles the holder to any gainful employment, including self-employment.
Prerequisites:
Third-country nationals who have resided in Germany for an uninterrupted period of five years with a residence permit
Securing your livelihood (securing your livelihood)
60 months of pension insurance contributions
Knowledge of the legal and social order (orientation course)
Sufficient living space (a living space of at least 12 m² must be demonstrated for each family member over the age of six.
For each family member between the ages of two and six, 10m² should be enough;
Children from 0-2 are not included)
Secured livelihood: Your livelihood is secured if you can cover your living expenses and sufficient health insurance cover without recourse to public funds.
Special standard:
Settlement permit (§ 26 (3) AufenthG) for persons entitled to asylum and refugees under the Geneva Refugee Convention
The settlement permit is issued after three years if the following requirements are met:
The German language is "mastered" (C1)
The livelihood is largely secured (at least
75%)
The BAMF has not notified the applicant in accordance with Section 73 (2a) of the Asylum Act that the conditions for revocation or withdrawal have been met
Basic knowledge of the legal and social order and living conditions in Germany (orientation course)
Sufficient living space (see above)
The settlement permit is issued after 5 years if the following requirements are met:
Sufficient knowledge of the German language (A2)
The livelihood is predominantly secured (at least 51%)
There are no requirements for revocation or withdrawal of the asylum decision
Orientation course
Sufficient living space (see above)

question: What are the requirements for funding from the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF)?
context:
Social justice
The state must respect and protect human dignity.
It should therefore ensure the best possible social justice.
To this end, it takes legal, financial and material measures.
All people in Germany who earn money pay part of their wages to the state.
The higher the income, the more you have to pay.
If you earn a lot, you pay more tax.
The state should spend this money on the welfare of people living in Germany.
This means, for example:
All people registered in Germany are entitled to basic medical care.
This includes medical treatment in the event of illness and accidents.
All people who have a job subject to social insurance contributions pay contributions to health insurance, long-term care insurance and pension insurance.
Every adult must make an effort to earn their own living.
If someone is unable to do this, help can be obtained from the state.
The state ensures that taxes are also used to balance social justice and to help in emergency situations (for example for refugees).
The state supports parents financially, for example through child benefit.
This is not permitted in Germany, for example:
Tax fraud, for example paying less tax than required.
Receiving state benefits even though there is no entitlement to them.

question: Who is entitled to citizen's income?
context:
Citizen's income
If you meet certain requirements, you are entitled to a citizen's allowance from the Jobcenter.
You can receive citizen's allowance if you are capable of working and entitled to benefits and therefore meet at least the following conditions:
You are at least 15 years old and have not yet reached the age limit for your pension.
You live in Germany and have your center of life here.
You can work at least 3 hours a day.
You or members of your benefit community are in need of assistance.
In need of assistance means that the income of your community of need is below the minimum subsistence level and you cannot cover your living expenses sufficiently from your own resources.
Able to work means that no illness or disability prevents you from taking up employment.
People who are not able to work can also receive citizen's allowance if they live in a benefit community with a person who is able to work and entitled to benefits.
You get:
a standard rate
Costs of the apartment and heating
Health insurance and long-term care insurance
Initial equipment for housing and clothing
Integration into the labor market.
Contact the Jobcenter.
You can apply for Citizen's Income online here.
Please note: Benefits under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act are subordinate to all other financial support and your own income.

question: What is meant by "primary care"?
context:
General practitioner, pediatrician and specialist
General practitioner
In Germany, there are doctors in every city who work in a practice and not in a clinic - these are called GPs.
Anyone with health concerns or questions should first go to a family doctor.
To avoid having to wait too long, it is important to make an appointment in advance.
You can choose your own family doctor.
As a rule, you don't change your family doctor.
There are GPs in almost every town.
They set their own opening hours.
GPs carry out important examinations and are your first point of contact in the event of illness.
Consult your family doctor if you
are acutely ill (e.g. flu or cold)
are chronically ill (e.g. diabetes or rheumatism)
Have pain
want to be vaccinated
are pregnant
General practitioners decide on necessary medication and whether a specialist examination is required.
Your GP can also give you sick leave if you are unable to work.
If necessary, your GP will refer you to a specialist who can carry out special examinations.
Here you can search for a family doctor or a specialist in your area.
Here you will also find the foreign-language health services available in the Rems-Murr district.
If you cannot find a doctor who speaks your language, you will need to find an interpreter.
Sometimes the costs of professional interpreters can be covered.
Pediatrician
Children are usually examined by pediatricians.
Regular check-ups and vaccinations at the pediatrician are important for the health of every child.
The prescribed preventive examinations are called "U examinations" and are always free of charge at a specific time.
When registering at a day care center, proof of complete screening examinations may be requested.
If your child is ill and cannot go to school, the pediatrician can issue a medical certificate.
Important!
Your child must be vaccinated against measles when attending a day care center or school.
Specialist
If you need a specialist doctor, your family doctor will refer you to a specialist.
They can carry out special examinations.
Women's health
It is important that women are regularly examined by a gynecologist.
In this way, diseases can be detected in good time.
These are called preventive medical check-ups.
You can also discuss the topic of contraception there.
Further information on this topic:
Video │ Good to know - Visit to the gynecologist │ Media center of the GWA St.
Pauli e.V.

question: What topics are dealt with in these self-help groups?
context:
Self-help groups
What are self-help groups?
Self-help groups are self-organized groups of people who have the same problem or illness and want to do something together to get better.
What happens in a self-help group?
The participants exchange ideas and information.
Examples: How do other affected people deal with the illness or the problem in certain situations in everyday life?
What information is available on specific diseases or problems?
The participants support and help each other.
Self-help groups are not a substitute for medicine or therapy.
But they are a very good and important addition.
What is said in the self-help groups is confidential.
Everything is voluntary, no one is forced.
What groups are there?
Here you can find out more about the self-help groups in the Rems-Murr district.
Self-help contact point District Office
The task of the advice center is to support self-help in the Rems-Murr district in a variety of ways.
Further information and contact details can be found here.
selbsthilfe@rems-murr-kreis.de

question: How can I find a job as an asylum seeker?
context:
Am I allowed to work if I come from a safe country of origin?
In addition to the EU member states, Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Ghana, Kosovo, Macedonia, Montenegro, Senegal and Serbia are currently considered safe countries of origin.
Permission to work as an asylum applicant from a safe country of origin depends on this,
whether you have a residence permit or tolerated stay permit
whether you are living in an initial reception center or have already been accommodated outside the initial reception center
when you submitted your application for asylum.
Then you are not allowed to work.
Then you can apply for an employment permit at the Foreigners' Registration Office.
You must complete and sign the job description and the declaration of employment and submit it to the Foreigners' Registration Office.
Then you are not allowed to work.
Then you can apply for an employment permit at the Foreigners' Registration Office.
Then you are not allowed to work.

question: Where can I find support for genital mutilation?
context:
Advice on female genital mutilation
Female genital mutilation (FGM) is prohibited in Germany.
Parents are also not allowed to leave the country to have their daughter circumcised abroad.
This is also prosecuted under German criminal law.
Girls and young women can apply for asylum if they are at risk of being circumcised.
Many girls die during the mutilation or as a result of it.
There are also many dangerous after-effects of mutilation.
If you are affected or threatened by genital mutilation, contact the help hotline at
The help hotline staff are there for you day and night and in various languages.
In Germany, it is possible to reconstruct the clitoris.
This reconstructive surgery can be performed by plastic surgeons.
Ask a gynecologist for advice.
You can find more information in the official protection letter of the Federal Government in several languages.
Contact details
There is a central contact point for women with FGM in Göppingen.
News - FGM/C Central Contact Point Baden-Württemberg (fgmc-bw.de)

An anti-discrimination office is an advice center for people who experience discrimination.
The Anti-Discrimination Office will help you if you have been treated unfairly because of:
Age

ethnic origin

sexual orientation
a disability
If discrimination has occurred at work, when looking for accommodation, in education or in everyday life, the Anti-Discrimination Office is the right place for you.
If discrimination has occurred in another area of your life, we will still be happy to help you.
Any person affected by discrimination can contact the Anti-Discrimination Office.

question: How many people live in the Rems-Murr district?
context:
Interesting facts about the Rems-Murr district
Facts, figures and data
The Rems-Murr district is located in the Stuttgart region of Baden-Württemberg.
The district takes its name from the Rems and Murr rivers.
With an area of 858 km² and 426,635 inhabitants, the Rems-Murr district is one of the larger districts.
A total of 31 towns and municipalities belong to the Rems-Murr district.
These include the six large district towns of Backnang, Fellbach, Schorndorf, Waiblingen, Weinstadt and Winnenden.
Economy
The Rems-Murr district is an attractive business location for large companies as well as small and medium-sized enterprises.
A special feature is its commercial and industrial structure.
There are numerous large companies in the Rems-Murr district, such as Stihl (chainsaws), Bosch (household appliances) and Kärcher (household appliances).
Around 15 percent of employees work in the mechanical engineering sector.
This is a state record in Baden-Württemberg.

question: How can I store my bike safely?
context:
Bicycle
What do you need to consider when cycling?
You can easily explore the Rems-Murr district by bike.
You can get anywhere quickly and inexpensively at any time.
There are special cycle paths in Germany and also in the Rems-Murr district.
Cyclists must also follow the traffic rules.
You can find an overview of the most important traffic regulations in Germany in various languages on the following page.
When buying a bike, make sure that it is roadworthy.
Some important traffic rules for cyclists:
Always drive on the right-hand side of the road.
Do not drive side by side, but one behind the other.
If there is a cycle path, you must use it.
Only children up to the age of 11 are allowed to use the footpaths by bike.
Repair your bike
Bike stores can repair your bike.
You have to pay for this.
In some municipalities, there are also bicycle repair shops that are run by volunteers.
This is usually cheaper.
You can also get support with repairs here.
Find out locally what offers and support options are available.
Here you will find a wide range of information in many languages.

question: What medicines can I buy in a pharmacy?
context:
Pharmacy and medication
Pharmacy
In Germany, you can only buy medicines in pharmacies.
You cannot get medication in other stores or at the doctor's surgery.
Every pharmacy can be recognized from the outside by the red A.
Pharmacies are open from Monday to Saturday.
Opening hours vary depending on the pharmacy.
If you urgently need a medicine outside opening hours, you will find a sign at every pharmacy with the name and address of the pharmacy that is open for emergency service.
Search for pharmacies near you
Search pharmacy emergency service
Medication
There are prescription and over-the-counter medications.
You can only obtain prescription medication if a doctor issues a prescription.
For example, medication for high blood pressure or diabetes and all antibiotics for bacterial infections require a prescription.
You can obtain over-the-counter medication from pharmacies without a prescription.
So you don't need to see a doctor beforehand.
Medication for colds and many medications for pain, for example, are available without a prescription.
Colors of the recipes:
Pink: This is the color of the prescription sheet for people with statutory health insurance.
Such a prescription is valid for 28 days.
Green: Doctors recommend over-the-counter medicines on these prescription sheets.
Such a prescription is valid indefinitely.
Blue: This is the prescription sheet for privately insured persons.
In most cases, such a prescription is valid for three months.
Yellow: Narcotics are prescribed on these prescriptions, for example highly effective painkillers.
Such a prescription is valid for 7 days.
Cost of medication
Statutory health insurance: Medication (pink prescription) is partially covered by health insurance.
You must pay a personal contribution of at least €5.
You do not have to pay this co-payment for children and young people up to the age of 18.
You must pay for medicines that do not require a prescription (e.g. cough syrup) yourself (green or blue prescription).
Health care for asylum seekers: Even with a prescription, not all medication is free.
You should therefore consult your doctor.

question: Where can I get these vaccinations?
context:
Vaccination protection
Many diseases are caused by bacteria or viruses.
Vaccinations are a good way to protect yourself.
If many people are vaccinated against a certain disease, further spread is prevented.
In Germany there are recommendations as to when which vaccinations should be given.
Several vaccinations are necessary against some diseases.
The recommended vaccinations are covered by health insurance.
If you have a vaccination certificate, you should show it when you visit the doctor.
A decision can then be made as to which vaccinations are required.
If you do not have one, your doctor will issue you with a "vaccination card".
Keep this document in a safe place.
You should take it with you to every visit to the doctor.
Have your children vaccinated too.
This will protect you and your family from diseases such as measles, rubella, polio, tetanus, whooping cough or influenza.
Here you will find multilingual information on which vaccinations are recommended by the Standing Committee on Vaccination (STIKO).
Measles vaccination
Important!
Your child must be vaccinated against measles when attending a day care center or school.
The German Measles Protection Act stipulates that all children over the age of one must have two measles vaccinations when they start kindergarten, day care or school.
Here you will find information in several languages.

question: What vocational training opportunities are there in Germany?
context:
Full school education
In Germany, there is not only dual training, but also training at a vocational college.
The vocational school also provides completed vocational training in theory and practice.
It usually lasts two to three and a half years.
Lessons take place full-time and include general education subjects as well as vocational subjects.
The vocational colleges differ greatly in terms of their fields of training, admission requirements, duration of training and further education options.
Inquire at the respective school in individual cases.

question: What rights are laid down in the Basic Law?
context:
Basic Law and human rights
The Basic Law
In every country there are rules that everyone has to abide by.
The most important law for Germany is the Basic Law.
It is a collection of 146 articles.
Each article stands for a law, i.e. a rule.
These rules determine how we live together in Germany.
Fundamental rights protect the freedom of each individual.
They are laid down in Articles 1 to 19 of the Basic Law (catalog of fundamental rights).
Here you will find the Basic Law in various languages.
Universal Declaration of Human Rights
Human rights are important rights that always apply to all people around the world.
Human rights are rights that every person has by virtue of being human.
They protect the dignity of every human being and are equally due to all human beings without distinction of any kind, such as skin color, gender, language, religion, political or other opinion, national or social origin, wealth, birth or other status.
There are 30 rights.
The most important are:
All people are worth the same.
Everyone is allowed to have their own opinion.
Right to peace and security.
The rules for living together in Germany are derived from these fundamental rights.
The State Office for Political Education of North Rhine-Westphalia has published the brochure "Demokratie für mich" (Democracy for me), in which these rules are clearly presented.
These rules and examples of what is and is not permitted in Germany are presented here under each keyword.

question: How can I complain about child abuse?
context:
Children's rights
Children and young people have rights.
These rights are set out in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.
It also applies in Germany to all children and young people under the age of 18.
In addition, there are many laws in Germany that protect the life, health and rights of children in a special way.
The protection of children always comes first.
This means, for example:
All children have the same rights.
No matter where they live, where they come from, what color their skin is, what their parents do, what language they speak, what religion they are, whether they are boys or girls, what culture they live in, whether they have a disability, whether they are rich or poor.
Children have the right to a name, a birth certificate, a nationality and a family.
The state always helps when children are lacking something.
Children should be able to live with their parents, unless this puts them in danger.
Parents can and must care for their children, protect and promote their health and well-being.
Children who have fled have the right to special protection and help.
Children must be protected so that they can grow up well.
Children must and may go to school.
School attendance is compulsory.
Parents must support their children in attending school.
School education is free in Germany.
Children are allowed to form their own opinions.
At the age of 14 at the latest, children can decide for themselves whether they want to belong to a religion and which one.
Children should be able to develop well.
The parents are responsible for this.
If they need support, the state must help and provide food, clothing and housing, for example.
Children whose parents are not married have the same rights as children who live with married parents.
This is not permitted in Germany, for example:
Children must not be neglected or abused.
Children must not be beaten or physically or mentally abused in any way.
Children are allowed up to the age of 13.
The following applies to employees under the age of 18
When they are older, they are only allowed to take on very limited work.
This must not impair their health and development.
Children may not be abducted or used as objects of trade.
It is forbidden to perform sexual acts on children.
Here you will find the rights of the child in various languages.
Contact point
Do you have a problem?
In the event of conflicts with your parents, school or other people who do not respect your wishes and rights, the Child Protection Agency is there for you and will find a solution to your problem.
For example, you can always call the number against grief
Rems-Murr-Kreis Child Protection Association:
www.kinderschutzbund-schorndorf-waiblingen.de
info@kinderschutzbund-schorndorf.de

question: How can I make an appointment with a doctor as an asylum seeker?
context:
Treatment certificate for asylum seekers
Persons in the ongoing asylum procedure require a medical certificate or a dental treatment certificate for medical treatment.
This is always valid for 3 months.
You can obtain the relevant treatment certificate from the benefits officer at the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Department in the Rems-Murr District Office.
When you go to a doctor, show the treatment certificate.
You are entitled to:
Services to prevent and alleviate illness and pain
Pregnancy benefits
Services for the detection of diseases
Benefits for the treatment of illnesses
If you have a residence permit, you must register with a health insurance fund.

Services to prevent and alleviate illness and pain
Pregnancy benefits
Services for the detection of diseases
Benefits for the treatment of illnesses
If you have a residence permit, you must register with a health insurance fund.

question: Where can I find career advice for my working life?
context:
Funding opportunities through the employment agency
Vocational training allowance (BAB)
Is the money you earn during your training not enough?
Then you can ask the employment agency or job center whether you can get financial help.
This supportive financing is called vocational training allowance (BAB).
You can find more information on the vocational training allowance here.
Prospects for young refugees
Have you fled your home country and would like to start an apprenticeship in Germany?
Find out about special offers from the employment agency.
If you are under the age of 25, the "Perspectives for young refugees (PerjuF)" program will help you find your way around the German training market.
Following this measure, you should be in a position to start a suitable apprenticeship.
Your language skills will be tested in the first 2 weeks.
It will also determine how much support you need.
You will then find out whether you are suited to working with wood or metal, for example, or whether you are suitable for housekeeping.
As a rule, participation lasts 6 to 8 months.
The placement specialists at your employment agency or the integration specialists at the job center will be happy to help you with any questions you may have.
Vocational guidance in working life (BBiE)
Whether you want to take on more responsibility in your job, update or expand your professional knowledge or reorient yourself professionally: The Employment Agency's career guidance service (BBiE) supports you in every phase of your professional life.
We provide you with comprehensive and individual advice at every stage - from initial orientation and the selection of suitable, subsidized further training to the search for a new job.
Making an appointment
Monday to Friday from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m:
Here you can find further information from the Federal Employment Agency.

question: What is HIV and how can you get infected?
context:
HIV/Aids and sexually transmitted diseases
HIV is the abbreviation for a virus.
If the virus makes you very ill, this is called AIDS.
STDs are diseases that are transmitted during sex.
On these websites you will find information in several languages on the subject of HIV and AIDS:
HIV and AIDS | Zanzu
Materials | AIDS-Hilfe Potsdam e.V. - We promote health.
(aidshilfe-potsdam.de)
Counseling on HIV / AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases at the Rems-Murr district health department
The AIDS counseling centers of the health authorities provide advice on AIDS/HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases such as hepatitis B, C, syphilis, gonorrhea or chlamydia.
Counseling is confidential, free of charge and anonymous.
The health authorities are subject to a duty of confidentiality.
The Rems-Murr district health department also offers a free and anonymous HIV antibody test.
Consultations take place in Waiblingen and Backnang.
All contact details and further information can be found here.

question: Where can I look for training with a tolerated stay permit?
context:
Training toleration (§60c)
Duration: "Guarantees" suspension of deportation for the duration of vocational training
Perspective: The transition to a residence permit after successful completion of the training is possible, provided that the requirements are then met.
Who is eligible for the tolerated stay permit?
Tolerated persons (§ 60a AufenthG) who have already started training during the asylum procedure
Tolerated persons who want to start training: these persons must already have been in possession of a tolerated stay permit in accordance with § 60a for three months
In order to obtain a tolerated stay permit, you must submit the training contract to the regional council.
The application is submitted via the Foreigners' Registration Office together with further documents.
Prerequisites:
Qualified training: Training in a state-recognized or comparably regulated training occupation
Standard training period of at least two years
In the case of helper or assistant training, qualified training in a bottleneck occupation must be compatible with this and a training place must be confirmed for this (e.g.
B. Nursing care for the elderly and nursing assistance)
Entry of the vocational training in the register of vocational training relationships, usually kept by the IHK or HWK.
clarified identity
The clarified identity may be waived if all reasonable and necessary steps to clarify the identity have been taken within the applicable period and the identity is/was still not clarified.
The regional council decides whether the training permit is granted despite the unclear identity.
You will not receive a training permit with an introductory qualification (EQ).
But the EQ, i.e. a longer internship in a company, still offers advantages: Preparation for vocational training and the possibility of an accompanying language course!
Contact person
If you have any questions, please contact the foreigners authority responsible for you.

question: What rights do I have as a newcomer in terms of personal freedom?
context:
Personal freedom
All adults are entitled to make their own decisions about themselves and their own lives.
Whether man or woman, young or old, with or without a disability, regardless of skin color or religious affiliation.
All people are allowed to do what they want as long as they abide by the law and do not restrict the freedom of others.
This means, for example:
Everyone can decide what they want to wear.
For example, women can decide whether they want to wear pants, dresses, long or short skirts, tight or loose clothing or a headscarf.
For example, men can decide whether to wear a suit and tie, a T-shirt and jeans, a turban, a hat or a beard.
Everyone is allowed to eat what they want and what they like.
The decision whether to eat meat (including pork or beef) is made by people alone.
The state has no generally valid or religiously based dietary regulations.
The consumption of alcohol is permitted for adults.
The consumption of alcohol by children and young people is prohibited.
Every woman and every man can decide for themselves whether and who they want to marry.
Every woman and every man is entitled to divorce.
Unmarried couples are allowed to live together and have children.
Members of different religions and faiths are allowed to marry and have children.
Contraception is permitted for both sexes.
A person's decision to use contraception must be respected.
Same-sex partnerships are accepted.
Same-sex couples can marry.
The rights of a civil partnership are similar to those of a marriage between a man and a woman.
Everyone decides for themselves how and where they want to live.
For persons in the asylum procedure, this right may be restricted until an asylum application is recognized.
Sexual acts between adults may only take place with mutual consent.
Any sexual activity with children is prohibited.
Private property is permitted for every man and every woman in Germany.
It is permitted to own a house or a plot of land.
Many companies are privately owned.
Women and men have equal rights when it comes to inheritance.
Important:
One's own freedom ends where it infringes the freedom or human dignity of others or violates the law.

question: What religious freedom is there in Germany?
context:
Religious freedom
Religion and faith are private matters in Germany.
The state does not dictate to anyone whether and in which God he or she should believe.
State and religion are separate.
This means, for example:
All people are free to practise and choose their religion and beliefs.
All people have the freedom to be non-religious and to say so.
Anyone who does not believe in God is allowed to say so publicly.
Members of different religions and faiths are allowed to marry each other.
Marriage only counts as a legally valid marriage if it is concluded before the registry office.
Marriages entered into exclusively within the framework of a religion are not legally binding in Germany.
This is not permitted in Germany, for example:
Putting religious rules or traditions above applicable laws, for example being married to several women at the same time or slaughtering an animal without special permission.
Boys may only be circumcised if this does not endanger their welfare.
Many people in Germany today are committed to dialog between religions.
The aim is the peaceful coexistence of religious people, people of faith and people of no religion.
The state is committed to ideological neutrality.
As long as the practice of a religion does not endanger democracy or the separation of state and religion, it is protected.

question: What is German Pension Insurance and what benefits does it offer?
context:
Pension
For many people, the question arises: What happens if I can no longer work in old age?
Germany has the social security system of the German Pension Insurance (DRV) for this purpose.
The German pension insurance website offers a lot of information and can answer some questions about pensions
German Pension Insurance
In principle, the pension is funded by contributions from employment subject to compulsory insurance.
As a rule, half of the contribution is paid by the employer and the other half by the employee.
If you are now in a position to claim a pension, you must apply for one.
The pension is not paid automatically.
You must submit an application at least 3 months before you plan to retire.
This makes the transition from employment to retirement easier.
You can find the nearest pension insurance advice center here.
There you can obtain more detailed information on your pension model and other benefits.
However, pension insurance not only pays a pension, but also provides other benefits.
This also includes rehabilitation measures, for example, in order to be able to work again.
It is important that the later pension benefit is not reduced as a result.
It can even increase if you remain fit for work for longer as a result of such a measure.

If you need a doctor in the evening, at night or at the weekend, but it is not an emergency, then call the medical on-call service.
If you are unable to come to the practice, a doctor will drive to your home.

The emergency practice is open in the evening and at weekends.

You can go to the emergency practice without an appointment.

question: What is the difference between shared accommodation and follow-up accommodation?
context:
Connecting accommodation
You will be placed in follow-up accommodation if you have lived in shared accommodation for more than two years or your asylum procedure has been legally concluded or you have been granted a residence permit.
In the case of subsequent accommodation, you will move out of the shared accommodation and into accommodation in a town or municipality in the Rems-Murr district.
From this point on, you can also move into your own apartment.
If you are no longer in temporary accommodation, but in subsequent accommodation or already live in your own apartment in the district, the integration management will help you.
Integration management can help you with questions about kindergarten, school, work, training, language courses, residence, family and problems.
You can find the relevant contacts under Towns and municipalities.

question: How does the process of recognizing a foreign qualification work?
context:
Foreign degree
You can have it checked whether your degree is recognized in Germany.
Please note that there is a difference between regulated and non-regulated professions when it comes to recognition.
Regulated professions
You may only work in regulated professions if you have a certain qualification.
These are for example
Medical professions
Legal professions
the teaching profession at state schools
Professions in the public sector
This means that you may only work in these professions if your professional qualification is recognized by the state (e.g. vocational qualification or degree).
In the Recognition Finder, you can search for the competent recognition body for regulated professions.
You will also receive information on how to proceed.
Non-regulated professions
You can work in non-regulated professions without state recognition of your professional qualification.
However, it is advisable to apply for a certificate evaluation.
The Central Office for Foreign Education (ZAB) in Bonn is responsible for the assessment of certificates for non-regulated study professions.
Further information
Here you can find further information on the recognition of your university degree from abroad.

question: What are the tasks of the Parents' Council?
context:
Important information for parents
Parents' evening
All parents are invited to a parents' evening.
You can exchange ideas with other parents and the teacher and get lots of information.
It is good if you make use of these meetings.
The dates will be communicated in a letter to parents.
It is important to read the letters to parents.
Parents' Council
There is a parents' council in every class.
This is elected by all parents during a parents' evening. The tasks and rights of the parents' council are regulated by law.
The parents' council takes care of problems that other parents report to it.
The parents' council represents the other parents in front of the school.
School social work
Many schools have school social workers.
These can support children and young people at school.
School social workers advise and help with school and private problems, anger or other worries.
The offer is voluntary and the school social workers work confidentially.
This means that they are not allowed to tell anyone about the problems.
Otherwise there are also guidance counselors or liaison teachers.
Ask at your school.
Tutoring
If you have difficulties in some subjects at school and need additional support, you can register for tutoring.
Tutoring is provided by a tutor and takes place outside of lessons.
Tutoring usually takes place in small groups or individually.
You can repeat content here or get extra tasks to practise.
Tutoring costs money.
If you are entitled to BuT, the costs for tutoring can be paid under certain conditions (confirmation from the school that your child urgently needs tutoring).
You have to fill out a BuT application.
If you need help finding tutoring, ask your integration manager, social counseling, youth migration counseling or migration counseling.

question: How can I apply for unemployment benefit II?
context:
Unemployment benefit
You will receive unemployment benefit if you lose your job.
You must have worked in Germany for at least 12 months in the last 30 months.
Under certain circumstances there are other requirements.
The employment agency decides whether you receive unemployment benefit.
1. register as a job seeker
You have been given notice, you have resigned or your fixed-term employment contract is about to end.
The Employment Agency will support you in your search for new employment.
We will also work with you to determine whether you are entitled to financial support.
It is important that you register as a jobseeker immediately.
Register as a jobseeker at least 3 months before the end of the employment relationship.
If you only find out about this later, register as a jobseeker no later than 3 days later.
You can do this in various ways:
On site at your local employment agency
by telephone at
online at https://www.arbeitsagentur.de/
2. register personally as unemployed
You must register as unemployed in person with your employment agency on the first day without employment at the latest.
This is the prerequisite for receiving unemployment benefit.
3. complete the application for unemployment benefit
Apply for unemployment benefit online.
Alternatively, you can obtain an application form from your employment agency to submit the application in writing.
Click here for more information.

question: What are the most common reasons for refusing to recognize foreign vocational training?
context:
Foreign vocational training qualification
If you have completed vocational training abroad, you can check whether this training is recognized in Germany.
As a rule, the respective chamber (Chamber of Crafts, Chamber of Industry and Chamber of Commerce) is responsible for this.
Chambers are contact points for various training courses.
You can search for the relevant recognition body in the Recognition Finder.
You will also receive information on how to proceed.
Please note that the Stuttgart Regional Council is responsible for recognizing the vocational training of educators and childcare workers.

Volunteering means that people volunteer for an issue alongside their work and without money.
You can volunteer in these areas:

Activities in the religious field

These people are often organized in associations.
