question: What is the broadcasting fee and who has to pay it?
context:
Broadcasting fees (GEZ)
What are broadcasting fees?
Germany has independent radio, television and online offerings from ARD, ZDF and Deutschlandradio.
They report free from economic and political influences.
Everyone pays money for this together.
This is called the broadcasting fee.
The law stipulates that a broadcasting fee must be paid for every home in Germany.
However, only one person per home has to pay the license fee.
Further information can be found here in various languages.
Do I also have to pay?
Some people can be exempted from payment.
For example, if you receive benefits under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act or other social benefits.
An application must be submitted for exemption from the broadcasting fee.
You can find the application for exemption here.
General information and videos on the subject of the broadcasting fee can be found here in several languages.

question: How can I find out if an emergency notification has been sent in my area?
context:
Life-threatening emergency
Police:
110
Fire department:
112
Ambulance, emergency doctor:
112
Important!
only in life-threatening emergencies and accidents
The emergency numbers on cell phones always work, even with a prepaid card without credit/money.
Important information for an emergency call:
Who is calling (your name)?
Where did something happen (address)?
What happened?
How many injured or sick people are there?
What kind of illnesses or injuries are present?
Waiting for queries!
Stay calm.
Speak slowly and clearly so that you are better understood.
Do not end the conversation.
The emergency call center ends the call when it has all the important information.
Be sure to get other people around you to help you if you need it.
Never put yourself in danger.
If you can, be sure to administer first aid or call someone who can.
Life-threatening emergencies are, for example:
severe shortness of breath
Unconsciousness
heavily bleeding wounds
Heart problems
Suspected stroke
Symptoms of paralysis
Complications during pregnancy
Poisonings
Severe pain
Important!
Don't forget your ID / proof of arrival when you go to the hospital!
If you are registered with a health insurance company, please bring your insurance card with you.
As an asylum seeker, you are allowed to go to hospital in an emergency without a treatment certificate.
At the hospital, you must show that you are an asylum seeker with your proof of arrival.

question: What is freedom of expression in Germany?
context:
Freedom of expression
All people are allowed to form their own opinions, express them freely and disseminate them.
People are also allowed to express these opinions publicly.
All media are also free, all people can inform themselves there.
Anyone who expresses their opinion freely must ensure that the personal honor or personal dignity of other people is protected.
This means, for example:
The government can be criticized.
Religion may be criticized.
Artistic works are allowed to provoke.
No one should dictate to writers, musicians or visual artists how they should work.
The government and religions can also be the subject of satire and critical art.
Anyone who feels insulted or whose personal honor or dignity has been violated can contact the police or a court.
This is not permitted in Germany, for example:
The use of anti-constitutional symbols and calls to overthrow democracy.
Insulting expressions of opinion that disparage other people.
Defamation or slander against other people.
To incite hatred and violence.

question: How does registration for integration courses work?
context:
Integration courses
The integration course consists of a language course and an orientation course.
In the language course you will learn German up to language level B1 in 600 teaching units.
The subsequent orientation course will give you an insight into the culture, politics and social customs in Germany.
There are also special forms of integration courses, some of which comprise more or fewer teaching units.
Who is the language course for?
Foreigners with a permanent residence permit.
You received your residence permit more than one year ago or have held it for more than 18 months (employee, family reunification, humanitarian reasons, long-term resident).
Late repatriates
Asylum seekers with a residence permit according to §55Abs.
Foreigners with a tolerated stay permit according to § 60 a Abs.
2 sentence 3 AufenthG.
Foreigners with a tolerated stay permit for training according to §60c Abs.
1 or a tolerated employment permit acc.
§ Section 60d para.
1 Residence Act
Foreigners with a residence permit according to §24 or §25 para.
5 Residence Act.
Foreigners with a residence permit according to §25b (§ 104c AufenthG - "right of residence by opportunity")
EU citizens
German nationals who do not yet speak sufficient German or are in particular need of integration.
What types of language courses are available?
There are various forms of integration course.
You can find them here.
General integration course
Literacy course
Integration course for second language learners
Youth integration course
Women's integration course
Parent integration course
Intensive course
Integration course for people with disabilities
How much does the language course cost?
Integration courses are free of charge for refugees and asylum seekers.
The course is also free of charge for other people in the target group who receive social benefits.
These persons require an application for this.
Further forms on costs and participation (e.g. application for a travel allowance) are available here.
When and where do the language courses take place?
There are full-time and part-time courses.
The integration course is generally offered full-time.
If you are working, it is possible for you to attend the course in the afternoon or evening in exceptional cases.
You can find local advice centers and integration courses here.
Integration course providers can be found here.
How can I register?
You can find the application forms here.
The application for the integration course for asylum seekers, tolerated persons and foreigners with a residence permit according to §24 and §25 para.
5 AufenthG can be found here.
Send the completed applications to the responsible regional office of the BAMF.
If you need help with your application, please contact the social support or integration manager, the migration advice center or the youth migration service.
You can find more information here.

question: What services does Economic Youth Welfare offer?
context:
Economic youth welfare
Economic youth welfare refers to financial assistance for the care of a child in daycare facilities or with a caregiver.
The caregivers receive money for the care they provide.
If you are unable to pay for this, the Youth Welfare Office may be able to cover all or part of these costs for you.
To do this, you must submit an application to the youth welfare office at the district office.
Further information can be found here.
You can find the relevant contact person here.

question: How does an asylum procedure work in Germany?
context:
General information on the procedure
Are you registered in Germany and living in shared accommodation?
What happens next?
Here you will find a series of multilingual explanatory videos on the subject of asylum procedures on the following topics:
Course of the asylum procedure
How do I prepare for the hearing?
What is an asylum decision and how does the appeal process work
The BAMF has compiled a lot of information for you here.
Here you will find a movie that explains the procedure.
The next steps are explained here:
1. personal application for asylum
You apply for asylum at the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF).
Important: You can only submit your application in person, you cannot send it by post.
You will receive the appointment and the responsible BAMF office with your proof of arrival.
If you have not been given an appointment, ask your social worker.
2. first interview appointment (asylum application)
A few days before your 1st appointment (asylum application, 1st interview appointment) or your 2nd appointment (interview, 2nd interview appointment), approach your social worker in the accommodation with your documents.
If you have your first interview at the BAMF, please remember to bring enough food with you.
There may be longer waiting times.
As long as you are in the asylum procedure, you have a residence permit.
3. personal interview
The 2nd interview date is the actual hearing.
The BAMF will decide on your asylum application.
It will then send you a notification (Bescheid).
Show the notification to your social worker.
They will explain to you what the BAMF has decided and what steps you can take.

question: How do I get a residence permit in Germany?
context:
Residence permit
Duration: limited
Status: Asylum seekers
Background: Issued to carry out an asylum procedure until a decision is made by the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF).
This is NOT a residence permit!
The permit for asylum seekers contains conditions regarding employment, housing and spatial restrictions.
The employment agency is responsible for finding work.
If you need a work permit, you can apply for one at the immigration office in your place of residence.
To do this, you must complete applications with the help of your employer.
Your social worker will help you fill it out.
These are the applications:
Job description
Declaration on the employment relationship
If you are not working, you will receive benefits under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act.

question: What steps are necessary to have foreign school certificates recognized?
context:
Foreign school-leaving certificate
The recognition of a foreign school-leaving qualification is particularly useful if you want to start an apprenticeship.
But you also have to have your school-leaving certificate recognized in order to start a degree course.
The Stuttgart Regional Council (Regierungspräsidium Stuttgart) checks foreign school-leaving qualifications (e.g. Hauptschulabschluss, Mittlere Reife, Fachhochschulreife/Hochschulreife).
You can contact the Baden-Württemberg Certificate Recognition Offices and have your degree checked.

question: How can I register for an integration course in the Rems-Murr district?
context:
Clubs in the Rems-Murr district
Associations are of great social importance in Germany.
They offer people the opportunity to achieve common goals and improve their language skills.
These goals can be of various kinds: sporting activity, leisure activities, commitment to the needy and disadvantaged, protection of nature or contact with like-minded people.
There are many sports clubs for a wide variety of sports in the Rem-Murr district.
But there are also music clubs and other hobby clubs.
Normally, an annual membership fee must be paid in order to be a member.
However, you can obtain more detailed information about this directly from the association.
In the case of low incomes, subsidies for membership fees in clubs for children and young people can be granted as part of the education and participation package.
Find out which clubs exist in your municipality.

question: How do the first and second votes work?
context:
Right to vote
People in Germany have the right to vote.
They are allowed to vote for politicians.
This is written in a law.
And these are the most important elections in Germany:
State parliament election
You elect politicians for the state parliament in your federal state.
The state parliament decides things for the federal state.
A new parliament is always elected after 5 years.
Bundestag election
They elect politicians to the Bundestag.
The Bundestag decides things for the whole of Germany.
A new Bundestag is always elected after 4 years.
European election
They elect politicians to the European Parliament.
The European Parliament decides things for all countries in the European Union.
A new European Parliament is elected every 5 years.
In Germany there are 2 different voting rights:
1. the right to vote
You have a German passport.
And you are 18 years or older.
Then you have the right to vote.
This means that you can vote.
For example in these elections:
Bundestag election
State parliament election
Municipal election
Mayoral election
Senior citizens' council election
2. the right to stand for election
You have a German passport.
And you are 18 years or older.
Then you have the right to stand for election.
This means that you can let other people vote for you.
You can then work as a politician.
For example, you then work:
For the German Bundestag
For the state parliament
For the municipal representation
For the Foreigners' Advisory Council
You are an EU citizen.
They can then vote in Germany in these elections:
Municipal election
European election

question: What is the difference between paid and unpaid breaks?
context:
Working hours
No more than 8 hours a day may be worked according to the Working Hours Act.
In exceptional cases, working hours may be extended up to 10 hours if an average of 8 hours per day has not been exceeded within 6 months.
You are entitled to breaks:
After 6 hours you must take a break of at least 30 minutes.
From 9 hours you are entitled to at least 45 minutes break.

From 9 hours you are entitled to at least 45 minutes break.

question: What should I do if I have an accident at work?
context:
Accident at work
If you have an accident during working hours or on the way to or from work, this is an accident at work.
In this case, you are covered by accident insurance through the company.
Before seeking medical treatment, please be sure to inform us that it is an accident at work.
Treatment is then paid for by the employer's accident insurance and not by the health insurance fund.
You can find out the name of the accident insurance company from your employer.
If you have an accident at work
are unable to work for more than one day or
require prolonged medical treatment or
fall ill again at a later date
you must consult a so-called transit doctor.
You can find accident insurance physicians on the website of the German Social Accident Insurance

question: What is child benefit and who is entitled to it?
context:
Child benefit and parental allowance
Child benefit
For all children in Germany, there is a right of residence from birth until they reach the age of 18.
Entitlement to child benefit from the age of 18.
In individual cases also up to the age of 25.
Year of life.
Your child must live in your household and be cared for by you.
Child benefit is only ever paid to one person, usually one parent.
If there are several children, the individual amounts are paid out as one sum.
You often receive at least €250 a month for each child.
If you have several children, the number of children determines the amount of child benefit.
You are entitled to more child benefit from the third child onwards.
How do I receive child benefit?
You must submit an application to the Family Benefits Office of the Federal Employment Agency.
Please also contact your benefit provider (job center or district office) for more information.
The application and further information on child benefit
Note for asylum seekers: You cannot receive child benefit during the asylum procedure.
This is only possible once you have a positive decision from the BAMF.
Responsible for the Rems-Murr district: Familienkasse Baden-Württemberg-Ost
Parental allowance
Many parents want to look after their child after the birth.
In return, you do not work for a certain period of time.
Or you only work part-time.
If you have applied for parental allowance, you can receive at least €300 per month.
But it can also be more.
You normally receive parental allowance for 12 months.
But it can also be longer.
You will receive parental allowance if you have a place of residence and stay in Germany.
You need a residence permit.
You must live with your child.
The application and further information on parental allowance
Apply for parental allowance digitally

question: What are municipal interpreter pools?
context:
Municipal interpreter pools
There are municipal interpreter pools in the towns of the Rems-Murr district.
The volunteers go to kindergartens, schools, social institutions, government offices or authorities.
They translate conversations verbatim, orally and neutrally so that misunderstandings do not arise in the first place.
However, further advice is not possible.

question: What is gender equality in Germany?
context:
Equal rights for men and women
Women and men have the same rights.
Women and men have the same duties.
This is reflected in the laws and in daily life.
This means, for example:
Girls and boys go to school together and receive the same lessons.
They take part in sports lessons together.
Women are allowed to study or learn a trade.
In principle, all professions are open to women.
Women take on responsibility in society, for example as policewomen, doctors, teachers or in public offices and authorities.
Their instructions must be followed.
Women decide for themselves what kind of work they want to do.
They can dispose of the money they earn themselves.
Women do not have to ask their husband, parents or other family members for permission to work, open an account or conclude contracts.
Women are allowed to dress as they wish.
Women decide for themselves whether, when and whom they want to marry.
Mothers are particularly protected.
You must and may not work for six weeks before and eight weeks after the birth.
They may not be dismissed because of their maternity.
The tasks and roles in the family are not prescribed.
Women participate in public life.
They attend cultural, political or sporting events, restaurants and bars.
Women can vote and be elected to political office.
Women and men are equal in inheritance law, daughters as well as sons.
Sexual touching, comments or requests are only permitted if everyone involved agrees.
A "stop" or "no" must always be respected.
This is not permitted in Germany, for example:
Any form of violence against women, including in marriage.
No one may be sexually harassed.
Rape, even within marriage, is punished.
No one may be forced to marry.
Coercion into marriage by force or threat is punishable.

Start with a Friend e. V. creates personal encounters between people with and without a history of immigration.

question: On which days does the night bus run in Augsburg?
context:
Public transportation
There is a good network of public transportation in Augsburg and the surrounding area, such as buses and streetcars.
The Augsburger Verkehrs- und Tarifverbund (AVV) is responsible for this network.
You can find all the important information on the AVV website at www.avv-augsburg.de.
For app users, both AVV (app: AVV.mobil) and Stadtwerke Augsburg (app: swa FahrInfo) offer free apps for download.
You need a ticket to travel by bus or streetcar.
Checks are often carried out on buses and streetcars.
If you do not have a ticket, you will have to pay a fine.
The second time, you will be reported to the police and fined much more.
So make sure you always have a valid ticket with you!
Fare zones and price levels
The area in which the AVV operates is divided into zones.
The price of the tickets depends on the number of zones traveled through.
The more zones you pass through, the more expensive your ticket will be.
Each zone corresponds to a price level.
Each zone is only counted once.
For example, if you travel through zones 20, 10 and 20 again, you need a ticket for price level 2 or
2 stripes on the stripe card.
However, the outward and return journeys count as two separate journeys.
The Augsburg city area includes fare zones 10 and 20.
The district of Augsburg comprises zones 30 - 70.
You can find the fare zone map here.
The timetables with the fare zones are also displayed at the stops.
Note: Your ticket is also valid if you change trains.
The most important tickets
Detailed information on all tickets and current prices can be found here.
Germany ticket
For 49 euros a month, you can use all means of public transportation and travel throughout Germany.
The Deutschlandticket is a subscription.
This means that it is automatically renewed every month.
But you can cancel it every month.
Always by 10.
of each month (for example: 10.
March) for the following month.
You can order your Germany ticket here.
It is then played on the smartphone.
You will need the "myAVV" app for this.
You can find the app in your smartphone's Apple or Google store.
Discount ticket for students, trainees, civil servants or volunteers
In Bavaria, these groups of people can get a discounted Deutschlandticket.
The discount ticket costs 29 euros.
It is also valid nationwide.
This ticket is valid for trainees from 01.
The person's place of education or residence must be in Bavaria.
To apply, you need a certificate of eligibility from your training center / educational institution.
You can apply for the discount ticket here.
Stripe card
9 strips for flexible use (one strip per zone)
Valid for 3 hours (no return and round trips)
No take-away options (one strip per person and zone)
You can find more information about the strip card here
One-way tickets
Once from A to B
Valid for 1 hour (no return and round trips)
No take-away options
4 Stops after boarding buses or streetcars, even across zone boundaries
Change possible
You can find more information about one-way tickets here.
Day ticket
Any number of journeys on the selected day
For adults aged 15 and over
For one person or groups (each additional person costs an extra charge)
Up to 4 children under the age of 14 can travel free of charge.
Valid Monday to Friday from 9:00 a.m., Saturday, Sundays and public holidays all day;
valid until closing time (i.e. until the last bus or streetcar leaves).
Please note: The names of the passengers must be handwritten on the day ticket!
You can find more information about the day ticket here.
365-euro AVV ticket for school pupils, trainees, interns and FSJ volunteers
The 365-euro AVV ticket is available for school pupils, trainees, interns and young people doing a voluntary social year.
For €1 a day, you can travel as often as you like on streetcars, buses and trains throughout the AVV network area - around the clock!
You can pay for the ticket in installments or all at once.
You can find all the information here.
Monthly pass for pupils
Pupils do not have to pay for the bus and streetcar themselves.
You can submit an application.
The cost of the monthly pass will then be covered.
For this, the journey to school for pupils in grades 1 to 4 must be more than 2 km.
For children and young people from the 5th grade onwards, the journey to school must be longer than 3 km.
Further information and download of the applications: www.landkreis-augsburg.de
Call and collect cab (AST), on-call bus
The call-and-collect cab (AST for short) and the on-call bus operate when there are no regular bus or train connections.
For example, a cab will pick you up from the station or a bus stop and take you to the door of your desired destination.
The journey request must be made by telephone at least 30 minutes before departure.
The regular AVV prices apply.
You can find more information here.
AktiVVO - minibus as required
The minibus runs on demand without fixed stops and without a fixed timetable.
Trips in the minibus can be booked by telephone or in the "AktiVVO" app.
Within a short time, passengers can get on and off at one of the AktiVVo stops or at the AVV regional bus stops.
The fare for the AktiVVo corresponds to the regular AVV fares.
The AktiVVO minibus commutes in these regions:
Holzwinkel and Altenmünster, Roth and Zusam valleys
Bobingen, Königsbrunn and Schwabmünchen
The AktiVVO is only on the road in these regions.
He's not going to Augsburg either.
It does not travel to any locations outside these regions.
Augsburg City Zone
In the city of Augsburg, you can use the bus and streetcar free of charge at a total of 9 stations around Königsplatz and the main railway station.
The free stops are one stop in each direction from Königsplatz and Moritzplatz.
You can find more information here.
At night
With the night bus you are also mobile at night (0.30 to 4 am).
The night buses run from Thursday to Sunday and on public holidays.
Passengers require a special night ticket (also available on the buses).
Regional trains run on some routes.
The regular AVV fare applies here.

question: What options do I have with dual training?
context:
Vocational school
Germany is well known for its dual education system.
The vocational school is part of the dual training system.
Who attends a vocational school?
Some young people have to attend a vocational school.
These are young people who...
do an apprenticeship and
are between 16 and 21 years old.
They are subject to compulsory vocational training.
Trainees with an Abitur or Fachhochschulreife are not required to attend vocational school.
You are still allowed to attend vocational school.
Duration and aim of the vocational school
Duration: two to three years
Goal: completed vocational training
Graduation: Vocational qualification, intermediate school leaving certificate
What do you learn at vocational school?
The task of the vocational school is to impart theoretical knowledge for the respective occupation.
Practical knowledge is acquired in the training company.
But there are also other subjects.
For example:
German
Social studies
Religious education
Sport (partial)
Foreign languages (partial)
There are also elective subjects (e.g.
B. Data processing, English).
You can take electives on a voluntary basis.
But you don't have to.
How and when do the lessons take place?
Vocational school lasts as long as your training in the company.
The times are regulated differently.
There are:
Part-time lessons on individual days of the week (1-2 days each week)
Part-time teaching as block teaching;
mostly for training occupations with small numbers of trainees (e.g.
B. nine weeks in the company, followed by three weeks of vocational school)
Full-time instruction (only in the basic vocational school year and vocational preparation year;
see below: "Young people without a training place")
How can things continue after that?
You have these options after completing vocational school:
Working in your profession
Attending a technical college or academy
Attending the Berufsoberschule (BOS)
Young people without an apprenticeship
Young people do not always find a training place.
If they have not yet completed compulsory schooling, they are required to attend vocational school.
You have these two options:
1st basic vocational school year (BGJ-s for short)
The basic vocational school year is aimed at young people who have not yet found a training place.
The vocational school also provides practical training in the first year of the apprenticeship.
After successfully completing the course, the apprentice immediately enters the 2nd year of training.
However, there are also training areas in which the BGJ is compulsory.
These include:
Occupations with wood (e.g.
B. Carpenter)
Professions in agriculture
Professions in housekeeping
2. vocational preparation year (BVJ for short)
The BVJ prepares young people for an apprenticeship or vocational activity within one year.
Compulsory vocational school attendance is deemed to have been fulfilled upon successful completion of the BVJ.
If vocational training is subsequently undertaken, the person is again deemed to be required to attend vocational school.
More information is available from the Neusäß State Vocational School Center:
State Vocational School Center Neusäß (BSZ)
District Administrator Dr.
sekretariat@bszneusaess.de
Search terms: learning for a job, no training place, help with training

question: Where can I register for training courses?
context:
Lifelong learning
Education is more than just school knowledge.
School is an important, but not the only place to learn.
This is why the district of Augsburg is committed to education outside of school.
There are lots of interesting things for all ages.
For example:
The interesting offer of the adult education center (VHS) Augsburger Land e.V. with its 34 local facilities.
You can find the offers here.
Numerous activities for children and young people, for example from the Kreisjugendring Augsburg-Land or in the youth centers: You can read all about them here.
Offers from family offices and volunteer centers: all further information under "Family".
You can find offers from educational institutions, clubs or associations on the education portalwww.bildungsportal-a3.de under "Course search" or under "Education locations".
Advice on the topic of lifelong learning
The educational advisory service can advise you on these topics, for example:
Catch up on school-leaving qualifications
Professional orientation
Returning to work
Financial support
Competencies and strengths
Educational offers in the region
Do you have a question?
Then get in touch with us:
Educational counseling

Volkhartstr.

question: What documents are required for asylum procedures?
context:
Residence documents
Residence permit - flight / asylum
Every person who comes to Germany to apply for asylum receives a residence document.
It is often referred to as an "ID card".
The residence document provides information about the status in the asylum procedure and whether there are any restrictions on gainful employment (When am I allowed to work?).
There are five different documents:
1. proof of arrival
Status: Asylum seekers
Background: Issued to persons who have applied for asylum.
Valid for the period between registration as an asylum seeker or
asylum seeker and official application for asylum at the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF).
2. residence permit
Status: Asylum seekers
Background: Issued to carry out an asylum procedure until a decision is made on the asylum application.
The Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) decides on the asylum application.
If the application for asylum is rejected as unfounded, there is the option of lodging a complaint with the administrative court.
The stay is deemed to be permitted until the decision of the administrative court.
The permit for asylum seekers contains conditions regarding employment, residence and, if applicable, spatial restrictions.
If a work permit is required, this can be applied for at the responsible "" foreigners authority (by employer or employee)
Responsible for job placement: "" Employment Agency
Responsible for social benefits: "" Social welfare office
3. fictitious certificate
Status: Recognized refugees
Background: Certificate for the period from the positive decision on the asylum procedure until the residence permit is issued (fiction of permission) or for a phase of review or extension of documents (fiction of continued validity).
4. residence permit
Status: Recognized refugees
Background: positive decision on the asylum application
The residence permit is a temporary residence title.
It is issued for the purposes specified in the Residence Act.
There are various residence permits for refugees on humanitarian grounds.
Opens up the possibility of a later permanent right of residence (settlement permit)
Unrestricted access to the labor market
Responsibility for job placement and social benefits: "" Jobcenter
5. acquiescence
Status: Tolerated
Background: negative decision on the asylum application
A tolerated stay is a suspension of deportation.
It is issued temporarily if deportation is impossible for legal, factual, humanitarian or personal reasons.
General toleration regulation possible for certain groups by order of the highest state authority for a maximum period of 3 months ("deportation stop")
Work permit is generally required, application at the responsible "" foreigners authority (by employer or employee)
Responsible for job placement:"" Employment Agency
Responsible for social benefits: "" Social welfare office

question: How does the "settlement permit" differ from the "residence permit"?
context:
Permanent residence
What residence permits are available for permanent residence?
Settlement permit according to § 9 Residence Act
With a settlement permit, you can live and work in Germany.
Without time and location restrictions.
Prerequisites are for example:
Legal residence in Germany for at least 5 years (previous periods of study and training are credited at 50%)
valid residence permit that was not issued for a temporary purpose (studies) or for humanitarian reasons
Proof of secure livelihood
Proof of secured living space
Proof of sufficient pension provision (at least 60 months of compulsory or voluntary contributions to statutory pension insurance in Germany)
sufficient German language skills and basic knowledge of the legal and social system and living conditions in Germany - usually demonstrated by
successful participation in an integration course
or
through certificates and proof of study relating to vocational training completed in Germany
or
other language certificates
In individual cases, you may need additional documents.
You can find more information on the requirements here.
Permanent residence - EU
Permanent residence - EU is an unlimited residence permit.
It offers the same rights as the settlement permit.
With the permit you can live and work in Germany.
Without time and location restrictions.
You can also live, work or study in other EU countries.
Exceptions are Ireland and Denmark.
Special regulations apply for individual countries.
You can find information on the requirements here.
Which residence permit is right for you?
That depends on your individual circumstances.
The Office for Immigration and Integration will be happy to advise you.

question: What support is available for housing emergencies?
context:
Help with the threat of losing your home
Outpatient emergency housing assistance from Diakonie
Are you afraid of losing your apartment?
For example, because of a notice of termination, an action for eviction or an eviction judgment?
Then you are not alone!
Diakonie's outpatient emergency housing assistance will help you.
The advice center advises you on all questions relating to housing shortages.
The specialists there will support you and arrange further help.
Important: Get help as early as possible!
This way you can meet any deadlines.
And avoid additional costs.

question: How does the Dublin procedure work?
context:
Dublin procedure
Dublin procedure
The Dublin procedure covers the 28 EU member states as well as Norway, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Switzerland.
The Dublin procedure determines which country is responsible for carrying out your asylum procedure.
As a rule, it is the country in which you were registered for the first time.
This is done with an electronic data comparison.
It may be that Germany is not responsible for carrying out your asylum procedure.
If Germany is not responsible, you will be sent back to the country responsible for you.
If you do not agree with this decision, you can seek advice.
You can get professional legal advice on whether it makes sense to file a complaint with the administrative court.
Further information on the Dublin Agreement in German and English

question: What is compulsory insurance?
context:
Health insurance is compulsory
Important: Everyone in Germany must have health insurance.
Statutory or private health insurance?
There is statutory and private health insurance.
Most people have statutory health insurance.
Some people have private health insurance.
You must fulfill certain requirements.
These people in particular have private health insurance:
Self-employed
Employees who earn a lot of money.
If you work, your health insurance is paid for by yourself and your employer.
Health insurance
You take out health insurance with a health insurance company.
There are many health insurance companies in Germany.
The health insurance companies have different services and offers.
Take a close look at the insurance.
Every person is free to choose their health insurance company.
Here you will find an overview of health insurance companies in Germany.
Insurance card
You will receive an insurance card from your health insurance company.
You need the insurance card for medical treatment.
The European Health Insurance Card is on the back.
The European insurance card is called the European Health Insurance Card, or EHIC for short.
This means you are also well covered in all EU countries.
And also in many other European countries.
And you are even insured in some countries outside Europe.
Note:
It is best to always have your insurance card with you.
Then you have the card to hand in the event of a medical emergency.
Information for asylum seekers
Different rules apply to asylum seekers.
Find out more in the section "Information for asylum seekers".
Health promotion and prevention services
Health promotion and prevention services help you to stay healthy.
The aim is to prevent illness.
The risk of illness is reduced by preventive measures.
These offers include, for example:
Nutrition courses
Back training
Yoga courses
etc.
There are many offers for health promotion and prevention.
Most health insurance companies cover all or part of the costs of the services.
Take advantage of the offers!
This way you can protect your health.
Ask your health insurance company about the costs beforehand.
Offers in the district of Augsburg
You can find health promotion and prevention offers in the district of Augsburg in the health portal.
You can find more information here.
Here you will find information for children and young people.

question: How do I fill in Asylum Protection Forms correctly?
context:
Forms of protection in the asylum procedure
Forms of protection in the asylum procedure
Many people are persecuted in their home country.
People can receive protection in Germany.
You have to apply for asylum.
When you apply for asylum, you start an asylum procedure.
It decides whether you are allowed to stay in Germany.
There are various forms of protection under German law.
Because there are different forms of persecution.
Your situation will be looked at closely during the asylum procedure.
You will then be granted a form of protection.
Here you will find an overview of the forms of protection.
Under the links you will find information in German, English, Turkish, Russian, French and Arabic.
Eligibility for asylum
Politically persecuted people are granted asylum in Germany.
This is stated in the Basic Law (Art.
16 A).
You will receive protection status if you are persecuted by the state in your home country because of
Your ethnicity
Your nationality
Your political convictions
Your religion or
Your membership of a particular social group (for example, due to sexual orientation).
Some people also fear punishment if they return to their home country.
This form of protection also applies in this case.
Learn more
Refugee protection
The Geneva Refugee Convention has defined who is considered a refugee.
The definition says: A refugee is outside the country of origin.
He is prosecuted by the state or non-state authorities for one of the following:
Ethnicity
Religion
Nationality
political conviction
Belonging to a certain social group (for example due to sexual orientation)
Legal basis: § 3 para.
Asylum Act (AsylG)
Learn more
Subsidiary protection
People who are at risk of serious harm in their country of origin are eligible for subsidiary protection.
Or who cannot claim the protection of their country of origin.
The threat can come from a governmental or non-governmental source.
These include:
Death penalty
Torture
inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment
serious individual threat to the life or integrity of a civilian as a result of indiscriminate violence in an international or internal armed conflict
Legal basis: § 4 para.
1AsylG
Learn more
National ban on deportation
A person seeking protection may not be deported if
repatriation constitutes a violation of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms (ECHR) or
there is a considerable concrete danger to life, limb or freedom in the country of destination.
Legal basis: § 60 para.
5 AufenthG, § 60 para.
7 Residence Act
Learn more

question: What benefits am I entitled to from the employment agency as a refugee?
context:
Employment agency and unemployment benefit
What does the employment agency do?
The Employment Agency performs the following tasks for citizens:
Careers advice for young people, first-year students and university graduates
Placement of apprenticeships or jobs
Promotion of vocational education and training
Benefits to promote participation in working life (inclusion)
Payment of unemployment benefit I (ALG I for short): Unemployment benefit I is paid to people who have lost their job.
ALG I is an insurance benefit.
Only people who have previously paid into the insurance scheme receive ALG I.
Promotion of equal opportunities for women and men
Information about the job and training market and about employment promotion services and benefits
Payment of child benefit
Which employment agency can I contact?
The Augsburg Employment Agency is responsible for the district of Augsburg:
Augsburg Employment Agency (visitor address)
Wertachstr.
Augsburg@arbeitsagentur.de
Monday to Friday from 8 a.m. to 12 p.m.
www.arbeitsagentur.de

question: Where can I find cheap cell phone rates?
context:
Smartphone
There are two different cell phone contracts in Germany: Prepaid contract and fixed-term contract.
The prepaid contract has no fixed contract term.
This means that you pay a certain amount for a certain period of time (often four weeks).
You do not have to cancel the prepaid contract if you no longer want to use it.
A fixed-term contract has a minimum contract term.
This means that you have to stay with a particular provider for a longer period of time.
The contract is automatically extended if you do not cancel.
If you do not want the contract to be extended automatically, you must cancel in writing.
Pay attention to the notice period.
Ten important questions for concluding a contract:
How high is the basic fee?
Does the fee increase after a certain time?
Is there a minimum monthly turnover (minimum costs per month)?
How long does the contract last (e.g.
B.twelve or 24 months)?
If I don't cancel the contract, it will be automatically renewed.
When do I have to cancel if I don't want to extend the contract?
How much does it cost to set up, switch and deactivate?
Which time cycle (60/1, 10/10) is used for the calculation?
How much does a minute cost (external/own network)?
How much does a cell phone with a contract cost and how much does a cell phone without a contract cost?
How much does the Internet cost?
How much do international calls cost?
You can find important information in five different languages (German, English, Arabic, Russian, Farsi) at the consumer advice center: www.verbraucherzentrale.de (search term: "multilingual information").
There you will also find explanatory videos on the topic in German, English, Arabic and Dari.

question: How can I apply for a work permit?
context:
Work and residence
Not everyone is allowed to work in Germany.
An important criterion is your citizenship or residence permit.
Unrestricted access to the labor market
The following persons have unrestricted access to the German labor market:
Nationals of an EU country
Nationals of the European Economic Area (EEA)
Persons with Swiss nationality
These persons do not require a special permit for employment in Germany.
Groups of persons with special regulations
There are special regulations for certain groups.
For example for:
Specialists
Highly qualified
Holders of the EU Blue Card
Researchers
Self-employed persons
Jobseekers
Employees who come to Germany as part of transfers within their company
Persons with a residence permit
Citizens of a third country require a permit for permanent residence in Germany.
This is called a "residence permit".
The residence permit also includes access to the labor market.
Labor market access for refugees
Refugees with a residence permit
Recognized refugees with a residence permit are allowed to work.
Access to the labor market is normally unrestricted for them.
Asylum seekers in ongoing proceedings
In AnkER facilities
Do you live in an AnkER facility?
Then you are not allowed to work for nine months.
After nine months, you are entitled to a work permit if
you come from a safe country of origin or
your asylum application has been accepted by the BAMF.
The employment agency checks the working conditions.
However, there is no priority check.
Priority check means checking whether the position can be filled by a person registered as a jobseeker in Germany.
You can obtain a work permit from the Office for Immigration and Integration.
You must submit an application for this.
You can find more information here.
Outside of AnkER facilities
Do you come from an unsafe country of origin?
Then you can apply for a work permit after 3 months.
The Office for Immigration and Integration will decide on your work permit.
Tolerated persons in AnkER
You can apply for a work permit after six months of toleration if
you come from a safe country of origin and
The decision on the application is made by the Office for Immigration and Integration.
The employment agency checks the working conditions.
However, there is no priority check.
Priority check means checking whether the position can be filled by a person registered as a jobseeker in Germany.
Persons with a tolerated stay permit due to unclear identity (§ 60b AufenthG) are always prohibited from working.
Tolerated persons outside AnkER
After three months, you can apply for a work permit at the immigration office if
you come from an unsafe country of origin and
The Office for Immigration and Integration will decide on your application.
The employment agency checks the working conditions.
However, there is no priority check.
Priority check means checking whether the position can be filled by a person registered as a jobseeker in Germany.
Persons with a tolerated stay permit due to unclear identity (§ 60b AufenthG) are always prohibited from working.
More information
You can find more information on the subject of residence and work on the BAMF website: www.bamf.de, search term "Access to the labor market"
Questions and information
If you have any questions about residence rights and work permits, the Office for Immigration and Integration is there for you:
Office for Foreigners and Integration
auslaenderamt@LRA-a.bayern.de
You can also make appointments online

question: Which insurance policies are compulsory in Germany?
context:
Insurances
Compulsory insurance
You must have these insurances in Germany:
"Health insurance
For drivers: Motor vehicle liability insurance
For employees: Statutory pension insurance
You can find important information at the consumer advice center: www.verbraucherzentrale.de.
The information is available in these languages:
German
English
Arabic
Farsi
Ukrainian
Romanian
French
Turkish
Bulgarian
Highly recommended: Liability insurance
You have caused harm to a person in Germany?
Then you have to pay compensation according to the law.
Even if it wasn't your intention.
This applies to personal injury, property damage and financial losses in the private sector.
For example, if you cause a traffic accident.
Or when your child breaks a window pane with a ball.
Many landlords and landladies require their tenants to have liability insurance.
Private liability insurance pays for these damages for you and your children.
Liability insurance is not compulsory.
You don't have to lock it.
But we strongly recommend it.
You can find explanatory videos with important information on liability insurance in German, English, Arabic and Dari at the consumer advice center;
Search term: "Multilingual consumer videos".

question: What documents are required for an apartment application?
context:
Apartment viewing
Finding a free apartment is difficult.
Many people often apply for a vacant apartment.
If you can submit important documents at an early stage, you will increase your chances of finding an apartment.
You can combine the documents into an "application folder".
The application folder should contain the following documents:
Cover letter (who am I/we are, what do I do for a living, how old are my children, why would I like to rent the apartment)
Tenant self-disclosure
Copy of ID/residence permit (note: copy front and back)
Copy of the notification from the job center/social welfare office if you are not working;
Proof of salary for the last three months if you are working
Copy of the Schufa information (= information on the solvency and payment behavior of a person;
also explained in a video by the consumer advice center in German, English, Arabic and Dari: www.verbraucherzentrale.de, search term "multilingual information")
Copy of the rental debt exemption
Proof of your liability insurance

question: What services does the Jobcenter offer?
context:
Benefits from the job center
Electricity
The electricity costs are not covered by the Jobcenter.
You have to pay the electricity costs from your own money.
If you rent a new apartment, the landlord or landlady will normally automatically notify the electricity provider (e.g.
B. Municipal utilities).
You can also look for a new provider.
You then have a notice period (usually two weeks).
You can then switch to the electricity provider of your choice.
The Enervie consumer portal provides a neutral overview of all providers.
You can also compare prices there: www.energieverbraucherportal.de.
Tip: The Team Stromsparcheck - SKM Augsburg advises benefit recipients free of charge on their energy consumption after moving in.
You can find all the information here:
www.stromspar-check.de.
Internet/ Television
Internet costs are not covered by the Jobcenter.

question: What educational courses does the technical college offer?
context:
Technical college
Who are technical colleges suitable for?
Technical colleges are for people who
have completed vocational training
who have professional experience.
What does the technical college offer?
The technical college offers in-depth vocational training.
Graduates of the technical college would like to take on management tasks in the future.
Or set up your own business or self-employment.
Duration and goal
Duration:
Full-time for up to two years, depending on the course;
Part-time or part-time for up to 4 years
Degrees:
State final examination or master craftsman examination,
Secondary school leaving certificate,
general higher education entrance qualification,
Fachhochschulreife (after a supplementary examination)
Types of technical schools in Bavaria
Technical colleges
approx.
26 training directions e.g:
Ophthalmic optics,
Metal construction technology,
Vehicle technology and electromobility,
more here

approx.
28 training directions e.g.
Building craftsmen,
Hairdresser,
Gas and water fitter,
Confectioner,
Painters and varnishers,

Wood business management,
Textile business management,

question: What is B2 level in professional German?
context:
Level B2 - for advanced learners
Telenovela: "Jojo seeks happiness"
The Brazilian Jojo comes to Germany.

question: What are the requirements for childcare allowances?
context:
Basic information on childcare
Important information on childcare
In Germany, there are numerous child daycare services in daycare centers and childminders.
Childcare has many advantages for you.
The teachers are very well qualified and do interesting projects with the children.
Your children will learn lots of new things in a positive atmosphere.
Above all, your children will learn German very quickly.
And they come into contact with other children.
That is very important.
Because children need other children to play together, to learn and to make friends.
Several short films on childcare in Germany show all these advantages.
The films are available in German, English, French, Russian, Arabic, Farsi, Dari, Turkish, Kurdish and Tigrin.
You can also see how children learn and play best in their first years of life.

question: Where can I find accommodation and meals?
context:
Services and financial assistance for refugees from Ukraine
Refugees from Ukraine can apply for benefits at the Jobcenter.
This applies to persons who
employable,
in need of help and
are aged between 15 and 65 years and 10 months.
And also their family members.
Do you belong to this group of people?
Then please submit an application to the Jobcenter Augsburger Land as soon as possible.
Information on the change of legal system
You will then be looked after by the Jobcenter.
They switch from the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act (AsylbLG) to the basic income support (SGB II).
Basic benefits for jobseekers in accordance with the Second Book of the German Social Code (SGB II)
Benefits are granted by the Jobcenter Augsburger Land.
These requirements apply in order to apply for benefits from the Jobcenter:
Registration after entering the Federal Republic of Germany
Application for a residence permit at the Foreigners' Registration Office of the District of Augsburg.
What are benefits under SGB II?
Cash benefits to secure your livelihood
Support with integration into work or training
For persons in private accommodation with relatives or acquaintances: reasonable accommodation costs
You can find all the important information here.
How can you submit an application?
You can find the applications, information sheets and documents here.
Here you will find a checklist for submitting your application.
What happens after the benefits have been approved?
Have you been granted benefits under SGB II?
You will then receive a written notification.
The money will be paid into your bank account at the beginning of the month.
Important: You must take out statutory health insurance as soon as possible.
Health insurance is compulsory in Germany.
Every person must have health insurance.
Social assistance benefits in accordance with the Twelfth Book of the German Social Code (SGB XII)
Certain people receive benefits under SGB XII instead of SGB II.
This applies to persons who...
are over 65 years and 10 months old
are permanently fully incapacitated for work (the assessment is made by a German pension insurance institution)
cannot receive benefits from the Jobcenter for other reasons.
Could you be affected by this regulation?
Then contact the social welfare administration responsible for your place of residence.
Important:Do you receive benefits according to SGB XII?
Then you must have health insurance.
If you do not currently have health insurance, health care will be provided with the involvement of the social welfare administration.
You can choose your statutory health insurance yourself.

question: From what age do children in Germany go to school?
context:
School education
How does school-based training work?
You learn a profession mainly in theory at school.
Depending on the profession, you will attend a vocational college, a technical college or a vocational college.
You do internships to gain practical experience.
The apprenticeship lasts two to three and a half years, depending on the profession.
You don't usually receive a salary during your training.
Some professions in Germany can only be learned in school-based training, for example dietician or healthcare and nursing assistant.
How do I find an apprenticeship?
If you would like to do a school-based apprenticeship, apply directly to the school.
In the district of Augsburg, you can complete school-based training at five vocational schools (BFS for short):
BFS for nutrition and care, BFS for childcare and BFS for dietary assistance at the vocational school center / Neusäß
BFS for Nursing / Bobingen
BFS for emergency paramedics / Schwabmünchen (private)

question: How can I benefit from this law as a specialist?
context:
Skilled Immigration Act
What is the Skilled Immigration Act?
Skilled workers can immigrate to Germany more easily.
This applies to specialists with
vocational training lasting at least two years or
University degree.
The Skilled Immigration Act lays down the rules.
You can find out more here.
Criteria for specialists
In principle, the following three criteria are considered:
1) Qualification
With the EU Blue Card, skilled workers with a recognized qualification can come to Germany.
2) Experience
People with professional experience are allowed to come to Germany.
This applies to people who...
have acquired a recognized professional qualification abroad and
have at least 2 years of professional experience.
A salary threshold applies to these people.
This means that you must earn more money than the specified minimum amount.
Persons without a professional qualification recognized abroad must have their professional qualification recognized in Germany.
3) Potential
People without a concrete job offer can also work in Germany.
The opportunity card was introduced for them.
It is based on a points system.
These criteria are taken into account:
Qualification
German and English language skills
Professional experience
Reference to Germany
Age
Potential of spouses and partners
An important innovation for asylum seekers
Are you an asylum seeker?
And you were born before 29.
Then you can apply for a residence permit as a skilled worker.
You don't have to leave the country for this.
And you don't have to go through a visa procedure.
You have to withdraw your application for asylum.
This is what you need:
a corresponding recognized qualification
a job offer or an existing employment relationship
Hotline for individual advice
You can obtain individual advice in German and English via the Federal Government's hotline:
Hotline "Working and living in Germany"
www.make-it-in-germany.com/de/service/kontakt/hotline

question: What are the penalties for violating the Measles Protection Act?
context:
Measles Protection Act
All children must be vaccinated or immune against measles.
The parents must provide proof.
This obligation also applies to children who are cared for in a children's home for at least four weeks.
And also for children in refugee accommodation.
Measles is one of the most contagious infectious diseases.
This is why almost all people without vaccination protection become infected with the virus after just one contact with a sick person.
Measles can lead to serious complications, particularly in children under five and adults over 20.
Inflammation of the middle ear or lungs and diarrhea are among the most common symptoms.
When are vaccinations given?
1st vaccination: Between the age of 11 and the age of 18.
and 14.
Month of life (after the 9th month at the earliest)
2nd vaccination: before the 2nd birthday at the latest
The minimum interval between the two vaccinations is four weeks.
The measles vaccination is given in combination with a vaccination against mumps, rubella and possibly
Chickenpox.
Further information on the measles vaccination can be found at: https://www.masernschutz.de/

Online videos on the asylum procedure in various languages
There are videos explaining the asylum procedure.
They are provided by the Bavarian and Munich Refugee Councils.
The videos are a guide to the asylum procedure.
Refugees can thus complete their asylum procedure in an informed and independent manner.
The videos are a basis for information.
They do not replace detailed advice.
Be sure to seek advice!
This way you can avoid serious mistakes and omissions.

question: What documents are required for the asylum application?
context:
Application for asylum
After registration and accommodation in the reception center, the asylum application is submitted in person.
Are you accommodated in the reception center in the district of Augsburg?
You will then be given an appointment to apply at the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees - Augsburg branch office:
Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF)
Augsburg branch office
service@bamf.bund.de
www.bamf.de (multilingual)
An interpreter will also be available for this appointment.
You submit your application for asylum.
And you will receive important information about the asylum procedure.
You have submitted your application for asylum?
Then you will receive a residence permit.
This is proof of your legal residence in Germany and your application for asylum.
As long as you are accommodated in a reception center, the government of Swabia is responsible for immigration and residence law issues:
Government of Swabia
Central Foreigners Authority Swabia
zab-poststelle@reg-schw.bayern.de
Residence obligation
The residence permit is initially associated with spatial restrictions.
This means that you may only stay in the district of your reception center.
Would you like to leave the area temporarily within the first three months?
Then you need a permit from the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees.
After the three months, you will need a permit from the relevant immigration authority.
Depending on your country of origin and the course of your asylum procedure, this geographical restriction applies for different lengths of time.
Change of address - important note!
Are you in the asylum procedure and have been granted permission or obliged to move?
Then you must inform the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees of your new address yourself.

question: Where can I find religious communities?
context:
Religion
Religion in Germany
Germany is a predominantly Christian country.
Many people belong to the Catholic or Protestant faith.
Of course, there are also many people who belong to other faiths.
In the meantime, many people no longer have a denomination.
This means that you do not belong to any religious community or denomination.
Christianity continues to play a major role in Germany.
That is why there are also many statutory Christian holidays.
Other religious holidays are also observed at school.
Pupils who wish to celebrate religious holidays may be exempted from school.
This should be discussed with the school at an early stage.
Faith is a private matter in Germany.
State and religion are separate.
However, the state and religion work closely together.
For example, there are religious education classes at school.
In Germany, every person is free to choose their own faith.
Religious freedom is a valuable asset.
Religious freedom
Religious freedom is the law in Germany.
Every person has the right to choose and practice their own faith.
The Basic Law must not be violated in the process.
Religious freedom includes:
All people are free to practise and choose their religion and beliefs.
All people have the freedom not to be religious.
Anyone who does not believe in God is allowed to say so publicly.
People of different religions and beliefs are allowed to marry each other.
A marriage must be performed at the registry office.
Only then is it a legally valid marriage.
Any person may also marry within the framework of religion.
However, this is not legally binding in Germany.
The Basic Law can be read in nine languages (German, Arabic, English, Farsi, French, Kurdish-Kurmanci, Russian, Spanish, Turkish): www.bamf.de (search term: "Broschüre: Das Grundgesetz").
Religious houses and associations
There are various intercultural associations, religious sites, initiatives and organizations in the district of Augsburg and the city of Augsburg.
You can find a list here.

question: What do the house rules say?
context:
House rules, waste separation and energy saving
House rules
The cohabitation of many or more people in one house requires mutual consideration and tolerance.
The landlord can stipulate certain rules for the cohabitation of tenants in an apartment building.
These rules are then laid down in the house rules.
The most important contents of house rules are
Quiet times/noise
Waste disposal
Use of the common areas
Ventilate
You can find detailed house rules in different languages here: www.allbau.de/kundenservice/hausordnung
Waste separation
Waste must be disposed of in the garbage cans provided.
There are different garbage cans for plastic, paper and cardboard, for fruit and vegetable waste (organic waste) and for other waste.
Please keep to waste separation, as a large part of the waste is reused and it is an important part of environmental protection.
What belongs in which garbage can?
When are the garbage cans emptied?
Where is there a recycling collection point?
You can find information at www.awb-landkreis-augsburg.de.
You can also use the AbfallApp.
If you have any further questions, you can contact the waste advisory service of the district of Augsburg.
Waste consulting
abfallwirtschaft@LRA-a.bayern.de
You can find information on waste separation here.
Saving energy through ventilation and correct heating
Make sure that you ventilate regularly.
This means that you open the window fully for five minutes at least three times a day.
It is also important that you heat correctly.
This will prevent mold from forming and you can save energy.
You can obtain detailed information and helpful tips in German, English, Russian, Arabic and Farsi from the consumer advice center: www.verbraucherzentrale.de (search term: "multilingual information").

question: Are there German language courses for beginners near me?
context:
Offers for children
German with a sock
German with Socke is a movie series.
It enables children between the ages of 5 and 10 to take their first steps in the German language.
In the individual short videos, Esther (a young woman) talks to Socke (a red sock) about all sorts of things - just like in real life.
Sock is red, imaginative, a bit cheeky and full of energy.
This leads to many situations in which Esther and Socke speak and act together in German.
Children can easily identify with Socke.
This is also the aim of this material: the children - like Socke - should be able to have their say and act in the foreign language.
There are activities and a student booklet to go with the videos.
The bee rescuers
With this free app, children aged 3 and over can learn German through play.
With no prior knowledge of the language, they leave the shelter of the forest together with the squirrel and bear.
They embark on an exciting journey to save the sick bees.
On their way through the snow-covered mountains, they meet animals that help them.
And who teach them more than 900 German vocabulary words.
"The Bee Saviors" can be played on two different difficulty levels and offers up to six hours of fun.
Vocabulary app for children
With the "phase6 hallo Deutsch" app, school-age children (and teenagers) learn German in a fun way.
Each word is first introduced and then practiced with various exercises.
Illustrations and educational games help with this.
The show with the elephant
The little blue elephant and his friends present stories to discover, marvel at and laugh along with for children aged 3 to 6.
One shipment takes approx.
25 minutes and is also very suitable for language development.
Children's channel WDR Mouse
The page with the mouse offers children between the ages of 6 and 9
Knowledge programs (in which, for example, the manufacture or function of an everyday object is explained)
Audio stories
Games
Craft tips
A "Sendung mit der Maus" program presents complex issues in an entertaining and understandable way for children.
One episode lasts approx.
30 minutes.
It is also suitable for language development for children with previous knowledge.
Lingo for kids
With Lingo, children aged 8 to 12 can practise German and learn new things.
There are exciting texts to read and listen to, experiments and craft tips.

question: What German courses are offered for immigrants?
context:
International class at the evening secondary school
You can obtain a German school-leaving certificate in the international class.
Who attends the international class?
Persons who...
come from another country,
are employed,
aged 17 to approx.
are 30 years old.
Goals
Progression to the higher classes of the evening secondary school with the aim of obtaining the secondary school leaving certificate
Consolidation of the German language (language level B2)
Offer
Intensive support in improving the German language.
Additional lessons in a normal evening secondary school class with all regular subjects:
German
Mathematics
English
Physics
History
Geography
Subjects from the compulsory elective subject group "Economics" (business administration / accounting, social studies) or "Social" (social studies, biology)
When do the lessons take place?
Regular lessons from 17:30 to 21:05,
from 16:45: Possibility of study groups, work in the PC room and support in the search for professional activities (possibly
internship).
Prerequisites
Secondary school certificate
Basic knowledge of German and English (German language level B1, English A2) spoken and written
Several years of previous school education in the country of origin or in Germany
Admission interview with school management and / or teacher
Where can I find the International Class?
The international class is affiliated to the evening secondary school for professionals:
Abendrealschule for professionals (on the 1st floor of the Agnes-Bernauer-Schule)
abendrealschule@augsburg.de
www.abendrealschule-augsburg.de

question: What does an asylum seeker orientation course involve?
context:
Initial orientation courses for asylum seekers
Initial orientation courses for asylum seekers with unclear prospects of staying
In an initial orientation course, you will gain your first knowledge of German for everyday life (work, health, mobility, housing).
You will also receive information about life in Germany.
Who can take part?
Asylum seekers who do not come from a country with a high recognition rate
Asylum seekers who do not come from a safe country of origin
If places are available: Asylum seekers with good prospects of staying if they cannot (yet) take part in the integration course
Persons of compulsory school age cannot take part in the initial orientation courses.
How is an initial orientation course structured?
A course consists of six modules.
Each module has 50 teaching units.
A teaching unit lasts 45 minutes and is abbreviated to "UE".
A course has a total of 300 teaching units.
Participation is free of charge.
The language consultations offer you individual advice.
Where can you do an initial orientation course?
These educational institutions offer initial orientation courses:
Vocational Training Centers of the Bavarian Economy (bfz) gGmbH Augsburg
Vocational training center of the Lehmbaugruppe (BBZ) Augsburg gGmbH
DAA - German Employees Academy Augsburg GmbH
You can find an overview of the current initial orientation courses in Augsburg and the surrounding area on the district's website under "Downloads" (on the right-hand side: "2) Current initial orientation courses").

question: What is language level B1 in German?
context:
Level A1 - for beginners
Complete A1 course: "Nico's way"
In this free and comprehensive course you will learn German at A1 level in 18 chapters.
Each chapter begins with a short video.
It is structured in the style of a telenovela.
Through the video you work on exercises and learn the German language step by step with Nico (the protagonist of the telenovela).
For each chapter there are grammar explanations, vocabulary lists, information about the country and the manuscript for the video.
The page can be set to 9 different languages.
For example: English, Arabic, Russian, Polish and more.
Complete A1 course with tutor
In this free course you will learn German at A1 level in 12 lessons with videos, audios, pictures and suitable tasks.
In the learning portal you will find a vocabulary trainer and phrase trainer for each lesson.
This way you can practise your new vocabulary.
You will also be supported by an online tutor who will answer questions or correct texts.
The portal can be set to 19 different languages.
For example: English, Arabic, Turkish, Albanian, Serbian, Polish and many more.
First steps in the German language
This little book offers a first aid in the German language with the alphabet, important terms, some grammatical basics and examples of everyday life.
Translation aids are available in English.
Vocabulary app: "City of words"
This free video game teaches you your first words in German with audio, pictures and example sentences.
You can also meet other players and play together or against each other in the "City of Words" and solve tasks.
The app can be set to 8 different languages.
For example: English, Arabic, Russian, Spanish and more.
Miniseries: "First paths in Germany"
With this free mini-series, you can experience everyday situations with the protagonist Nevin, e.g. on the bus, at the doctor's or looking for an apartment.
You can also watch a short video.
Then you work on exercises to match the video.
Vocabulary trainer
With this free vocabulary trainer you can practise vocabulary, phrases and example sentences for conversational situations, organized by topic.
There are over 50 source languages.
For example: English, Arabic, Polish, Albanian, Serbian and many more.
German forum and online community
Would you like to join a Whatsapp learning group?
Would you like to chat in German with learners from all over the world?
Or are you looking for a learning partnership?
Then you will find what you are looking for in the online community on the Goethe-Institut website.
You will also find various German exercises at all levels, including A1.
Learn German on the Deutsche Welle website
On the Deutsche Welle website you will find various offers for learning German.
You can...
Listen to messages that are spoken more slowly for learners.
learn how Germans live in the Deutschlandlabor.
get to know other learners in the online community.
Watch videos on various topics.
train your listening comprehension.
Read up on grammar questions.
work on many exercises.
The site is available in 30 languages.
For example: English, Arabic, Bosnian, Greek, Polish and many more.
Learn German for beginners
The website offers everything you need to get started in German: grammar rules, vocabulary from different areas of life, idioms, listening comprehension exercises and interactive learning tools.
A placement test helps you to assess your own language skills.
The site is available in five languages:
German
English
Turkish
Arabic
Ukrainian
There is an e-book especially for Ukrainian refugees to learn German.

question: What public holidays does Germany have?
context:
Public holidays, school vacations and time changeover
Holidays
No work is done on a public holiday for religious or secular reasons.
Stores and authorities are closed on these days.
The following holidays are on the same date every year:
01.01.
New Year
06.01.
Three Wise Men
01.05.
Labor Day
08.08.
Peace Festival (only in the city of Augsburg)
15.08.
Assumption of the Virgin Mary
03.10.
Day of German Unity
01.11.
All Saints' Day
25.12.
1st Christmas Day
26.12.
2nd Christmas Day
Other holidays shift from year to year.
You can find an overview of public holidays in Bavaria here.
School vacations
Vacations are the times of the year when pupils are off school.
In Bavaria, the new school year begins every year in September.
Fall vacation: There is a week around All Saints' Day (public holiday).
Christmas vacation: There are two weeks around Christmas and New Year (public holidays).
Winter vacation: There is a week's winter vacation in February.
Easter vacation: There are two weeks of vacation in spring
Whitsun vacation: There are two weeks of vacation in early summer.
Summer vacation: In summer, the school year ends at the end of July/beginning of August with six weeks of vacation.
You can find an overview of all upcoming public vacations and vacations here, for example.
Religious holidays
Jewish, Muslim and Orthodox pupils are exempt from lessons on certain religious holidays: www.km.bayern.de/ministerium/termine/ferientermine.html
Please inform the school if your child cannot come to school due to these holidays.
Intercultural calendar
The intercultural calendar provides an overview of the most important holidays of the different religious communities.
Time change
There is also a time change in Germany.
This means that the clock is set forward by one hour from winter to summer time.
The clock is set back by one hour from summer to winter time.

question: How can I get financial support for contraceptives?
context:
Contraceptive fund
Every woman and every couple should be able to make their own decision about the timing of a pregnancy and the number of children.
For this reason, the district of Augsburg provides a contraceptive fund.
This means that the district covers the cost of contraceptives for certain people.
Please note: The fund is capped.
A certain amount is earmarked for the contraceptives fund.
Once this limit has been exhausted, no more costs can be covered.
There is no legal claim.
It is a voluntary service provided by the district.
For whom are the costs covered?
These requirements must be met:
Residence in the district of Augsburg
at least 23 years old (under 23 years old the statutory health insurance covers the costs)
Receipt of social benefits:
Citizen's income (SGB II),
Social assistance (SGB XII),
Housing benefit,
Child supplement or
Benefits under the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act (AsylbLG).
What costs are covered?
The costs for:
Pill
Copper IUD
Hormone coil
Hormone implant
Three-month injection
Vaginal ring
Contraceptive patch
Sterilization for women and men
The contraceptive method must be prescribed by a doctor.
How do you apply for the costs to be covered?
You submit your application to the pregnancy counseling service at the Augsburg District Office.
You must seek advice from the office beforehand.
Augsburg District Office
schwangerenberatung@LRA-a.bayern.de
You can also use the virtual citizens' office.
What do you need for the application?
Notification of your social benefit
Identity card and confirmation of registration
for the pill, vaginal ring or contraceptive patch: prescription from a doctor
for IUDs, three-monthly injections, hormone implants or sterilization: cost proposal from a doctor
Consultation with the pregnancy counseling service
Invoice from the pharmacy or doctor or
of the doctor (dated after the consultation at the pregnancy counseling)
Keywords: contraception, conception, contraception protection, no baby, don't want to get pregnant, pregnancy
