question: What does "bicycle transport" on trains mean?
context:
Bicycle
Bicycle
Cycling is fun in the Augsburg district!
A well-developed network of cycle paths with excellent signposting makes cycling not only a sporting hobby, but also a healthy and inexpensive alternative to buses, trains and cars.
For people who enjoy cycling, here are a few tips:
Always drive on the right-hand side of the road
Do not ride side by side, but one behind the other.
If there is a cycle path, you must ride on the cycle path (always on the right-hand side of the road in the direction of travel).
Only children up to the age of eleven may use the footpaths by bicycle.
It is dangerous if you hit the streetcar tracks with your tires.
You can find important traffic rules in a flyer from theADFC (Allgemeiner Deutscher Fahrrad-Club) Munich in 12 different languages (Albanian, Arabic, German, English, Farsi, French, Italian, Kurdish, Russian, Spanish, Tigrinya and Turkish): www.adfc-muenchen.de/adfc-muenchen/arbeitsgruppen/asyl/
Acquisition and repairs
When buying, make sure that your bike is equipped as follows and is therefore roadworthy.
If your bike is not properly equipped, you will have to pay a fine if it is checked by the police:
Front and rear light
Reflector front and rear
Reflectors in the spokes (two per wheel)
Reflectors on the pedals
Bell
Two independent brakes
Addresses of used bike stores and repair workshops in the city and state of Augsburg:
TheZ bicycle workshop
Bahnhofstr.
Friday 15:00 - 18:00
fahrradwerkstatt@die-z.de
Chain and crank (used bikes, repairs)
Monday to Friday, 8 a.m. to 3 p.m., Thursday, 8 a.m. to 5.30 p.m.
Der Fahrrad-Laden Lechhausen (used bicycles)
Wednesday and Friday, 6pm to 8pm (April-September) or 4pm to 6pm (October-March)
Bikekitchen Augsburg (repair bikes yourself, with instructions)
Thursday, 6pm to 8pm, every first Friday of the month, 4pm to 8pm
For people who enjoy cycling...
For people who enjoy cycling, the Augsburg district cycling officer is open to requests, ideas and criticism.
Cycling officer
Jonas Fricke
radverkehr@LRA-a.bayern.de
Have you discovered a disturbing or dangerous spot on the cycle path?
With the STADTRADELN reporting platform, you can also easily report annoying or dangerous spots.
Help the district of Augsburg to make the cycle paths safer atwww.landkreis-augsburg.de/radar or via the free "Stadtradeln" app.

question: Which integration courses can I attend in Germany?
context:
German courses
Integration courses
Adult refugees from Ukraine have the opportunity to take part in an integration course free of charge.
A certificate of eligibility is required to take part in an integration course.
You can get the certificate of eligibility either from the Jobcenter or from the BAMF.
Certificate of eligibility from the Jobcenter
Anyone who is registered with the Jobcenter and receives benefits (AlgII) has been obliged by the Jobcenter to attend an integration course since July.
This means that the Jobcenter sends you the certificate of eligibility.
You can use this to register for a German course at a language school.
Anyone who is registered with the Jobcenter and is obliged to attend an integration course must register for a German course.
You can find out which language schools offer integration courses and when new courses start on an overview list, which is updated monthly for the district and city of Augsburg.
The current list can be found on the website of the District Office here under "Downloads" under "Integration courses".
Authorization certificate from the BAMF
You can apply for the authorization certificate at the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF).
As soon as the refugees have received a fictitious certificate (= temporary residence permit from the foreigners authority) or their residence title, they can submit a voluntary application for admission to the integration course to the BAMF.
You can find the application form on the BAMF website here.
Step 1: Fill out the application for admission to the integration course:
Enter personal data
Reason for entering Germany: "Other reasons: War in Ukraine"
Justification of the application for admission to the integration course: "Other
Reasons: German needed to live and work in Germany"
Signature of the applicant
"I apply for exemption from the cost contribution for the integration course: I am
financially needy for other reasons" (proof is not required).
be settled, as refugees from Ukraine with the admission
automatically exempt from the cost contribution obligation and thus the course
free of charge).
Signature of the applicant
Step 2: Make a copy of the ID card
Make a copy of the fictitious certificate or residence permit and send it to the
Enclose application
Step 3: Submit application
The completed application together with a copy of the ID card
to the following address:
Federal Office for Migration and Refugees,
Streitfeldstr.
39
Step 4: Wait for an answer from the BAMF
As soon as the BAMF has processed the application, you will receive the
Authorization certificate sent to you.
Step 5: Find a language school and register
With the authorization certificate from the BAMF, you can register with a
Register for an integration course at a language school.
Which language schools offer integration courses and when new courses
can be found on an overview list that is published monthly for the district of
and the city of Augsburg.
The current list can be found on the website of the District Office here under "Downloads" under "Integration courses".
You can also find more information about the integration course on the BAMF website here.
You can find help with the application process and other questions on the subject at the language advice centers at the Augsburg District Office.
And finally, a tip: Until you receive your residence permit and then, in a second step, the certificate of eligibility for an integration course from the BAMF, you may be able to bridge the gap with free online courses.
A compilation of links and tips for online learning can be found here.
Entry courses
The vhs Augsburger Land offers online courses for beginners in German.
You can find the courses on offer here.
Language course advice in Ukrainian and Russian

question: How much does a childhood vaccination cost in Germany?
context:
STIKO recommendation for combination vaccinations
The Standing Committee on Vaccination (STIKO) currently recommends these combination vaccinations for children up to the age of 12:
1. 6-fold combination vaccine against diphtheria, tetanus (tetanus), polio, whooping cough (pertussis), Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), hepatitis B:
Other vaccine combinations are also possible.
For example, the vaccination is also available without Hib and/or hepatitis B.
The 2+1 vaccination schedule is intended for this combination vaccination.
The 1st vaccination should be given at the age of 2 months (from the 8th week of life).
The 2nd vaccination should be scheduled eight weeks later (at the age of 4 months).
The 3rd dose should be planned another six months later, i.e. at the age of 11 months.
At five to six years of age, you should have the vaccination booster.
You should have a second booster against diphtheria, polio and whooping cough between the ages of 9 and 17.
After that, the vaccination can be renewed every ten years.
Information on the individual diseases
Diphtheria
Diphtheria is a bacterial infectious disease.
Diphtheria affects the mucous membranes of the throat and the skin.
Tetanus (lockjaw)
The tetanus bacterium often hides in the soil.
Small wounds or bites from splinters and thorns are sufficient for the bacterium to enter the body.
Polio
Approx.
95% of those infected do not notice their infection.
About 5% have a fever, sore throat and headache.
For every 100.
Infected patients develop permanent, flaccid paralysis of the arm or leg muscles.
In the worst case, this can lead to paralysis of the speech, swallowing or breathing muscles.
Whooping cough (pertussis)
The disease has flu-like symptoms.
The symptoms last approx.
for two weeks.
In the following four to six weeks, agonizing coughing fits occur, which can lead to vomiting.
Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
The rather unknown disease "Hib" can be particularly serious for infants and small children.
Possible consequences are meningitis and epiglottitis.
Hepatitis B
The risk of contracting hepatitis B is relatively low for infants without a family history of the disease (i.e. other family members with a known history of the disease).
Nevertheless, the STIKO recommends vaccination, especially as there is a high risk of chronic forms of the disease following an illness.
Chronic means that the disease develops slowly and lasts a long time.
2. combination vaccine against mumps, measles, rubella (MMR) and, if applicable
Chickenpox (MMRV):
With this vaccine combination, the 1st vaccination is recommended for children aged 11 to 14 months.
The second vaccination can be given after a minimum interval of four weeks, but no later than 15 to 23 months of age.
Information on the individual diseases
Mumps
Mumps is characterized by inflammation and swelling of the parotid glands.
Approx.
1/3 of sick infants do not develop any signs of the disease themselves, but are infectious to other people.
Rubella
Rubella is dangerous for pregnant women.
Infection can damage the woman's unborn child during the first four months of pregnancy.
A high number of vaccinated people can prevent the virus from spreading across the country.
This is why the vaccination recommendation is not only aimed at girls and women who want to have children.
Chickenpox (varicella)
Chickenpox is extremely easy to transmit.
Any contact with an infected person leads to infection.
The consequences of chickenpox are fever and fatigue in the first few days.
This is later followed by a skin rash with blisters on the face, body, arms and legs.
Mucous membranes and the hairy scalp can also be affected by the rash.

question: What documents are required for a Schengen visitor visa?
context:
Visitor visa (Schengen visa)
Visitor visa (Schengen visa)
Holders of a valid Schengen visa (text on the visa label: "valid for Schengen states" in the language of the issuing state) may stay in the entire Schengen area for a period of 180 days up to 90 days.
Here you can get more information (also in English)
Please note that you must leave the country within the period of validity of your visa.
You must leave the Schengen area to do this.
A Schengen visa that has not been issued by the embassy for three months can be extended in Germany.
However, the requirements for this must still be met.
It is not possible to change the purpose of the visa.
The application must be justified.
These can be reasons:
force majeure,
humanitarian, professional or serious personal reasons.
If you do not have your visa extended by the foreigners authority and only leave the country after your visa has expired, you are breaking the law.
The foreigners authority will then check whether your stay must be terminated.
Re-entry would only be possible if there is no re-entry ban.
There may also be criminal proceedings in court.

question: What documents are required for the residence permit?
context:
Register and log in
Applying for a residence permit
After registering, you can apply for a residence permit (here: residence permit) at the Office for Immigration and Integration at the Augsburg District Office.
You can find the application form here.
Appointment at the Office for Immigration and Integration
An appointment with the Office for Immigration and Integration is required for the application.
Appointments can be booked online here.
When booking an appointment online, "Your session has expired" appears first.
You must then click on "Book new appointment".
As "Service" you must select "Residence permit for humanitarian reasons (asylum)".
Then click on the appropriate box with the first letter of your surname and enter the number of people (including children) who require a residence permit.
The waiting times for an appointment are approx.
4 weeks.
You have to be patient.
A lot of people need an appointment at the moment.
You must bring the following documents with you to the appointment:
Passport and birth certificate, alternatively: other proof of identity proving origin Ukraine
if available: Allocation notice for the district of Augsburg
Registration of residence with the responsible residents' registration office
The address for the appointment:
You don't speak German well yet?
Then bring an interpreter with you to the appointment.
The residence permit also gives permission to take up gainful employment with unrestricted access to the labor market.
For further information, please contact the Office for Foreigners and Integration at the Augsburg District Office.

question: What does the Asylum Seekers Benefits Act cover in the district of Augsburg?
context:
The district of Augsburg
What is a district?
A district is an association of several towns, markets or municipalities.
A total of 46 towns, markets and municipalities belong to the district of Augsburg.
The district of Augsburg
The district of Augsburg is an attractive place to live and work.
This is why more and more people are moving to the district.
A little more than 250,000 people now live here.
This makes the district of Augsburg the third largest district in Bavaria.
The district of Augsburg is very popular with companies, investors and start-ups.
For example because of
the central location between Munich and Stuttgart
its proximity to the city of Augsburg
ideal transport connections.
The district of Augsburg combines an attractive economic area with an excellent quality of life.
Here you can enjoy pure joie de vivre in a wonderful natural and cultural landscape.
City or country?
The district of Augsburg surrounds the city of Augsburg from the north, west and south.
Nevertheless, the city of Augsburg and the district of Augsburg are two independent municipalities.
The city and state of Augsburg work closely together in many areas.
Together with the district of Aichach-Friedberg, the district and the city of Augsburg form the A3 region: www.region-a3.com.

question: What are the benefits of participating in self-help groups?
context:
Self-help
Self-help groups
There are difficult situations in life.
Then it is good and important to talk to other people.
Many people have already experienced similar situations.
You can exchange ideas with those affected in self-help groups.
A self-help group provides a protected environment for such discussions.
Any affected person can take part.
You can find an overview of self-help groups in the district and region of Augsburg here.
Search for a self-help group
Are you looking for a self-help group?
Then this post will help you:
Contact point for self-help groups

question: Where can I find free application help in Germany?
context:
Writing applications
If you have found an interesting job advertisement, you must write an application.
An application consists of three parts:
Cover letter
Curriculum vitae
Certificates
The following office will help you write your application:
Employment Agency - Vocational Information Center (BiZ)
Monday to Wednesday: 7.30 a.m. to 4 p.m., Thursday: 7.30 a.m. to 6 p.m., Friday: 7.30 a.m. to 12 noon
There are many tips and examples for writing an application on the Internet:
Make it in Germany (in 14 foreign languages)
Just landed (in six foreign languages)
Planet profession
Writing unsolicited applications
There is no specific position you would like to apply for?
But would you like to work in a particular company?
Then you can send an unsolicited application to this company.
Because there are always vacancies in companies.
In such cases, companies often resort first to applications that have already been received.
An unsolicited application can therefore be worthwhile!
An unsolicited application consists of the same parts as a normal application.
Nevertheless, there are a few things to bear in mind.
You can find tips on the Internet, for example at:
www.bewerbung.com/initiativbewerbung
www.azubiyo.de/bewerbung/initiativbewerbung
www.karrierebibel.de/initiativbewerbung

question: How can I cancel my contract with the license fee (GEZ)?
context:
Internet, TV and broadcasting license fee (GEZ)
Internet and TV
You are free to choose your provider.
You often have to adhere to a minimum contract term of 24 months with your old provider.
Termination is only possible in special cases.
Broadcasting fee (GEZ) - compulsory
In Germany, every household has to pay broadcasting fees.
This finances public broadcasting media in Germany.
Some people may be exempt from this fee obligation.
For example, if you receive social benefits or have other reasons for exemption.
More information (also in other languages) is available here: www.rundfunkbeitrag.de/welcome/index_ger.html
Information for asylum seekers
You have no legal right to television (TV) in your asylum accommodation.
This means that there does not have to be a television in the accommodation.
Maybe you have a television.
You may then be sent an invoice for the broadcasting fee.
If you receive an invoice: Show it to your accommodation provider.

question: How can I find a shared flat?
context:
Shared flats (WGs)
In a shared flat, people live together who are usually not a family.
You can live with friends or strangers in a shared flat.
If you are looking for an apartment for yourself, a shared flat can be a good alternative to an apartment of your own.
Living in a shared flat means that you share an apartment with other people.
Each flatmate has their own room.
You only share communal areas such as the bathroom, kitchen or living room.
You save money if you live in a shared flat.
You share the rent in a shared flat.
The best way to find free rooms in shared flats is either on the website "WG-gesucht" ( www.wg-gesucht.de ) or on the corresponding Facebook pages or
Groups such as "WG & apartment Augsburg wanted".
For refugees, there is a special platform called "Zusammenleben Willkommen" (Living Together Welcome) for finding a shared flat and with some explanations and insights into life in a shared flat.

question: What is the difference between a Bachelor's and a Master's degree?
context:
The German higher education system and helpful links
Would you like to study in Germany?
Then you need the school-leaving certificate "Abitur" or "Fachabitur".
Do you have a university admission from your home country?
Then you can also study in Germany.
You must have your university admission from your home country recognized.
You can find the information here.
You need language level C1 to study.
Types of universities
There are different types of universities in Germany.
The universities lead to various degrees and career paths:
Universities
They have a strong scientific orientation.
If you would also like to obtain a doctorate, a university is suitable for you.
Universities of Applied Sciences
They are very practice-oriented.
Art, film and music academies
At these universities, the focus is on artistic subjects such as fine arts, drama, graphics, singing or modern media.
All universities offer Bachelor's and Master's degree programs.
There are state and private universities:
Most universities in Germany are financed by the state.
They are state-owned.
Private universities are independent of the state.
Some of them charge high tuition fees.
University and colleges in Augsburg
University (www.uni-augsburg.de)
University of Applied Sciences (www.hs-augsburg.de/international)
Private University of Applied Sciences for Economics and Management (short: FOM) for professionals (www.fom.de/hochschulzentren/augsburg)
Advice for prospective students
Are you interested in studying in Germany?
Then there are offices and agencies that can help you.
In Germany, these advice centers are called either "Akademisches Auslandsamt" or "International Office".
There you will receive advice on all questions relating to your studies.
These offices also organize many intercultural activities.
This makes it easier for you to get to know German and other foreign students in Augsburg.
Interesting links about studying in Germany
You can find general information about studying in Germany here: www.daad.de/de/ (also in English)
www.study-in-germany.de (in German and English)
Free preparatory course for university studies in Germany: Ready for Study
Free online university for refugees: KironOpenHigher Education

question: What does vacation entitlement during an internship mean?
context:
Rights and obligations during an internship
Internship contract
No internship contract is required.
But it's good to have an internship contract.
This is because the regulations for the internship are laid down there.
Working hours
Depending on age, there are different regulations on working hours during internships:
Under 15 years of age: Work is generally prohibited.
This does not apply to internships for school pupils, for example.
Adolescents aged 13 and over may also carry out light activities (e.g.
e.g. tutoring, delivering newspapers).
Young people under the age of 15 are under special protection: they may work a maximum of 7 hours per day and a maximum of 35 hours per week.
Between the ages of 15 and 18: Young people of this age may work a maximum of 8 hours per day and a maximum of 40 hours per week.
Over 18 years: The regular working time of 8 hours per day should apply.
However, regular means that there may be exceptions.
If there is a lot to do, interns are allowed to work more than 8 hours.
A maximum of 10 hours may be worked per day.
Breaks
People on internships may and must also take breaks.
Age also plays a role in the break times:
Under 18 years of age: If you work between 4.5 and 6 hours, you must take a 30-minute break.
For more than 6 hours even 60 minutes.
Over 18 years: If you work for more than 6 hours, you must take a 30-minute break.
For working hours of more than 9 hours, even 45 minutes.
Duty of confidentiality
Interns learn a lot about the company during their internship.
Much of the information is confidential.
This means that interns are not allowed to pass on this information.
This is called "confidentiality".
For example:
One person is doing an internship in a doctor's surgery.
She learns a lot about the patients there.
For example, the names and illnesses of the patients.
She must not disclose this information to anyone.
Illness
In the event of illness, the intern must inform the internship company immediately.
Interns often need a medical certificate from a doctor.
It is best to ask the internship company whether a certificate is required.
Vacation
There is no entitlement to vacation during a mandatory internship.
It is possible to take vacation during a voluntary internship.
But only if the internship lasts more than 4 weeks.
The vacation days depend on the age of the intern and the duration of the internship.
Behavior in the workplace
Interns mean time and work for the internship company.
Interns should be aware of this.
Interns should therefore behave accordingly.
You can find tips on this under "Ten tips for interns".
Entitlement to an internship certificate
Interns are entitled to an internship certificate.
This means that the company or business must issue an internship certificate.
The internship certificate is important for the intern.
It helps later when applying for an apprenticeship or job.
It describes which activities the intern has carried out.
Sometimes the assessment of your performance during the internship is also included in the certificate.

question: Where can I find a driving school for the German driving license?
context:
Car and moped
German driver's license
You need a driver's license to drive in Germany.
You have to get your driver's license at a driving school.
You have driving lessons there.
At the end you have an exam.
The exam consists of two parts: A written part and a practical part.
You have to pay for the driver's license yourself.
You may drive a car alone from the age of 18.
Young people can get their driver's license at the age of 17.
However, they may only drive with an adult.
This is called "accompanied driving".
Foreign driver's license
Would you like to drive in Germany?
And you already have a driver's license from your home country?
Then your driver's license may also be valid in Germany.
However, you may also have to retake the practical and/or theoretical exam.
The driver's license of people with EU citizenship is generally recognized.
Driving licenses from third countries such as Syria, Iraq or Afghanistan are usually not recognized in Germany.
The theoretical exam is available in many languages: German, Arabic, Turkish, Spanish, French, Russian, Polish, Romanian, Italian, Portuguese and English.
The driving license authority can answer questions about your driving license:
Driving license authority
fahrerlaubnis@LRA-a.bayern.de
Opening hours and further information can be found at www.landkreis-augsburg.de/auto-verkehr.
Moped driver's license
You also need a driver's license for a moped.
You have to take driving lessons at a driving school.
You then have to pass an exam.
You have to pay for the driver's license yourself.

question: What does "Berufs Deutsch" mean in German?
context:
German at work
German at the workplace
There is a wide range of exercises at levels A1 to C1 relating to everyday working life.
On this page you will find an overview.
There you will get to know different professions.
You can practise professional situations, such as making a phone call, writing a business letter or an application.
There are many tasks for different professional fields: social and technical professions, professions in the trades, in the office, in the service sector or in culture.
You can use it to practise typical language actions and communication situations for your job.
You will also learn important vocabulary.
Vocabulary for the profession
The Lunes app accompanies you at school, in training and at work.
The app provides support with technical terms and job-specific vocabulary.
You will find numerous vocabulary words with pictures in various modules.
A read-aloud function helps you to learn.
Different types of exercises (multiple choice, practicing articles or writing whole words) make it easier to learn and remember vocabulary.
And it's fun at the same time.
Vocabulary for the job
On this page you will find lists of the most important vocabulary for your everyday working life.
You can choose between different professions.
For example: geriatric care, electronics, specialist sales, horticulture, machine and plant management, carpentry and many more.
You can visit the site in English, Arabic, Farsi, Russian and Turkish.
B1 - German on the job
With this free course you can practise German for your job.
You can choose from the following professions: Catering, plant engineering, building cleaning, nursing, retail.
There are seven learning units for each occupational field.
They contain videos and tasks that will help you learn the vocabulary, phrases and typical sentences used in the respective industry.
B2 - German for the workplace
In this free course you will learn German for the workplace at B2 level in 20 lessons with videos, audios, pictures and suitable tasks.
A tutor will support you online.
He or she answers questions or corrects texts.
German for construction workers
This platform is specifically for people who work on construction sites or would like to work there.
The platform is for people who speak little or no German.
20 lessons prepare you linguistically for working on construction sites.
You will get to know the work on a construction site.
You will also learn a lot about health and safety on construction sites.
You also learn to communicate in your job.
Each lesson consists of a video and exercises on vocabulary, grammar and pronunciation.
App: "One day of German - in care"
This app is for learners of German from level B1.
They practise vocabulary, grammar and pronunciation for medical and nursing professions in a playful way.
They also deepen their communication skills from conversations with patients, colleagues and superiors.
The app is free of charge.

question: What documents are required for registration?
context:
Registration after arrival
Registration for people in private accommodation or in decentralized asylum accommodation
Ukranian refugees live in private apartments.
Or in decentralized asylum accommodation.
They are all registered with the Office for Foreigners and Integration of the Augsburg District Office.
Registration procedure
This is how registration works:
1. fill in the form
You fill out the form for a simplified initial registration.
A few days later you will receive a certificate by post.
With the certificate you can then look for work.
2. presentation at the Office for Foreigners and Integration
Arrange a personal appointment at the Office for Foreigners and Integration of the Augsburg District Office.
Go to this page: Online appointment system
Select "Residence permit for humanitarian reasons (asylum)".
Then select the alphabetical assignment of your surname (last name).
In the online appointment system you will find all the appointments of the Foreigners' Registration Office for the next four weeks.
If no dates are displayed, all dates are fully booked.
New dates are added regularly.
Try again at a later date!
You should be patient.
Many people need an appointment at the moment.
For the appointment you need:
Passport and birth certificate (alternatively: other proof of identity that proves your origin from Ukraine)
If available: Allocation notice for the district of Augsburg
Registration of residence with the responsible residents' registration office
Biometric photograph
3. register residence
Register your place of residence.
You do this with your municipality.
Please make an appointment at the Residents' Registration Office.
Registration after arrival at the anchor center
Ukrainians without private accommodation can find a first point of contact at the ANKER Center of the Swabian government.
Here you will find the ANKER Center.
People without private accommodation should register there.
This is the first important step towards obtaining a humanitarian residence permit.
Registration takes place on site at the ANKER facility in Swabia.
Those registered receive a so-called "white paper".
This is the basis for further necessary steps and official procedures.
You can find the most important questions on entry and residence on the website of the Federal Ministry of the Interior here.
Unaccompanied refugee minors
More and more people are having to leave their homes because of the war in Ukraine.
Among them were numerous accompanied and unaccompanied children and young people.
The Office for Youth and Family Affairs is looking for people who take in children and young people without a legal guardian.
Some people have accompanied children and young people to Germany without their parents.
They should contact the Office for Youth and Family Affairs.
You can find a sample power of attorney for custody here:
Parental power of attorney
Power of attorney for custody of third person
For the application, you will need the identity documents of the person giving and receiving the power of attorney.
Would you like to take in children and young people from Ukraine?
Then contact the Office for Youth and Family Affairs:
Office for Youth and Family
Ulrich Kappl

question: Who can help me register if I don't speak German?
context:
Registration after arrival
Registration for people in private accommodation or in decentralized asylum accommodation
Ukranian refugees live in private apartments.
Or in decentralized asylum accommodation.
They are all registered with the Office for Foreigners and Integration of the Augsburg District Office.
Registration procedure
This is how registration works:
1. fill in the form
You fill out the form for a simplified initial registration.
A few days later you will receive a certificate by post.
With the certificate you can then look for work.
2. presentation at the Office for Foreigners and Integration
Arrange a personal appointment at the Office for Foreigners and Integration of the Augsburg District Office.
Go to this page: Online appointment system
Select "Residence permit for humanitarian reasons (asylum)".
Then select the alphabetical assignment of your surname (last name).
In the online appointment system you will find all the appointments of the Foreigners' Registration Office for the next four weeks.
If no dates are displayed, all dates are fully booked.
New dates are added regularly.
Try again at a later date!
You should be patient.
Many people need an appointment at the moment.
For the appointment you need:
Passport and birth certificate (alternatively: other proof of identity that proves your origin from Ukraine)
If available: Allocation notice for the district of Augsburg
Registration of residence with the responsible residents' registration office
Biometric photograph
3. register residence
Register your place of residence.
You do this with your municipality.
Please make an appointment at the Residents' Registration Office.
Registration after arrival at the anchor center
Ukrainians without private accommodation can find a first point of contact at the ANKER Center of the Swabian government.
Here you will find the ANKER Center.
People without private accommodation should register there.
This is the first important step towards obtaining a humanitarian residence permit.
Registration takes place on site at the ANKER facility in Swabia.
Those registered receive a so-called "white paper".
This is the basis for further necessary steps and official procedures.
You can find the most important questions on entry and residence on the website of the Federal Ministry of the Interior here.
Unaccompanied refugee minors
More and more people are having to leave their homes because of the war in Ukraine.
Among them were numerous accompanied and unaccompanied children and young people.
The Office for Youth and Family Affairs is looking for people who take in children and young people without a legal guardian.
Some people have accompanied children and young people to Germany without their parents.
They should contact the Office for Youth and Family Affairs.
You can find a sample power of attorney for custody here:
Parental power of attorney
Power of attorney for custody of third person
For the application, you will need the identity documents of the person giving and receiving the power of attorney.
Would you like to take in children and young people from Ukraine?
Then contact the Office for Youth and Family Affairs:
Office for Youth and Family
Ulrich Kappl
Volkhartstr.
4-6.
Ulrich.
Kappl@LRA-a.bayern.de

question: What is the difference between LED and energy-saving lamps?
context:
Save energy
How and where can energy be saved?
Saving energy means achieving the desired "performance" with less final energy (electricity, fuels and combustibles).
But it also means simply doing without something for once.
We can save energy everywhere: in the home, in industry and commerce and in transportation.
This will pay off sooner or later through the energy costs saved.
This brings double benefits: for the environment and for your wallet.
This checklist tells you how you can save money by using as little electricity and hot water as possible.
To prevent mold from forming in your home, it is important to heat and ventilate properly.
The checklist is available in German, English, Arabic, Kurdish and Dari.

question: What does gender equality mean in Germany?
context:
Equality between women and men
Legally, women and men are equal in Germany.
This means that women and men have the same rights in Germany.
Every person - whether man or woman - is allowed to decide about themselves and their own life.
Women and men should have the same opportunities - personally, professionally and within the family.
In everyday life, equality between women and men has not yet been achieved in Germany.
This is why the federal government actively promotes equality.
For example, through these activities:
The compatibility of family and career is promoted by measures such as parental allowance, the expansion of childcare and all-day education and childcare services in elementary school.
The German government is committed to increasing the number of women in management positions.
Women still earn less than men.
In future, men and women should receive the same salary for equivalent work.
The so-called "Remuneration Transparency Act" makes a valuable contribution to this.
The law makes it possible for employees to receive information about the criteria and procedures according to which they are paid.

question: What is TBE and how can I avoid it?
context:
Further STIKO vaccination recommendations
1. tBE (tick-borne encephalitis)
TBE is transmitted via tick bites.
Possible consequences of the disease are inflammation of the brain, the meninges and the spinal cord.
Bavaria, Baden-Württemberg and southern parts of Hesse, Thuringia and Saxony in particular are considered risk areas in Germany.
Vaccination against TBE is recommended by the STIKO in these areas in particular.
All children can be vaccinated against TBE from their 1st birthday.
2. flu (influenza)
Influenza is as contagious as a normal cold (flu-like infection).
Transmission in kindergartens and schools usually occurs from child to child.
Or about objects.
Children with pre-existing conditions are particularly affected.
They can lead to complications such as pneumonia.
The recommendation for an annual flu vaccination is therefore only aimed at children with a higher risk of complications.
You can find further information on the pre-existing conditions concerned here.
3. HPV (human papillomavirus)
Papillomaviruses can cause cancer in the long term.
Vaccination can therefore reduce the risk of cancer of the cervix, anus, penis and throat.
Vaccination before the first sexual contact offers the best protection.
Both vaccinations are recommended between the ages of 9 and 14.
4. meningococci
Meningococci are bacteria that can cause bacterial meningitis or blood poisoning (sepsis).
Children under the age of 5 and adolescents in particular are among the risk groups.
Vaccination against meningococcal type C is recommended at the age of 12 months.
There is currently no general recommendation for vaccinations against other types (B and ACWY).
The bacteria are transmitted via the so-called
Droplet infection.
This means, for example, coughing, sneezing or kissing.
5. pneumococci
Pneumococcus is the most common pathogen causing serious bacterial infections.
They can cause meningitis, pneumonia or middle ear infections.
They are particularly dangerous for babies and small children.
Three vaccinations against pneumococci are recommended.
These should be administered at the same time as the vaccination against tetanus, diphtheria and whooping cough.
6. rotaviruses
Rotaviruses are the most common cause of diarrhea and vomiting in children.
The pathogen is very contagious.
This is why almost all children contract the disease in the first five years - usually at the age of 2.
In infants in particular, a large loss of fluids and salt can lead to dangerous dehydration.
This may have to be
be treated in hospital.
Vaccination against rotaviruses is given two or three times, depending on the vaccine.
The first vaccination should be given between 6 weeks and 2 months of age.
The second vaccination at 3 months.
And the third, if necessary, at 4 months.
Vaccination against the coronavirus is currently only recommended for children aged 5 to 11 years with the "Comirnaty" vaccine from BioNTech/Pfizer.
Vaccinations can be given three to six weeks apart between the first and second vaccination.
The vaccination recommendation is primarily aimed at children who have an increased risk of a severe course due to a previous illness.
In addition, the recommendation also applies to children who are surrounded by people with a high risk of severe COVID-19 if they cannot be vaccinated themselves or the vaccination protection is not sufficient.
There is currently no recommendation for children without pre-existing illnesses or pre-existing illnesses of close contacts.
Nevertheless, it is possible to have your child vaccinated after consulting a doctor.
Further information on the pre-existing conditions concerned can be found at:
https://www.zusammengegencorona.de/impfen/kinder/corona-schutzimpfung-ab-5-jahren/
Further information on the vaccination recommendations mentioned here.

question: What documents are required to enter Germany?
context:
Entry - Visa procedure
Entry as part of a visa procedure
If you are entering Germany with a D visa for a longer stay, you must note the following after your arrival:
First you have to register at your chosen place of residence.
German law stipulates a period of 14 days for this.
In the district of Augsburg, you register at the residents' registration office in your town hall.
Here you will find a list of all municipalities and town halls in the district.
After successful registration you will receive a registration certificate.
The second step is to apply for a residence permit:
The national visa (category D) will be issued to you for entry.
It is not issued for the planned duration of your stay.
That is why you need a residence permit.
You must apply for a residence permit at the Foreigners' Registration Office.
It is important that you apply for a residence permit while your visa is still valid.
The residence permit is limited in time and can be extended.
The residence permit also depends on the reason for your entry,
whether you are allowed to work or not,
what work you are allowed to accept and
whether time restrictions apply to employment in Germany.
Extension of the residence permit:
Please note that you should apply to extend your residence permit 6 to 8 weeks before it expires.
Depending on the purpose of your stay, there may be other things to consider.
You can also obtain this information from the Foreigners' Registration Office.

question: How does the right to stay differ from the right to stay?
context:
Opportunities right of residence
Opportunities right of residence
Since 31.
The aim is to give people who have been living in Germany for a long time a legal residence permit.
The requirements are:
Persons with a tolerated stay permit who have been resident in Germany since at least 31.
You must be registered before 01.
Applying for the right to stay: If you meet the necessary requirements within the 18 months, you can apply for the right to stay in accordance with § 25a AufenthG or § 25b AufenthG.
The requirements are:
Securing your livelihood
Clarification of identity,
Knowledge of the German language#
For teenagers and young adults between the ages of 14 and 26: Tolerated persons or holders of the right of residence between the ages of 14 and 26 can receive a residence permit if they have integrated well.
For tolerated persons or holders of an opportunity residence permit (Section 104c AufenthG): Tolerated persons or holders of an opportunity residence permit (Section 104c AufenthG) can receive a residence permit if they have integrated sustainably.
If you meet the requirements, you can fill out the application for a residence permit, print it out and send it to the following address:

question: What requirements do I have to fulfill to attend a technical secondary school or vocational secondary school?
context:
Fachoberschule (FOS) and Berufsoberschule (BOS)
Fachoberschule (FOS for short) and Berufsoberschule (BOS for short) both belong to the Berufliche Oberschule Bayern (BOB for short).
Fachoberschule (FOS)
Who attends the FOS?
For the Fachoberschule you need an intermediate school leaving certificate with an average grade of at least
3.5 in the subjects German, Mathematics and English.
Duration and aim of the FOS
Duration: two to three years (depending on the degree)
Goal: Achieve a higher education qualification (see "Possible qualifications")
Possible qualifications: Fachhochschulreife, subject-restricted higher education entrance qualification, general higher education entrance qualification
This enables the FOS to study.
What does the FOS teach?
The FOS provides theoretical knowledge in the following fields of study:
Technology
Economy and administration
Social services
Agriculture, biotechnology and environmental technology
Design
Health
International economy
In addition, FOS students complete 6 months of practical training.
Tips for the FOS
There is a preliminary class for the FOS.
The preliminary class prepares students for attending the FOS in one year.
More information can be found here.
There is a registration period for the FOS.
Please note the dates for admission to the FOS!
Vocational high school (BOS)
Who attends the BOS?
For the BOS you need an intermediate school leaving certificate with an average grade of at least
3.5 in the subjects German, Mathematics and English.
And you need to have completed vocational training.
Duration and aim of the BOS
Duration: one to two years (depending on the degree)
Goal: Achieve a higher education qualification (see "Possible qualifications")
Possible qualifications: Fachhochschulreife, Fachgebundene Hochschulreife or
general university entrance qualification
This enables the BOS to study.
What does the BOS teach?
The BOS provides a general and theoretical education in the following fields of study:
Technology
Economy and administration
Social services
Agriculture, biotechnology and environmental technology
Health
International economy
Tips for BOS
The BOS can also be attended part-time.
There are courses that prepare students for the BOS: Part-time preliminary courses and full-time preliminary classes.
More information can be found here.
The BOS is also available online: The Virtual Vocational High School Bavaria (VIBOS) allows you to combine work and school in the best possible way.
This is because the online course is designed so that you can complete it while working.
More information can be found here.

question: Where can I find accommodation and meals?
context:
Further steps and everyday life
Health care
Are you ill or have a medical emergency?
Then you can go to a doctor's surgery or - in an emergency - to a hospital.
You can also claim benefits in the event of illness, pregnancy and childbirth.
This applies as soon as you receive benefits under the AsylbLG.
This primarily applies to the treatment of acute illnesses and pain conditions.
If treatment is necessary, the doctor's surgery or hospital will request a medical treatment certificate from the Foreigners' Registration Office at the Augsburg District Office.
Emergency treatment can take place before written authorization is granted.
The costs can also be covered after the treatment.
Corona vaccination
You can be vaccinated against coronavirus free of charge.
You can find more information on vaccinations here.
You can find information in Ukrainian here: https://www.stmgp.bayern.de/coronavirus/impfung/#ukraine
Visiting school and daycare center
You can register your children for school.
You can do this directly at the school responsible for your place of residence (primary or secondary school).
This applies to all children and young people between the ages of 6 and 15.
The same applies to the daycare center.
Please contact your respective municipality.
Young people over the age of 15 are no longer required to attend school.
They may be accepted at a secondary school if they have attended one in Ukraine.

Ukrainian Association Augsburg
The association coordinates various initiatives.
They help migrants from Ukraine.

German-Ukrainian dialog

For example, for appointments at the immigration office or the education authority.
People with their own migration experience work in language and cultural mediation.
They were specially trained for linguistic and cultural mediation.
This means that you translate the conversation.
And they clear up cultural misunderstandings.

People with their own migration experience work in language and cultural mediation.
They were specially trained for linguistic and cultural mediation.
This means that you translate the conversation.
And they clear up cultural misunderstandings.
Some authorities and institutions offer free language and cultural mediation for the consultation.
Ask directly when making an appointment.
You can also bring an interpreter with you.
You have to pay for this yourself.
The Augsburg interpreting pools will help you find the right interpreter:
Augsburg interpreter pools
Babel" interpreter pool
Mon - Fri from 10.00 am - 1.00 pm
babel@assyrer-augsburg.de
"kunterMund" language and cultural mediators
Oberbürgermeister-Dreifuß-Str.
eb@diakonie-augsburg.de
"SprInt" (language and integration mediator)
Anne Pawletta
Wertachstr.
anne.pawletta@tuerantuer.de
You can find more detailed information at www.tuerantuer.de/sprach-und-kulturmittlung.
Help hotline "Violence against women"
Women affected by violence can now also find support in Ukrainian.
On request, the advisors can add an interpreter in the required language to the conversation within a minute.
Counseling is free of charge, anonymous and confidential.
Help hotline "Violence against women"
www.hilfetelefon.de/das-hilfetelefon/beratung.html

question: What help is available for refugees from Ukraine?
context:
Further steps and everyday life
Health care
Are you ill or have a medical emergency?
Then you can go to a doctor's surgery or - in an emergency - to a hospital.
You can also claim benefits in the event of illness, pregnancy and childbirth.
This applies as soon as you receive benefits under the AsylbLG.
This primarily applies to the treatment of acute illnesses and pain conditions.
If treatment is necessary, the doctor's surgery or hospital will request a medical treatment certificate from the Foreigners' Registration Office at the Augsburg District Office.
Emergency treatment can take place before written authorization is granted.
The costs can also be covered after the treatment.
Corona vaccination
You can be vaccinated against coronavirus free of charge.
You can find more information on vaccinations here.
You can find information in Ukrainian here: https://www.stmgp.bayern.de/coronavirus/impfung/#ukraine
Visiting school and daycare center
You can register your children for school.
You can do this directly at the school responsible for your place of residence (primary or secondary school).
This applies to all children and young people between the ages of 6 and 15.
The same applies to the daycare center.
Please contact your respective municipality.
Young people over the age of 15 are no longer required to attend school.
They may be accepted at a secondary school if they have attended one in Ukraine.
Meeting points and advice centers
Ukrainian Association Augsburg
The association coordinates various initiatives.
They help migrants from Ukraine.
The association also provides the necessary information and advice.
The association offers an integrative teaching program for children as part of the Ukrainian Saturday School Augsburg.
German-Ukrainian dialog
The association supports people in need in their everyday lives.
He is available to help and advise refugees.
It promotes integration and offers a wide range of educational opportunities.
Migration counseling
People seeking protection receive advice from the refugee and integration advice service and the migration advice service:
Diaconia Augsburg
Caritas Augsburg: Advice for refugees
Caritas Augsburg: Migration counseling

question: How can I register for a German course on the A3 education portal?
context:
Education portal A3
Would you like to continue your professional training and are looking for a suitable offer?
Are you looking for a language course and don't know where?
Would you like to attend a yoga class?
Or do you want to do further training to become a business administrator?
Or are you wondering: Where are there libraries in the district?
Or kindergartens?
Then the A3 education portal is the right place for you!
What is the A3 education portal?
The A3 education portal is a joint project of the city of Augsburg, the district of Augsburg and the district of Aichach-Friedberg.
The portal presents all educational and advisory services in the region.
There is also a lot of up-to-date information on the subject of education and further training.
What can I find on the A3 education portal?
Course search: Search for the right course for you.
Counseling services: There is a counseling service in the region for almost all life issues.
You can find the right course for you via the education portal.
Providers: There are many training providers in the region.
On the portal you can get an overview and search specifically for providers.
Funding: The portal provides information on the possibilities of financial support for your professional development.
Dates: You can find regional events relating to education and further training on the education portal.
Where can I find the A3 education portal?
Click on this link:
www.bildungsportal-a3.de

question: What documents are required for the asylum procedure?
context:
Hearing
Personal interview
This is the most important appointment in the asylum procedure.
You will receive an invitation.
An interpreter will be present.
You absolutely must keep this appointment.
You can't come?
Then let us know as soon as possible!
You need an important reason.
You must communicate this.
Otherwise your application for asylum may be rejected or the proceedings may be discontinued.
Procedure of the hearing
At the hearing, you can explain why you had to flee your country.
You will be asked questions about:
Your biography
Your life situation
Your travel route to Germany
the reasons for your persecution in your country of origin
Do you have proof for your descriptions?
Then you should bring them with you.
The hearing is conducted by specialized employees.
Who can come to the hearing?
You don't have to go to the hearing alone.
Can accompany you to the appointment:
a lawyer
a representative of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)
another person of trust who is not themselves in an asylum procedure
In the case of unaccompanied minors, the guardian may attend the hearing.
Your descriptions will be translated.
And there is a protocol.
The protocol will then be translated back to you.
This way you can make additions or corrections if necessary.
At the end you will receive the protocol.
If everything is correct, you confirm this with your signature.
Here you will find information from the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees on how to prepare for the personal interview at
German,
Arabic,
Albanian,
English,
Farsi,
French.
Here you will find a collection of materials for personal consultation

question: What vocational training can I do in Germany?
context:
Vocational training
In Germany, you have a better chance of getting a job if you have the right training.
There are professions for which a degree is necessary.
Other professions can be learned in a vocational training program.
Germany has a very good vocational training system.
Vocational training is worth a lot in Germany.
Many employers are looking for people who have vocational training.
Those who complete an apprenticeship therefore have a very good chance of finding a job.
There are two different types of vocational training: dual training and school-based training.

question: Where can I find support after my asylum decision?
context:
Decision of the BAMF
Decision on the asylum application
After the personal interview, the Federal Office for Migration and Refugees checks all descriptions, information and evidence.
It is checked whether one of the four forms of protection exists on the basis of the Asylum Act:
Eligibility for asylum
Refugee protection
subsidiary protection
Ban on deportation
The asylum application will only be rejected if none of these forms of protection can be recognized.
The decision will be justified in writing and sent as a "notification" to
the applicant, or
to persons who have been authorized in these proceedings (lawyers).
the responsible foreigners authority.
The decision is negative
If your asylum application is rejected, you will receive a negative decision and a deportation warning.
Deportation threat means: You will be asked to leave the Federal Republic of Germany by a certain date.
If you do not leave the country by this date, you may be forcibly deported.
There are two different types of rejection:
simple refusal: you must leave the country within 30 days.
Rejection as "manifestly unfounded": In this case, the deadline for leaving the country is only one week.
Contestation
If you do not agree with the rejection, you can take legal action against the decision in both cases.
This must be done very quickly after receiving the decision.
Therefore, go immediately to the integration and refugee counseling service in your accommodation.
You will receive support there.
You should always seek advice and representation from a specialist lawyer for asylum and residence law if you wish to take legal action.
You will be informed of all deadlines and legal options in the written notification: This information is referred to as "information on legal remedies".
Voluntary departure
If you decide to leave voluntarily, you can receive financial support for a new start in your country of origin.
You can get advice on voluntary departure here:
Central Return Counseling South Bavaria
info@zrb-suedbayern.de
www.zrb-suedbayern.de/
Inform the immigration office as soon as possible that you wish to leave the country voluntarily.
The decision is positive
You are recognized as entitled to protection.
The next steps are:
Fictitious certificate or
Electronic residence permit (eAT): Immediately after the positive BAMF decision has been delivered, you must apply for an identity document or residence permit.
take care of an equivalent.
You can obtain this from the Office for Immigration and Integration.
You are now allowed to work in Germany without restrictions.
If you don't have a job and are dependent on support, you will no longer receive the money from the social welfare office.
You must submit an application to the Jobcenter.

question: Where can I find a midwife?
context:
Important information on pregnancy and birth
Pregnant women are under special protection in Germany.
You are entitled to advice and medical care.
Guide to maternal health
The "Guide to Maternal Health" provides answers to many specific questions.
It is available in seven languages:
English
Kurdish
Russian
Turkish
Arabic
Serbo-Croatian
Pregnant - and now?
If you are pregnant, you must first go to the gynecologist.
to the gynecologist (gynecologist or
gynecologist).
Have the check-ups carried out there.
You will then receive a maternity pass.
The maternity record is a document containing important information about your pregnancy, your health and that of your child.
Always take your maternity pass with you in case of emergencies.
During pregnancy and in the postnatal period, pregnant women can be accompanied by a midwife.
Would you like support from a midwife?
Then it's best to search early!
Each midwife can only look after a few pregnant women.
They are therefore booked up early.
You can find a midwife, for example, via the midwife list of the pregnancy advice center at the Augsburg District Office.
For medical questions about family planning, pregnancy and birth
On the "Zanzu" portal you will find information in 13 languages on topics such as family planning and pregnancy.
There is also a dictionary of medical terms.
The MiMi health project (with migrants for migrants) provides information on the individual stages of pregnancy in the "Guide to maternal health".
The guide (search term: maternal health) is available at
Arabic
German
English
Kurdish
Russian
Serbo-Croatian
Turkish
Maternity protection for working pregnant women
Working pregnant women enjoy special protection - known as maternity protection.
Maternity protection begins six weeks before the birth and ends eight weeks afterwards.
This protection is regulated by law in Germany.
Pregnant women are generally not allowed to work during this time.
Your workplace remains intact.
You can return to work at the end of your maternity leave.
In addition, pregnant women may not work more than 8.5 hours per day.
They are also not allowed to do any heavy physical work.
You can find out more about this from your employer, from one of the advice centers listed below or here.
Financial support
If you have little or no income, you can apply for unemployment benefit II or social assistance.
After the twelfth week of pregnancy, the Jobcenter or social welfare office will pay expectant mothers an additional requirement.
And also the initial equipment for pregnancy and baby.
Delivery and aftercare
Your gynecologist will refer you to a maternity clinic.
Ask there for a midwife for aftercare.
If the clinic does not provide a midwife, contact "Frühe Hilfen/ KoKi".
You will receive a birth certificate from the clinic.
You need a birth certificate from the registry office to apply for a birth certificate for your child.
You also need the birth certificate if you are applying for parental allowance.
Notification to the registry office
Newborn children must be registered with the registry office.
The maternity clinic is responsible for registering the birth with the registry office.
For the birth certificate you need:
Your ID card
the birth certificate from the clinic
Your marriage certificate (if available)
What to do in the event of an unwanted pregnancy?
Pregnancy is not always desirable.
There are opportunities for support in the district.
Pregnancy counseling advises when
women who wish to terminate their pregnancy ("pregnancy conflict counseling") or
nobody should know about the birth ("confidential birth").
Counseling is free of charge and anonymous if desired.
Pregnancy counseling
Susanne Kierok
Susanne.kierok@LRA-a.bayern.de
Sybille Weiß
Sybille.weiss@LRA-a.bayern.de
Appointments can also be made via the Virtual Citizens' Office.
Helpline for pregnant women in need
The helpline helps pregnant women when
they are in difficult life situations or
no longer know what to do
want to hide their pregnancy.
The helpline is anonymous and free of charge.
Counseling is confidential.
This means that no other person hears about the phone call.
The advice is available in 18 languages.
Helpline for pregnant women in need
Termination of pregnancy (abortion)
Sometimes women want to terminate the pregnancy.
This can continue until the end of the 12th week.
The procedure can be carried out without penalty up to the sixth week of pregnancy.
The following requirements must be met:
Advice from a state-approved advice center that issues an advice certificate
Three-day waiting period between counseling and abortion
The abortion is performed by a doctor.
Here you will find brief information on abortion in several languages.
State-recognized pregnancy advice centres in Augsburg
At pro familia you can get advice on these topics:
Pregnancy and birth (until the child is three years old)
Considerations regarding abortion
Family planning and contraception
Sex education
Partnership and sexuality
Separation and divorce
State-approved advice center for pregnancy issues pro familia Augsburg e.V.
augsburg@profamilia.de
www.profamilia.de/augsburg
The following applies to asylum seekers:
Notify the forthcoming birth to the Office for Social Benefits and your accommodation provider.
The accommodation supervisor checks whether there is enough space for the child in the accommodation.
A baby crib is also ordered.
Newborn children must be reported to the accommodation management.
Please give your accommodation manager a copy of your birth certificate.
Your child will then be registered.

question: What school-leaving qualifications can I obtain in Germany?
context:
Secondary schools
Middle school
Duration:five to six years
Goal: Preparation for an apprenticeship or profession
Degrees:
Qualifying secondary school certificate (Quali)
Secondary school certificate
Secondary school leaving certificate (for high-achieving students by attending the M branch)
Secondary schools in the district of Augsburg: 15 secondary schools.
Good to know:
When choosing a primary or secondary school, you must observe the "Sprengelprinzip".
This means that each primary or secondary school is responsible for a specific area (called a "Sprengel").
Children must then attend a specific school.
Would you like your child to go to a different primary or secondary school?
Then you must submit a guest school application.
You must give good reasons for your wish to go to another school.
You can find detailed information with a school search at www.km.bayern.de/eltern/schulsuche.html.
Secondary school
Duration:six years
Goal: Preparation for an apprenticeship in all kinds of professions or transfer to a technical secondary school (FOS)
Qualification: Secondary school leaving certificate / intermediate school leaving certificate
Secondary schools in the district of Augsburg: six secondary schools.
Grammar school
Duration:eight to nine years
Goal: Preparation for university studies
Degree: General higher education entrance qualification (Abitur;
Authorization to study at universities and colleges)
Grammar schools in the district of Augsburg:five grammar schools
Support centers and special schools
Duration: Special schools are available for all ages
Goal: Individual support and encouragement for children with special educational needs (e.g.
e.g. severe learning difficulties, delayed development, disabilities)
Degrees:
Secondary school certificate
Qualifying secondary school certificate (Quali)
Support centers and special schools in the district of Augsburg: three state and two private schools.
Private schools
There are also two private schools in the district of Augsburg: an international school (grades 1-12).
grade) and a Montessori school (1st-10th grade).
class).
You can find more information here:
International School: www.isa-augsburg.com
Montessori School Dinkelscherben: www.montessoridinkelscherben.de

question: What are the rules for asylum accommodation?
context:
For refugees
Asylum seekers and tolerated persons should generally live in accommodation for asylum seekers.
This is stated in the Asylum Procedure Act (AsylVfG) and the Asylum Seekers' Benefits Act (AsylbLG).
Some federal states provide accommodation in private homes.
In all federal states, recognized refugees are allowed to move into their own apartment.
There are rest periods in the accommodation and everywhere in Germany.
Rest periods are from 10 p.m. in the evening until 6 a.m. in the morning.
Rest periods are regulated by law.
Everyone should be calmer during this time.
You are also not allowed to listen to loud music.
This ensures that living together in the accommodation and in the neighborhood remains harmonious.
You will find the rest periods and other rules in the "house rules" of your accommodation.
The house rules regulate how we live together.
Please note the house rules.
Always respect the rules and rest periods.
Sometimes asylum seekers want to move out of their assigned accommodation for special reasons.
You would like to rent an apartment yourself.
They must first coordinate this with the benefits authority.
In such cases, 30 euros per month per person will be deducted from the benefits.
Electricity is also granted as a so-called benefit in kind.
No matter where you live, make sure you use energy sparingly.
And also proper waste separation.
There are also instructions in various languages.

question: Which integration courses are offered?
context:
Office for Foreigners and Integration District of Augsburg
Tasks
The Office for Immigration and Integration regulates the residence of foreign nationals whose main place of residence is registered in the district of Augsburg.
The Office for Immigration and Integration is also called the Immigration Office.
Make an appointment
To speak to an employee of the Office for Immigration and Integration, you must make an appointment.
You can make an appointment here.
When booking an appointment online, "Your session has expired" appears first.
You must then click on "Book new appointment".
Then you have to select the "Service".
In other words: Why do you need the appointment?
Then click on the appropriate box with the first letter of your surname and enter the number of people (including children) who require a residence permit.
The waiting time for an appointment is now at least 4 weeks.
You have to be patient because a lot of people need an appointment at the moment.
You can also download many documents from the Foreigners' Registration Office website.

question: Where can I find a multi-generation house in Germany?
context:

question: What documents are required for the asylum appeal procedure?
context:
Legal action
Legal action
You do not agree with the negative decision on your asylum application by the BAMF?
Then you can sue.
You are the "plaintiff" or the "claimant".
The BAMF is the "defendant".
In the event of an appeal, the Munich Administrative Court will review the BAMF's decision.
If it agrees with the BAMF, the case will be dismissed.
The obligation to leave the country remains in force.
If the administrative court does not agree with the BAMF, you will receive a residence permit.
The BAMF is then obliged to grant you protection.
You can also take legal action against a positive decision by the BAMF.
For example, if you do not agree with the form of protection granted (exception: recognition of refugee status).
You should always seek advice and representation from a specialist lawyer for asylum and residence law.

question: What are the requirements for an integration course?
context:
Integration courses for adults
What is an integration course?
The Federal Office for Migration and Refugees (BAMF) offers integration courses.
In an integration course you will learn German and many things about Germany.
For example on topics such as...
Work and profession
Training and further education
Care and education of children
Shopping
Living
Rights and duties in Germany
How can I do an integration course?
When do I have to attend the integration course?
Voluntary visit: authorization certificate required
Would you like to attend the course voluntarily?
Then you need a permit from the BAMF, a so-called "Berechtigungsschein".
With this authorization certificate, you can register for an integration course at a language school.
Whether or not you receive a certificate of eligibility depends on your residence status.
You can get help with this from the "Learn German" advice service.
The consultation can also help with the application for the certificate of eligibility.
Commitment from the Office for Foreigners and Integration
Some people are required to attend an integration course by the Office for Foreigners and Integration.
This means that you must attend the integration course.
Important information at a glance
- The general integration course lasts several months and takes place full-time or part-time (e.g. for working people).
- It consists of a language course with 600 teaching units (short: UE = 45 minutes) and an orientation course on life in Germany with 100 UE.
- The aim is to achieve language level B1 on completion of the course.
You will then receive a certificate.
- The certificate is important.
For example, if you are looking for work or want to do an apprenticeship.
The certificate can also be important if you want to stay in Germany permanently and need a permanent residence permit.
- There are also special integration courses for certain groups of people.
For example, for women (with childcare), working people or people who cannot read and write.
- Participants with a BAMF authorization certificate pay 220 euros per module (=100 hours).
They can get 50% of this back if they successfully complete the course within two years.
- Participants without a BAMF authorization certificate pay 440 euros per module (=100 hours).
-The course is free of charge for recipients of social benefits.
You will be exempted from the costs upon request.
Necessary travel costs can also be reimbursed.
The language advice centers offer individual advice on this.
You can also find more information here.
Language schools (also known as course providers) that offer integration courses in Augsburg and the surrounding area:
ADK Augsburg German Courses
Vocational Training Center (BBZ) Augsburg gGmbH
Vocational Training Centers of the Bavarian Economy (bfz) gGmbH Augsburg
BIB Augsburg
Caesar Language & Education Institute
DAA - German Employees Academy Augsburg GmbH
Kolping Academy Augsburg
Languages Prisma GbR
Böhm Language Center
Language Forum International German Courses
Alterlingua Language Institute
Sprachinstitut Pittner
vhs - Volkshochschule Augsburg e.V.
vhs - Volkshochschule Augsburger Land e.V.
You can find an overview of the current integration courses in Augsburg and the surrounding area on the district's website under "Downloads" (on the right-hand side: "1) Current integration courses").
You can also find local integration courses on the BAMF website here.
Integration courses for the hearing impaired
The Heesch language school in Munich offers integration courses up to level B1 for the hearing impaired.
The BBW Munich has a BIK class for hearing-impaired immigrants.

question: What documents do I need to register at the Augsburg District Office?
context:
The Augsburg District Office
The Augsburg District Office administers the district of Augsburg.
The District Administrator is elected by the citizens.
He heads the district administration office.
The district administration office is a district authority.
At the same time, it is a state authority of the Free State of Bavaria.
It has various tasks:
Mandatory tasks (e.g.
e.g. construction and operation of hospitals, youth welfare, social welfare services, nature conservation).
Voluntary tasks that are organized at the company's own discretion depending on its financial resources (e.g.
B. Promotion of cultural or social institutions)
The district administration office offers many services for citizens.
For example, advice centers for families, older people or young people.
You can find a good overview on the website (see below).
Good to know: Friendly people work at the district office!
The employees will be happy to help you!
Do you need help?
Don't understand something?
Would you like to suggest something?
Then get in touch!
You will find a contact person for almost every question.
She will be happy to help you.
Augsburg District Office
info@LRA-a.bayern.de
Monday to Friday from 7.30 a.m. to 12.30 p.m., Thursday additionally from 2 p.m. to 5.30 p.m.
www.landkreis-augsburg.de

So you can make some appointments online from home.
This saves you a trip to the district office.

Smartphone, laptop or PC with webcam and microphone
Stable Internet connection

question: What health insurance policies are there in Germany?
context:
The German healthcare system
German healthcare system
In Germany, many facilities are part of the healthcare system.
The healthcare system has three areas:
1. outpatient medical care by doctors and pharmacies.
"Outpatient" means that the patient goes home after treatment.
2. inpatient medical care through acute care in hospitals.
"Inpatient" means that the patient stays in hospital for treatment.
3. health protection of the population through services provided by the public health department, e.g. infection protection and preventive services.
"Preventive" means: offers to maintain health and avoid becoming ill).
The outpatient and inpatient care services provide medical treatment for sick people.
Everyone is free to choose their own doctor or facility.
The public health department ("Öffentlicher Gesundheitsdienst") fulfills many different tasks.
You can find a list here.
The public health department also fulfills preventive tasks.
For example, they provide information and advice on the subject of health.
This should enable a healthy life in the district.
The health department organizes many projects at schools.
These projects provide information on the topic of "health" in a fun way.
They explain what is important for a healthy life.
You can find more information about the health department here.
You can find offers for health promotion and prevention here.
Good to know
Hospitals treat seriously ill and life-threateningly injured people.
So they will help you in an emergency!
For minor injuries or illnesses, go to a doctor's surgery.
You will get good help there.
You may need a doctor at night or at the weekend.
But it is not always an emergency.
You can then go to the medical on-call service.
Medical on-call service
only in the evening and at weekends
116 117
Dental emergency service
only on weekends
www.notdienst-zahn.de (also in English)
Pharmacy emergency service
from cell phone: 22 8 33(max.
69 cents/min.)
The German healthcare system in 14 languages
The brochure "Health for all - A guide to the German healthcare system" contains important information in 14 languages.

question: Which countries can I visit as an asylum seeker in Germany without a visa?
context:
Entry without a visa
Third-country nationals from so-called privileged states - residence without a visa
Citizens of certain countries may enter the Schengen area without a visa.
This concerns persons from:
Australia
New Zealand
United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland
Israel
Japan
Canada
Republic of Korea
United States of America
These persons may stay in Germany or the Schengen area for a maximum of 90 days within 180 days.
You must take this into account if you are planning multiple entries or longer stays.
You may not exceed the maximum permitted length of stay.
You must set the departure date accordingly.
List of countries without or
with visa requirement for Germany / Schengen area
Attention:
You must leave Germany once the maximum period of residence has expired.
But also from the Schengen states.
Do you want to stay or work here for longer than three months?
Then you must apply for a residence permit at the immigration office.
Or you cannot leave the country within the deadline?
Even then, you must contact the Foreigners' Registration Office before your stay expires.
For some reasons, it may allow you to stay longer.
For example with:
force majeure
humanitarian, professional or serious personal reasons.
You must adhere to these rules!
Otherwise it is a violation of the law.
The foreigners authority can terminate your stay.
There may also be criminal proceedings in court.
You may also be banned from re-entering the country.
Then you will not be allowed to re-enter Germany.
